webTitle: Petit takes demanding Spanish test at the back

fields.headline: Petit takes demanding Spanish test at the back
fields.trailText: Emmanuel Petit must prove tonight that he finds opposing forwards easier to control than his middle finger. In the absence of four Arsenal centre-backs he will play as an emergency defender. Suddenly the Gunners' 5-1 lead looks far less convincing.
fields.body:
Emmanuel Petit must prove tonight that he finds opposing forwards easier to control than his middle finger. In the absence of four Arsenal centre-backs he will play as an emergency defender. Suddenly the Gunners' 5-1 lead looks far less convincing.

Petit has not played at centre-half since he left Monaco in 1997. But with Tony Adams and Matthew Upson injured, and Martin Keown and Gilles Grimandi suspended, he will feature either in a back three or, more likely, alongside Oleg Luzhny. Arsène Wenger knows an early goal would change the tie's complexion.

"Deportivo La Coruna have shown quality and anything can happen," Arsenal's manager said. "In Nantes [in the last round] we could have been 3-0 down inside 10 minutes, and here we are playing the top team in the Spanish league who are strong at home. I don't think it's all over."

Yet, even without the non-flying Dennis Bergkamp, Arsenal should get the away goal they need to be safe. And Wenger has told Petit he must be a non-swearing Frenchman.

"He's intelligent enough to know he shouldn't react," he said. "To respond to these people is to tell them they have an influence on you." Now the 29-year-old can expect more abuse than ever.

More of a concern is Adams, in France trying to cure groin inflammation, and Wenger had some advice for the England coach: "If I was Kevin Keegan, I would go to church and pray that Tony Adams is fit before Euro 2000."

Arsenal (possible, 4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Petit, Winterburn; Ljungberg, Parlour, Vieira, Silvinho; Kanu, Henry.

webTitle: Weaver unravels causing City's stock to plummet after

fields.headline: Weaver unravels causing City's stock to plummet after
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 3 QPR
fields.body:
The familiar sound of grumbling engulfed Moss Side as football's great underachievers dusted off the self-destruct button to leave their paling supporters reaching for the antidepressants yet again last night.

In a classic night of Maine Road misfortune Joe Royle's side rediscovered their penchant for shooting themselves in the foot and dissolved in a vat of their own incompetence to present QPR with their first win in 10 attempts. Cityitis is the term that Royle uses to describe their idiosyncrasies and their goalkeeper Nicky Weaver will be suffering from a particularly heavy dose this morning, having been guilty of giving away two goals with a display that an alehouse player would have been embarrassed about.

City's previous three games had all finished with honours even, and QPR had six consecutive draws to their name.

All the early indications pointed to a break in monotony in favour of the hosts. Gerard Wiekens thudded a header against the crossbar and every City attack seemed capable of breaking down the visitors' resistance. But as the minutes ticked by the sense of uneasiness that has resurfaced among City devotees in recent weeks came to the fore again and quickly took its toll on the questionable confidence of the home players.

As the dissent levels increased in volume QPR emerged from their cocoon to take the lead with a moment destined for Danny Baker's archive collection. Richard Langley's free kick lacked power and pace but Weaver spilled the ball with all the elegance of Raimond van der Gouw. From three yards it was a gift that was gratefully gobbled up by Chris Kiwomya.

Worse was to follow on 45 minutes and again Weaver was the culprit. This time it was Ian Baraclough's innocuous shot which proved too hot to handle and the goalkeeper's attempt to clear the ball from a prostrate position succeeded only in kicking it against Wiekens and into his own net.

Weaver was playing his first home game since turning 21 last week. If he was presented with the key to the door, he may wish to swap it for a new pair of gloves after this display.

Certainly the young Yorkshireman was grateful to have received the Nationwide League goalkeeper of the month award before kick-off. Had it been presented afterwards he might have dropped it. Classic City; classic cock-up.

At least he could do nothing about Mikkel Beck's penalty after Wiekens had tripped Kiwomya in the 73rd minute.

Jeff Whitley's reply 12 minutes later with a low drive from 25 yards out was the most meagre of consolations.

fields.headline: Wallace shoots Rangers towards title
fields.trailText: Celtic 0 - 1 Rangers
fields.body:
Rangers last night wrapped up the championship with the same kind of care and forethought that marks out those people who buy their Christmas presents in the summer sales. The Ibrox side are, to all intents and purposes, uncatchable with two months of the season left, a clear 12 points in front of Celtic.

Once again the Bhoys were in overall control of an Old Firm match but could not make that superiority pay. For 80 minutes it looked as if they could not lose. Ten minutes later they were trooping off with heads buried in their hands.

Those closing moments summed up their whole campaign. After Celtic had donned their working clothes to batter their way through the atrocious underfoot conditions, they managed to lose their way.

In the 81st minute Giovanni Van Bronckhorst's clever pass to Neil McCann gave him the yard he needed to get away from Johan Mjallby, who pulled him down. Jorg Albertz, usually so reliable, drove the penalty against Jonathan Gould, who kept it out with his legs.

But there was worse to come for Celtic. Three minutes later Van Bronckhorst placed his pass into that same channel, where spaces had started to appear as Celtic tired. This time Rod Wallace made the run and squeezed his shot inside the post. The Englishman may have had a fitful season but the Ibrox manager Dick Advocaat has been loyal, and his patience was spectacularly rewarded.

Celtic's approach, on the face of it, was exceedingly cautious. They played four defenders and two wing-backs, hardly encouraging the other midfielders to get forward. The home side were just intent on placing as many shields as they could between themselves and the free-running Rangers midfield.

In fairness it worked through the first half, as Rangers could not find any rhythm on a pitch unsuited to their purposes. Indeed Celtic created a number of chances to take the lead. The best of them all came in the seventh minute, when Stéphane Mahe wandered down the left and crossed so well that Craig Moore was taken out of the game.

The ball fell to Mark Viduka eight yards out. He controlled it well and seemed bound to score when he side-footed the ball towards the corner of the net. However the Rangers goalkeeper Stefan Klos made a truly remarkable save, almost doing the splits and stopping the effort with his outstretched left foot.

With Viduka and Jackie McNamara finding more space than should have been available on the right flank, Celtic's decision to leave the finer arts in the dressing-room seemed justified as they lumped the ball out of the mud towards the green bits. But as time went on, they began to rue that lost early chance.

There was no shortage of spirit either. When the defender Tom Boyd was caught by the boot of Rod Wallace , his eye started to swell alarmingly. But his visit to the touchline was short-lived and he came back to provide a through ball which gave Viduka another chance to score the elusive goal.

But that was missed as well and at half-time Rangers had good reason to be happy about the scoreline, if nothing else. After 90 minutes they were simply delighted.

webTitle: The cruel world of Auntie, as told by David Icke

fields.headline: The cruel world of Auntie, as told by David Icke
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner reports on the current incarnation of the former Hereford goalkeeper and sports presenter David Icke.
fields.body:
Whatever happened to all the heroes?" asked the Stranglers in their 1977 hit record, and I think they may have been on to something.

The BBC programme This Is Your Life, for instance, which once regularly featured people who had smuggled Jewish children out of Nazi Germany, or nurses who had devoted their lives to working with lepers in Africa, is now almost exclusively concerned with the mostly unremarkable lives of television "personalities".

This week it was John Craven. Last week it was David Vine, or old Viney as his colleagues invariably called him.

Both seemed decent enough chaps: nice wives, nice children. Both had at some time rescued through their consummate professionalism a live broadcast that was heading for disaster. An elephant, we learned, once peed on old Viney's foot during a programme, and Craven had to share a studio for some years with Noel Edmonds.

However, not one Jew or African appeared to thank our heroes for their lives. The lifelong efforts of Craven and old Viney would also appear to have left us absolutely no nearer a cure for cancer.

What was interesting was the rather cosy picture of the BBC that emerged from the programmes. Here apparently was an organisation, uniquely in my experience of the media, utterly devoid of petty professional jealousies, where egos were checked in at the door so that nothing might get in the way of the joyous family atmosphere that Craven and old Viney conveyed to us through their skill of smiling and reading the autocue at the same time.

This is in marked contrast to the picture of the BBC painted by that respected commentator on contemporary affairs, David Icke. Those of you worried that the former Hereford goalkeeper, who left the Green Party in 1991 to reveal he was the son of Godhead, might not have a platform for his bracing world view will be relieved to hear that he now has a regular column on the Football 365 website .

His latest outpourings concern the problems at BBC Sport. "Is BBC Sport dead?" he asks, "or has it just retired to a bungalow on the coast?"

Icke, you should know, is a man who claims on his own website that former President Bush and the British royal family are "key members of an elite of human-reptile hybrids whose rituals are designed to tap into fourth-dimensional energy forces and deprive ordinary human mortals of their consciousness". So he is clearly not a man to mince words.

He also worked as a presenter for BBC Sport for most of the 80s, and so can lay claim to specialist knowledge. The BBC Sport for which he worked, though, seems to bear little relation to the one that employed old Viney.

"It was not unknown," writes old Ickey on Football 365, "for tea mugs to be thrown through television sets in the director's gallery when a caption took too long to appear." The department, he says, was ruled through fear and intimidation.

Few are spared Icke's impressive bile. The presenter David Coleman is accused of intimidating the backroom staff with volleys of abuse, and the head of sport is alleged to have kept everyone in a constant state of insecurity in the belief it would make them work harder.

"The man needed help," writes Icke, which appears a bit rich coming from someone with a deep belief in the spiritual qualities of the colour purple, who predicted George Bush would "summon oppressive evil forces at a black mass in a dank stone burial chamber deep inside the Cheops pyramid at Giza in Egypt on new year's eve".

However, even if his words do little to discourage those who would place him at the top of a list of Britain's premier fruit loops, the picture Icke paints of the BBC seems more plausible than the sanitised one we are constantly fed by This Is Your Life.

S ure, his views are those of a fairly embittered former employee (and all the more fun for that), but when he says that young talent was treated so badly at BBC Sport that as soon as there were alternatives it left in pursuit of bigger cheques and greater opportunities, he has a point.

Enjoy Icke's Football 365 columns - titles include Leicester City Are Football's Vampire Slayers, and Football Is The New Cocaine And Chairmen Are The Dealers - and hope that This Is Your Life will honour him soon. His magnificent madness makes him a kind of hero.

webTitle: Pearce breaks leg and Hammer hearts

fields.headline: Pearce breaks leg and Hammer hearts
fields.trailText: West ham 2 - 0 Southampton
fields.body:
West Ham rose five places in the Premiership table last night and the prospect of European football will add extra interest to the remaining weeks of their season. However, Stuart Pearce will play no further part after he was carried off having suffered another broken leg.

It was the same left leg that Pearce cracked in September and which had permitted his return to the side only 10 days ago. He appeared to suffer the injury while trying to stop Hassan Kachloul shooting for goal in the fifth minute.

Nevertheless, West Ham put aside that early blow to record a convincing victory over Glenn Hoddle's Saints through goals from Paulo Wanchope and Trevor Sinclair.

It was Pearce who had administered a heavy challenge on Marian Pahars in the first minute, an introduction that clearly stated that if the little Latvian was to impress for Southampton as he had done against Middlesbrough at the weekend he would first have to pass a physical examination. Pearce then had the audacity to forcibly lift Pahars to his feet, suggesting the forward had made too much of the tackle.

Yet it was the former England stalwart, six weeks away from his 38th birthday, who was hobbling in obvious distress moments later.

Before Pearce departed he had tested Paul Jones from close range as the match opened at a furious pace. Harry Redknapp had restored Joe Cole to his line-up after he sat out the victory at Watford and with Wanchope bright and eager for the ball Southampton's rearguard were set for a busy evening.

Southampton, defeated only once under Hoddle, had decided that attack was the best form of defence and both Kachloul and Jo Tessem were quick to get up in support of Kevin Davies.

But it was West Ham who secured the lead in the 18th minute thanks to some clever work down the right from Sinclair, who cut the ball back low for Wanchope to ram home.

Scott Minto took over from Pearce but the left side of the defence was a worry for the home team and Southampton began to exploit some space.

Kevin Davies broke away on the half hour and despatched a powerful drive against the crossbar, and a short time later Pahars beat Minto only to find Craig Forrest equal to the shot.

But Sinclair had shown his ability to beat a man on several occasions and he repeated the trick three minutes after the break to score West Ham's second goal. He came inside from the left to outwit Jason Dodd before defeating Jones rather too easily on the goalkeeper's near post.

 Michael Owen scored his first goal of the year last night to give England's European Championship hopes a boost. Owen played his first full 90 minutes since being sidelined with a hamstring injury in late-January in Liverpool reserves' 1-1 draw at Blackburn.

webTitle: Akinbiyi in the dock over headbutt

fields.headline: Akinbiyi in the dock over headbutt
fields.trailText: The Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after the stormy match with Nottingham Forest last month.
fields.body:
The Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after the stormy match with Nottingham Forest last month.

Akinbiyi was sent off after butting Tony Vaughan in the fifth minute of the game at Molineux. The Forest player was also dismissed but then Akinbiyi initially refused to leave the pitch and lashed out at his own team-mates, appearing to catch the Wolves captain Keith Curle in the face.

Wolves have already disciplined their £3.5m signing, who has also apologised for his actions.

Glenn Hoddle has made his first signing for Southampton, paying £300,000 for Benfica's Moroccan international Tahar El Khalej.

But El Khalej, 31, cannot play immediately. He is awaiting a Portuguese passport which would give him automatic entry to English football.

El Khalej has played the majority of his 71 internationals in midfield but Hoddle will deploy him in defence.

fields.headline: Wise revives the Blues
fields.standfirst:
Wise 27
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: It was not the tastiest Chelsea performance in recent history, but revenge was sweet for Gianluca Vialli's side last night. Eight days after losing in Marseille in Group D, they strengthened their chances of securing a quarter-final place with a narrow victory secured by Dennis Wise's 27th-minute goal.
fields.body:
It was not the tastiest Chelsea performance in recent history, but revenge was sweet for Gianluca Vialli's side last night. Eight days after losing in Marseille in Group D, they strengthened their chances of securing a quarter-final place with a narrow victory secured by Dennis Wise's 27th-minute goal.

Chelsea's defending was often shaky and the Marseille substitute Ivan de la Pena hit the post in the closing minutes. But the Premiership side go to Feyenoord next week in good heart if not in sparkling form.

Their determination to carve out a result was evident from the outset, with Vialli opting for a revamped attacking formation that saw Gustavo Poyet postioned just behind the strikers Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola. With a compact central midfield comprising Wise, Didier Deschamps and Jody Morris, width was expected to be supplied by the full-backs Albert Ferrer and Celestine Babayaro.

The main casualty of this re-design, and perhaps also a scapegoat for last week's defeat in France, was Dan Petrescu, who was not even given a place on the bench.

There was certainly a zest to Chelsea's play early on. Poyet shot just wide after only two minutes, then Zola was set up in front of goal by Flo only for Jacques Abardonado to arrive with a timely saving tackle.

Shortly after it was the turn of the hero of last week's encounter, Marseille's reserve goalkeeper Stéphane Trevisan, to rescue his side again when Poyet nodded on Wise's corner to Babayaro, whose close-range header forced the keeper to conjure a fantastic reaction save.

All was not going well for the French, keenly aware that a victory here would would get them back into the race for a quarter-final spot. So there was little thought of going ultra-defensive last night as the coach Bernard Casoni stuck by the 3-4-1-2 formation which succeeded a week ago.

In the first 20 minutes Marseille put together enough neat passing moves to remind Chelsea of their threat on the break. Cyrille Pouget went close and Marcel Desailly needed to be alert to block Jerome Leroy's shot.

However, on 27 minutes Chelsea eased their nerves by taking the lead. Marseille's defence failed to clear properly and the ball fell to Flo on the left of the area.

The tall striker then turned provider, chipping in a far-post cross which Zola, despite his lack of inches, did well to head down to Wise, who controlled the ball 12 yards out and slammed it past Trevisan.

But Marseille hit back smartly. A combination of Chelsea giving the ball away and Ibrahima Bakayoko's runs created a couple of chances which allowed Ed de Goey to show why he has just claimed the club record of 22 clean sheets in a season. First he

produced a diving stop to deny Bakayoko, then two minutes later did well to get his feet to a fierce strike from Leroy.

fields.headline: Houllier gets his man
fields.trailText: Emile Heskey will become the second-most expensive British player in history when he moves from Leicester to Liverpool for £11million tomorrow.
fields.body:
Emile Heskey will become the second-most expensive British player in history when he moves from Leicester to Liverpool for £11million tomorrow.

The two clubs have agreed a fee for the England striker, who travelled with his advisors to Liverpool tonight with a view to finalising the deal.

It means the player known as 'Bruno' should be available to make his debut in Saturday's Anfield clash with Sunderland, who 22-year-old Heskey helped destroy 5-2 last weekend in what now looks like his Leicester swansong.

A Liverpool spokesman confirmed: "The two clubs have agreed a fee and subject to a medical we expect to sign the player tomorrow."

Only England captain Alan Shearer, who cost Newcastle £15million, will have cost more than Heskey, who overtakes Chelsea's £10million recruit Chris Sutton in the list of high-cost British transfers.

Leicester manager Martin O'Neill made a last-ditch effort in talks earlier this week to persuade Heskey to stay at Filbert Street via a lucrative new contract.

Instead he has opted to team up with his former England Under-18 strike partner Michael Owen, one of the main attractions in his wanting to move to Merseyside.

There has been constant speculation during the past few months that Heskey would make the move to Anfield.

His profile rocketed after he produced a stunning full debut for England against Argentina at Wembley last month.

But Leicester-born Heskey stayed to help the Foxes win the Worthington Cup and clinch a place in Europe before opting for his dream move.

Heskey burst onto the Premiership scene as an 18-year-old on the Foxes' return to the top flight in the summer of 1996.He has stayed loyal to his home-town club but now feels the time is right to try his luck on a bigger stage.

The prospect of Heskey, Owen and Robbie Fowler - when he is fit again - in partnership will be a mouth-watering one for Liverpool fans.

It is another sure-fire sign that manager Gerard Houllier is putting together a squad destined to challenge for the Premiership title in the next couple of years.

Leicester will have to come to terms with losing their prized asset - but they will at least have the consolation of having the funds to try to find a replacement.

The Foxes have been linked this week with Wimbledon striker John Hartson - after the collapse of his move to Tottenham - and West Ham's Paulo Wanchope.

But already at the club is a player capable of filling Heskey's role in Stan Collymore if he shows the kind of form which brought him a hat-trick against Sunderland on a regular basis - and stays out of trouble.

webTitle: US genetics firm in cancer check deal

fields.headline: US genetics firm in cancer check deal
fields.standfirst: Concern that plans could stop NHS lab tests
fields.trailText: The controversial US firm Myriad Genetics, which claims to have patented two of the genes that cause breast cancer, has announced a licensing agreement with a British company to carry out cancer screening in the UK.
fields.byline: James Meek, Science Correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The controversial US firm Myriad Genetics, which claims to have patented two of the genes that cause breast cancer, has announced a licensing agreement with a British company to carry out cancer screening in the UK.

Scientists at the 15 national health service laboratories which carry out genetic tests for susceptibility to breast cancer have expressed concern that Myriad's plans to move into Britain would herald legal action to stop their work, even though their tests are cheaper.

But the agreement announced yesterday between Utah-based Myriad and the British firm Rosgen so far only covers patients able to pay for the tests privately.

David Ashworth, Rosgen's business development manager, said last night: "Neither we, nor Myriad, have any plans to stop NHS labs doing any testing whatsoever.

"The agreement we have signed with Myriad specifically states that neither company intends or expects to have any such dealings with the NHS."

In the US, pressure from Myriad has led to all other labs ceasing to test for the breast cancer susceptibility genes.

Myriad claims to have patented the two genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2, although Britain's Institute of Cancer Research claims it discovered BRCA2 first.

The Dutch and Norwegian governments have expressed alarm over Myriad's gene patent claims.

But in Britain, the prime minister, Tony Blair, said in parliament last month that the government had "no interest" in the issue of gene patenting "other than to ensure people get the best treatment possible."

Rosgen, based on the Roslin campus near Edinburgh where Dolly the sheep was cloned, said yesterday that it had licensed Myriad's technology for five years.

It would take referrals from the NHS, but only from patients able to pay privately, and only if the NHS agrees to provide counselling services for the patients involved.

Gene mutations are though to be linked to 7-10% of all breast and ovarian cancers.

Women with mutations have a 56-87% chance of developing breast cancer by age 70, compared to 12% in the population as a whole.

Women may be referred for genetic tests if they have a family history of breast cancer or if relatives have the mutations.

The results of a positive test can be traumatic - including a decision on whether to have a preventative mastectomy - so counselling is essential.

Myriad has criticised the existing British labs as "homebrew" operations. Greg Critchfield, president of Myriad, said yesterday: "The agreement with Rosgen clearly places the UK in a leadership role along with other countries in North America and Asia in providing these gold standard testing services to its citizens."

webTitle: Yet another disaster that needed TV's endorsement

fields.headline: Yet another disaster that needed TV's endorsement
fields.standfirst: By Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: There is something wearily familiar about the sequence of events that have unfolded in Mozambique. For three weeks the country laboured under the worst floods in living memory. No one outside took much notice. South Africa dispatched a handful of military helicopters on rescue and aid missions. Britain gave some money to cope with the medical emergency. The United Nations sent a team to investigate.
fields.body:
There is something wearily familiar about the sequence of events that have unfolded in Mozambique. For three weeks the country laboured under the worst floods in living memory. No one outside took much notice. South Africa dispatched a handful of military helicopters on rescue and aid missions. Britain gave some money to cope with the medical emergency. The United Nations sent a team to investigate.

But it was only when the television cameras arrived, and viewers across Europe and the United States got a glimpse of what it is to have your house washed away while you climb the nearest tree, that the crisis was taken seriously.

It was the same story in Somalia. The Americans were dragged in by the television pictures. Western governments pretended the Rwandan genocide didn't exist, but as Hutu refugees started dying in their tens of thousands from cholera on the TV news, the money gushed in.

A disaster is defined as such only when enough people look its way. By then it is often too late for many victims who might have been saved. Each time there are the same promises that the lessons will be learned. No doubt some are, but when it comes to the next crisis, they rarely seem to be applied.

Natural disasters are notoriously difficult to plan for. But the flooding in Mozambique was drawn out over five weeks, with sufficient warnings that it was going to worsen, and that when the time came, help would be needed quickly and on a large scale.

UN, British and other foreign officials reel off their donations of blankets and logisticians. But what really mattered in the first days were rescue helicopters, and they were not on hand, except for those already sent by South Africa. No money had been set aside for additional aircraft. No one bothered to explore where more helicopters might be found.

The flaw is in the system. Disasters such as the Mozambique floods require a much larger organisation and funds than individual aid organisations or governments can offer. They require a pot of money already to hand, and people with the authority to spend it to provide whatever is most urgently required.

Presumably that responsibility should fall to the UN. After the first wave of floods hit Mozambique, the UN sent a team from its humanitarian disaster office that spent 10 days in the country. Its critics say it left without establishing a means of coordinating relief efforts. A similar team subsequently then returned to do the same job. The two most senior UN officials in Mozambique were out of the country as the latest crisis hit.

We will never know how many lives could have been saved by a quicker reaction. But you can be certain of one thing. Afterwards there will be hand-wringing and meetings and promises that the lessons of Mozambique 2000 have been learned. Then, some time in the next few years, another calamity will befall another African country. And the victims had better hope that it is a slow news week on CNN.

fields.headline: ITN 'attempted to destroy' left-wing magazine
fields.trailText: ITN attempted to "completely destroy" a left-wing magazine which criticised their coverage of the Bosnian war, a jury at the High Court in London heard today.
fields.body:
ITN attempted to "completely destroy" a left-wing magazine which criticised their coverage of the Bosnian war, a jury at the High Court in London heard today.

Mick Hume, the editor of LM magazine (formerly Living Marxism), was giving evidence in a libel case brought by ITN and two reporters against the magazine. Mr Hume, 40, defended his decision to publish the article by Thomas Deichmann in his magazine in February 1997 which claimed ITN reporters had misrepresented the image of an emaciated Bosnian Muslim standing behind barbed wire in their award-winning report on the Serb-run Trnopolje camp in August 1992.

He said it was a "great piece of investigative journalism that deserved to be published", and which involved important issues about journalistic standards and the "use and misuse of the Holocaust".

Mr Hume said he had not contacted ITN to get their version of events before publishing the article, saying: "I was worried that if I was to contact an institution like ITN for their reaction they would attempt to suppress that story before it was ever published."

He said his decision had been vindicated because, after the article was published, ITN had "attempted to have my magazine completely destroyed".

He said he had "no personal malice or grudge" against ITN or the two ITN reporters, Penny Marshall and Ian Williams, who are claiming damages over a press release, editorial and article headed "The picture that fooled the world", published in 1997.

LM, which denies libel and pleads justication and fair comment, had asserted that there was no barbed wire surrounding Trnopolje but that it was around the news team, who were filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

Mr Hume said it was unprecedented for a major media organisation like ITN to sue a small independent magazine for libel, adding: "I believe the truth should be judged in the court of public opinion. I believe in press freedom and the right of the public themselves to decide the truth and not for them to have that decided by ITN or the High Court."

He added: "I felt these two reporters were guilty of taking sides, not with Muslims, but the victims. I felt they had developed an emotional involvement with the story and had presented a sensational image of the suffering of those victims, knowing it would be taken as an image of concentration camps."

Mr Hume said he had taken no side in the Bosnian civil war but criticised the tendency to make "easy and casual" comparisons between the Holocaust and conflicts around the globe which does "a disservice to victims of the Holocaust".

Giving evidence, Mr Deichmann said he had visited Trnopolje in 1996 and stood by his claim that inmates at the camp could leave at any time.

The case continues today.

fields.headline: 'Labour faces the neighbour from hell'
fields.standfirst:
Steve Pound, Labour MP for Ealing North, on the Labour Party's mayoral crisis

Knives out for McDonagh after selection fiasco
fields.trailText: Thursday, 6.30pm: Steve Pound, Labour MP for Ealing North, on the Labour Party's mayoral crisis.
fields.body:
The Labour Party has shown its commitment to returning democracy to Londoners by setting up the Greater London Authority, its Mayor and Assembly.

Having spent months in committee and in consultation the Labour Party is in the unfortunate position of having built a wonderful structure but is facing the neighbour from hell moving in.

We are criticised for expressing a preference for one candidate over another.

This is the same Labour Party that was criticised - and rightly so - for allowing candidates to stand in Greenwich and Govan who were clearly not up to the job. Yet the very same people who accused us then of having no control over candidate selection now assert that we are exercising too much control. Dammed if you do and dammed if you don't.

The sorry fiasco of Jeffrey Archer shows what the consequences are of allowing a charismatic but unprincipled rogue to self-select his party's candidacy.

We have been here before. From Oswald Mosley to David Owen there have been people who felt that they were bigger than the Party and when things didn't go exactly the way they wanted they took their ball home and set up their own team. In every case the result has been ignominious failure and a swift descent into obscurity.

Ken's case is especially tragic. He is certainly the most influential London politician of my generation and one who could have achieved so much if he cared a little more for London and a little less for Ken.

Ken came into the House in 1987 and I have yet to meet anyone who can point to any achievement during his fourteen years as an MP. Under the circumstances it is very understandable that he wants to go back to his glory days of the early 1980s.

His candidacy is self-indulgent but it will not split the London Labour Party. We have real and serious questions to ask about the operation of the ballot and the whole sorry selection process. But there is one thing that unites us all. Someone who turns their back on the Party that did so much for them has cast themselves into the outer darkness.

Ken has the capacity to cause a deal of distress to the London Labour Party. He could win the Mayoralty and spend four years without any support from the Assembly or central government. I doubt that he could achieve anything other than an extension to his chat-show guest career. A new Channel 5 series called "Have I got Newts for You" may not attract a wide audience. If Ken's case is tragic, then so is the miserable farce that this process has descended into.

I hope that the Prime Minister is big enough to shake hands with whoever wins the election in May. I think that he is big enough to do that. For London's sake I hope that Tony Blair shakes hands with Frank Dobson - that's Frank G. Dobson.

If Ken's case is tragic, then so is the miserable farce that this process has descended into. I hope that the Prime Minister is big enough to shake hands with whoever wins the election in May. I think that he is big enough to do that. For London's sake I hope that Tony Blair shakes hands with Frank Dobson - that's Frank G. Dobson.

fields.headline: Doctor's secret Serb camp photos
fields.trailText: A doctor told the high court in London yesterday how he risked his life to photograph badly beaten inmates at a Serb-run camp during the Bosnian conflict and handed the camera to an ITN crew.
fields.body:
A doctor told the high court in London yesterday how he risked his life to photograph badly beaten inmates at a Serb-run camp during the Bosnian conflict and handed the camera to an ITN crew.

Idriz Merdzanic, a Bosnian Muslim, said that he was taken against his will, with two other doctors and medical staff, to Trnopolje camp in north-west Bosnia in May 1992.

The doctor was giving evidence in a libel case brought by ITN and reporters Penny Marshall and Ian Williams, who are suing Living Marxism (now LM) magazine over claims that they misrepresented the camp by using the emotive image of an emaciated Bosnian Muslim standing behind barbed-wire, in their award-winning report in August 1992.

Speaking through an interpreter, Dr Merdzanic told Mr Justice Morland and a jury that he had treated men who had been severely beaten and women who had been raped by the Serb guards. About 10 metres away from the surgery was a laboratory room used to interrogate prisoners, he said.

"They were taking wooden legs from the tables and they would beat people with those, whatever they would find there. We heard the screams and the beatings. Some of the people that they beat up, they would bring them to us to help them, to dress their wounds."

Dr Merdzanic, 41, said he used another inmate's camera to photograph injured men in the interrogation room. One of the men later died. He said he took the pictures "hoping then that one day we would be able to show them to show everybody what happened".

The camera was hidden in a water tank in the surgery. "If it had been discovered, I would probably have been killed."

He passed the camera to Ms Marshall when the ITN crew visited the camp and the pictures were later shown around the world in the news report about the camps at Trnopolje and Omarksa.

Dr Merdzanic, who lost more than a 20lbs while in the camp, said the Serbian Red Cross doctors gave inmates no medicines except DDT powder for bugs and head lice.

But after the ITN visit, he said, the International Red Cross came to the camp, the wire was taken down and convoys of inmates were allowed to leave, although some young men were taken off the convoys and killed. ITN and the two reporters are claiming damages over an LM press release, editorial and article headed The picture that fooled the world, published in 1997.

LM, which denies libel and pleads justification and fair comment, asserts that there was no barbed wire surrounding Trnopolje, which was a collection centre for refugees and not a prison, and that the barbed wire in fact surrounded the news team who were filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Bradley and McCain quit presidential contest

fields.headline: Bradley and McCain quit presidential contest
fields.trailText: Bill Bradley and John McCain, the two outsiders in the US presidential campaign, both announced they were withdrawing from the race for the White House today, after being comprehensively defeated by Al Gore and George W Bush in the first batch of state primaries.
fields.body:
Bill Bradley and John McCain, the two outsiders in the US presidential campaign, both announced they were withdrawing from the race for the White House today, after being comprehensively defeated by Al Gore and George W Bush in the first batch of state primaries.

Bill Bradley pulled out of the contest and promptly agreed to back his fellow Democrat, Al Gore, for his forthcoming contest against the Republican favourite George W Bush.

"The vice-president and I had a stiff competition and he won," Mr Bradley said. He telephoned Mr Gore earlier in the day to tell him personally he was withdrawing from the race.

"I will support him in his bid to win the White House," Mr Bradley said at a withdrawal news conference. "Now is the time for unity."

Barely an hour later, Arizona senator John McCain's withdrawal from the Republican presidential contest was less gracious. He "wished Mr Bush well" but refrained from backing his campaign outright.

Mr McCain pledged to return to the Senate and continue to battle for the reform of government and the party system, in what was a veiled criticism of the remaining two presidential contenders, both of whom are creatures of the US political establishment.

"I will never walk away from a fight which I know is right and just for our country," he told the assembled press. "I will keep fighting to give the government back to the people."

Mr Bradley also insisted that while he had lost, "the cause for which I ran has not been defeated".

His underdog campaign, launched 15 months ago, flourished last year as he argued for universal health insurance and strict gun controls. He also walked picket lines, spoke of his commitment to race relations and assailed Mr Gore for his past ambivalence on abortion.

But the Democratic party's core constituencies, namely organised labor, minorities and abortion-rights groups, rallied around the Gore campaign, which gathered new conviction this year as the vice-president flexed his debating muscles in a series of increasingly impressive public appearances.

Mr Bradley failed to exploit Mr Gore's links to the Democratic party's fundraising excesses of 1996 and eschewed much of the traditionally effective negative campaigning.

Other factors working against Mr Bradley included his slightly distant public persona and competition from Republican John McCain for independent voters.

fields.headline: Teletubbies say eh-oh to PlayStation
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The Teletubbies are to spearhead a BBC move to sell the first games for the Sony PlayStation to be specifically designed for toddlers.
fields.body:
The Teletubbies are to spearhead a BBC move to sell the first games for the Sony PlayStation to be specifically designed for toddlers.

Tinky Winky, Dipsy, Laa-Laa and Po will star in the console game Play with the Teletubbies, which is aimed at children aged two to four and is due to go on sale next month.

The BBC's commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, aims to release three games for children under six before Christmas, with titles based on the children's favourites Bob the Builder and Noddy to follow.

Its strategy is to lure younger children to the PlayStation platform as their older siblings and adult gamers move on to the PlayStation 2 console which will be launched in the UK later this year.

It is estimated that by the end of the year, over a quarter of all UK households will own a PlayStation and, reasoning that children will pass on old equipment to younger members of the family, the BBC believes there is a market for games aimed at ever-younger players. The toddlers' games will be priced at around £25.

Dave Lee, the BBC's director of multimedia, has already developed the Teletubbies game for the PC format, where he said it had worked well with two-year-olds.

"We put the product through focus group testing in a nursery environment," he said. "Children are just hypnotised by the Teletubbies show and our task is to make that an interactive experience," he said.

Toddlers will have to learn to master the PlayStation keypad to manipulate the characters and play simple games such as hide and seek.

Mr Lee said that toddlers learn very quickly how to use the controls, but he added that in case their fingers could not manage the controls, the game had help screens so that their parents could assist.

Mr Lee said there was no danger of two-year-olds becoming addicted to PlayStation games because their attention span was too low. He added: "We have a responsibility. You could equally say that sitting them in front of a video all day is a bad thing. The point is they are interacting and developing their hand-eye coordination."

webTitle: BBC launches £5m bid to find new talent - and shed its elitist image

fields.headline: BBC launches £5m bid to find new talent - and shed its elitist image
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC will today launch an £5m, year-long search for its next generation of broadcasters and producers in an attempt to strengthen its talent base.
fields.body:
The BBC will today launch an £5m, year-long search for its next generation of broadcasters and producers in an attempt to strengthen its talent base.

The BBC Talent campaign, which is open to any member of the public, will offer up to 40 jobs across the corporation's networks and aims to end the perception that it is elitist.

Executives hope the campaign will find talent among people who had previously felt that the BBC was not for them, particularly minority groups.

Alan Yentob, the BBC's director of television, described the campaign as "a practical chance to make the dreams of many people a reality".

Among the starry opportunities on offer are the chance to report for the Holiday programme, present science and children's programmes, be the star of a TV comedy or win a year's traineeship at Radio 1.

More than 30 top performers and writers have backed the campaign including Richard Curtis, Ben Elton, Harry Enfield, Steve Coogan and Angus Deayton. They will hold masterclasses and act as mentors to the winning applicants.

Partners in the programme include the Guardian, Kellogg's, Odeon Cinemas and WH Smith. They will help by promoting the scheme, distributing entry brochures and hosting question and answer sessions with BBC stars at venues around the country.

A search for new comedians will be held, with qualifying heats around the country leading to a final at the Edinburgh Festival which will be broadcast on BBC1.

There will be a trawl for new comedy writers and producers. Up to 10 sitcom scripts will be commissioned, with the winner broadcast on Radio 2.

An ideas lab will be created, with 10 places available to develop new programmes. BBC2 will hand out three commissions in drama, documentary and entertainment to people already working in television and awaiting their big break.

Matthew Bannister, director of production at the BBC, said: "There were over 60 initiatives across the BBC to bring in new people. We felt it was not focused. We want to show that the BBC's doors are open to new talent in a big and powerful way, by putting some real contracts on offer."

Although it is a costly scheme - the BBC will invest up to £4m in contracts and programmes and has received £1m worth of marketing support from commercial partners - Mr Bannister hoped it would run in different areas on an annual basis.

fields.headline: Cybershopping: Music
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Music
fields.body:
shopsmart.com is a good place to start. It won't necessarily find you the cheapest deal but it will point you in the right direction. Prices are in dollars at cdnow.com so you can't calculate the exact cost until you've gone to the trouble of creating an account. The What's Hot selection - featuring the likes of Steely Dan and absence of any mention of Travis, for example - is perhaps not tailored to British pop tastes.

For ease of use, head to amazon.co.uk or bol.com. Amazon highlights new releases so if, for example, you're buying a present for a jazz fan and don't know the genre well, it will help you choose. While there, you might also want to check out the DVD and video shop, which went live on Thursday. Bol.com currently has a three for £20 offer.

The cheapest overall prices are to be had on sites which don't charge for delivery, jungle.com, for example.

If you're shopping for pop its easy, but the list of other genres is quite baffling. 101cd.com has a detailed classical search form for specific tracks or to allow you to browse by composer.

webTitle: How much can you pay for . . .

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.standfirst: . . . table mats
fields.trailText: . . . table mats
fields.body:
I've never quite seen the point of tablemats. If you can't put plates on to a table, then why is it there? Tablemats were clearly invented so that fussy elders could fuss a little more, making you lift up your plate just after you've started so they can slip a wee mat underneath it. Sorry love, don't mind me, before they pop back into the kitchen for the other 10 things they've forgotten but which you know you should be helping to carry in to the table.These placemats are so expensive however, that fussy elders would not be able to allow even a bit of light plate resting: £130 for two broken shell table mats, from Nina Campbell (0171-225 1011).

You'd probably need to put tablemats on top of them, or something.

fields.headline: Human traffic
fields.standfirst: The smell of new-mown grass, the subliminal sound of white noise - retailers use all kinds of tricks to make you spend more money.  Helen Jones  reveals the hidden persuaders
fields.trailText: The smell of new-mown grass, the subliminal sound of white noise - retailers use all kinds of tricks to make you spend more money.
fields.body:
Have you ever found yourself buying stuff you never knew you needed? You're not alone. According to Jeffrey Robinson, author of The Manipulators, shoppers are at the mercy of retailers who are using increasingly sophisticated ways of persuading us to shop. "Making money is the nature of the exercise and as little as possible is left to chance. Study after study constantly refines the deliberate application of manipulative techniques to trigger emotional responses to products and services," he says.

Traffic generation is the buzzword among retailers. It involves getting consumers to move around the entire store so they see all the products on offer. Vast amounts of money are invested by companies into research and development of traffic generation. It's a highly competitive area and besides, retailers are not keen for consumers to know the extent to which they are manipulated as they push the trolley up the aisle. As a result, many of the designers and psychologists involved in new ideas are bound by confidentiality and only talked to us if we agreed to anonymity. One retail designer says: "There are lots of tricks used in retailing. You put the cash desks, changing rooms or lavatories at the back of the store, not to save space but to make sure customers have to walk past other merchandise to get to them."

Some retailers use escalators to carry people up to other floors but stairs for descent, positioned at opposite ends of the store to increase traffic generation.

Rune Gustafson, managing director of 20/20, a retail design company, explains that supermarkets, in particular, try to pace the flow of shoppers. "The speed at which you travel round the supermarket isn't uniform. There is a slower-paced layout to make you linger over buying a nice bottle of wine and a faster-paced layout for commodities such as soap powder."

Most stores are "zoned" which means that products are grouped together by theme. "A fashion retailer will put suits and shirts and ties together to tell a story because people will buy the complete look," says Gustafson. And Marks & Spencer now groups together all the components for lunch - sandwiches, crisps, fruit and soft drinks. "In the past you used to have to wander round to get all these items and some people couldn't be bothered."

"Zoning has boosted sales by 30%," says another designer, who has worked for the company. If a retailer wants to sell lots of a product then it is positioned on shelves at about 4ft 6in high - or average eye level - because consumers don't generally look at bottom shelves. Hot spots - large displays at the end of aisles offering bargains, special offers or the latest "must have" product are also intended to get customers moving through the store. Retailers try to imitate natural light because it makes us buy more says Robinson. "It makes products look better and, because it is more akin to sunlight, our bodies respond better to it."

Fast food restaurants rely heavily on orange, red and pink tones. "These colours excite, make us eat more quickly and therefore vacate the table sooner for the next customer." Softer blue tones are used in areas where retailers want customers to relax and browse but are never used in food halls, says Robinson, "because foods don't look good surrounded by blue".

Oddly, few retailers put much thought into the lighting in changing rooms - although the mirrors are often deceptively flattering, the lighting generally isn't. Paco Underhill, a "retail anthropologist" who analyses stores on behalf of retailers says, "The lighting should make everybody look like a million bucks." He says that in the future changing rooms will have different light settings so shoppers can see what an outfit looks like in daylight, under fluorescent light or by candlelight.

Then there's the music. Finding yourself jigging along to your favourite track when out shopping for clothes is not unusual. Fashion retailers play music associated with clubbing or a night out to put customers in a good mood. Psychologists at the University of Leicester are researching the effect of music on shopping habits and how it influences what people choose. Over a period of two weeks they played French and German music at a local branch of Asda. "The results were clear. When French music was played, sales of French wine outnumbered sales of German by a third. Sales of German wine rose when German music was played," says Dr Adrian North.

A similar experiment carried out in the US, found that if classical music was played in off-licences, shoppers would gravitate towards more expensive wines.

Silent stores can make consumers self-conscious, so some stores use "white noise", a dull hum like the sound a fridge makes. It is barely discernible but puts people at ease. The potential uses of sound are fascinating. One psychologist is experimenting with it to reduce shoplifting. "We introduced a simulated radio station at a shopping centre with music and announcements. For example, if you lose your child, contact a security guard and if you want to enter our competition, contact our security guard. The endless references to security cut theft by 34%," he says.

Scents also influence behaviour. "In future, multi-sensory experiences such as sounds, texture and scents will be increasingly important," says Jasmine Montgomery of Fitch, a design group. Whether it is the smell of cakes baking, or of a particular type of disinfectant that reminds you of infant school, aromas produce an emotional rather than a rational response and are a very powerful marketing tool."

A research psychologist agrees that used properly, scent is influential: "Pumping lavender around a store will not make customers buy more shirts but aromas can be used in an associative way and put customers in the mood. The smell of coconut oil or rum punch could be used in a travel agency to evoke the idea of booking a holiday."

Travellers using BA lounges at Heathrow are assailed with the smell of new-mown grass, courtesy of the Aroma Company. Its director, Sarah Harrop, explains: "We have worked with BA to produce a fragrance to bring the outside inside to jaded passengers who move from office to plane to office." She says scents can help reflect a brand's values and make an environment more pleasant. "A lot of companies go for natural fragrances such as 'mountain air' but if you walk into a store and can smell something really distinct then we have got it wrong." Harrop says that a smell of peppermint can be used to keep people alert and citrus to uplift.

Internet shopping is already changing how people shop. Groceries apart, it will become even more of a leisure activity than it already is. That's the view of Marian Salzman, who is a futurologist at Brand Futures Group, a New-York based consultancy. "Stores will have to work harder and offer more to entertain consumers to encourage them to shop. The National Basketball Association Store in New York not only sells merchandise but has basketball courts where shoppers are encouraged to play," she says.

And it may not be long before the hidden persuaders reach right out through the store door to grab you in the street. Saltzman predicts: "Mobile phones will become more sophisticated and will be able to detect where you are on the high street. If you are outside a branch of Gap, for example, they will be able to send you a message saying that if you go inside now you will get 20% discount."
fields.bodyText: Have you ever found yourself buying stuff you never knew you needed? You're not alone. According to Jeffrey Robinson, author of The Manipulators, shoppers are at the mercy of retailers who are using increasingly sophisticated ways of persuading us to shop. "Making money is the nature of the exercise and as little as possible is left to chance. Study after study constantly refines the deliberate application of manipulative techniques to trigger emotional responses to products and services," he says. Traffic generation is the buzzword among retailers. It involves getting consumers to move around the entire store so they see all the products on offer. Vast amounts of money are invested by companies into research and development of traffic generation. It's a highly competitive area and besides, retailers are not keen for consumers to know the extent to which they are manipulated as they push the trolley up the aisle. As a result, many of the designers and psychologists involved in new ideas are bound by confidentiality and only talked to us if we agreed to anonymity. One retail designer says: "There are lots of tricks used in retailing. You put the cash desks, changing rooms or lavatories at the back of the store, not to save space but to make sure customers have to walk past other merchandise to get to them." Some retailers use escalators to carry people up to other floors but stairs for descent, positioned at opposite ends of the store to increase traffic generation. Rune Gustafson, managing director of 20/20, a retail design company, explains that supermarkets, in particular, try to pace the flow of shoppers. "The speed at which you travel round the supermarket isn't uniform. There is a slower-paced layout to make you linger over buying a nice bottle of wine and a faster-paced layout for commodities such as soap powder." Most stores are "zoned" which means that products are grouped together by theme. "A fashion retailer will put suits and shirts and ties together to tell a story because people will buy the complete look," says Gustafson. And Marks & Spencer now groups together all the components for lunch - sandwiches, crisps, fruit and soft drinks. webTitle: Oil price gush boosts Shell and BP shares

fields.headline: Oil price gush boosts Shell and BP shares
fields.trailText: Shares in BP Amoco and Shell roared ahead yesterday as crude oil prices remained above the $30-a-barrel level not seen since the 1991 Gulf war.
fields.body:
Shares in BP Amoco and Shell roared ahead yesterday as crude oil prices remained above the $30-a-barrel level not seen since the 1991 Gulf war.

The share price rise came in the wake of a deal by both groups to sell their common interest in Altura Energy, an American southwest oil and gas field, to Occidental for $3.6bn.

BP Amoco stock rose 49p or 9.69% to close at 554.5p while Shell was up 5.6% at the close at 488.5p amid continuing uncertainty about whether the oil-producers' cartel, Opec, would agree to boost output later this month.

But Saudi Arabia, a proponent of increased supplies to dampen volatile prices, and Iran, an opponent, agreed yesterday to "balance the market in order to reach sustainable price levels conducive to world economic growth and market stability."

The surge in oil prices - coupled with extensive cost-cutting - has substantially increased bigger oil groups' earnings but sent a shudder through the US in election year.

Bill Richardson, US energy secretary, was forced to reject suggestions that petrol could reach $2 a gallon, piling the pressure on Opec to reverse last year's production cuts when it meets on March 27.

The Saudi-backed Centre for Global Energy Studies said that a price level of $17-20 would stabilise the market, encourage demand and promote new fields.

The BP/Shell deal over Altura means the two keep a small interest in the low-cost producer.

fields.headline: A life in crime
fields.standfirst: Whodunnits are no longer all about posh amateur sleuths and gritty private eyes, says crime writer  Ian Rankin. Nowadays, they reflect every part of human existence
fields.trailText: Whodunnits are no longer all about posh amateur sleuths and gritty private eyes, says crime writer Ian Rankin. Nowadays, they reflect every part of human existence.
fields.body:
Here's the scoop: crime writing is sexy. Crime writing is currently in - which is where it should always have been. Forget Miss Marple and arsenic in the crusted port. Today's crime writers are dealing with the real world, real problems, real dramas. Like surgeons, they wield a scalpel, slicing open society and probing the wound, finding the cancers of corruption, deceit, unemployment, dope. And the surgery? The surgery is in the writing: clean, sharp, incisive, with dialogue Hollywood would kill for.

Pick up any Elmore Leonard, any Lawrence Block, and you'll get a masterclass in dialogue. For action and perversion, turn to James Ellroy, crime fiction's self-proclaimed "Demon Dog". He doesn't just snap and howl: given half a chance, he'll rip your head off with images and scenes that seem to have been transcribed in some antechamber of hell. This is visceral, immediate writing. It has urgent things to say. It demands the attention. It doesn't let go.

Young readers and young writers are being drawn by this. They may not have read their Agatha Christie, but you can be sure they know their Tarantino by heart. They watch The Sopranos; they wish they could have been Al Pacino in the first Godfather movie; they know that crime fiction is no longer the domain of the "dime a word" pulp writer. Crime fiction can do anything, explore any avenue, use myriad voices and locations. There are wonderful crime novels set in Franco's Spain, Nazi-occupied France, cyberspace, futuristic Edinburgh. Even in ancient Rome. There are funny crime novels and sad ones, brutal ones and elegant ones. Romantics and cynics are drawn to the form. There are even "accidental" crime writers - like me, for instance.

Where did it all come from? Did Edgar Allan Poe pen the first whodunnit stories? Should the English writer (and friend of Dickens) Wilkie Collins be credited with the first full-length crime novel? Do we start further back, with murder and mystery in Shakespeare? Or how about Sophocles, whose Oedipus has a good claim to be an early detective story? Stories down the ages have depended upon tension and deferred answers to keep their readers and listeners guessing. It's like with jokes: if the punchline was told straight away, you'd lose interest. So it is with all narratives. Crime fiction merely codifies this principle.

The "golden age" of crime fiction is supposed to be the 20s and 30s, when the traditional English whodunnit was at its height, practitioners such as Christie, Marjorie Allingham, Dorothy L Sayers and Ngaio Marsh giving it style and substance. On the other side of the Atlantic, Chandler and Hammett reacted against this "cosy" school. Chandler in particular felt it his duty to take crime back on to the "mean streets" (his phrase) by making it urban and relevant to its time and place. Interestingly, the private eye - hero of the American golden age - had as his predecessor the cowboy. Both were based on the "knight errant", bringing a certain chivalry to bear on morally barren landscapes. The private eye always had his holy grail, be it ultimate truth or a cache of money, and there was always a damsel in distress (though often they were more calculating than seemed the case).

Crime fiction has always depended on archetypes and has always dealt with the fears of its time and its readership. The cliches of Fu Manchu and evil butlers refer to middle England's fear of foreign invasion and working-class uprising. In these books the detective is often a titled gentleman or shrewd spinster, and the police officers - almost always working class - defer to these gifted amateurs, knowing their rightful and proper place.

It was all Sherlock Holmes's fault. He came along just at the point where the public's honeymoon with the real-life detectives of Scotland Yard ended. The fledgling police force failed ignominiously (and all too publicly) to apprehend Jack the Ripper. There's perhaps something of the Ripper himself in Holmes's arch foe Moriarty: a criminal mastermind who outwits Lestrade of the Yard every time. Only Holmes (based in part on the real-life French detective Vidocq) has a chance of rescuing polite society from destruction. Intellect and innate goodness save the day; the status quo is preserved.

American crime fiction has never really broken faith with Chandler and Hammett. A new breed of feminist private eyes appeared in the 70s - but it's important that they were still private eyes. Paretsky's VI Warshawski and Sue Grafton's Kinsey Milhone even sound like characters from The Big Sleep or The Long Goodbye. This is not to say that there are no "cosies" in the US, no English-style amateur sleuths - there are. But the most successful creations in post-war American crime fiction have tended to be either PIs or cops.

In the UK, we caught on to the professional cop thing a bit late. It actually took TV, in the form of Dixon of Dock Green and Z-Cars, to make us realise that we could write about police detectives, that they needn't necessarily be bumbling Lestrades or forelock-tugging flunkies. Georges Simenon showed us the way, his Maigret being a shabby, down-to-earth cop who depended on luck, shoe leather and the skills of his team. This wasn't the cunning, forensic brain of a Sherlock Holmes but the realistic depiction of a humane individual who just happened to solve crimes for a living.

These days we've got detectives who are veterinarians and detectives who are child psychologists; we've got old ones, young ones - we've even household pets solving crimes. Crime writing is a broad church: there's plenty of room for everyone. And the quality is better than ever. Novelist and critic Val McDermid has said that if the 30s represented a golden age, then the present day should be classed "crime fiction's platinum age".

Crime stories sell; crime films are some of the classiest around; and whether it's The Cops or The Sopranos, crime makes great TV too. But for the pinnacle of quality, you need to go to the writers. Writers like Andrew Vachss, a scary-looking guy with an eye-patch, whose books have a singular message: sexual abuse (especially that of children) is an evil we tolerate at our peril. His work has earned him death threats from paedophile groups.

Then there's James Sallis - he's right up there, one of the best of the best. His series of novels about private eye Lew Griffin is thoughtful, challenging and beautifully written. Sallis, also a poet, is capable of smart phrasing and moments of elegiac energy.

Jon Jackson is a real pro who's capable of surprising himself and his audience. Jon's too good ever to get stereotyped - he keeps moving. Tony Bourdain offers an affecting glimpse into the daily grind and uncommon heart of a tough guy. There's not a word wasted: Bourdain does more with meaningful silences than some writers do with 10,000 words of text. Doug Winter writes heart-stopping action - his language a terse, slangy rush of adrenaline.

Crime fiction has that power to seduce. The reader gets a vicarious thrill, the zing of tramping those mean streets without ever having to stop for a shoe-shine. It's been said of horror fiction that readers go to it because humanity has an interest in that which we fear. The same can surely be said of crime fiction. We go to it to find ordinary people put into extraordinary situations, and we learn something of ourselves by studying their movements through this new landscape.

Jung once said the detective story "makes it possible to experience without danger all the excitement, passion and desirousness which must be suppressed in a humanitarian ordering of society". Crime stories walk the wild side and take the reader with them, introducing us to the darker side of our nature.

· Extracted from the introduction to Criminal Minded, an anthology of crime short stories by four new writers (£1, Canongate Books)

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.trailText: Bradley to bid presidential race farewell
fields.body:
Bradley to bid presidential race farewell

The rout became so foreseeable in recent days that televisions at Brady's election night party at a Manhattan hotel weren't tuned to election news, but instead played videotapes of Bradley speaking.

The mood was much lighter than at most gatherings held by losing campaigns because there was no suspense or let down. Instead, supporters had come to salute Bradley for running, and for all that he had done in the past. Several said they felt that the country had lost a great opportunity.

Mike Allen, The Washington Post

Bradley plans to end campaign today

Magic was in the air as Bill Bradley returned to his hometown last September. Pundits and pollsters swooned, vice-president Al Gore's campaign was in disarray, and Mr Bradley began his own presidential race with a speech as lofty as his plays as a high school basketball star in that very same gymnasium.

And then, of course, Mr. Bradley crashed back to earth.

James Dao and Nicholas D Kristof, The New York Times

Just a matter of time until Bradley bows out

While Gore hired feminist image specialist Naomi Wolf to help convert him into a power-suit-wearing Alpha Male, Bradley remained the genteel, cardigan-wearing policy wonk he was known for being on the Senate floor. Bradley also suffered by having the air sucked out of his campaign by the fierce battle between John McCain and George W Bush.

After Bradley's strong showing in the Feb 1 New Hampshire primary, the public focused on Republican races in Michigan, South Carolina, Delaware and Arizona, and Bradley was not able to do much to garner media attention. Gore, meanwhile, partly by virtue of being the vice-president, stayed in the public eye and surged in the polls.

Michael Eskenazi, Time Magazine

McCain, Bradley close to conceding

Buried in a bicoastal landslide, John McCain prepared Wednesday to fold his insurgent campaign and effectively concede the GOP presidential nomination to George W Bush.

In New Jersey, his Democratic counterpart, Bill Bradley, also readied to end his uphill campaign today at a news conference in his home state. Campaign insiders said Bradley would endorse Al Gore, starting the party's healing process.

Mark Z Barabak and Cathleen Decker, The LA Times

McCain to halt campaign; steps towards Bush uncertain

Senator John McCain will announce today that he will halt his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, a campaign official said last night.

McCain, who suffered major setbacks in Tuesday's primaries, is expected to withdraw from the race. He cancelled campaign events, a senior aide said, in a sign that his candidacy was near an end.

During the last few weeks of the campaign for the Republican nomination, McCain and Texas Governor George W Bush, two men who began the contest calling each other "friend", have spoken like bitter enemies. The candidates and their surrogates have sniped at, undermined, complained about, and wounded each other, the acrimony drowning out issues and policy.

Yvonne Abraham and Anne E Kornblut, The Boston Globe

Don't be shocked if McCain makes it a three-ring circus

John McCain is dead. Long live John McCain?

The Arizona maverick's campaign for the Republican nomination effectively ended Tuesday night. As painful as it is for McCain Republicans to admit, this is largely the result of the candidate's mistakes.

But don't count McCain out yet. He will now face enormous pressure to run this fall as a third-party candidate, perhaps on the Reform Party ticket.

Nothing doing, he's saying.

Don't bet on it.

Rod Dreher, The New York Post

fields.headline: Germany suspends BNFL fuel contracts
fields.trailText: The German government delivered yet another blow to British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) yesterday by suspending indefinitely on safety grounds all contracts to buy reprocessed fuel from the company.
fields.byline: Paul Brown and John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
The German government delivered yet another blow to British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) yesterday by suspending indefinitely on safety grounds all contracts to buy reprocessed fuel from the company.

It means the company's new £300m reprocessed fuel plant at Sellafield will probably never open and puts in doubt the future of the £1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant which has as its only purpose the production of plutonium for the fuel. It also makes the government's plans to part-privatise the company before the next election, raising £1.5bn, even more difficult.

The action of BNFL's biggest customer after Japan follows a highly critical report on safety at Sellafield from the government's chief nuclear inspector, and the revelation that fuel was delivered to both countries with false documentation.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has become embroiled in a row over the disclosure in the Guardian yesterday that BNFL paid £500,000 a year to have its own man working inside the British embassy in Tokyo with a diplomatic passport and negotiating on behalf of the government.

MPs yesterday demanded that Mr Cook withdraw the diplomatic credentials of Tom McLauglan, who holds the post of councillor (atomic energy) in the embassy.

Mr Cook is also being asked to list how many other companies "buy" posts in British embassies and to list diplomats who are in reality employees of companies with financial or trade links with the countries concerned.

Two Labour MPs, Alan Simpson and Llew Smith, tabled questions yesterday on the issue. Mr Smith, MP for Blaenau Gwent, said: "It is crucial for the government to have an accurate view through its embassy of what is happening in Japan on the nuclear issue - you cannot expect an employee of the company at the centre of a row to give an uncritical and objective account of events."

Mr Simpson, MP for Nottingham South, said "The government must radically re-examine BNFL's claim that Thorp is anything but an economic and environmental albatross. My best advice to my government is when in a hole stop digging."

The Japanese have already cancelled their contracts and demanded that Britain takes back unused fuel delivered with false quality control checks.

BNFL has been trying to reassure the government it can repair the damage to relations with Japan caused by the falsifications. This is part of a campaign to get the department of environment to approve a licence for a £300m plant to convert reprocessed fuel at Sellafield. Getting a licence is dependent on BNFL making out a convincing economic case to the department that the company has enough orders to make the plant pay.

This now appears to be an impossible task.

At the same time as cancelling the fuel shipments, the German environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, cast doubt on the resumption of spent nuclear fuel shipments to Sellafield for reprocessing in the Thorp works. The shipments were suspended after warnings about radiation leaks.

Mr Trittin said new shipments were "completely open to question".

fields.headline: The black economy
fields.standfirst: Chancellor Gordon Brown has promised to crack down on the black economy, after the publication of a government-sponsored report by Lord Grabiner on the scale of the problem. Mark Tran looks at how the informal sector works and how the government plans to tackle it
fields.trailText: What is the black economy?
fields.body:
What is the black economy?

Lord Grabiner defines the black - or informal - economy as any undeclared economic activity, covering casual moonlighting, work paid cash in hand and organised crime. The report cites several examples, including that of a couple where the wife worked full time in a nursing home, while the husband claimed a jobseeker's allowance without reporting her earnings.

How big is the informal economy?

By its nature, the size of the informal economy is hard to measure and estimates run anywhere from £50bn to £80bn a year, or 8% of gross domestic product. Lord Grabiner tends to think these estimates are exaggerated, but avoids giving a precise sum. Gauging the scale of benefits fraud is easier. Lord Grabiner says that at any one time, 120,000 people are simultaneously working and claiming benefits. This type of fraud is estimated to cost taxpayers £465m annually.

What kind of businesses tend to be part of the black economy?

Typically low-wage and labour-intensive. Examples include domestic service, taxis, mini-cabs, market trading, hotels and catering, agriculture and fishing, fashion and clothing manufacture. Most large-scale crime, such as drug trafficking and money laundering, is also part of the black economy.

Is fraud getting more sophisticated?

Yes, Lord Grabiner says modern technology is being used more and more. Professional-looking false invoices can be created by computer, enabling firms to exaggerate their tax-deductible expenses. There are even businesses that exist solely to manufacture and trade in invoices.

What does the government propose to do?

The chancellor is expected to adopt most, if not all, of the report's 17 recommendations in his March 21 budget. Most notably, people convicted twice of welfare fraud will have their benefits withdrawn for a specified period in a US-style "two strikes and you're out" move. The inland revenue could also be given power to make "reverse searches" of the telephone directory - enabling them to use a telephone number to find a person's name and address - to track down people running businesses from home without paying tax or while claiming benefit. Civil liberties groups would probably oppose such a move. Data rules currently forbid such searches and would need to be changed.

Are there any carrots besides sticks in Lord Grabiner's proposals?

He rejects a general amnesty, which he says would not work, but recommends a confidential anonymous hotline offering advice to people in the black economy on how to put their affairs in order.

Why is the government cracking down now?

Mr Brown says it is a way of regaining billions of pounds lost every year, "leaving honest, hard-working taxpayers footing the bill". The effort is the chancellor's latest attempt to reduce the dole queues by requiring everyone who can work to take up a job. Cracking down on benefits fraud also seems to be popular politically although, as Lord Grabiner notes, the benefits mainly affected (£20.8bn) actually represent a relatively small proportion of the total social security budget of almost £100bn.
