webTitle: Not scrounging but drowning: the truth about asylum seekers

fields.headline: Not scrounging but drowning: the truth about asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Explained: how the asylum system works
fields.trailText: Thursday, 2.45pm: Diane Taylor, a reporter who specialises in asylum issues on the hysteria over refugees
fields.body:
A week of exposes by the right-wing press about the activities of 'refugee beggars' - many of them from Romania - has climaxed with a warning from Roger Davies, a stipendiary magistrate at the central London Horseferry Road Magistrates Court, that beggars who use babies as an incentive for people to give them money face jail.

Media coverage of women exploiting their own babies to supplement state benefits is likely to harden some hearts to the kind of difficulties most asylum seekers face. And no doubt Jack Straw and his officials are quietly pleased with this turn of events.

Public hostility towards asylum seekers will make it much easier to slip in the changes contained in the new Immigration and Asylum act, many of which become active on April 1.

While attention is focused on a small but high profile group of healthy-looking beggars, many coming from a single community , it is easy to overlook the plight of thousands of others such as those from the Camaroon who are arriving emaciated, tortured with electrodes, beatings and scalding water only to be sent back to a likely death by the home office which does not accept that torture takes place in that country. But like the overwhelming majority of asylum seekers you never see them begging on the streets, displaying their wounds as some kind of income generation scheme.

Asylum seekers who apply for asylum at their port of entry will receive vouchers from April 1 set at 30 per cent below the official poverty line. Those who apply once they are already here are to have vouchers phased in over the next few months along with the home office's plans to disperse them around the country. The forcible dispersal has had to be put on hold because the home office has failed to secure sufficient accommodation contracts around the country to start moving everyone out. Many single adults already receive vouchers and have reported prejudice in supermarkets from both cashiers and customers because the vouchers make them an easily identifiable target.

And the ill-fated , delayed dispersal scheme has hit problems before it has even officially got off the ground . Asylum seekers who have been placed in areas with few non-white, non-English speaking residents have been creeping back to London although they forfeit their measly voucher rations by doing so because the racism they have encountered is too much to bear.

But all that's played down because it doesn't quite fit in with the 'scrounger' stereotpye that's sold to us every day.

Until we start treating asylum seekers with more humanity they will continue to suffer terrible hardships and our collective morality will continue to look threadbare.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText:
In brief, plus casting news
One of Cider House Rules' stars complains of racial bias in the film's marketing campaign, and, on the casting couch, Helen Mirren signs up to play the shrink in The Pledge, Chris Penn joins the cast of Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang, and David Arquette plays a postie in Seinfeld script team's See Spot Run.
fields.body:
The Cider House Rules may be one of the more heartening surprises of this year's Oscars, with a startling seven nominations, but not everyone involved with the film is happy. Actor Delroy Lindo, who has a meaty role as the leader of a group of black migrant workers, has all but accused Miramax of racism in their marketing of the movie. Speaking to Entertainment Weekly, Lindo has alleged that The Cider House Rules' advertising campaign has deliberately ignored his own contribution and that of the film's other black actors (including rapper Heavy D and singer Erykah Badu). "There are no African-Americans in the advertisements I've seen on the TV," says Lindo. "[It makes it look like] I'm not in the film and nobody of colour is in the film Do I take it personally? Yes." While a Miramax spokeswoman has claimed that the current advertisements are just one individual phase of the film's marketing, Lindo's claims are supported by co-star Heavy D: "Even if it's unintentional, it's still bad because we get overlooked," he claims.

Casting couch

 Helen Mirren has signed on to play Jack Nicholson's shrink in The Pledge, a noirish crime drama set in the 50s and adapted from material by Swiss playwright Friedrich Dürrenmatt. The film begins production in Canada this month, with Sean Penn directing. It will be Nicholson's first acting work since bagging an Oscar for As Good as it Gets back in 1997.

 Chris (brother of Sean) Penn will arrive in England this month to co-star opposite Swedish actor Stellan Skarsgard in the indie thriller Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang. Directed by rising British director Stewart (Fast Food) Sugg, the film is an odd-couple comedy-thriller about an icy hitman (Skarsgard) forced into adopting a hulking brute with the personality of a toddler (Penn, naturally). Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang begins shooting in London on March 27.

 Currently playing to packed American cinemas in Scream 3, David Arquette will star as a hapless postal worker who takes in a crime-fighting dog in the Warner Bros comedy See Spot Run. The film, written by Alex Berg, Jeff Schaeffer and Dave Mandel, who all cut their teeth scripting episodes of Seinfeld, will begin production in the summer.

fields.headline: Stephen King
fields.trailText: 1. Horror writer Stephen King is to release his latest opus on Monday - but, like a Telstar record, this offer is not available in any shop.
fields.body:
1. Horror writer Stephen King is to release his latest opus on Monday - but, like a Telstar record, this offer is not available in any shop.

2. Spurning the printing press which has made him so rich (inventor Johannes Gutenburg), Mr King is to publish Riding the Bullet in electronic form only.

3. From midnight on Monday 14 March, readers will be able to download the book for PC, PDAs or e-books, by following this link. Price: $2.50.

4. There will then be no medium through which Mr King has not imposed his twisted vision of the world on an eager audience; 50 films have been made of his books and stories.

5. Further, he recently released Blood and Smoke only as an audio recording, and got back to the 19th century with the serialisation of The Green Mile. We await The Shining: The Musical with great interest.

6. This is not the first time an author has published on-line; Arthur C Clarke has published a six-page essay online, and pioneers are already testing the possibilities of the medium.

7. And Project Gutenberg continues to amass an online library of classics, from the electronic Electra to the digital Dostoevsky.

8. Riding the Bullet also allays fears that King had set down his quill (or in this case, mouse). In a not particularly eerie echo of his bestselling book Misery, King was knocked down by a "fan" last year, and feared he would never write again.

9. The book trade trembled; King is one of the world's most successful authors. The recent Forbes list of the highest earning entertainers placed him seventh, just behind fellow airport stalwart Tom Clancy, and King in February signed a $30m three-book deal.

10. Admirers of the Spike Jonze film Being John Malkovich should spare a thought for users of the Being Stephen King site - dedicated "to those of us whose daily reality is dictated by who we are not."

Find out more in the Books Unlimited author profile, with biography, critical verdict, work online and useful sites.

webTitle: Bank of England leaves rates unchanged

fields.headline: Bank of England leaves rates unchanged
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) has left interest rates unchanged at 6%.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) has left interest rates unchanged at 6%.

The decision, which came at noon today, will offer respite to homeowners and the manufacturing sector after four interest rate rises in the last six months.

Weak domestic manufacturing and industrial production data released on Wednesday strengthened expectations the Bank of England would keep rates steady and led analysts to forecast that the economy is slowing down.

Output from the manufacturing sector fell by 0.4% in January compared with the previous month, suggesting a slowdown. For the year as a whole, manufacturing output has risen just 1.8%, well below analysts' forecasts of 2.5% and below the growth rate for the economy as a whole.

Philip Shaw, UK group economist at Investec Bank, said: "Today's decision comes as no surprise following rises in four of the last six months.

"Bank governor Eddie George and deputy governor David Clementi have both made hints that it's time for a pause. The critical judgment is how long it will last."

"UK business will breathe a sigh of relief," said Ian Peters of the British chamber of commerce. "Four rate rises in the last six months have inflicted severe pressure on manufacturing and exporters. The overvalued pound has led to a sharp deterioration in the trade deficit and the squeeze on margins could hit investment."

The current UK rate is nearly double the 3.25% rates common throughout euroland. However, the inflation rate excluding the cost of home loans stands at just 2.1%, comfortably below the government's 2.5% target.

fields.headline: Weekend of sure things
fields.standfirst: If you want Mike Hodgkinson's advice, you'll go for the clean sweep with a bold, uncompromising Premiership accumulator
fields.trailText: Mike Hodgkinson knows a good thing when he sees it. Listen to him
fields.body:
A quick glance at the Premiership's weekend card reveals a slew of bankers, leaving you no option but to go for the clean sweep with a bold, uncompromising accumulator. The aim here is to furnish yourself with the money you intend to lose at the Cheltenham festival next week.

Aston Villa, Liverpool and Newcastle should all breeze through their respective opponents - Coventry, Sunderland and Watford - to land the home win. The Sky Blues looked especially poor last weekend; the Mackems haven't won away in donkeys; and the Hornets are pants. Three down, seven to go.

If John Hartson had turned up at White Hart Lane this week for a re-union with former boss George Graham, he would quite possibly have become the catalyst for a mini Spurs revival. But the deal fell through, leaving a draw against Southampton the likely outcome. Glenn Hoddle's men won't particularly be looking forward to a return to the big smoke after their midweek defeat by West Ham, but should have enough in the tank to force the draw against unsteady Tottenham.

The two remaining draws involve the biggest risk - both concern sides who could possibly win the Champions League. Everton travel to Stamford Bridge on the back of an outstanding recent run and they will face a side who have consistently disappointed after fine shows in Europe.

Derby have the harder task at Old Trafford, but their Premiership win here three seasons ago - coupled with last weekend's mauling of Wimbledon - should help them raise their game. Former Manchester City hero Georgi Kinkladze is in line for honours after his stunning return to form against the Dons and may be worth a first scorer bet for a bit of extra interest.

That leaves four aways, but you can wade into them with better than average confidence. Arsenal have won their last four at Middlesbrough - the score at Fortress Riverside was 6-1 in the Premiership last season - and they can continue the good work on Sunday. West Ham are unbeaten in their last four at Hillsborough and will steam into Sheffield Wednesday on the back of a pleasing midweeker against the Saints. It'll be good to see Paolo di Canio back in the town where he was either brilliant or absent - and where he instigated referee Paul Alcock's infamous comedy tumble. If he's fit, more Di Canio madness is a virtual certainty.

Leicester have fared well in their raids on Wimbledon over recent seasons. With Stan Collymore and Emile Heskey up front they have firepower in abundance - and the Dons have conceded an average of three goals in each of their last four games.

That just leaves Leeds, who strolled it against Coventry last week - one of their most controlled and assured performances of the season. How much that was down to Coventry's crapness is open to debate - Gordon Strachan, for one, was none too pleased with his admittedly understrength team - but many expect David O'Leary's men to hand out a footballing lesson to Bradford on Sunday. It's hard to disagree.

Premiership accumulator

Bradford v Leeds - away win
Chelsea v Everton - draw
Liverpool v Sunderland - home win
Manchester United v Derby - draw
Middlesbrough v Arsenal - away win
Newcastle v Watford - home win
Sheffield Wednesday v West Ham - away win
Tottenham v Southampton - draw
Wimbledon v Leicester - away win

Derby have the harder task at Old Trafford, but their Premiership win here three seasons ago - coupled with last weekend's mauling of Wimbledon - should help them raise their game. Former Manchester City hero Georgi Kinkladze is in line for honours after his stunning return to form against the Dons and may be worth a first scorer bet for a bit of extra interest. That leaves four aways, but you can wade into them with better than average confidence. Arsenal have won their last four at Middlesbrough - the score at Fortress Riverside was 6-1 in the Premiership last season - and they can continue the good work on Sunday. West Ham are unbeaten in their last four at Hillsborough and will steam into Sheffield Wednesday on the back of a pleasing midweeker against the Saints. It'll be good to see Paolo di Canio back in the town where he was either brilliant or absent - and where he instigated referee Paul Alcock's infamous comedy tumble. If he's fit, more Di Canio madness is a virtual certainty. Leicester have fared well in their raids on Wimbledon over recent seasons. With Stan Collymore and Emile Heskey up front they have firepower in abundance - and the Dons have conceded an average of three goals in each of their last four games. That just leaves Leeds, who strolled it against Coventry last week - one of their most controlled and assured performances of the season. How much that was down to Coventry's crapness is open to debate - Gordon Strachan, for one, was none too pleased with his admittedly understrength team - but many expect David O'Leary's men to hand out a footballing lesson to Bradford on Sunday. It's hard to disagree. fields.headline: Death rays
fields.standfirst: The shining - a new horror show from the far distant universe.  Tim Radford on the search for gamma ray bursters
fields.trailText: The shining - a new horror show from the far distant universe. Tim Radford on the search for gamma ray bursters
fields.body:
Swift is a little satellite preparing to go in search of the brightest thing in the universe. When it gets launched in 2003, it will be on the lookout for the mysterious bursts of gamma rays that have been astonishing astronomers for decades.

A gamma ray burst lasts for about two minutes. But during that time, it is brighter than all the rest of the universe put together: a brief blaze from some unimaginably fierce cosmic traffic accident.

Invisible light of this ferocity raises huge questions which nobody can yet answer. By the time scientists have detected a gamma ray burst and tried to turn other telescopes on it, the blaze has faded. The aim of Swift, now being prepared by David Palmer of the Goddard space flight centre run by Nasa in Maryland, and by a team which includes scientists at Leicester university and at the Mullard space sciences lab in Surrey, is to detect these explosions of radiation in the distant universe, and train other instruments on it within seconds.

Gamma ray bursts are a kind of proof that JBS Haldane was right: the universe is not only queerer than we may suppose, it is queerer than we can suppose. They were first detected more than 30 years ago by Cold War satellites looking for violations of the nuclear test ban treaty. It took a while to persuade people that the telltale radiation was coming from outer space not Inner Mongolia or some other nuclear testing ground. And it took a while to come to terms with the other puzzle: how could these things be so violent?

Swift will peer at a huge arc of the sky. It has a screen of randomly scattered lead blocks, sitting above 32,000 detectors, 4mm squares of cadmium zinc telluride each 2mm deep, and when a gamma ray hits one of these, it gives off an electrical signal. The shadow cast by the lead blocks will reveal the direction of the radiation.

It will be the signal for Swift to change position in a big hurry, and get to work with x-ray and optical telescopes to pinpoint the source. It will also measure the redshift for the radiation burst, which will tell astronomers how fast the mysterious radiating object is receding, and therefore how far away. David Palmer expects the bursts to be very far away.

"If one occurred in our galaxy at 1,000 light years away, it would be for a few seconds 10 times as bright as the noonday sun, and the optical brightness is one part in one thousand of the gamma ray brightness," he says. "The atmosphere absorbs gamma rays - but if it absorbed that much, it would produce chemicals in the upper atmosphere which would destroy the ozone layer, so the biosphere would be in pretty bad shape afterwards."

A gamma ray burst in this galaxy 65 million years ago could, some argue, provide an alternative explanation for the disappearance of the dinosaurs. Fortunately, such explosions might happen in a galaxy like this one only at intervals of a million or 10 million years. But there could be 100 billion galaxies in the discernible universe. That means that there could be a gamma ray burst somewhere in the sky, every day.

There will, says Palmer, be more than one explanation for gamma ray bursts. Some last only a few thousandths of a second; some last for whole minutes, and one seemed to explode in multiple bursts every few days. "My guess is that some are probably something akin to a supernova, and others are neutron stars spiralling into each other. It's as if you took two neutron stars and converted them entirely into energy as gamma rays, with nothing left over. Maybe it's just poverty of imagination, but I don't know any reasonable way to do that."

That might explain why some gamma ray bursts are so brief. Neutrons stars are one stop from oblivion: they pack the mass of something like the sun into a parcel a few miles across, so that a cubic inch of neutron starstuff would weigh millions of tons.

"If you have two neutron stars, then the timescale once they start tearing each other apart is milliseconds and that's because you have two things which are the size of a mountain and moving at the speed of light."

So why do some gamma ray bursts last so long? "If you have a supernova-type gamma ray burst, you have the centre of the star collapsing and the rest of the star has to fall down into it, and that takes a long time because you usually start with a star many times larger than the sun. You get a black hole at the centre, everything has to spiral down the drain, jets have to eat their way through the poles of the star and through the envelope of the star: that also takes time, possibly hours, possibly less."

But earthbound clocks might not measure the time of a gamma burst truly. Something that actually involved an explosion of months could seem - by the time it crossed the vastness of space - to last only for seconds because of some teasing Einsteinian trickery with time and space. And anyway, Dr Palmer says, a satisfactory explanation of one burst will not be an explanation for all such events.

"There are hundreds of gamma ray bursts every year. Every one looks different. If we say at least 95% are either colliding neutron stars or supernovae that would still leave 5% that we don't know what they are, and there are quite a few weird science theories around."

One of these (he doesn't like it much, but it's there) involves trying to imagine a region of the universe where neutrinos, the immeasurably small, barely detectable particles that pour from the sun in their squillions, and pass through the earth as if it wasn't there at all, rotate in the wrong direction. If so, that region would be separated from this part of the universe by a cosmic membrane through which neutrinos could not pass, because they'd have to turn around. This membrane would have surface tension, which would pull the neutrinos into a kind of high density bowl. Suppose a star fell into this neutrino porridge: it would burn up in a twinkling, go supernova, and discharge energy which would have to escape in some form, so why not gamma rays?

Or try this: what if a piece of cosmic string (a bit of freak stuff left over from the first moment of creation, thinner than an atom but even an inch of it weighing millions of tons) sliced through a star? If you were to count the number of degrees in a circle around a piece of cosmic string, it would not be 360, it might be only 90. So suddenly you'd have the sphere of a star which was only 90 degrees and the extra mass would have to go somewhere. "It is unlikely," says Palmer "to be very calm about it."

fields.headline: A lesson in incompetence
fields.standfirst: Guardian foreign editor Edward Pilkington examines the revelation that a Nato spy leaked Kosovo bombing plans to the Serbs
fields.trailText: So now it is falling into place. Almost a year after the start of the Kosovo war we are starting to be able to answer a question that has baffled commentators and military analysts since the war began: why, despite the displays of overwhelming force and aviatic wizardry that nightly filled our television screens, was the world's most sophisticated fighting force so peculiarly ineffective?
fields.body:
So now it is falling into place. Almost a year after the start of the Kosovo war we are starting to be able to answer a question that has baffled commentators and military analysts since the war began: why, despite the displays of overwhelming force and aviatic wizardry that nightly filled our television screens, was the world's most sophisticated fighting force so peculiarly ineffective?

Throughout the war were we told by Nato's chirpy press spokesman Jamie Shea that the air bombardment was working, that it was systematically taking apart the Yugoslav army. And yet at the end, after 79 days and more than 3,000 bombing missions, thousands of Serb soldiers, with tanks and heavy guns still intact, emerged from their hideouts punching the air and smiling at the television cameras.

A squirming Nato has already provided some clues to this riddle. Much of the US air force that made up the bulk of the Nato assault was debilitated by the inability of its radar system to penetrate cloud cover - though how a state-of-the-art war effort could be foiled by something as primordial as water vapour is another puzzle.

And now we know that in the early weeks of the campaign a spy was operating at the heart of Nato and divulging its lists of bombing targets to the Serbs. No wonder the bombers failed to hit their targets - the targets had been moved in full knowledge that the raids were coming.

The disclosure of the leaking of Nato's bombing list exposes a mind-boggling incompetence on the part of those entrusted with prosecuting Europe's first war since 1945. No amount of cheerful chat from Jamie Shea will legitimise the fact that for the first few weeks of the war top secret lists were circulated to no fewer than 600 people.

This in itself was a product of Nato's loose construction. The alliance that embarked on the Kosovo war was composed of 19 member states - several of whom, notably France, Italy, Greece and latterly Germany, were ambivalent about the value of military action.

But there is a danger of confusion here. It was not Nato's constitution that was at fault, but the bungling of its high command.

The Pentagon will no doubt jump on the spy revelations to press its objections to Nato's structure. What America would like is an "alliance" run from Washington with a little marginal help from London. Paris, Rome, Athens and Berlin should stop acting like spoiled children and do what they are told.

If that line were allowed to take hold it would be unfortunate. The lesson of the new disclosure is not that we need less democracy within Nato. The lesson is that we need people at the top of its military pyramid who know what they are doing.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Wild Rover

Lynn Walker of Bournemouth bought a new Rover 800 at the beginning of last year. She discovered the central locking and rear window heating weren't working and that the driver's window opened and closed by itself. The dealer, Sewards, repaired the car, but returned it with the window still stubbornly hyperactive. Again, it was taken in and tinkered with to no avail. The key fob stopped unlocking the door, the ashtray jammed and two more windows went haywire. The car was taken in three more times for a total of 20 days and finally, on Christmas Eve, it began leaking, soaking the back seat and boot. Walker returned it to the dealer, where it has remained ever since. Sewards has offered to refund her £10,000 but that leaves Walker £4,000 out of pocket.

"We are pleased to say we are working with the dealer to resolve the situation," says Rover, which has now given Walker an extra £1,000 on condition she buys another Rover. "Some of these problems were not typical of the range," says a spokesman. Given that Walker's courtesy Rover had a jammed door, as did an alternative purchase she inspected, she needs all the reassurance she can get.

Teed off with VW

Lynn Hankins of London has been engaged in a similar battle but with Volkswagen. She returned her new Golf the day after buying it because the steering pulled strongly to the left. She was told the problem would correct itself and to return if it still pulled after 1,500 miles. It did, but when Hankins went back she was told this was characteristic of the model. Eventually she commissioned an AA inspection. The mechanic agreed that the car pulled and found it had up to three times more paint on the bodywork than it should have. This time Volkswagen agreed to refund the cost of the car bar the £1,500 Hankins had already made on finance. "They claimed the refund was due to the paintwork and that as we had only discovered this recently we had enjoyed six months ownership," says Hankins. "I pointed out that I complained the day after purchase, but they still won't budge."

"We had hardly any complaints about steering pulling, until BBC Watchdog did a feature on it," says a Volkswagen spokesman, plaintively. "We are sure there's no inherent design fault, but it's obviously affected by the camber of the road." Hankins, though, insists the pulling was so severe she had to turn the wheel to the right to achieve a straight line. Volkswagen says it has now authorised a full refund.

Meter eater

Most motorists have at some point fallen victim to an over keen traffic warden. Spencer Barnshaw, for one, feels mercilessly victimised. He fed in a 20p coin into a Greenwich meter which failed to register, ditto a second, so he left an explanatory note on the windscreen. He returned 10 minutes later to find a traffic warden writing a ticket. Greenwich council checked the meter and declared it in perfect working order. It won a subsequent appeal, insisting that Barnshaw should have moved to another meter, reported the fault and reclaimed his 40p. Not long afterwards, Barnshaw's partner did just that when a £1 inserted into a neighbouring meter failed to register, but this pulled no weight with Greenwich and she, too, was fined. "I know someone who used to work for Westminster council's parking department," says Barnshaw. "He told me meters often malfunction, especially when it's cold or damp which it often is early in the morning."

Greenwich council is having none of it. It points out that Barnshaw's appeal was rejected and denies meters are affected by the weather. "Years ago they did suffer occasional faults in the early mornings, but not now. In this case, no faults were found."

Cellnet extra

Mobile phone companies are now up there with double-glazing salesmen and second-hand car dealers in terms of irate customers and D Greggs, a pre-pay phone owner, is among many who have spent too long on BT Cellnet's helpline. But at least the pleasure has always been free. Now he has been informed he will be charged 20p a minute to report any problems. "Cellnet boasts that it has opened this new customer care centre in Bury to improve its service to pre-pay customers," he says. "Now we know who's been lined up to pay for it."

BT Cellnet protests that the charges are to help fund a £60m investment in its helplines and that it was either that or a blanket service charge. So people have to pay for redress if there is a fault on their line. "We will continue to award goodwill gestures on an individual basis to those who deserve it," says Cellnet.

Bronze turkey

Dominic Bartley of St Albans has meanwhile been spending enraged hours on the phone to One 2 One. Last June he bought two mobiles for use in emergencies under the Bronze-All-In-One deal. He paid £199.98 for the line rental on both phones, but a couple of weeks later was billed again for the same sum while, at the same time, being thanked for his payment. A 45-minute wait on the helpline brought a promise of redress, but the August bill repeated demand for the payment. An emergency subsequently arose but his wife found that her line had been disconnected. When Bartley called a third time to complain he discovered the company had the wrong address on its computer. He says: "When I chose the bronze deal I assumed I was purchasing the third best service, not a third-rate one."

One 2 One is coy about the cause of Bartley's woe but says the problem has been resolved, two months free line rental as compensation.

No One 2 One contact

Louisa Spivack of London has been with One 2 One for three years but recently decided to switch to a better deal with Orange. However, she was told she had signed a contract with One 2 One in February last year and therefore was still in her initial agreement period and unable to break free. "A lot of my personal details are wrong on this contract which makes me suspect that they've mixed me up with someone else."

A One 2 One spokesman assures Consumer that Spivack's case has been investigated and the dispute resolved. "He was having technical problems with his divert," he says, before discovering that he has confused Louisa Spivack with someone else. He promises to call back with the proper details but, although we have left three messages over as many weeks, he is still waiting to get round to it.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

webTitle: Return of Sierra Leone's lost generation

fields.headline: Return of Sierra Leone's lost generation
fields.trailText: Three hundred children spill out across the dusty courtyard, wrestling, running, exuberant. A month ago they were child soldiers deep in the bush of Sierra Leone, often wreaking havoc in their home villages.
fields.body:
Three hundred children spill out across the dusty courtyard, wrestling, running, exuberant. A month ago they were child soldiers deep in the bush of Sierra Leone, often wreaking havoc in their home villages.

"There are five-year-olds here who can fire a gun . . . seven-year-olds who have been longer with the rebels than they were with their own families," says one of the aid workers trying to reclaim this lost generation.

Only a handful of these children can be sent home after six weeks of intensive debriefing at this centre for ex-combatants. They come from the northern and eastern diamond areas still under rebel control, and no one can be confident that they will not suffer the same fate as other youngsters and be re-enlisted.

Instead, they are sent to local foster families who - encouraged by the local mosque and Christian churches - take them in, despite their own difficult circumstances in an economy destroyed by the war. "The communities have to accept them; they're not from the moon, they're from Sierra Leone, no matter what they've done," says one social worker.

A fragile peace ending the seven-year civil war has been in place since last July. A United Nations peacekeeping force, Unamsil, is in place and will see its numbers increase to 11,000 in the coming weeks.

But in recent days armed rebels of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) have blocked Indian and Ghanaian UN troops from deploying in the diamond areas, and guerrillas have seized military equipment from Kenyan and Guinean peacekeepers.

On the route north out of the capital, Freetown, there are roadblocks every couple of kilometres. Most are erected by government soldiers; some are set up by the RUF. Looting and rape by rebels and their bands of abducted children still occur.

One boy in the centre pulls up his T-shirt to show the letters RUF cut into his chest. Many girls who have made it back after being abducted show similar scars, which their school uniforms do not cover.

"We tell them they have to learn to live with it; they can't cover their arms for the rest of their lives," says one teacher. But it is the unseen marks inflicted during their years as combatants that cause the greatest concern for the future of their society.

One seven-year-old in the centre is nicknamed Mike Tyson. He is a stocky child who has no memory of family life. He can only remember life with his RUF commander. The boy has a wound on his head where he was hit with a rifle butt, but like every child you talk to, he will still tell you how much he loved his commander.

Commanders bring their children into this interim centre, run by the Caritas aid agency, to be demobilised.

"These kids have been through outrageous, phenomenal brainwashing . . . but with a very strong team you can turn them around," says Leonard, the team leader.

Many of the children suffer drug withdrawal symptoms. Some have used marijuana, others have been on "blue book", a kind of cocaine.

One 12-year-old boy arrived, claiming to be a lieutenant colonel. He was accompanied by a 40-year-old man carrying his luggage, saluting him, and calling him sir. "It took him quite a few days of long sessions talking to us to see that things were going to be different here," says Leonard. Another boy came in as a supremely self-assured "major". Two weeks later he apologised for his behaviour.

One child, abducted when she was eight months, was held until she was 18 months old by a commander and his girlfriend, who posed as the child's mother. Caritas staff suspected that the girl was not the mother, and in a tough confrontation the commander not only admitted that he had stolen the child, but he also identified her home village.

"That was a really emotional day when we took that baby for a reunion with her mother and grandmother," says Leonard. "The old lady fainted with shock. The commander had used the baby as bait, hoping the mother would follow it into the bush."

The children have fought with the RUF and the Sierra Leonean army's various splinter groups. In many cases all of their relationships with adults have been based on violence.

Most of these boys come from families of peasants or diamond diggers. None can predict how they may fit back into their former lives, nor whether the men who manipulated them so ruthlessly are themselves ready for a future without war.

The stakes are high. Peacekeeping disasters in Angola and Rwanda are recent memories in Africa. The peace agreement that brought the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, into government in Sierra Leone was bitterly contested by human rights groups because it contradicted the principle of no impunity for war crimes. Many people also believed the new set-up could not work.

But the UN secretary-general's special representative, Oluyemi Adenji, shows every sign of taking a far tougher line with the rebels than was the case in Angola or Rwanda.

Moreover the UN is committed to spending $30m this year on a disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration programme. The programme is aimed at helping 45,000 former fighters, hundreds of thousands of refugees in camps in Guinea, and 1m displaced people.

Most Sierra Leoneans believe the peace has to work, whatever its price. No one can travel along the road from Freetown airport without seeing the camp for the 400 amputees whose stumps are the rebels' signature of horror. Children, including a baby too young to walk, have been mutilated for life. But the chairman of the camp, Moktar Jallah, who has lost an arm and an ear, says: "We have accepted the amnesty in the name of peace. I know the men who did this to me, I've seen them, and I've told them I want no revenge."

webTitle: Harland and Wolff: staring into the abyss

fields.headline: Harland and Wolff: staring into the abyss
fields.trailText: Thursday, 4pm: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown on the yard which dominates Belfast
fields.body:
Belfast is the last British city with a skyline dominated by a shipyard. The giant cranes of Harland and Wolff - Goliath and Samson - loom over Queen's Island, near the mouth of the River Lagan. They symbolise the city itself, as much as the 150-year-old company which has launched 1700 ships into Belfast Lough.

But now Harland and Wolff is staring glumly into a future dark with uncertainty. Its order book is ominously slender, and its finances are in turmoil following a series of hugely expensive disputes with customers.

The glittering prize which could haul the company back from the brink - a contract to build Cunard's giant new liner the Queen Mary II - is cruelly receding from its grasp. Cunard president Larry Pimentel has clearly indicated that the Belfast firm's rival bidder, Chantier de l'Atlantique of France, is the frontrunner. "Frankly, I think the French are far ahead," he said.

The Belfast yard is hoping against hope that the final decision will be swayed by Cunard's long - and marketable - tradition of British-built liners. The problem is that Harland and Wolff has not built a passenger vessel since the launch of the supremely beautiful P & O liner Canberra in 1961.

Since then, it has specialised first in super-carriers, and latterly in high-tech oil rigs and support vessels. Neither its expertise nor its capacity are in doubt. The company has built carriers of up to 330,000 tons capacity - three times the size of the QM2 specification - and claims that if anyone ever wants a million-ton ship, it could build one.

The problem is that the particular skills needed to assemble and fit out a luxury liner faded out of the shrinking British shipbuilding industry more than a generation ago. The John Brown yard on the Clyde, which launched the original Queen Mary in 1936, is no more than a memory. The yards of the Tyne, the Wear and the Mersey have gone the same way, as have most of the great Royal Naval dockyards.

Even in its high-tech glory, Harland and Wolff seems an anachronism in British industry, which has long since lost the taste for heavy engineering projects which cannot hope to turn a fast buck.

And yet the company, now part of the Norwegian based Fred Olsen conglomerate, remains part of Belfast's culture, as much as its skyline. In its glory days it employed 15,000 men, turning out warships, cargo vessels and passenger liners for the world. Now the workforce is less than 2,000.

The decline has been long and cruel. In the 1970s, when the yard was struggling to compete for oil-tanker orders against the Japanese and Koreans, the sardonic joke was that the last ship Harland and Wolff delivered on time was the Titanic.

But at least the company has also sloughed off its unenviable reputation as a hotbed of sectarianism. Well within living memory it was unthinkable that Roman Catholics could get a decent job with Harland and Wolff. Even if the management was willing to take them on, they would have to pass through fiercely Protestant East Belfast to get to work.

Equal opportunity legislation has put an end to the discrimination and bigotry which once marred the shipyard's name. And though it has shrunk, it remains a key employer of skilled labour and a major contributor to the Northern Ireland economy. Last autumn, as it faced a potentially crippling financial crisis, peace mediator George Mitchell stepped in to patch up another agreement, between Harland and Wolff and one of its American customers, Global Marine.

That intervention recognised the central importance of the yard to Belfast's economic well-being. But unless Cunard can be persuaded to revert to its buy-British policy, the future looks bleak indeed.

fields.headline: A great result for cricket
fields.standfirst: Tim de Lisle applauds the decision by the ECB to award BBC radio a new, five-year contract to cover England's home series
fields.trailText: Sometimes, whole years pass without anything very encouraging taking place at the offices of the England and Wales Cricket Board at Lord's. But in the space of three days this week, there have been two excellent developments.
fields.body:
Sometimes, whole years pass without anything very encouraging taking place at the offices of the England and Wales Cricket Board at Lord's. But in the space of three days this week, there have been two excellent developments.

First the 18 counties agreed to hand a chunk of their huge powers to an executive Management Board, which just might take the tough decisions needed to save the English game - halving the county programme, extinguishing at least one one-day competition, doing away with benefits, and insisting on good pitches and practice facilities. The turkeys are at last beginning to understand that no-one is asking them to vote for Christmas, merely for the survival of their species.

No sooner had that happened, than the ECB was faced with a dilemma so neat that it could have come straight from a play by Michael Frayn. It concerned the rights for ball-by-ball radio commentary on home Tests, held by the BBC since the days when EW Swanton was no more than a grand young man.

Kelvin Mackenzie of TalkSport said he would beat any amount offered by the BBC by 50 per cent. Greg Dyke, probably the first BBC Director-General ever to have a little bit of Kelvin in him, came up with a cunning counter-offer: not just ball-by-ball on Radio 4, as usual, but a highlights show on 5 Live, and two updates a day on Radio 1. ("That's the new one from Marilyn Manson. And now over to Headingley, where we join Christopher Martin-Jenkins.")

So the choice was a stark one: more money but fewer listeners, or less money but more listeners, plus, for a few surreal minutes, the ear of the nation's youth. The ECB had to "think long and hard" about it, according to their chairman Lord MacLaurin, which is a bit alarming. But this is not the time to carp. The main thing is, they made the right choice. TalkSport talked money, and money talked - but reach talked louder.

This is a great result for cricket, which is now guaranteed five years' exposure on three radio stations instead of one, all of them bigger than TalkSport, and all of them better. Test Match Special has its faults (too cosy, too public-school, too set in its ways, too accommodating to old farts), and Talk's winter coverage had its strengths (Bob Woolmer's views, Chris Cowdrey's voice), but there is still a wide gulf between the two. TMS is more than just a sports programme: it's an institution, and a largely positive one. Distinctive, lyrical, and able to reach out to people who are barely cricket fans at all, it is greater than the sum of its farts.

It also slots naturally into a greater whole - Radio 4, the most intelligent radio station in the country. TalkSport, when it's not At The Test, is shaping up like 5 Live at its Saturday-evening worst: all fatuous football phone-ins. And if you can't blame them for having ads, you can hold your head in despair at their willingness to allow advertorial. Talk's most vital task last winter was to establish their commentary team, to build an authority to rival TMS. By forcing them to say "Regus.com, instant offices worldwide!" every two minutes, Kelvin Mackenzie ensured that that goal would remain out of reach. Rumour has it that the fee Regus paid was around £150,000, the same amount that Mackenzie had paid the South Africans for the rights. However much it was, it wasn't enough. An undoubted star at The Sun, Mackenzie is still at sea when it comes to the air.

TMS needs to learn from this brush with death. It must take some risks, vary the pace, and discover some talent: in the last 25 years, it has unearthed only one regular run-of-play commentator, Jonathan Agnew. If John Arlott or Brian Johnston came along now, they would probably be turned away on the grounds that they never played Test cricket. Ex-players have their place, but unless they have spent their winters learning the ropes of journalism like Aggers, that place is the summariser's chair.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Youngest and oldest Test-century makers
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who is the youngest and who is the oldest to score a Test century? asks Kannan Tirupachanur
fields.body:
Who is the youngest and who is the oldest to score a Test century? asks Kannan Tirupachanur

The youngest is Mushtaq Mohammad, who was only 17 years and 82 days old when he made 101 for Pakistan v India at Delhi in 1960-61. Sachin Tendulkar was 30 days older when he made his first one, for India v England at Old Trafford in 1990. The oldest is Jack Hobbs - 46 years 82 days old when he made 142 for England v Australia at Melbourne in 1928-29. The oldest in the last ten years was Graham Gooch - 40 years 315 days old when he made his last Test ton, 210 for England v New Zealand at Trent Bridge in 1994.

I am doing a family history and would like to know more about Tom Richardson, who played for Surrey and England around the turn of the last century? asks Ron C

Tom Richardson was an immensely strong fast bowler who took 2104 wickets in a career which lasted only 13 seasons. He passed 100 wickets in ten of those seasons, and actually took 290 wickets in 1895. The previous year, for Surrey v Essex at The Oval in 1894 he took all ten wickets in an innings. He also took 88 wickets in his 14 Tests for England. He was born in Byfleet, Surrey, on August 11, 1870, and died of "congestion of the brain" in France on July 2, 1912, when he was only 41.

Which family event made Test history during the third match of the 1997 Ashes series? asks Colleen

Doing a quiz, by any chance? That match was Dean Headley's debut, which meant that his family became the first to provide three generations of Test cricketers. Dean's grandfather George, the first great West Indian batsman, played 23 Tests and averaged a magnificent 60.83. His father Ron was a stylish left-hand opener who played for Worcestershire and Jamaica, and was called up to play two Tests for West Indies in England in 1973. Dean is the first of the three to bowl for a living, and the first to play for England (he was born in Stourbridge, in the West Midlands, while his father was playing here).

Given that a bowler is no-balled when any part of his foot is not on the line, is the batsman required to be across the line or merely on it to be safe from a run-out or stumping? asks Jamie Wilson

The no-ball law says that a delivery is fair as long as "Some part of the front foot whether grounded or raised was behind the popping crease". And Law 29 says that "A batsman shall be considered to be out of his ground unless some part of his bat in his hand or his person is grounded behind the line of the popping crease". So both batsman and bowler have to be behind the line rather than on it.

I am trying to trace whether someone called Edward Cook played any first-class cricket for Middlesex, probably in the 1960s? asks Allan Jamieson

The only Cooks (or Cookes) who have played for Middlesex are Colin, who played a few matches as a batsman between 1981 and 1984, and Simon, the medium-pacer who is on their staff now. You might mean Edward "Ted" Clark, who played 196 matches for Middlesex between 1959 and 1976. He scored a century on his first-class debut, against Cambridge University at Fenner's in 1959.

Can you tell me the name of the trophy given to the county cricketer who scores the fastest century of the English season? asks Sal

It is called the Lawrence Trophy, and is named after Sir Walter Lawrence, the industrialist who first presented it in 1934. Initially it was given for the fastest century in minutes, but is now given to the quickest one in terms of balls received. The winner in 1999 was England's Andrew Flintoff, who reached three figures in only 61 balls for Lancashire against Gloucestershire at Bristol. The first winner, in 1934, was Frank Woolley of Kent. There was no award between 1939 and 1965, but it was revived in 1966, when Ken Barrington won it, and it's been awarded annually since.

I was wondering if you had heard of a Sri Lankan player called Aruna Seneviratne, whose son Martin is in my cricket team (Lane Cove Under-12s)? asks Rob Loosli from Sydney, Australia

No-one of that name has played an official Test or one-day international for Sri Lanka. And he also doesn't seem to be mentioned in a huge history of Sri Lankan cricket that recently landed in the Wisden office. That book does mention quite a few Seneviratnes, so possibly he is in there under his full name.

A friend of mine has been talking knowledgably of a player called Solkar, who he says was a specialist batsman who was only called into action as a bowler in times of dire need but had a good record against Geoff Boycott. Ring any bells? asks Morgan Kavanagh

It's Eknath Solkar, the left-handed Bombay batsman who played 27 Tests for India between 1969-70 and 1976-77. He scored 1068 runs in Tests, at an average of 25.42, and also took 18 wickets (59.44) with his gentle, club-standard bowling. He did get Boycott out (for 6) in the first Test of 1974, at Old Trafford, whereupon Boycott made himself unavailable for Test cricket (he didn't re-appear until 1977). Solkar was also a magnificent close fielder, adding to the menace of India's great spinners of that time - Bedi, Chandrasekhar, Prasanna and Venkataraghavan, the current Test umpire.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

I am doing a family history and would like to know more about Tom Richardson, who played for Surrey and England around the turn of the last century? asks Ron C Tom Richardson was an immensely strong fast bowler who took 2104 wickets in a career which lasted only 13 seasons. He passed 100 wickets in ten of those seasons, and actually took 290 wickets in 1895. The previous year, for Surrey v Essex at The Oval in 1894 he took all ten wickets in an innings. He also took 88 wickets in his 14 Tests for England. He was born in Byfleet, Surrey, on August 11, 1870, and died of "congestion of the brain" in France on July 2, 1912, when he was only 41. Which family event made Test history during the third match of the 1997 Ashes series? asks Colleen Doing a quiz, by any chance? That match was Dean Headley's debut, which meant that his family became the first to provide three generations of Test cricketers. Dean's grandfather George, the first great West Indian batsman, played 23 Tests and averaged a magnificent 60.83. His father Ron was a stylish left-hand opener who played for Worcestershire and Jamaica, and was called up to play two Tests for West Indies in England in 1973. Dean is the first of the three to bowl for a living, and the first to play for England (he was born in Stourbridge, in the West Midlands, while his father was playing here). Given that a bowler is no-balled when any part of his foot is not on the line, is the batsman required to be across the line or merely on it to be safe from a run-out or stumping? asks Jamie Wilson The no-ball law says that a delivery is fair as long as "Some part of the front foot whether grounded or raised was behind the popping crease". And Law 29 says that "A batsman shall be considered to be out of his ground unless some part of his bat in his hand or his person is grounded behind the line of the popping crease". So both batsman and bowler have to be behind the line rather than on it. I am trying to trace whether someone called Edward Cook played any first-class cricket for Middlesex, probably in the 1960s? asks Allan Jamieson The only Cooks (or Cookes) who have played for Middlesex are Colin, who played a few matches as a batsman between 1981 and 1984, and Simon, the medium-pacer who is on their staff now. You might mean Edward "Ted" Clark, who played 196 matches for Middlesex between 1959 and 1976. He scored a century on his first-class debut, against Cambridge University at Fenner's in 1959. Can you tell me the name of the trophy given to the county cricketer who scores the fastest century of the English season? asks Sal It is called the Lawrence Trophy, and is named after Sir Walter Lawrence, the industrialist who first presented it in 1934. Initially it was given for the fastest century in minutes, but is now given to the quickest one in terms of balls received. The winner in 1999 was England's Andrew Flintoff, who reached three figures in only 61 balls for Lancashire against Gloucestershire at Bristol. The first winner, in 1934, was Frank Woolley of Kent. There was no award between 1939 and 1965, but it was revived in 1966, when Ken Barrington won it, and it's been awarded annually since. I was wondering if you had heard of a Sri Lankan player called Aruna Seneviratne, whose son Martin is in my cricket team (Lane Cove Under-12s)? asks Rob Loosli from Sydney, Australia No-one of that name has played an official Test or one-day international for Sri Lanka. And he also doesn't seem to be mentioned in a huge history of Sri Lankan cricket that recently landed in the Wisden office. That book does mention quite a few Seneviratnes, so possibly he is in there under his full name. A friend of mine has been talking knowledgably of a player called Solkar, who he says was a specialist batsman who was only called into action as a bowler in times of dire need but had a good record against Geoff Boycott. Ring any bells? asks Morgan Kavanagh It's Eknath Solkar, the left-handed Bombay batsman who played 27 Tests for India between 1969-70 and 1976-77. He scored 1068 runs in Tests, at an average of 25.42, and also took 18 wickets (59.44) with his gentle, club-standard bowling. He did get Boycott out (for 6) in the first Test of 1974, at Old Trafford, whereupon Boycott made himself unavailable for Test cricket (he didn't re-appear until 1977). Solkar was also a magnificent close fielder, adding to the menace of India's great spinners of that time - Bedi, Chandrasekhar, Prasanna and Venkataraghavan, the current Test umpire. Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: Andrei Tarkovsky: Andrei Rublev
fields.trailText: Tarkovsky was a damned good director - a metaphorical looking glass, as one critic has said, providing man with a reflection of himself... Andrei Rublevis epic in scale and scope - a commentary on the physical and spiritual foundations of Russia itself
fields.body:
'Making two a year from 1960 onwards, I could have made 20 films. Fat chance with our idiots", wrote Andrei Tarkovsky in his diaries in 1970. In fact, Tarkovsky, the greatest and most imitated director Russia has produced in the last 50 years, made seven full-length films between 1962 - when Ivan's Childhood burst upon the world - and 1986, when The Sacrifice was completed. Two of these films were made outside Russia where the authorities deeply suspected his motives and were unwilling to accord him state funds.

In defence of the authorities (who often were indeed idiots), Tarkovsky was difficult to please. As an artist he felt entitled to be. I remember visiting the location set of The Sacrifice on the Swedish island of Faroe. It was bitterly cold, and since a night scene was called for, the cast, including the British actress Susan Fleetwood, waited for Tarkovsky, shivering in night attire. He was half an hour late and, according to a production assistant, had spent much of that time staring at himself in the mirror, readjusting his scarf and hat. "If he wasn't such a damned good director," Fleetwood said, "I'd have left long ago."

But, of course, he was a damned good director - a metaphorical looking glass, as one critic has said, providing man with a reflection of himself. Perhaps his most Russian film and, oddly enough, the film that has been most appreciated in the west, is Andrei Rublev, Tarkovsky's second. It is epic in scale and scope - a commentary on the physical and spiritual foundations of Russia itself.

Rublev was not a fictional character but an icon painter and monk who lived and worked on the cusp of the 13th and 14th centuries, trained by the even more celebrated Theophanes the Greek. Tarkovsky attempted to paint a portrait of the time, as much through psychological truth as ethnographic accuracy. The landscape of Russia did the rest. "Our Russia - it has to endure everything," says Rublev at one point to the spectre of Theophanes, who replies that it probably always will.

The film begins with a peasant launching himself in a balloon from a cathedral across the landscape of medieval Russia and ends with a superb montage of Rublev's surviving icons. In between, Rublev witnesses the often horrific sufferings of a divided Russia, split between feuding princelings and Tartar invaders.

There are eight episodes in all, the most notable being the story of a boy who, to save his life, pretends he can cast a giant bell and succeeds through blind faith - a feat that inspires Rublev to paint again.

The film is as much about the role of the artist in society as it is about the emergence of the Russian nation. Rublev can only create art by sharing the sufferings of the age in which he lives. All Tarkovsky's films say this, and their spiritual preoccupations and the poetic formulation of these that sets them apart. You can object to his vision as messianic and sometimes fundamentalist. It is hard, however, to mock the impact of his films.

fields.headline: Stone's star keeps rising
fields.trailText: Oliver Stone is reported to be in final negotiations to direct a remake of A Star is Born. The Warner Bros production would re-team the loose-cannon director with actor Jamie Foxx, who is currently starring as a hotshot quarterback in Stone's sporting saga Any Given Sunday.
fields.body:
Oliver Stone is reported to be in final negotiations to direct a remake of A Star is Born. The Warner Bros production would re-team the loose-cannon director with actor Jamie Foxx, who is currently starring as a hotshot quarterback in Stone's sporting saga Any Given Sunday.

Previously filmed in 1937, 1954 and 1976, A Star is Born has become something of a Hollywood perennial, with its romantic tale about the see-sawing fortunes of a rising young actress and an established movie star on the wane.

Its most notable interpretation is George Cukor's glitzy 50s treatment, starring James Mason and Judy Garland, while the reviled 70s version starred Barbra Streisand and Kris Kristofferson and changed the tale's backdrop from the movies to MOR rock.

Stone's version is said to be an update on the original tale, and the involvement of Afro-American actor Foxx looks set to put a new racial spin on the tale. The script has been written by Stephen Rivele and Christoper Wilkinson, who worked on Stone's 1995 film Nixon.

For Stone, the project looks like another step on his route back into the movie mainstream. Having established himself as one of Hollywood's more respected film-makers with pictures like Platoon and Born on the Fourth of July, Stone veered increasingly into bombastic left field with Natural Born Killers, Nixon and U-turn, all of which brought progressively diminishing returns at the box office.

The vigorous but conventional Any Given Sunday has shown Hollywood's money men that he can still be trusted to direct a star-driven, big-budget production that appeals to as broad audience as possible. Assuming he keeps a cool head on his shoulders, A Star is Born should merely underline the fact.

fields.headline: Obituary: Zuzanna Shonfield
fields.standfirst: Writer who also contributed to her husband's books
fields.trailText: Zuzanna Shonfield, who has died aged 81, had a zest for life and a great capacity for friendship. Only she could have brought together - at her Italian villa - the children of a 1980s Conservative cabinet minister and those of a leading British Trotskyist. Or, as a 1930s student and Communist, arrive at a Oxford university Labour club hop in a Schiaparelli ball gown.
fields.body:
Zuzanna Shonfield, who has died aged 81, had a zest for life and a great capacity for friendship. Only she could have brought together - at her Italian villa - the children of a 1980s Conservative cabinet minister and those of a leading British Trotskyist. Or, as a 1930s student and Communist, arrive at a Oxford university Labour club hop in a Schiaparelli ball gown.

The author of The Precariously Privileged (1987) a fine, scholarly history of a Victorian family's trials and triumphs, she was, until recently, working on a book about London's East End in 1911. Married to the economist Sir Andrew Shonfield, she worked as his willing, and unpaid assistant for much of their marriage and, after his 1981 death, edited his uncompleted books, The Use Of Public Power (1982) and In Defence Of The Mixed Economy (1984). Indeed her family believe she wrote a substantial part of the latter work. She was also involved with the Andrew Shonfield Association, founded to develop the seminal ideas of Shonfield's book Modern Capitalism.

Zuzanna was born in Warsaw, into a wealthy, cultured Jewish-cum-Roman Catholic family. Her father was a dilettante scholar, with a fortune from sugar manufacture, her mother later became curator of the Los Angeles county museum's textiles collection. Their fashionable home was in a building designed by her grandfather.

Educated by governesses until she was 12, she moved on to a progressive school and then, aged 16, to Roedean girls' public school in Sussex. In 1938 she went to Somerville college, Oxford to read French and German.

She soon switched to politics, philosophy and economics and joined the Communist party. In 1942 she married Andrew Shonfield, and now out of the Communist party, went to work in a factory. From 1943 until the birth of her son in 1950, she was a market researcher.

Zuzanna, a British citizen who also managed to be Polish, Jewish, Catholic, English - and even a little Italian - was not a woman deterred by conflicting viewpoints. Many of her immense and variegated company of friends she had shared with Andrew; he too was a cosmopolitan polymath whose career took him from Oxford and the Financial Times to a chair at the University of Europe in Florence.

She cultivated those friends assiduously into her buoyant old age, at home in Chelsea's Paulton Square or at her villa in Poggio al Sole, between Siena and Arezzo. She was eager to hear what others had to say, and always had perceptive comments, whether it be the latest novel, biography or film, English convulsions over the European Union or the quirky toughness of Indian democracy.

Her intelligence and generosity of spirit kept Zuzanna Shonfield as young in personality as the Somerville undergraduate of the 30s. She understood England better, through reading and observation, than many of the natives of this part of Europe.

Her son and daughter survive her.

 Zuzanna Shonfield, writer, born January 31 1919; died February 1 2000

webTitle: Stephen King tests the internet with his latest tale of horror

fields.headline: Stephen King tests the internet with his latest tale of horror
fields.trailText: There is always a twist in a Stephen King story, and his latest work is no different. Having just tipped his hat to publishing's past with a serialised novel, The Green Mile, the master of horror embraces the future by offering his latest story exclusively over the internet.
fields.body:
There is always a twist in a Stephen King story, and his latest work is no different. Having just tipped his hat to publishing's past with a serialised novel, The Green Mile, the master of horror embraces the future by offering his latest story exclusively over the internet.

King describes his latest story, Riding the Bullet as "a ghost story in the grand manner" and says he is keen to see what sort of response a book published in this manner will get.

The 66-page tale will be available from Tuesday and buyers can download it for $2.50 to read on a computer, personal organiser or electronic book.

The publishers Simon and Schuster Online will make it available through websites of e-book manufacturers and online booksellers.

In another twist, reminiscent of his own stories, King completed Riding the Bullet while recuperating from a near fatal accident in which he was hit by a van last June while out walking on a country road near his summer home in Lovell, Maine.

After the accident he said he found it extremely difficult to begin writing again, but Riding the Bullet was part of his recovery. He is now eagerly awaiting the reaction to this latest story.

"I'm curious to see what sort of response there is and whether or not this is the future," King said in a statement.

Other - mostly science fiction - writers have experimented with similar distribution of their work, but King is the first of the world's top selling authors to try it.

"This is really the first effective market test," said Keith Loris, president of SoftLock.com of Maynard, Massachusetts, which provided some of the technology. "Up to now, this has been technology in search of a market."

King recently signed a three-book deal rumoured to be worth £30m in what is said to be the most valuable literary contract in history. The sum shatters previous records and turns the author of more than 30 bestsellers, including Carrie, The Shining and Misery, into the colossus of commercial fiction.

webTitle: Potter mania grips New Labour MPs

fields.headline: Potter mania grips New Labour MPs
fields.trailText: Once Labour MPs could be relied up to recommend robust reading. Marx maybe, or something with a social conscience. Now they are falling over themselves to endorse a public schoolboy called Harry Potter.
fields.body:
Once Labour MPs could be relied up to recommend robust reading. Marx maybe, or something with a social conscience. Now they are falling over themselves to endorse a public schoolboy called Harry Potter.

The Ragged Trousered Philanthropist - which perennially topped the lists of Labour MPs' favourite novels before the 1997 election - has been overtaken by J.K.Rowling's classless Harry Potter. Only one of 100 MPs asked to donate a book to their local library chose Robert Tressell's distinctly Old Labour classic.

"That says it all really," said MP Austin Mitchell, who modestly bequeathed his own book, Westminster In Pictures to Grimsby library. "I'm only shocked they are not recommending management manuals and the latest public relations texts."

The rebel spirit is not entirely dead. Labour's Robert Marshall-Andrews recommended Francis Wheen's Karl Marx, while David Kidney, fresh from voting against the government on jury trials, gave his vote to George Orwell's Animal Farm, the political satire about reformers who become as bad as their old masters as soon as they take power. Kidney, however, insists he meant to draw no parallels with New Labour.

Labour's Barbara Follett spurned her husband, the airport novelist Ken Follett, for the self-improvement of Roget's Thesaurus. "Every time I open it I learn something new," she said.

But the most bizarre choice was the Eurosceptic Tory MP Sir Teddy Taylor's championing of the History Of Serbian Culture, edited by PavleIvic, a confidant of Slobodan Milosevic, who has confessed to a grudging admiration for the mass killer Arkan.

Sir Teddy described the book as "the best historical book I have ever read. I want to share my love of the treasures of Serbian culture with the people of Essex".

Labour's top titles

Karl Marx by Francis Wheen
Mention of the M-word is almost as anathema as the L-word in today's Labour party. But Robert Marshall-Andrews dares to recommend Francis Wheen's acclaimed biography which reveals the wild, brilliant and permanently broke man behind the beard.

The Harry Potter trilogy by JK Rowling
Lots of cross-party support for the apprentice wizard and "publishing phenomonen". But particularly strong among Blair babes, such as Caroline Flint. Could this be because its creator is from Edinburgh, like Tony, and that just like him, Harry went to private school too?

Animal Farm by George Orwell
The hated ancien regime is overthrown - but the new bosses adopt the ways of the old masters. Sound familiar? Labour's David Kidney said: "It's the book which most influenced my political development, but I don't think it has any particular lessons for the Labour party now."

webTitle: Laureate pleads for poetry in schools

fields.headline: Laureate pleads for poetry in schools
fields.trailText: The poet laureate Andrew Motion last night called for an overhaul of how poetry is taught in school to dispel once and for all the myth that it is "difficult and irrelevant".
fields.body:
The poet laureate Andrew Motion last night called for an overhaul of how poetry is taught in school to dispel once and for all the myth that it is "difficult and irrelevant".

Poetry was a "basic and visceral" force through which people felt impelled to express themselves in times of great joy or trouble. Giving the annual arts council lecture at the Royal Society of Arts in London, he said its natural "hotline to our hearts" was demonstrated by vast outpouring of verse by ordinary people after the death of Princess Diana, or after the Soho bombing.

"It's a high claim, but it's one that I have no hesitation in making. We forget this emotional power at our peril. Poetry is always a primitive and visceral thing, however it might be surrounded with various kinds of sophistication."

He said as well as bringing more poets into schools, there should be special weekend conferences for teachers so they could discuss how to get over the mental block that poetry was difficult to teach and somehow irrelevant.

Mr Motion said there needed to be greater efforts to demystify poetry, and said teachers were as important as poets in this drive. Although he welcomed the government's literary hour scheme, "literacy is the beginning of a process and beyond it lies the huge country of free and unhindered reading, and of culture in general".

After the death of Diana, he was "struck by how many thousands of the bouquets had little verses attached to them. The same thing happened some time later, when flowers given in memory of those killed in the Soho bomb were laid out in Soho Square. Almost all those flowers were also accompanied by a poem. Most, to be frank, were not really literature at all - but that isn't the point.

"The same thing happens at moments of intense pleasure and celebration as well, like when we fall in love."

Mr Motion also dealt with his own initially controversial appointment as laureate, and used the example of his hero Keats to allude to how a writer could be a public poet without either being on the barricades or a stooge of royalty or the government.

"I'm not trying to suggest that I want to shy away from the reality of these events," he said. "Rather that I want to engage with them while remaining alert to their symbolic values.

"The poem I wrote for the wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys Jones, for example, is one which wants to remind its readers of the questions which preoccupy all people in love and getting married: will the things we say today last into the future etc.

"If I had written any of these poems in another way, I'm certain that I would have been lured into writing to order.

"In every case I had a phrase from Keats's letters resonating in my head: 'We hate poetry that has a palpable design on us.'"
fields.bodyText: The poet laureate Andrew Motion last night called for an overhaul of how poetry is taught in school to dispel once and for all the myth that it is "difficult and irrelevant". Poetry was a "basic and visceral" force through which people felt impelled to express themselves in times of great joy or trouble. Giving the annual arts council lecture at the Royal Society of Arts in London, he said its natural "hotline to our hearts" was demonstrated by vast outpouring of verse by ordinary people after the death of Princess Diana, or after the Soho bombing. "It's a high claim, but it's one that I have no hesitation in making. We forget this emotional power at our peril. Poetry is always a primitive and visceral thing, however it might be surrounded with various kinds of sophistication." He said as well as bringing more poets into schools, there should be special weekend conferences for teachers so they could discuss how to get over the mental block that poetry was difficult to teach and somehow irrelevant. Mr Motion said there needed to be greater efforts to demystify poetry, and said teachers were as important as poets in this drive. Although he welcomed the government's literary hour scheme, "literacy is the beginning of a process and beyond it lies the huge country of free and unhindered reading, and of culture in general". After the death of Diana, he was "struck by how many thousands of the bouquets had little verses attached to them. The same thing happened some time later, when flowers given in memory of those killed in the Soho bomb were laid out in Soho Square. Almost all those flowers were also accompanied by a poem. Most, to be frank, were not really literature at all - but that isn't the point. "The same thing happens at moments of intense pleasure and celebration as well, like when we fall in love." Mr Motion also dealt with his own initially controversial appointment as laureate, and used the example of his hero Keats to allude to how a writer could be a public poet without either being on the barricades or a stooge of royalty or the government. "I'm not trying to suggest that I want to shy away from the reality of these events," he said. "Rather that I want to engage with them while remaining alert to their symbolic values. "The poem I wrote for the wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys Jones, for example, is one which wants to remind its readers of the questions which preoccupy all people in love and getting married: will the things we say today last into the future etc. "If I had written any of these poems in another way, I'm certain that I would have been lured into writing to order. "In every case I had a phrase from Keats's letters resonating in my head: 'We hate poetry that has a palpable design on us.'"

fields.headline: City limits
fields.trailText: Small town clubs have little or no chance to win the league nowadays. WSC bemoans the fact.
fields.body:
The death of Chris Balderstone last week provided another irresistible opportunity to mention the fact that Carlisle United were briefly top of the league in 1974. If there was one comfort to be taken from his premature passing it was that at least he did not die with his old club placed last in the Football League. Two days later Chester's point from a goalless draw at Plymouth pushed the Cumbrians into pole position to join the Conference next season.

Carlisle's season in the top flight was regarded as something of a freak even at the time, but their decline mirrors the long-term trend in English football towards not merely big-club, but also big-city domination. With the exception of Blackburn, who had an obvious advantage, the last provincial team to make a semi-serious stab at winning the league was Norwich, who finished third in the first season of the Premier League.

When Carlisle had their moment in the sun, the First Division was also home to single-team towns such as Stoke, Burnley, West Bromwich, Ipswich, Wolverhampton, Leicester and Luton, not to mention Derby, who won the title. Since then London, above all, has prospered, adding quantity if not quality to the top division. Every club in the capital except Fulham, Brentford and Leyton Orient visited during the 90s.

These days it is by no means impossible for a club from a relatively small town to "do a Carlisle", as Barnsley and Bradford have proved in recent seasons. What does seem unlikely is that any town with a population of less than, say, 300,000, will ever produce a team that is a realistic title contender again.

The biggest clubs tend to come from the biggest cities and, as we know, the biggest clubs are now in a far better position to consolidate their wealth and advantage than they ever have been before. The loss of provincial teams as a credible force at the top end of the league is just one more price to pay for that process set in train by satellite television and cemented by the Champions League.

Not that they all have to sink as far as Carlisle - that took the very special genius of Michael Knighton to achieve. Unfortunately we will never know how different the football world might look if he had succeeded in taking over Manchester United in the early 90s.
