webTitle: India shrugs off Clinton's visit to rival

fields.headline: India shrugs off Clinton's visit to rival
fields.standfirst: The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: India warned yesterday that President Clinton's decision to visit Pakistan this month would send a "signal of support" to the new military regime of General Pervez Musharraf, but insisted that a "warm welcome" still awaited the US leader in New Delhi.
fields.body:
India warned yesterday that President Clinton's decision to visit Pakistan this month would send a "signal of support" to the new military regime of General Pervez Musharraf, but insisted that a "warm welcome" still awaited the US leader in New Delhi.

Officials shrugged off the announcement by the White House that the US president would fly into Islamabad on March 25, at the end of a five-day tour of India and Bangladesh. "The visit is about the cooperative relationship between India and the US," an external affairs ministry spokesman said.

The president informed the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, of his intentions in a phone call on Tuesday night. He is expected to spend four hours with the general and his advisers at an airport near Islamabad, an encounter which falls short of an official visit.

The announcement, which follows weeks of dithering by the Clinton team over whether to tack Pakistan on to the end of the South Asian tour, was welcomed yesterday by General Musharraf. "It vindicates the legitimacy of my government's stance and gives credence to our aim to put things right in our country.

"It also shows Mr Clinton's desire to resolve the Kashmir problem and bring peace to the region," he said during a function for International Women's Day.

New Delhi did not ask Mr Clinton to avoid Pakistan, but did its its best to lobby against the visit. The government is now taking consolation from the fact that the US president will be in India for five days, during which he will visit the Taj Mahal, Hyderabad, Jaipur and Bombay, and in Pakistan for only four hours.

Although he arrives in India on March 19, he begins his tour with a visit to Bangladesh the following day, the first ever to the country by a US president.

Indian officials brushed aside Pakistani newspaper reports describing Mr Clinton's visit as a national "triumph", and renewed their claim that Pakistan was responsible for cross-border terrorism in Kashmir - a charge which Islamabad always denies.

"The US has already articulated more than once its concern over terrorism. There is a particular problem of terrorist groups which operate and base themselves in Pakistan," an external affairs ministry spokesman said.

The US president has been under pressure from lobbyists at home not to visit Pakistan though several other groups called for engagement with Gen Musharraf.

Mr Clinton's visit to India is the first since Jimmy Carter went there in 1978. He received a lukewarm reception after questioning the wisdom of his host's nuclear strategy.

webTitle: My lying, miserable, loathsome, honourable friend

fields.headline: My lying, miserable, loathsome, honourable friend
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: I do apologise for returning to the topic of the London mayor. It must seem frightfully dull for everyone who lives outside the Great Wen. The only excuse I can offer is that the mayoralty has become a symbol of Labour's travails. Ken Livingstone is their mid-term blues. We are between elections, people want to vote against the government, but no one in their right mind   could support the Tory party in its present state.
fields.body:
I do apologise for returning to the topic of the London mayor. It must seem frightfully dull for everyone who lives outside the Great Wen. The only excuse I can offer is that the mayoralty has become a symbol of Labour's travails. Ken Livingstone is their mid-term blues. We are between elections, people want to vote against the government, but no one in their right mind could support the Tory party in its present state.

So people in London have the chance to vote for Ken instead. It's a small consolation for the prices, the crime, the ghastly public transport, and the gangs of gloomy young men in plastic jackets who block most tube station entrances.

The allegory of Ken's stand against the party machine is now so powerful that it affects almost everything else in British politics. For instance, William Hague began prime minister's questions yesterday with another query about crime.

Street crime was up, he said, by 50%. "Ken Livingstone has said that the real deterrent is policemen on the streets, and he should know, because he has had something stolen from him."

Tony Blair's reply was inadequate, to say the least. He referred to Ken as "my honourable friend", when in fact he has been suspended from the party, and the correct parliamentary description would be "my lying, miserable, bastard, loathsome, God I wish he would crawl away and die, enemy". Though he can't say that.

"It's pretty obvious who the Conservative party is supporting, and it isn't their own candidate!" he went on. No, prime minister, quoting a candidate does not mean you're supporting him.

Mr Hague, having made his joke once, decided to make it again. "Burglary is up by 9%, car crime by 5%, muggings by 50%, and ballot rigging by 100%!"

Mr Blair returned with a fine example of logic chipping. (American gardeners use wood-chippers, which can turn a tree into kindling within seconds. Mr Blair has a logic-chipper in his brain, which he uses to handle difficult questions.)

He recalled the Tory vote on Tuesday night against the partial abolition of trial by jury. If they had supported the bill, "we would have had an extra £120m to fight crime he prefers instead to spend it on the lawyers."

That seemed just a little cheeky from a family that has grown fat on the law, and which as recently as last weekend was instructing lawyers against their own nanny. The Tories jeered.

Charles Kennedy said that the London mayor fiasco proved that the prime minister was not a control freak, but a control failure. And, he asked sweetly, to whom would Mr Blair give his second-choice vote? (We get to vote twice here, like in Mayor Daley's Chicago.)

"Since I am confident we will be winning this campaign, we don't have to offer a second preference," Mr Blair replied. No doubt in the same way Bill Bradley is still confident of becoming president of the United States.

Mr Hague pointed out that John Prescott had said this week that he was "not a fan" of directly elected mayors. Mr Blair said the deputy prime minister was "perfectly entitled to his view, unlike ordinary Labour party members, who aren't". (Sorry, forget the last seven words, they just popped out.)

He went on: "It is completely pathetic that you, as leader of the Conservative party, are driven first to support Lord Archer when you can't get him, Mr Norris, and now you can't get Mr Norris elected, Ken Livingstone. What a comment on your leadership of the Conservative party!"

"What a comment on your leadership," Mr Hague shot back. What a comment on them both.

fields.headline: Vote Ken, vote polenta
fields.standfirst: Livingstone - gourmand about town | The bishop's blunder | Fragrant Susan KramerThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Livingstone - gourmand about town | The bishop's blunder | Fragrant Susan Kramer
fields.body:
A bore? Nope. Beardy? Obviously not. A shagger? Who cares? The greatest challenge facing Ken Livingstone's opponents is finding an appropriate slur. Watching Frank Dobson trying to nail Ken is like watching Tom trying to squish Jerry: Livingstone just bounces back, grinning. The man is insult-proof. This week, as Dobbo and the rest did their worst, the barrage of abuse either pinged harmlessly off, or boomeranged straight back to its authors.

"Liar" left him intact, even though it was true. "A disaster" was just wishful thinking. The nastiest comment Dobbo could contrive, presumably after days of reflection, was to accuse Ken of self-interest - "the ego has landed" - which you can only really imagine being effective if it came from a person who had set their face against all forms of personal advancement - an unidentified anchoress, say, or a Tory backbencher. Even so, the charge has been echoed often enough by his supporters to suggest that there were hopes of making it stick: Don't Vote for Ken the Egoist! They should perhaps reflect that it didn't do too badly as an aftershave.

The latest accusation is Livingstone's unpopularity with the City: Don't Vote for Ken, the Man the Business Community Abominates! A party spokesman led the way with: "There is no doubt this man is bad for business" - a charge echoed, uncannily, by Trevor Kavanagh in the Sun. He reported that foreign investors are already shivering with fright: "Bharat Desai, head of information technology giant Syntel, described Mr Livingstone as 'dangerous for business'."

Over here, the chairman of the JD Wetherspoon pub chain said: "If Mr Livingstone became mayor I would strongly advise companies not to invest in London." Another businessman, quoted in the London Evening Standard, complained that Living stone is not the man to "enhance the image of the capital and create a bit of fun for the capital".

I'm afraid this is no more likely to stain Livingstone's reputation than the charge of egotism. For one thing, many people will find it hard to imagine a more magnetically attractive attribute than being despised by the chairman of the JD Wetherspoon pub chain; moreover, Ken's alleged antipathy to all things glossy, fun and capitalistic no longer bears examination. Quietly, almost stealthily, Livingstone has transformed himself from the frugal geek of City mythology into a knowing gourmand-about-town, whose commitment to lunch is only rivalled by that other fabulous trencherman, Fatty Soames. Back in 1981, the Evening Standard described Ken's impoverished diet: lunch in the GLC canteen followed, occasionally, by a bag of chips on the way home: "The asceticism seems real enough," marvelled Max Hastings. "He is simply a man consumingly dedicated to politics. And to power."

And now, as a regular restaurant reviewer for the Standard, he brings that same consuming dedication to lunch. And dinner. And wine. "Over the past year," Livingstone wrote recently, "I must have visited some of the newest, most talked-about restaurants that London has to offer." As he regularly, sorrowfully concedes, those restaurants are not cheap. "Daphne's is an expensive evening out," he observed after a meal in the notorious celebrity pit where the grilled Dover sole costs £25. "But who can knock it when they can bash out a side-order like zucchini fritti?" Quite.

Again, visiting Teca, which he describes as "a modern, elegant restaurant", he discovered that "cost is an issue here", though not an issue that seems to interest him very much. Inevitably, most diners in these places are on expenses. When he went to Teca, for instance, "almost everyone there was a business person". The very business persons who are meant to be paralysed with fear at the prospect of Livingstone are in fact his dining companions.

While some old-fashioned socialists might be unable, in such circumstances, to resist making disparaging comments along the traditional pig-and-trough sort of lines, Livingstone is all unabashed enthusiasm. Even in the restaurant in the old County Hall, which was "sold off cheaply to become a posh hotel", he refuses to bear a grudge: "To be fair, a great deal of effort has gone into preserving County Hall in all its glory . . . On my most recent visit, Geoff Hurst was at the next table." The Ivy he pronounces "gorgeous"; Orso is like "a secret gathering devoted to good food and wine"; the Blue Print Cafe will "keep the public coming back here year after year"; while Pied A Terre, the Michelin-starred restaurant ("very much a posh night out") has him in stammering ecstasies.

"What I think was a peppered snail was heavenly . . . I was on a different planet with the heavenly seared scallops . . . a friend's foie gras was described as the best they had ever tasted . . . It's difficult to see how you could go wrong with sole fillets poached in champagne velouté with asparagus, oysters and caviar . . ." Alas, the cost of this feast is £42.50 for two courses. But as Livingstone notes of the fixed price menu: "It's expensive, but has the advantage that you know in advance what you're going to spend." Who, reading this prudent tip, can doubt that London's economy will be safe in his hands?

Aside from his unfeigned delight in his good luck, and an obviously robust constitution, Livingstone's most distinctive characteristic as restaurant reviewer is his reliance as a fish-eating vegetarian on a somewhat restricted range of dishes. Risotto is a Livingstone staple, praised when of a good or "perfect consistency, as opposed to the stodgy risotto you sometimes get lumbered with". New Labour loyalists who fear that years of treacherous sniping lie ahead, should perhaps take heart that Ken dotes on Italian cuisine as much as the next cabinet minister, never tiring of garlic or truffle oil. Indeed, though our future mayor has, himself, mocked "polenta-eating Islingtonites", this turns out to be a favourite dish, particularly at Vasco and Piero's Pavilion, where "they do an excellent polenta."

Clearly, the more widely circulated Livingstone's restaurant reviews, the more - if such a thing is possible - they will enhance his reputation. When he began this sideline in 1993, he playfully told readers of Esquire magazine that his column had "a vital role to play in convincing the British people that the good life and socialism are not incompatible". He has gone on to prove something even more remarkable: that writing for Associated Newspapers and socialism are not incompatible - no, not even when one of those newspapers regularly attacks you as an unreconstructed loony whom the business community cannot possibly trust.

So that's another insult gone. What's left? Don't Vote for Ken, he's Frightfully Greedy? I doubt it. Obesity is on the way up.

Cold comfort for the infertile flock

A letter to a newspaper denouncing Ken Livingstone for being "a non-breeder, in other words he does not cast his seed, which is the reason for his existence" is considered so hilarious that it features in the current edition of Private Eye. Is it possible the Bishop of Rochester saw an early copy? For now, he too attacks non-breeders, describing married couples with no children "self-indulgent and incomplete". Normally, one would dismiss this as just the kind of tactless, interfering twaddle that bishops are paid to produce, and still not a patch on anything Cardinal Winning has come up with lately. But this episcopal idiocy deserves some response. For no good reason, other than the British tradition of pretending that the Anglican church is an intellectual and moral force: the Bishop of Rochester, Michael Nazir-Ali, is the Chair of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Association's Ethics Committee.

The job of the HFEA is to regulate medical treatment for infertile people. As the HFEA points out: "About one in six couples suffer from problems of infertility at some time in their lives." Many of these couples will never have children: they may be too old, or unable to afford private treatment, or beyond the help of current reproductive medicine. The bishop as good as tells them their lives are worthless, warning that "the pleasures of career and travel will cloy after a while". He adds that the church should look kindly on people whose marriages break down because one partner does not want children. Does this also apply to the non-afflicted partner in involuntarily childless couples? The bishop is nearing the end of his term on the HFEA committee. No doubt his distinguished work for that body will only reinforce speculation that he may succeed George Carey.

 Just as some of us were wondering if anyone would ever try to win the women's vote in the mayoral elections, Susan Kramer and Sally Hamwee presented their "non-adversarial, constructive" message in a club which is not only women-only, but serves a particular kind of woman - the sort who wants to spend "a relaxing and pampering sojourn", gossiping and trying out beauty treatments such as the "Sanctuary's ultimate aromatherapy experience, pure, unashamed indulgence . . . incorporating the use of fresh rose petals, candle light, and Temple Bells . . ." Although anyone who has visited the Sanctuary, will be thrilled by the prospect of London as an enormous health spa, surrounded by mirrors and populated exclusively by naked women, it is unclear whether congestion charges alone will be enough to pay for the conversion. No doubt that skilful accountant, Steven Norris, will be able to enlighten us, once he has made an initial fact-finding expedition.

fields.headline: The education we deserve
fields.trailText: The horrific state of Stanley Deason school was not inevitable (Education - the great divide, March 6); nor is the apparently similar state of the community it is supposed to serve. The responsibility lies with successive governments which have deliberately allowed this to happen.
fields.body:
The horrific state of Stanley Deason school was not inevitable (Education - the great divide, March 6); nor is the apparently similar state of the community it is supposed to serve. The responsibility lies with successive governments which have deliberately allowed this to happen. Don't let us permit Blair or Blunkett to shove the blame on teachers. Proper funding, which would have enabled social care and control to have shaped this into a happier area, was and is possible, but the meanness of the public, nurtured and encouraged by political parties that were not prepared to lead, preferred massive tax cuts to better schools and hospitals and a fairer, more efficient police force. It is time the culprits in high positions accepted responsibility.

David A Craig
Bromsgrove, Worcs

 Nick Davies concludes "there is almost no connection between reality and the easy consensus of distant journalists and politicians" when comparing Roedean and Stanley Deason schools. This political malaise affects education, health and crime. We help people prepare their means statements for the magistrates. The reality is that poverty is so bad that decent people are propelled into crime, die young, give birth to underweight children, fall ill through stress and inadequate diet, despair of clothing their children adequately for school and have unmanageable debts. The easy consensus fails to take the government to task for grossly underestimating the depth of poverty which has built up. The hole in the middle of the polo mint policies of the "third way" awaits a diagnosis which admits to the reality, expense and social dangers of the extreme poverty of millions of adults in and out of work in Britain.

Zacchaeus 2000 Trust

But the crucial need in our more deprived areas will not be met through the normal allocations to local education authorities.

He fails to acknowledge the inbuilt restraint on spending - the electorate's desire for low taxes. fields.headline: Buying a myth
fields.standfirst:
Super Tuesday was a great one for George W Bush, but a bad day for America

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Super Tuesday was a great one for George W Bush, but a bad day for America
fields.body:
George W Bush has just purchased his party's nomination. Anti-sleaze candidate Senator John McCain is beaten but his charismatic warnings about democracy for sale will still ring out in this election. As Gore and Bush now both head off for another vigorous round of greedy fundraising to buy multiple short, sharp, TV attack ads, campaign money will be a big talking point. But the money that in the end may really count is the money Bush plans to buy the voters with: tax cuts. The question is whether enough of the people can be bribed enough of the time to let Bush buy the White House the way he has bought himself everything else.

The Bush message is simple, primal and potentially deadly: money, money, money. Lashings of it, golden promises ladled out at every rally, pouring like a lava flow from his website, handed out in IOU leaflets at every rally with a ready-reckoner to show every taxpayer how much richer they will be through his phenomenal tax cuts. Slashing and burning his way through the whole tax system, he will abolish death tax altogether and let inheritance rip. Crudely this appeal to greed is clothed in the high moral tones of the right: government is essentially evil, so keeping money out of its hands is virtuous. Doing good to yourself by not paying tax is doing good to your country too.

He has whistle-stopped 100 airports. As everywhere else, in Rochester, upstate New York, bands, Republican dignitaries and some 2,000 people turn out to hear the speech he has been selling from coast to coast. Dapper, slightly simian, too small eyes too close together, he is a feeble shadow of a feeble father. That president without qualities has brought forth a man with only negative qualities and less than nothing in his past history to recommend him. (He seems even worse in the flesh than on television.) "My priorities are my faith and my family!" he declares, but the one punch in his every speech is mammon. And why not? The power of money has bought this unaccomplished man everything he has - a place at Yale, a place in the National Guard to avoid Vietnam, an oil business, then rescue by his dad's good ol' boys when it went bust, the Texas governorship and now the greatest slush fund ever accumulated by any candidate, making him the creature of every unsavoury interest including big tobacco and the National Rifle Association.

So is it surprising that his unique selling point, the one that raises the roof in stomping and cheers, is money? He learned these words at his Daddy's knee: "Read my lips: no new taxes." But his father lost next time partly because those same lips failed to deliver. This time this Bush is handing out an electoral bribe of colossal proportions the like of which no one has tried before. No doubt William Hague and Michael Portillo will be watching what happens with eager fascination.

His standard speech is larded with untruths: "Taxes are the highest since world war two when we had 7m men in uniform." To great cheers he promises to give away the big budget surplus, which currently goes mainly on repaying national debt. "I know the surplus is not the government's money, I know it is the people's money! It's risky, they say, to give people their money back. I'll tell you what's risky - to leave money in Washington DC!" Bush calls himself a "compassionate conservative" but on his lips "compassion" has a new meaning: "It's conservative to cut taxes. It's compassionate to give people their money back."

To be sure he says other things too in his standard text. "Sharpening the military sword" is a favourite - a return to the mythical star wars missile shield costing unimaginable trillions. (But where will the money come from?) And education, a critical voter concern in this election. Bush will take away money from failing poor schools and give it to parents as vouchers. He sneers at the head start programme, saying he'll get money back from that too - though its phenomenal success with deprived pre-school children made it one of the few LBJ "great society" programmes that survived the Reagan era.

But all that is just a little flannel in which to dress up his shameless main message: money. Can voters, even in a time of unprecedented boom, still be bought with the largest, crudest bribe ever waved beneath their noses? Pollsters and politicians on both sides of the Atlantic always fear they can. In the privacy of the polling booth the offer of a minimum $2,000 in every tax payer's hand is a powerful pull. (Far more, of course, to the already super-rich.) This will be the ultimate clinical trial of what money can buy in a democracy and rightwing parties everywhere will be watching the experiment.

The Gore camp pretends not to be rattled by this. Polls and focus groups show people saying that in these good times tax cuts aren't where it's at. They want better schools, healthcare and infrastructure. Who needs money in their pocket when that money spent collectively can buy the things they know they really, really want. But do they really, really mean it? Gordon Brown and Tony Blair will be watching this election with equal intensity. If Al Gore wins in November they might gain the confidence to bound into the next election explaining why paying more tax can get the voters more of what they want, ignoring all Tory tax hand-out blandishments. If Gore wins on a No Tax Cuts ticket then that old "eternal truth" that voters always vote with their pockets will be exposed. It is a shame this essential message is to be delivered by such a dismally poor candidate as Al Gore. But his one advantage is that Bush is even less attractive, an even more charm-free zone. It will be a flawed electoral experiment, mired in other issues, but it is as good as we shall ever get.

The Gore camp comforts itself: it's the economy, stupid. Voters do not want to risk upsetting this golden moment (though jitters in the markets this week and the coming oil price rise may change the picture somewhat by November). Gore will warn that the American economy could not take Bush's explosive tax-cut cash injection. While Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, will scrupulously avoid comment, the look on his face may be enough to remind voters that he would have to send interest rates soaring to keep inflation at bay, throttling off investment, shooting up mortgage and borrowing rates, strangling growth and employment, plunging headlong out of this magic boom. This is what Mr Brown should be telling British voters too now: higher taxes are a more productive way to dampen inflation than higher interest rates. But will he?

That may depend on whether leaden, dead-eyed Al Gore can make the US electorate sit up and understand that Bush offers poisoned gold. A difficult message to get across in the desperately truncated political language of demi-semi-soundbites. But it will settle for a long time the question of whether money in the hand always out-dazzles everything else.

webTitle: Treasury minister cleared of shares accusation interest

fields.headline: Treasury minister cleared of shares accusation interest
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: A government minister was yesterday cleared of breaking parliamentary rules after he failed to declare a large shareholding in a consultancy which may benefit from changes to tax rules that he announced last year.
fields.body:
A government minister was yesterday cleared of breaking parliamentary rules after he failed to declare a large shareholding in a consultancy which may benefit from changes to tax rules that he announced last year.

Stephen Timms, the financial secretary to the treasury, was accused of breaking the rules in a complaint made to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards.

Alan Butler, from Wilmslow, Cheshire, said Mr Timms had spoken in parliament last year in favour of changing a tax loophole which would benefit his former consultancy, Ovum Holdings Ltd, in which Mr Timms owned a large shareholding. MPs must declare any interest in debates and are banned from initiating legislation that could benefit them personally.

Mr Butler - through his Independent MP, Martin Bell - said that when the company is floated on the stock exchange Mr Timms and his wife could become paper millionaires, with their shares worth £10m.

But an investigation by Ms Filkin found that Mr Timms had not broken any rules. He was a former employee and shareholder of Ovum Holdings from 1986 to 1994. After the management buyout in 1995, the company was renamed Ovum Holdings Ltd and there was a big rise in the value of Mr Timms' shares.

Mr Timms said that after entering government in 1998 he had transferred 80% of his shares to a charitable trust and put the remaining 20% in a trust for the benefit of his children, nephews, nieces and godchildren. There was a delay in the transfer but it was completed last month. He denied that the changes in the law would particularly benefit the consultancy.

Ms Filkin ruled he no longer had a direct financial interest and threw out the complaint. Her decision was upheld by the Commons standards and privileges committee.

webTitle: Views from the staff room and estate

fields.headline: Views from the staff room and estate
fields.trailText: It is ironic that the day after the Blairs defended their children from press intrusion, you managed to parade the private lives of so many young people (some of whom were under my pastoral care); and so many of my colleagues.
fields.body:
It is ironic that the day after the Blairs defended their children from press intrusion, you managed to parade the private lives of so many young people (some of whom were under my pastoral care); and so many of my colleagues. Stanley Deason was, admittedly, a difficult school. But the head of a neighbouring school was appointed in the spring of 1994 to turn the school around and within two terms had in place systems which brought order to the classroom and established a regime where learning could take place. After her appointment, Mrs Coleman began to dismantle these systems.

"Met" Metcalfe was a highly respected former member of staff and governor. He had received an award for his services to the community and even in retirement gave an endless amount of time running Duke of Edinburgh award schemes. Stanley Deason had the largest number of DoE award holders in the county. This scheme was one of the first casualties of Ms Coleman. The staff were totally supportive of the students in the school. Ms Coleman was the only member of staff to "label" the pupils as "damaged".

David Kemp
Head of year, Stanley Deason school, 1993-99

 Less than 10 years ago Stanley Deason was a thriving comprehensive. Our two eldest sons left with eight A-C grade GCSEs each. At the same time they were well on their way to completing their Duke of Edinburgh gold award. As a parent I had only relief that the boys were doing better than I had at my old secondary mod. One of the proudest moments of my life was watching the boys and girls of Stanley Deason, line up with the girls of Roedean at Kensington Palace to receive their Duke of Edinburgh gold awards.

Gill Palmer
Brighton

 I am 47, an ex-headteacher who recognises so much of what happened to Libby Coleman. Last week I drove past Roedean and later on got lost on the Whitehawk estate as I made my way to visit my daughter at Sussex University. She achieved her place through hard work and the dedication of many teachers in the state sector. Blunkett continues to sleep in the past.

Adrian Townsend
Garsington, Oxford

webTitle: Saddam is using the children of Iraq

fields.headline: Saddam is using the children of Iraq
fields.trailText: Your leader (March 8) criticises our policies on Iraq then advocates an almost identical solution. All members of the UN security council are working hard to implement resolution 1284.
fields.body:
Your leader (March 8) criticises our policies on Iraq then advocates an almost identical solution. All members of the UN security council are working hard to implement resolution 1284. No one expected the weapons inspectors to be back yet: Unmovic chairman Hans Blix started work only a week ago. They could be back within weeks. And if Iraq co-operates, sanctions will be suspended - something all of us want.

However, it is a lie propagated by Saddam that sanctions are responsible for the suffering of the Iraqi people. We have done our best to relieve it. There is no limit on Iraqi oil sales to pay for the "oil for food" programme. Iraq is the world's second-biggest oil producer so well over $8bn a year is available for foods, medicines, clean water, electricity, education, agriculture and the oil industry.

For example, the UN recommends Iraq set aside at least $91m for nutrition every six months. They allocated only $24m. John Pilger's documentary showed harrowing pictures of Iraqi children in a cancer ward. The doctors said they could not get the drugs they need. This is a scandal. The fault lies with the Iraqi government. They fail to order enough medicines and fail to distribute them properly. Around 25% of medicines imported into Iraq lie in warehouses .

Saddam plays politics with suffering. He believes TV pictures of malnourished Iraqi children serve his interests so he makes sure there are plenty of malnourished children to film. In northern Iraq, where Saddam's writ does not run, health indices are actually improving.

It would be grossly irresponsible to abandon the attempt to deny Saddam weapons of mass destruction. He would threaten his people and his neighbours. What is the alternative that John Pilger, George Galloway and others advocate? Abandon sanctions. Trust Saddam to improve conditions for the people. Cross our fingers as he smuggles in a new stock of weapons. And wish the best of luck to the Kurds, the Shia and his neighbours. The truth is that the critics have no alternative except one which would leave Saddam free to do as he likes. That is a risk we cannot take.

Peter Hain MP
Minister of state, Foreign office

fields.headline: Fresh start or false dawn
fields.trailText: Prior to becoming the local MP for Brighton Kemptown in 1997, I was a councillor for Marine ward, which includes both Roedean and Stanley Deason schools. Your article took me back to that bleakest of times, five years ago when the previous government showed it did not care about the conditions the children were growing up in.
fields.body:
Prior to becoming the local MP for Brighton Kemptown in 1997, I was a councillor for Marine ward, which includes both Roedean and Stanley Deason schools. Your article took me back to that bleakest of times, five years ago when the previous government showed it did not care about the conditions the children were growing up in. I was especially dismayed when they introduced blunt league tables that failed to recognise the social challenges that many of Stanley Deason's pupils faced.

Since then much has changed, with a new education authority, education action zone status and a new school replacing Stanley Deason. You will have set back many parents' optimism about the future - local people are involved in the East Brighton Community Partnership, which is bidding' for up to £50m from the new deal for communities initiative. Residents have found the solutions to be complex, including education, unemployment and crime, but shown themselves willing to take on that challenge. What a pity that you failed to say what has happened for the better in recent years and thereby blamed David Blunkett rather than his predecessors.

Dr Des Turner MP

 One of Whitehawk's major problems is a media stereotype that presents only a picture of intensely negative events. Good news about the area includes a new youth club run by local volunteers, excellent musical and dramatic productions at both primary and secondary schools in the area, the development of a local credit union with a training programme that has enabled a quarter of the participants to obtain paid work, a new children's playground and three new tenants' and residents' associations.

Cllr Catherine Shelley
Brighton, Marine ward

 Last July Stanley Deason was closed down and given the New Labour "fresh start" treatment. Everything changed: staff, curriculum, name, only the buildings and the children are the same. Now it's called East Brighton Media & Arts College. Supported by partnerships with business it will bid for a specialist school status if it manages to improve exam results.

We are assured it will work. But the latest school reports suggest there is just as much unrest as before, with pupil behaviour still bad and staff turnover high. It will take more than a lick of paint and spinning tales of success to achieve the progress the pupils so desperately need. fields.headline: Rabbinical economics
fields.trailText: Nick Davies (Blunkett's magic trick, March 7) says a select committee in July 27 1998 saw through the £19bn deception, and that it was "uncovered by researchers" that education spending was less than that of the Tories. No experts or researchers were necessary.
fields.body:
Nick Davies (Blunkett's magic trick, March 7) says a select committee in July 27 1998 saw through the £19bn deception, and that it was "uncovered by researchers" that education spending was less than that of the Tories. No experts or researchers were necessary. All the required information was given straightforwardly in the tables included in Gordon Brown's spending review issued on July 14 1998. I had a letter published in the FT on July 21 using data from the spending review that showed Mr Brown's claims on education were hollow.

Walter Stanners
 Cambridge

 Last night in a talk on Jewish humour I heard Rabbi Malcolm Weisman tell the story of a distraught husband consulting his rabbi about the birth of a child to his wife of three months. Don't worry said the rabbi, you have been married for three months, your wife has been married for three months, and you have both been married for three months. There, your child has been born after the proper nine months. I had not expected to find this arithmetical method being adopted by the government

A Christian Exeter

 I now know why Tony Blair said his first priority was "Education, education, education". He meant he was going to give the education service the same sum of money, three times, over a three year period.

Gruffudd Roberts
 Sir Ddinbych
gruffr@drws.freeserve.co.uk

 Although I am no mathematician, it is obvious that the figure of £19.2bn extra funding quoted in the article does emerge from the year-on-year increases quoted. You may not like the way they are presented, but to present them as having been "conjured out of thin air by trickery" is more misleading.

Mike Henning
 Shepton Mallet, Somerset

fields.headline: Selling schools short
fields.standfirst:
Labour has failed to deliver the cash

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Rarely has a new government generated so much expectation in schools. After 18 years of financial squeeze, teachers welcomed a new Labour government, with a record majority, and one clear priority standing above its otherwise modest promises: education, education, education. Three years on, deep disillusion has descended.
fields.body:
Rarely has a new government generated so much expectation in schools. After 18 years of financial squeeze, teachers welcomed a new Labour government, with a record majority, and one clear priority standing above its otherwise modest promises: education, education, education. Three years on, as our Guardian Education poll this week demonstrated, deep disillusion has descended: over half believe their job is declining, with only 16% perceiving an improvement; and large numbers are so fed up that they are getting ready to quit. Our three-part special investigation into schools by Nick Davies this week helps explain why.

The first reason is hype. Last April's new three-year spending programme was described as "the biggest single investment in education in the history of our country". Even the NUT believed the now infamous figure cited - £19bn - meant an end to "the famine in funding". One year on, schools are still waiting to be fed. Part of the problem is the severe squeeze which education services suffered in the previous two decades, as set out by Davies yesterday. But a more important part is the fundamentally dishonest way in which the £19bn was aggregated. Study Davies's disaggregation in Tuesday's Guardian. Neither teachers nor the public have been fooled. The hype has been counterproductive because it helped generate the cynicism picked up in our poll. As Tony Travers, the London School of Economics analyst, has shown, Labour at the end of this first term will still be spending less than John Major in his first year.

A second lesson is the stark conditions facing teachers in state schools, vividly contrasted by Davies with private schools which spend twice as much on each pupil. Pay is not the main factor. It is only 10% higher. Far more important is the extra staff private schools employ, allowing teachers to concentrate on their specialty and giving more time for preparation and homework marking. As our survey shows, unrelenting pressure on state school teachers is a major cause of their dismay. Ministers were right to raise pay, but they must dramatically increase staff numbers too. Then there is the problem of the neighbourhood comprehensive. By definition neighbourhood schools will generate more inequality, since neighbourhoods are unequal. The solution is not a return to the 11-plus and a selection system which stamped 80% of children as failures. Instead we need new ways of widening catchment areas. The development of new specialist schools in technology, modern languages and sports is one.

Finally there are the private schools. Every country has them, but in none are they as dominant as in England. They seriously distort the system. Labour dropped its plans to abolish them two elections ago. That was right. The European Convention on Human Rights protects them. Removing their charitable status would not eliminate them. Far better would be to require them to share their superior facilities more widely with surrounding schools. New summer schools for state pupils, which universities started last year and will now extend, should widen access. Two-thirds of all pupils who get three As at A-level are in the state sector, but only 50% of Oxbridge applicants come from it. There should be more of them in all our top 15 universities. Britain should also use scholastic aptitude tests, as the Americans do. They would identify pupils with degree potential who for reasons of poor schooling or an impoverished home have poor A-levels. We urgently need such a key to open doors too long closed to them.

webTitle: Ready, steady, Gore - but race with McCain leaves Bush winded

fields.headline: Ready, steady, Gore - but race with McCain leaves Bush winded
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Super Tuesday was super for Al Gore, less so for American democracy. The man in the suit has become the guy to beat after his primary whitewash of Bill Bradley. He has finally escaped Bill Clinton's shadow, proving along the way that "Clinton fatigue" was an analysts' myth.
fields.body:
Super Tuesday was super for Al Gore, less so for American democracy. The man in the suit has become the guy to beat after his primary whitewash of Bill Bradley. The vice-president emerges from the Democratic nomination race both politically and sartorially sharper. For that he owes a debt to Mr Bradley who forced him to define his candidacy, on issues like gun control and healthcare, and whose dogged challenge energised his campaign. He has finally escaped Bill Clinton's shadow, proving along the way that "Clinton fatigue" was an analysts' myth. Voters credit Mr Gore and the current administration for America's economic boom. The primaries also seemed to show that, increasingly, they like and trust him. He beat all-comers in California's "beauty contest" vote. He has wiped out George W Bush's national lead. Crucially in this year of uncommitted swing-voters, he has centre-ground appeal. Right now, Big Al has "Big Mo". Whether he can sustain it until November in what will be a tough fight is another matter.

Mr Bush, on the other hand, heads for the Republican nomination a sadder if not a wiser man. His rival John McCain collapsed the GOP's "big tent", running as a reformer against insider politics, big-bucks corporate contributors, Christian fundamentalists, and Reagan-style fiscal irresponsibility. He forced the "compassionate conservative" Bush to lurch to the right, away from the battlefield upon which the White House is always won, denying him independents and first-time voters. And he showed that character is this year's key issue. Mr McCain won admiration for his on-the-hoof, Vietnam-hardened, streetfighting style. Mr Bush, in contrast, came across as a man of uncertain judgment, limited intellectual grasp, and with a propensity for dirty tricks when things go badly - the "any which way but lose" approach. Whereas Mr Bradley ultimately strengthened Mr Gore and his party's victory hopes, the deeply divisive Bush-McCain dogfight may have done lasting damage to the Republican cause in both the presidential and congressional elections.

That Mr Bush still won handily in the end underlines what a fierce grip the two main party machines retain on the US electoral process - despite all the brouhaha about open primaries, mould-breaking, and politics for the people. Last autumn, they promoted a Bush v Gore title bout. Now the primaries are all but over, guess what? It's Bush v Gore.

webTitle: Lebanon piles the pressure on Israel over withdrawal

fields.headline: Lebanon piles the pressure on Israel over withdrawal
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: President Emile Lahoud yesterday warned that Lebanon will not be able to protect Israel from Palestinian guerrilla raids over the border if Israel withdraws unilaterally from south Lebanon.
fields.body:
President Emile Lahoud yesterday warned that Lebanon will not be able to protect Israel from Palestinian guerrilla raids over the border if Israel withdraws unilaterally from south Lebanon.

The statement from the Lebanese president is the toughest yet in campaigns by Lebanon, Hizbullah and Syria to underline the dire risks that Israel will run if its withdrawal from Lebanon does not come as part of a wider agreement involving a pullout from the Golan Heights.

There is unquestionably a good measure of bluff in the menacing rhetoric coming from all parties to the conflict. But if there is no breakthrough in the stalled Syrian-Israeli peace talks, the brinkmanship will grow increasingly perilous as the clock ticks towards the July deadline which the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has set himself to leave Lebanon.

The talks broke off in January over demands that Israel commit to a full withdrawal from the Golan Heights.

"How can we guarantee these frontiers when there are tens of thousands of refugees in Palestinian camps?" asked Mr Lahoud. He added that Lebanon was "not disposed to assure Israel's well-being".

A unilateral withdrawal would leave a question mark over the refugees' right to return to the land from which Israel drove them.

He said the solution to the refugee problem lay primarily with Israel, adding: "The Israelis call for security guarantees after their withdrawal; the threats they make in case these are not given are completely unacceptable because acceptance would amount to accepting the settlement of Palestinians on our soil."

He said that Lebanon wanted a settlement of the refugee problem and a complete withdrawal from the Golan Heights, as well as from south Lebanon, before it could respond to Israel's security demands.

There are 367,000 Palestinian refugees in Lebanon. All religious communities are united in the belief that a settlement could not allow the refugees to stay.

It was to thwart attacks by Palestinian guerrillas that Israel first established its "security zone" in south Lebanon in the late 70s. Since the expulsion of the PLO from Lebanon, Palestinian raids have been very rare.

Palestinians in Lebanon and the occupied territories do not disguise their admiration for Hizbullah's achievements, leaving many Israelis asking when they might start emulating this militancy.

Since Israel's withdrawal decision, Lebanon has been making plain its full alignment with Syria's strategy.

Asked if there would be no peace for northern Israel before Israel ended its occupation of Golan, the information minister Anwar Khalil said: "Obviously. This is what I believe, what everyone familiar with the situation in Lebanon believes and this is definitely the position of the Lebanese government."

His comments reinforce the growing assumption that, barring a wider agreement involving Syria, Lebanon will not seek to establish its authority, through the deployment of the army, in areas evacuated by Israel. It is also likely to oppose any similar proposal for UN forces.

Israel and the PLO will resume negotiations in Washington later this month in an attempt to seal a final peace treaty by September 13, the US Middle East peace envoy, Dennis Ross, said yesterday.

The breakthrough followed the second summit in less than 24 hours between Mr Barak and the Palestinian president, Yasser Arafat.

webTitle: How the Serb army escaped Nato

fields.headline: How the Serb army escaped Nato
fields.standfirst:
'They came out to burn villages when they wanted to, they hid when the weather was good'

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The conclusion in a secret US defence department report that Belgrade had a spy in Nato in the early days of the Kosovo conflict backs up suspicions raised at the time by other military sources and raises the question of how much it affected allied operations and the conduct of the war.
fields.body:
The conclusion in a secret US defence department report that Belgrade had a spy in Nato in the early days of the Kosovo conflict backs up suspicions raised at the time by other military sources and raises the question of how much it affected allied operations and the conduct of the war.

Nato commanders, not to say political leaders, became increasingly frustrated by their inability to destroy Serb units carrying out atrocities on ethnic Albanians, precisely the activity Nato's military action was designed to prevent.

Nato's initial targets - those which Belgrade knew about in advance, according to the US reports - were mainly fixed sites, including anti-aircaft missile emplacements and military barracks.

The Serbs were reluctant to "lock-on" their missiles to Nato aircraft since this would make them vulnerable to counter-attack by Nato pilots. However, allied pilots throughout the 78-day bombing campaign reported attacks from surface-to-air missiles, fired, it seems, without their base being identified.

The first phase of the Nato campaign did not include targets over Kosovo - indeed, it was assumed that Slobodan Milosevic would put up his hands before new targeting plans would need to be agreed.

It was known that Yugoslavia had built an extensive system of underground shelters for its troops, guns and aircraft - a relic of President Tito's era, in preparation for a possible invasion by the Soviet Union. Many of its camouflage techniques, including the use of dummy weapons emplacements, the Serbs had learned from the Russians.

General Nebojsa Pavkovic, commander of the Yugoslav army in Kosovo, tells the BBC's Moral Combat programme this Sunday: "We used other measures, too: camouflage, decoys, and it was mainly these that Nato aircraft destroyed."

Nato pilots found small mobile targets so hard to find that on some days they dropped half their bombs on so-called "dump sites" known to be empty.

General Mike Short, commander of the allied air forces, said: "The Serbs dictated the pace of events, they dictated the battle rhythm. They came out to burn villages when they wanted to, they hid when the weather was good."

The question is how much did access to Nato intelligence give the Serbs warnings of allied attacks on specific targets - possibly even enabling them to place Albanians in military buildings and military vehicles in civilian convoys in areas they knew were going to be attacked.

But Nato did not start to strike targets in Kosovo until later in the war. In the first weeks of the conflict Nato commanders were frustrated by something the Serbs could do nothing about. Bad weather persistently prevented British laser-guided "smart" bombs from identifying targets.

And Nato's mistakes - killing civilians in urban areas and on Kosovan roads and railways - occurred mainly in good weather. Critics of the bombing campaign also said mistakes were the inevitable result of Nato's policy of restricting its pilots to bombing from 15,000 feet or above - a policy dictated not least by political considerations, notably Washington's determination to avoid horrified public reaction to the sight of "bodybags" coming home.

Failure to identify targets on the ground in Kosovo led Nato commanders - after fierce arguments between member governments - to strike economic and industrial targets, including power stations and the Serbian television headquarters in Belgrade.

Military commanders, in the first few weeks of the war, were cautious about what their bombers had achieved. Swept on by the rhetoric of their political masters, however, they began to make claims which they were to regret.

By early May, Nato was claiming that its aircraft had destroyed more than 200 tanks and had cut off Serb forces in Kosovo from their supply bases. It portrayed a Serb army whose morale was crumbling from mounting casualties, shortages of food and fuel and lack of sleep, as it dispersed into smaller and weaker units to escape the relentless bombing.

After conceding that the initial war aims - which were to avert a human disaster, as George Robertson, then defence secretary, put it - had failed, Nato claimed it was progressively destroying the Albanians' tormentors.

Yet when the western media saw the Serb military withdraw from Kosovo in early June, they saw convoys of Serb tanks, armoured cars, guns, trucks and military equipment untouched by Nato's air assault.

Nato's bombing campaign, with thousand of sorties and the dropping of tens of thousands of bombs, including sophisticated precision weapons, succeeded in damaging just 13 of the Serbs' 300 battle tanks in Kosovo.

A Nato spy could have provided Belgrade with crucial information, but the implication of the secret US reports is that two weeks into the conflict he or she no longer had access to allied targeting secrets.

His or her presence would certainly have hit the morale of Nato's commanders. But he or she is unlikely to have had any impact on the later conduct of Nato's campaign. This was determined by broad political necessities and military shortcomings.

Nato's final tally of hits and misses

Nato planes flew more than 3,000 bombing missions, for the loss of one plane to enemy fire, during the 79-day war from late March to June last year

After 1,955 of those missions, pilots reported hitting their targets (some claims were duplicates)

93 Yugoslav tanks were hit (out of a rough total of 600) - 26 of them "catastrophically" destroyed and 67 severely damaged

153 armoured personnel carriers were hit (out of an estimated 600)

389 artillery and mortar pieces were struck

His or her presence would certainly have hit the morale of Nato's commanders. But he or she is unlikely to have had any impact on the later conduct of Nato's campaign. This was determined by broad political necessities and military shortcomings. webTitle: Mystery Swede with Kremlin links who helped end war

fields.headline: Mystery Swede with Kremlin links who helped end war
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A Swedish financier played a crucial role in persuading Slobodan Milosevic that the Russians would not come to his aid days before the Yugoslav president agreed to a peace deal with Nato, according to a BBC documentary on the Kosovo war.
fields.body:
A Swedish financier played a crucial role in persuading Slobodan Milosevic that the Russians would not come to his aid days before the Yugoslav president agreed to a peace deal with Nato, according to a BBC documentary on the Kosovo war.

Peter Castenfelt - known to be trusted by Boris Yeltsin, the ailing Russian president, and the Russian security apparatus - was used in a secret channel opened by the Germans in an attempt to end the conflict.

After secret talks in the Kremlin, he was driven by the Russian security service to the border between Romania and Serbia. He was then taken to Belgrade where he stayed for four days at the end of May last year.

Mr Castenfelt's role is revealed by Karl Kaiser, adviser to the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. He told the BBC: "It was not easy for Germany. This country was particularly interested in getting the war ended. There was a possibility that the crisis could evolve in a way that could end up in a tragedy".

He said the message the Swede took to Belgrade was: "The security apparatus in Moscow said 'end the war'. Or 'here are some conditions that look acceptable to us, and we cannot help you beyond it, so exit now'."

The condition was that though the K-For peacekeeping troops would be "Nato-led" they would still be a UN force.

The Castenfelt visit was closely followed by a meeting in Belgrade between Mr Milosevic, Viktor Chernomyrdin, Mr Yeltsin's official envoy, and the Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari, which finally paved the way for the entry of K-For troops.

However, the peace nearly began with a highly dangerous confrontation with Russian troops. General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, backed by Javier Solana, the organisation's secretary general, ordered 500 British and French paratroopers to be put on standby to occupy Pristina airport where an advance party of Russian troops were heading.

The plan was vetoed by General Sir Mike Jackson, the K-For commander, in consultation with London. The British general told his military chief that the plan risked sparking a third world war.

But this was not the end of it. General Leonid Ivashev, a senior Russian officer, tells the BBC that "we had several air bases ready. We had battalions of paratroopers ready to leave [for Pristina] within two hours."

Gen Clark planned to order British tanks and armoured cars to block the runways. But what he describes as "an appropiate course of action" was again overruled by Britain.

Instead, Gen Clark asked neighbouring countries, including Hungary, a new member of Nato, and Romania, a keen candidate for Nato membership, not to allow Russian aircraft to overfly their territory.

In an interview with the Guardian shortly after the end of the conflict, General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, emphasised the role of the Russians in getting Mr Milosevic to agree to withdraw his forces from Kosovo. But Germany's back-channel and the role played by Mr Castenfelt has never previously been revealed.

Why he was so trusted by Mr Yeltsin and his security advisers is unknown. What is clear is that Mr Yeltsin persuaded the Russian military to accept the deal, possibly by promising them more money and a free hand in Chechyna.

The BBC programme also reveals the extent to which senior US military commanders were deeply frustrated by political constraints on their bombing campaign. Asked what impact the high-flying bombing strategy had on Mr Milosevic's ability to cary out ethnic cleansing, General Mike Short, US commander of allied air forces, replies: "I don't think it impacted on him at all."

He discloses that more than once he considered resigning.

General Henry Shelton, chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, says: "The one thing we knew we could not do... we could not stop the atrocities or the ethnic cleansing through the application of our military power."

Nato military chiefs, who were advised, wrongly, that Mr Milosevic would buckle after a few days of bombing Yugoslavian air defences, wanted to hit Serbia much harder and sooner with heavy attacks on a wide range of military and economic targets.

General Klaus Naumann, the German chairman of Nato's military committee at the start of the conflict, says: "I said on one occasion to the [Nato] council, we cannot stop this by using air power alone. It's impossible. No one in the political arena should have had the illusion that we could do it."

Tony Blair concedes that the air campaign hindered, rather than stopped, ethnic cleansing. That, he says, is because of the "limitations" of "that type of military action".

Washington was furious with British attempts to talk up the possibility of sending in ground forces, an option which Washington considered impossible politically and logistically, and which was unacceptable to the German, Italian, and Greek governments and probably many more of the allies.

Nato's failure to stop the exodus of ethnic Albanians from Kosovo led to increasing frustration in Nato's capitals, with Washington placing the blame on the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. Ivo Daalder, a member of Bill Clinton's national security council, says: "Madeleine's war, as it became called, all of a sudden didn't look so good."

webTitle: Nato spy leaked bombing raid plans to the Serbs

fields.headline: Nato spy leaked bombing raid plans to the Serbs
fields.standfirst:
Classified US report reveals that Belgrade was passed top-secret flight plans and target details
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A spy in Nato provided the Serbs with top-secret details of allied bombing raids against Yugoslavia last year, including targets to be hit and precise flight paths, according to high-level US sources.
fields.body:
A spy in Nato provided the Serbs with top-secret details of allied bombing raids against Yugoslavia last year, including targets to be hit and precise flight paths, according to high-level US sources.

An internal classified report drawn up for senior US defence officials concludes that the Serbs had access to Nato's daily orders for air raids and reconnaissance flights during the first two weeks of the allied bombing campaign, which began on the night of March 24.

By the end of the second week of the campaign, according to the report, Nato started to change the way the orders about bombing raids were distributed. The effect on what the Serbs appeared to know about Nato's bombing plans was immediate, it concludes.

The existence of the report is revealed in a BBC2 programme, Moral Combat: Nato at War, to be broadcast on Sunday night.

It says that the leaking of secret Nato war plans meant that the Serbs also knew when Nato's "detection assets" - spy planes and unmanned reconnaissance drones - would be deployed. Serb army and police units could move their men and equipment around with less risk of detection and in advance of bombing raids.

The report - an investigation into the lessons learned from the Kosovo conflict, which ran from March to June last year - says Belgrade's secret source was human and was not the result of hacking into Nato's coded computer system, called Chronos.

General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, suspected early in the bombing campaign that Belgrade had a spy in the organisation's Brussels headquarters, according to a senior source there. "I know I've got a spy, I want to find him," he is said to have told colleagues.

Nato military chiefs immediately checked the distribution of the daily "air tasking orders" or ATOs. To their horror, they discovered that 600 people had access to them. "You could have knocked me down with a feather", said one senior US air force officer who asked not to be identified.

The large distribution list - understood to comprise military personnel and unlikely to have included diplomats or members of Nato governments - was based on the number of people authorised to see operational details of the alliance's earlier no-fly zones over Bosnia. The Bosnia plans had been agreed with the Serbs, so were not sensitive.

The top-secret Nato air orders were an entirely different matter. As soon as US commanders knew how many people were on the distribution list, they narrowed it to 100.

Another source, in the Pentagon - the US defence department - also said there was evidence of a Serb spy. Pilots at Nato's operational headquarters at Vicenza in northern Italy were expressing concern that the Serbs were "picking up on our runs".

Speaking on the record to the BBC, Gen Clark was asked if he thought there was a spy "at Nato headquarters". He replied: "Absolutely not". When asked whether there was a spy "in Nato", he said: "I don't think so." He confirmed, however, that there was an investigation into Nato's procedures. "We restricted who had access to the air tasking orders and we tightened them up and we kept some sensitive items off the ATOs," he said.

He added: "I think they [the Serbs] knew about the categories we were going after on the first night."

It was reported last year that the US F117A Stealth fighter shot down by a Serb anti-aircraft missile in the first week of the bombing campaign may have been attacked after its secret flight plan was passed to Belgrade by a spy at Nato headquarters.

A Nato official was quoted last August as saying that an alliance military officer had passed details of the Stealth mission to a Russian intelligence official who tipped off Belgrade.

In November 1998, a French officer, Pierre-Henri Bunel, admitted that the month before he had passed on Nato's overall target plans to a Yugoslav diplomat in Brussels. This was in October last year, five months before the bombing began. He was reported as saying that he had acted out of hatred for the US.

Of Nato's 19 member countries, two - Italy and Greece - maintained diplomatic missions in Belgrade during the conflict. The secret US report is understood to give no indication of how a Nato spy could have passed information to Belgrade. Nor does it speculate about his nationality.

The BBC programme also reveals that a Swedish financier was sent on a secret mission to Moscow and Belgrade during the war. He told President Slobodan Milosevic that the Russians had agreed to a peace plan saying: "We cannot help you ... so exit now."

Moral Combat: Nato at War will be broadcast by BBC2 on Sunday. Allan Little is foreign affairs correspondent for the BBC

webTitle: US denies authorisation for British aid flight to Iraq

fields.headline: US denies authorisation for British aid flight to Iraq
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: US officials at the United Nations yesterday withheld authorisation of an airlift of medical supplies to Iraq organised by the Labour MP George Galloway and supported by Britain. They demanded an explanation of the "purpose" of each person travelling on the aircraft.
fields.body:
US officials at the United Nations yesterday withheld authorisation of an airlift of medical supplies to Iraq organised by the Labour MP George Galloway and supported by Britain. They demanded an explanation of the "purpose" of each person travelling on the aircraft.

Accusing the US of "overruling and humiliating" the British government - which backed the application to the UN sanctions committee after temporarily supporting a ban last weekend - Mr Galloway announced he would fly the £115,000 of vaccines and medicines to Jordan and take them overland to Baghdad instead.

The decision to call off the first direct civilian flight between Britain and Iraq since the 1991 Gulf war, scheduled for Saturday, was taken after the Glasgow Kelvin MP and anti-sanctions campaigner was given a three-hour deadline to supply technical air craft details along with the intentions of the 29 passengers.

He was told by the foreign office yesterday that he would have to leave supplies of typhoid vaccine behind because, contrary to earlier assurances, they were covered by sanctions as a potential "dual use" ingredient in biological weapons.

A foreign office spokesman said that, while British officials had not anticipated that "these questions were going to be asked" by the New York-based sanctions committee - which has administered sanctions against Iraq since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990 - they did not amount to a "wrecking proposal from the Americans or anyone else". The government had still hoped to win agreement for a humanitarian flight, the spokesman said.

Mr Galloway, who has been working privately with the foreign office minister Peter Hain for a couple of months to win British support for the flight, said that the questions had been "unanswerable and aimed at wrecking a fledgling attempt by the British government to take a slightly more conciliatory approach to relations with Iraq".

But Mr Hain last night accused him of a "cynical and dishonest" manoeuvre in cancelling the flight and insisted that there had been no need to do so in response to what he said were routine inquiries.

Mr Galloway intends to press ahead with legal action against the government, seeking a judicial review of its decision to refer the airlift to the sanctions committee, and damages for the cost of the cancelled flight.

Earlier this week, the numbers of passengers on the flight - which was backed by the crown prince of Dubai - had been reduced from 207 to 29 to win the support of the foreign office, after Mr Hain expressed alarm that it was turning into an anti-sanctions publicity stunt.There are also said to have been pressure from Downing Street.

fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week
fields.body:
"What makes the phenomenon of Caprice so very interesting, culturally and politically, is that she seems to be the very embodiment of our celebrity culture, in which a politician is indistinguishable from a bottle of perfume and fame is achieved at all cost - at any cost. That Caprice is in danger of becoming an icon illustrates the dearth of female role models in our politics. Where are the inspirational female icons to rival Nancy Astor, Barbara Castle and Margaret Thatcher?"

Jason Cowley on the rise and rise of Caprice, New Statesman

"Women like myself struggled to be taken seriously as musicians in this industry in the 70s"

Suzi Quatro's reaction to Geri Halliwell's breast-clutching at the Brit Awards, Daily Mail

"Geri Halliwell is said to be unhappy with her PR chap and is looking for another representative. His options will be limited. In order to get publicity, she's already pretended to have an affair with Chris Evans, appeared virtually naked in her tarty Donatella Versace frock and in a cheap, simulated sex scene at the Brit Awards. About the only option left to any new PR would be to suggest sex in public"

Lynda Lee-Potter's reaction, Daily Mail

"I might cynically suggest the first mobile vid-phones will, in the grubby hands of young men and teenage boys, become a substitute for the office photocopier, beaming unwanted and unlovely images of themselves to those who do not want them. The phone rings, you answer it, and there's Percy"

David Aaronovitch ponders the uses of new technology, Independent

"Women are tougher ... more capable of surviving. They have this native meanness. They hurt" John Malkovich gets profound, Arena

"I say to people: 'I just can't believe it's going to be as good as having a bulldog.' I adore my bulldog"

Johnny Vaughan on the imminent birth of his child, New Woman

"Certainly not!"

Jodie Kidd's response to whether she'd ever go out with her armpits unshaven, Independent

"When you're doing a scene like that, you have the most bizarre fucking creations covering up your bits and bobs. He had a little covering and I had a little covering ... You watch scenes like that and you wonder 'Are they really doing it?' ... And now I know, the actors are wearing little coverings, like socks"

Kate Winslet explodes the mystery of on-screen sex scenes, Elle

fields.headline: Mummy's girls
fields.standfirst: Ros Mark, former Blair nanny turned target of tabloid hate and the woman who has leapt to her defence: her mum.  Terri Apter examines that tricky mother-daughter relationship
fields.trailText: Listen to women speak as mothers and their voices deepen with compassion. Listen to women speak about their mothers and their voices break with irritation as they swap stories about difficult, trying people who don't mind their own business and don't let go. Terri Apter examines that tricky mother-daughter relationship
fields.body:
Mother-love has two very different faces. Listen to women speak as mothers and their voices deepen with compassion. They show respect for that overwhelming protectiveness, along with delight and pride. Listen to women speak about their mothers and their voices break with irritation as they swap stories about difficult, trying people who don't mind their own business and don't let go.

Mothers are slow to let go, especially of daughters. While they may be more prone to pick up and wash up after a son, they are alert to special dangers on behalf of a daughter. If her reputation is at stake, they turn tiger. Former Blair nanny Ros Mark has her mother riding out like a knight in shining armour to clear her name: "Ros is not a money-grabber and she's not a thief. In fact, she's in tears."

There is something particularly touching about this staunch defence. We recognise it as something totally unsurprising. Most of us take a loyal mother for granted - and like so many things we take for granted, mother-love is sometimes sneered at. A mother gives praise, offers help, checks up on a daughter, and meets with a groan. The weary: "Oh Mu-um" is all too familiar to any woman who has watched a girl become a woman.

Adrienne Rich remarked in her book Of Woman Born that the mother-daughter relationship is "the great unwritten story". But what remains largely unwritten is not its dark side - not the conflict, the supposed envy, the competition, the interference. These appear in fairy tales, with the dark side of a mother's love represented by the stepmother who cannot tolerate her daughter's maturing beauty (Snow White) or freedom (Rapunzel) or coming of age (Sleeping Beauty). From Pride and Prejudice, where the shallow and silly Mrs Bennet constantly acts against her daughters' best interests, to Bridget Jones' Diary, where a mother triggers groans in both character and reader by praising someone else's job, child or marriage, we see that familiar "impossible mother". Then there's Monica's mother in the TV series Friends, who likes her daughter's new hairstyle because it hides her ears. The stereotype of the mother is someone who stays close so she can make you feel bad about yourself.

Many problems that occur in women have been attributed to mothers who won't let go. Explanations of eating disorders have, until very recently, come in various versions of "it's all the mother's fault". An anorexic girl is thought to deny her own appetite because her mother made her feel guilty or confused about her own, independent needs. Only recently have social pressures and physiological brain function been highlighted as causes, with mothers portrayed as willing to do anything to help their daughters.

Then there is the problem of girls' and women's ambivalent motivation. Why do so many women step off the career fast-track? Well, the story goes, women are afraid of a mother's envy; pass her by and there's hell to pay. Only recently has women's so-called fear of success been highlighted as a shrewd assessment of the costs of high-pressure careers.

There's no doubt, though, that the air between a mother and daughter is highly charged. The fact is, if you take any parent/child pair, the one that comes up with the most arguments is the mother/daughter one. A few years back, I did some research on mothers and teenage daughters. What I expected to find was that their quarrels arose from a daughter's attempt to reject her mother so she could survive as a woman. I expected that because that's what established theory told me I'd find.

But these quarrels were shaped within a deep and loving bond. As the teenage girls jumped through their ritual mother abuse ("You don't understand anything!" and "I can't believe you said that!"), they had a positive goal. They wanted to shake a mother out of her old patterns of seeing a daughter, to force her into a new awareness of the young woman they were becoming. They kept fighting because they hoped that, this time, they'd get the right response: that their mother would see them for who they really were and love them all over again. Mother-daughter arguments are often exercises whereby the girl turns to her mother to help her build up her own sense of self.

In the past, hating one's mother has had a political thrust. The critic Elaine Showalter said mother-hating was the feminist enlightenment of the 1950s and 1960s. It was a metaphor, really, for disliking certain aspects of one's own womanhood. Catching out persistent female traits within ourselves, we blamed our mothers. And if we wanted to be women who stood on our own two feet, then we had to be wary of a mother's helping hand. We might get used to her support and forget we could stand alone.

But no one should have to stand alone, always. The need for a mother who thinks well of us and will champion us is long-lived. Research on midlife women shows women's overall wellbeing is related to their relationship with their mother. Adult women who have a good and close relationship with a mother have higher self-esteem, are less anxious and less depressed than are women who are at odds with their mothers. They also value these relationships - even though they are somewhat abashed. "I know it sounds silly," 38-year-old Beth says, "but when I'm low, there's nothing like going home and having Mum look after me."

Instead of expressing worry about her mother's pain or her father's anxiety, she said: "If Mum dies, who will look after me?" As I stared at this 36-year-old woman, with her newly published article and photos of her baby displayed on the desk, I thought: "You don't need anyone to look after you. You can look after yourself." But her panic registers the all too familiar need for someone to be our champion as only a mother can.
