fields.headline: Seeing is believing
fields.standfirst: More black women are entering the public arena than ever before . . . then fading away before our very eyes.  Bonnie Greer asks why
fields.trailText: More black women are entering the public arena than ever before . . . then fading away before our very eyes.  Bonnie Greer asks why.
fields.body:
I always looked forward to Christmas because that was when I got a new doll. My dollies were the centre of my world. I loved them. My dollies were me. Before dawn, I rushed into the room where the presents were. I saw my new doll. She was taller and more elegant than the others. She wore an ice-pink party dress with matching bonnet. But she was ugly to me. She was black.

I am reminded of this as I ponder the latest black actress to break into mainstream TV, the light-skinned Naomi Russell who will join the cast of Coronation Street later this month. My grandmother used to say: "If you're white, you're all right; if you're brown, stick around; if you're black, get back." She would have known the truth of that. She was a dark-skinned woman who married a man light enough to be known as "The Black Clark Gable". Her light-skinned children, including my mother, were invited up to Grandmother's for tea. The dark ones stayed at home.

If you are a black woman with dark skin, you are largely invisible, except to those who love and need you. You are taught never to wear bright colours, to keep your voice down, to be cleaner, smarter than other women. It is a reality you grow up with, absorb, make your own because you must. We become our own cheerleaders.

In many ways, we are not so far on from the late 50s, when I first saw that doll. Dark-skinned women should bring the issue of skin tone into the open, "out" those who relegate us to the bottom of the heap. But how can we? If you can't be seen, you're usually not heard.

In Love's Labour's Lost, Shakespeare gives us a response to black skin and womanhood that is so direct, it is bone-chilling. When Berowne proclaims his love for a dark-skinned woman, his king replies: "By heaven, thy love is as black as ebony... Black is the badge of hell, the hue of dungeons and the scowl of night."

Yet in spite of this, there is the paradox of the Black Virgin. Black Virgins and Black Madonnas exist all over Europe. They are said to have extraordinary powers; Joan of Arc was a devotee. For many Catholics, the spiritual Queen of England is black: Our Lady of Walsingham, The Black Madonna of England. But how many little dark-skinned girls growing up now will know that for many Europeans, the Mother of God is the same colour as they are?

I found Walsingham by chance, by serendipity. It was also by serendipity that I stumbled upon the first of three images of Naomi Campbell that stay in my mind. I saw it in the London Underground shortly after my arrival in Britain from the US in 1986 and it stopped me in my tracks. On the poster was a brown-skinned young girl. Her direct gaze met the eye of the beholder. She had full lips, short hair. She was real. Though I looked nothing like her, I could suddenly see a glimpse of my own image, my real face without mediation.

On the streets of London and New York City, suddenly you could see women in bright colours, loud lipstick, even with blonde streaks in their hair. They let themselves linger in the sunshine, all because Naomi was in the world. Naomi made us visible. She was us. Seeing her face on the tube that day helped make me decide that if Britain could appreciate someone with skin as dark as hers, then I wanted to stay.

But the second Naomi image is the classic American Vogue cover taken early last decade. They are all there: Linda, Cindy, Claudia. Naomi has the same languid smile as the others, the same long hair. She has been changed. It was too good to last.

The final image is in a cosmetic ad. Naomi's complexion has been bleached white by computer. This pale Naomi looks like any other pretty girl. What makes her truly beautiful has been erased.

It is over 14 years since I saw her for the first time, yet it feels like I am back at that moment, on a cold Christmas morning in the late 50s, when there was nothing attractive about a black girl.

We are born what we are born, it's the lottery of life. You make the best of what you have and get on with it. But just imagine yourself in a world in which so little reflects you, so little reflects your daughter, so little will reflect your daughter's daughter.

In Shakespeare's play, Berowne's reply to his king is a defence not only of his dark-skinned lover but of all dark-skinned women: "Is ebony like her? Oh wood divine!"

 Bonnie Greer will appear at the Spit-Lit literary festival, Spitalfields, London E1 on Sunday.

webTitle: Establishment men primed for main event

fields.headline: Establishment men primed for main event
fields.standfirst:
After Super Tuesday Al Gore and George W Bush will make formidable opponents in race for the White House

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Mr Gore and Mr Bush reached this week's triumphs by different routes. Mr Gore began as an unimpressive and even vulnerable Democratic frontrunner but became stronger and infinitely more effective as the campaign moved towards his Super Tuesday obliteration of Bill Bradley.
fields.body:
Mr Gore and Mr Bush reached this week's triumphs by different routes. Mr Gore began as an unimpressive and even vulnerable Democratic frontrunner but became stronger and infinitely more effective as the campaign moved towards his Super Tuesday obliteration of Bill Bradley.

Mr Bush, on the other hand, began as a seemingly irresistible Republican candidate with good positioning and stupendous resources, but reached this week's trouncing of John McCain only after big political and campaign costs. He is thought to have spent $60m (£36.5m), compared with Mr Gore's less than $40m.

The contrast between the winners' two campaigns is striking. Mr Bradley's threat peaked in late 1999, and although he and Mr Gore occasionally turned nasty in their televised debates earlier this year - and relations between the two men grew testy in private - their contest mostly remained within bounds.

Moreover, between New Hampshire and Super Tuesday, the Democratic rivals did not have to face a single primary contest. The Gore-Bradley contest was conducted at a distance, and with the polls showing the New Jersey senator slipping steadily out of contention. The final exchanges of the Democratic battle have been positively gentlemanly.

By contrast, Mr Bush and Mr McCain faced a succession of battles, which produced a vintage rollercoaster contest which was as closely fought as anything the Republican party has seen in a quarter of a century.

The Bush-McCain battle started out lighthearted but became increasingly intemperate in public and ruthlessly underhand in private. The threat to Mr Bush from the Arizona senator only became truly apparent with his win in New Hampshire - less than six weeks ago.

From then until now, both sides ploughed money into angry television ads and the Bush camp, in particular, seemed ready to enlist - or turn a blind eye to - any attack dog ready to take the field against Mr McCain.

Mr Bush has benefited from parallel efforts on his behalf by religious fundamentalists, anti-abortion lobbies, the tobacco industry and Texas financiers who underwrote last weekend's attack on Mr McCain's record on breast cancer and the environment.

Yet the reason why Mr Bush has won should not be mistaken. Though he certainly played dirty at times, he defeated Mr McCain because more Republicans in the overwhelming majority of the states believed he is their party's best chance of defeating Mr Gore in November. And, with his wins in big states like California, Ohio and New York, Mr Bush proved this week he has a claim which cannot be brushed aside.

Money remains the key to Mr Bush's campaign. By raising so much in the past, the Texas governor has been able to forgo the need to claim matching federal funding of his campaign - unlike Mr Gore or Mr McCain. This gives Mr Bush an advantage in the next phase of the battle, since he will be allowed to raise as much money as he can to fight the Democrats. Mr Gore, by contrast, will have to watch his wallet more cautiously.

On the Democratic side, Mr Gore has emerged as a truly formidable campaigner. The vice-president stumbled and bumbled on the campaign trail last year but the threat from Mr Bradley compelled him, last autumn, to shift gear and move his campaign home to Nashville. Since then he has not looked back.

Nevertheless, his victory was the direct and explicitly intended beneficiary of a reconfigured Super Tuesday primary system.

For years, the great fear of the vice-president's advisers had been that his path to the nomination would be bloody and lengthy. Accordingly, Mr Gore set out to stack the process against any potential rivals and to intimidate other contenders from venturing into the contest.

With Mr Gore's active involvement and support, the Democratic National Committee agreed in 1998 that the primary in California, the largest state in the union and the biggest must-win state for any presidential hopeful, should be moved up from its traditional position in June to the new date in March.

The idea was to make California and New York a citadel for Mr Gore, the establishment candidate. On Tuesday, the system worked perfectly for Mr Gore, who had made more than 60 visits to California during his seven years as vice-president, and who had sewn up the local party establishment there and in New York months ago.

Mr Gore won all 11 primary races on Super Tuesday, most of them by enormous margins. His win was a triumph for party machine politics of the highest order.

In the end, however, the central reason for Mr Gore's success is that no one in the Democratic party - and certainly not Mr Bradley - has been able to put together a compelling argument for the Democratic party to abandon either the politics or the politicians of the Clinton-Gore years. Mr Gore may not be the most thrilling candidate in the world, but he bestrides middle America on the issues which voters care about.

fields.headline: McCain ponders his next move
fields.standfirst: Defeated camp takes heart at high profile for funding reform
fields.trailText: Fading US presidential hopeful John McCain flew home yesterday to his family retreat at Sedona, Arizona, to consult aides about whether to continue his fight for the Republican nomination in the wake his heavy defeats in the key states of California, New York and Ohio on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Fading US presidential hopeful John McCain flew home yesterday to his family retreat at Sedona, Arizona, to consult aides about whether to continue his fight for the Republican nomination in the wake his heavy defeats in the key states of California, New York and Ohio on Tuesday.

Despite his failure to beat his rival George W Bush, he has consoled himself with the fact that his candidacy has thrust campaign financing and the role of the influential lobbyists on to the political agenda.

While he put on a brave face and thanked his Californian team on Tuesday night at what had been intended as a victory rally, his supporters conceded that his bid to be the first US president of the new millennium had almost certainly come to an end.

Mr McCain said at the rally that he would,"take a little time to reflect on the direction of our campaign", but the message was fairly clear - he has accepted that the crusade may be over, at least in terms of winning the Republican nomination.

His aides are adamant that he will not accept an invitation to stand for the Reform party and he is apparently lukewarm about accepting a post as Mr Bush's running mate, considering the abuse the Bush campaign has heaped on him. What is less clear is what effect his "crusade" for campaign reform will have.

Mr Bush has already started to borrow some of the phrases about such reform from his rival, but few imagine that the Texas governor is serious about major funding reform, since it was big-money backing that helped secure the Republican candidature.

What is clear is that Mr Bush and Al Gore will now attempt to seize the reformer's mantle, which was clearly a success with voters. Both will come up with some measure to address the way in which powerful lobbies fund politicians and expect returns on their investment.

webTitle: Search is on for running mates who'll keep up

fields.headline: Search is on for running mates who'll keep up
fields.trailText: John McCain doesn't want to be vice-president and neither does Bill Bradley, which is probably just as well because no one is likely to issue invitations to either of them.
fields.body:
John McCain doesn't want to be vice-president and neither does Bill Bradley, which is probably just as well because no one is likely to issue invitations to either of them.

Mr McCain's reasons were characteristically forthright: "The vice-president has two duties. The first is to inquire daily into the health of the president and the other is to attend the funerals of third world dictators."

There are other duties, of course, such as presiding over the US Senate and taking care of as much business as the president wishes. And the health of the president is not always good.

Lyndon B Johnson stepped up from vice-president to the top job when John F Kennedy was assassinated in 1963 and George Bush stepped in temporarily 19 years ago when Ronald Reagan was shot, even though the secretary of state, Alexander Haig, claimed he was in charge.

And, as Al Gore is on the point of proving yet again, if you are the number two and want to run for president you will not be denied the nomination by your party when the time comes.

Presidential candidates need to evaluate what their potential running mates bring to the party. Mr Gore is a southerner and so may be looking for a running mate from the North for balance. He has strong support from minority communities and so is considered unlikely to choose a black candidate. But his appeal to women voters is less persuasive than that of Bill Clinton and so he might choose a woman.

Neither he nor George W Bush needs to make a move until their party conventions in the summer and, in any case, they might ignore conventional calculations, as Arkansan Mr Clinton did in 1992 by choosing Mr Gore, from Tennessee. The ticket had narrow geographical appeal but it worked.

"I think the choice will be someone he's comfortable with and someone who doesn't make geographical sense," said Democratic party pollster Paul Maslin of Al Gore. "Maybe even someone who is older."

That could mean the governor of North Carolina, Jim Hunt, or Florida senator Bob Graham, both 63-year-old moderates with a reputation for steadiness. Mr Hunt is the most experienced governor in the US - he is finishing his 16th year in the job - and is admired for his education reforms, which might help to nullify one of Mr Bush's favourite campaign themes. Mr Graham could help in Florida, where Mr Bush's brother is governor.

Bill Richardson, the former ambassador to the United Nations, has several qualities that require consideration. His mother was born in Mexico, which could challenge Mr Bush's claim on Hispanics and would do no harm in the key state of California to say nothing of his home state of New Mexico, which is Republican. He was with Mr Gore at his Super Tuesday celebrations in Nashville.

Another figure with a track record is George Mitchell, the former senate majority leader who brokered Northern Ireland's Good Friday peace agreement. He wanted to be Mr Clinton's secretary of state, but lost out to Madeleine Albright.

She kept her distance on the question of impeaching Mr Clinton but is not regarded as a team player and questions about her husband's business deals with China might be a gift to the Bush camp.

Many, such as New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman, for instance, are pro-choice on abortion.

Elizabeth Dole's considerable experience means that she will be in Mr Bush's mind. She was seeking the Republican nomination until late last year, has served in cabinet posts, headed the US Red Cross, and her husband Bob - perhaps better remembered as an advocate of Viagra - ran for the White House last time. But she is a southerner.

Tom Ridge is thought by many to be the favourite to become Mr Bush's running mate after doing a good job as governor of Pennsylvania. But George Pataki, governor of New York, is known to want the job and will have done his chances no harm by ultimately delivering victory in the state primary for Mr Bush.

It is even possible that the Texas governor could grab a few headlines by choosing JC Watts, the only black Republican congressman.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: 'Gay abuse' policemen suspended Two Metropolitan police officers have been suspended following claims that a gay colleague was subjected to an 18-month campaign of victimisation, Scotland Yard said yesterday.
fields.body:
'Gay abuse' policemen suspended Two Metropolitan police officers have been suspended following claims that a gay colleague was subjected to an 18-month campaign of victimisation, Scotland Yard said yesterday.

The gay officer claimed he had been repeatedly assaulted, subjected to homophobic abuse and on one occasion had his underwear torn off by colleagues.

The victim complained to senior officers last month and the pair, based at a south London police station, were suspended on February 22 in the middle of a campaign by the force to stamp out homophobic crime.

Another five officers are under investigation but have not been suspended, a spokeswoman said.

The suspensions came a week after actress Lynda Bellingham launched the anti-crime initiative targeting domestic violence, hate mail, racist and homophobic crime. Ms Bellingham, whose ex-husband conducted nearly two years of abuse against her, opened the campaign saying: "No one should have to live in fear or feel that they are alone. I would urge any victim to come forward."

Dome offers half price evenings The Millennium Dome is to do away with its bewildering "double days" in summer and introduce half-price tickets for midweek evening visits.

The chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, hopes the new measures will help him squeeze 45,000 people a day into the Greenwich attraction, with the dome open from 9am to 11pm on Fridays, Saturdays and bank holidays.

Originally, two sessions a day were planned over the summer months to make the most of the long evenings, but many in the leisure industry dismissed the arrangements as confusing and impractical.

Now the former Disneyland executive, who took over from Jennie Page, is instead offering a £10 evening ticket from Sundays to Thursdays from April 1. In addition, there will be a 20% discount for second-time visitors.

The changes come as timed tickets are having to be introduced to cut down the 90-minute queues for the dome's body zone. Children on free school trips, however, who have been barred from the zone, will now be allowed inside, though they will still be kept away from the dome's two other popular attractions, the play and rest zones.

Mr Gerbeau also announced a new "spectacular" last act to the millennium show, which is staged in the dome's central area, and which has been one of the few unqualified successes.

After a disappointing January, attendances have risen dramatically to top 500,000 in February and the New Millennium Experience Company is confident of reaching its 10m visitors target. - Fiachra Gibbons

Night lights 'no danger to eyesight' Night lights will not make your baby nearsighted, according to new research published today in Nature.

The research from Ohio in the US is in dramatic contrast to research from Pennsylvania 10 months ago, which found that leaving the light on in the nursery increased the risk of myopia up to fivefold.

Karla Zadnik, an optometrist at Ohio state university at Columbus studied 1,220 children and could find no link between a light on in the bedroom at night in the first two years of life, and the development later on of nearsightedness.

It did not matter if the child slept in a room with a dim bedside light, a 100 watt bulb blazing overhead, or complete darkness. She found only one link: children who were nearsighted were more likely to have nearsighted parents.

The conclusion: maybe heredity had something to do with it.

Her results are supported in Nature by a second team at the New England college of optometry in Boston, who questioned the parents of 213 children about their sleeping habits as babies. Once again, those who slept in the dark were just as likely to be myopic as those who had been given night lights. There were no near-sighted children among the small group that slept with the light on all the time.

But the matter may not end there. Eyes develop rapidly in the first two years of life. Richard Stone and a colleague at Pennsylvania university's school of medicine, who triggered the original alarm about night lights and nearsightedness, point out in the same journal that it is still possible that sleeping with a light on may accelerate the onset or provoke the condition in a small group of children predisposed to severe myopia. - Tim Radford

Residents close doors on toxic gas People living near a chemical factory in Runcorn, Cheshire, were told to stay indoors for three hours yesterday after toxic gas seeped out of a storage container.

The alarm was raised at the ICI Rock Savage plant after a ton of hydrogen chloride gas spilled out of a container owned by European Vinyls Corporation. Three people were taken to hospital with breathing difficulties.

Residents in the nearby villages, Weston and Weston Point, heard a whooshing or popping noise when the gas started to leak. They had to stay inside with doors and windows closed while it dispersed.

Traffic on the M56 was brought to a standstill because a slip road was closed while emergency services cleaned up the area.

John Redmond, a spokesman for Cheshire fire brigade, said hydrogen chloride could be very dangerous and could kill people in high concentrations, but the leak did not pose a danger. A curtain of water jets had been used by the fire brigade to minimise the leak.

Alan Mercer, manager of a nearby filling station, said he heard a loud pop from the chemical plant and saw a cloud of gas moving towards Weston village. "It must have been some sort of acid because we could feel it burning our faces slightly," he said. "This is certainly the worst incident we have had from the works for a long, long time."

Mike Price, from the Weston residents' action group, said: "I could see a cloud of vapour, which looked like steam, spread across the village."

Staff were allowed to return to the site after the area was declared safe.

European Vinyls Corporation is Europe's biggest producer of PVC. Last month, 16 families were forced to relocate after traces of chemicals from the ICI site were found in their homes. - Helen Carter

Sun pays damages to school head A headteacher alleged to have humiliated her former deputy by tricking him into presenting a chocolate penis to a retired female colleague, yesterday accepted "substantial" libel damages at the high court in London.

Joan Morris, head of Sageston primary school near Tenby, Pembrokshire, since 1991, who sued over articles in the Sun in 1998 reporting allegations made against her by her former deputy head, also received an "unqualified apology" and legal costs.

Her counsel, Catrin Evans, told Mr Justice Morland that the newspaper reported the allegations that she had carried out a "vicious and sustained campaign against him in which she had bullied and tormented him over a period of a year, causing him to suffer a nervous breakdown and give up teaching".

Ms Evans said the Sun also reported that the former deputy had claimed to have been humiliated by Mrs Morris allegedly "tricking him into presenting a chocolate penis to an unsuspecting retired lady colleague at a party".

Mrs Morris was also accused of abusing her position as head by ensuring he was isolated from other staff.

Ms Evans told the judge: "These allegations are extremely serious ones to level at a headteacher and - if true - would clearly mean the claimant was unfit to continue in her post."

The defendant, News Group Newspapers Ltd, publisher of the Sun, had published the allegations as if they were the unchallenged truth and at no time contacted Mrs Morris to ask for her comment, counsel said.

Ms Evans said Mrs Morris "never bullied, tormented or carried out a campaign against her deputy who appeared unable to cope with the pressure of his job and ultimately retired from Sageston on grounds of ill health".

She continued to "enjoy the support of the teachers, parents and governors at Sageston".

News Group Newspapers accepted that the allegations were without foundation.

webTitle: Gore and Bush square up for battle

fields.headline: Gore and Bush square up for battle
fields.standfirst:
Presidential campaign already under way after rivals crushed


The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Fresh from decisive victories over their party opponents in this week's Super Tuesday primary contests, Al Gore and George W Bush shifted decisively into presidential election mode yesterday, beginning an eight-month battle for the hearts and minds of middle America in the race to succeed Bill Clinton.
fields.body:
Fresh from decisive victories over their party opponents in this week's Super Tuesday primary contests, Al Gore and George W Bush shifted decisively into presidential election mode yesterday, beginning an eight-month battle for the hearts and minds of middle America in the race to succeed Bill Clinton.

With Bill Bradley expected to pull out of the Democratic contest today and John McCain consulting colleagues about whether to fight on in the Republican race, Mr Gore and Mr Bush lost no time in positioning themselves for the general election in November.

Mr Bush abruptly softened the tone of his Republican campaign by quickly emphasising the education issue and stressing his racial inclusiveness in victory remarks in Texas after his big win over Mr McCain on Tuesday.

Meanwhile Mr Gore told supporters in Tennessee that he was the "mainstream candidate" and pointed to the economy, gun control and a pro-choice stance on abortion as key issues in his emerging contest with Mr Bush.

The abruptness of the change of tone and direction in the campaign reflects the decisive quality of the Super Tuesday results, in which 11 states held presidential primaries for both parties, with a further five states holding caucuses for one or both parties. The overwhelming wins for the two frontrunners mean that the primary dogfight, in which the candidates have spent nearly $200m, could in effect be finished this week.

Mr Gore was the undisputed big winner of the night, defeating Mr Bradley in every contest from coast to coast. The New Jersey senator failed to get within 10 percentage points of the vice-president in any contest, and was crushed in New York and California, the night's biggest prizes, as well as in his home state of Missouri.

"He won. I lost," Mr Bradley confessed in a speech to supporters in New York late on Tuesday, and aides confirmed yesterday that Mr Bradley will today withdraw from the contest and endorse Mr Gore, a move that has fanned speculation that the erstwhile challenger may be in the running for the vice-presidential slot on the Democratic ticket.

On the Republican side, Mr Bush stopped Mr McCain nearly as comprehensively. The Arizona senator won four New England states on Tuesday - though failing to pick up the ancestral Bush holiday home state of Maine - but he fell emphatically short in each of the three key states, California, Ohio and New York, in which he had counted on winning at least one big victory. The ease of Mr Bush's win, combined with the daunting arithmetic for Mr McCain of the battle for delegates in remaining states, led to widespread speculation yesterday that the Republican contest may also soon be over.

"We may meet again in future primaries," Mr McCain said of his rival in post-election remarks in Hollywood, a remark that suggests the senator now sees the writing on the wall. Mr McCain spent yesterday closeted with family and close advisers on his ranch north of Phoenix as he weighed his options. Senior aides were reported to be divided about whether to stay in the contest, although the balance of power seemed to favour withdrawal.

Mr Bush, meanwhile, took time in Austin yesterday to cast an absentee vote for himself in next week's Texas primary, which looks now like being more of a formality than ever. After sitting at a voting booth and putting on glasses to mark the ballot paper, Mr Bush said "I'm ready" for the contest with Mr Gore.

The Texas governor signalled a future line of attack on Mr Gore, dubbing him "an agent of Washington" and a partner in an administration that had set the wrong tone for America. Mr Bush said he wanted to reach out to Mr McCain's supporters and described the bruising primary contests as a helpful experience to his candidacy. "People saw I could get whipped and bounce back," Mr Bush told reporters. "I feel battle-tested."

Mr Gore went on television yesterday to call for the general election to be a contest of "ideas and not insults". He lost no time in challenging Mr Bush to set aside his millions of campaign dollars and agree to a mutual ban on TV advertising in the forthcoming battle. The two men should conduct two televised debates each week, Mr Gore proposed.

Officially, the presidential election campaign does not begin until after the party coventions in July and August - at which the vice-presidential nominees are also agreed - with formal campaigning between early September and election day on November 7.

In practice, however, the Gore-Bush campaign began yesterday, with both men well aware that in 1996 Mr Clinton used this period to establish an irreversible advantage over Senator Bob Dole.

webTitle: Film star provokes row in Ballymena

fields.headline: Film star provokes row in Ballymena
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: When James Currie, the mayor of Ballymena, pondered who should receive the freedom of his borough, he could think of no more famous son than the Oscar nominee Liam Neeson.
fields.body:
When James Currie, the mayor of Ballymena, pondered who should receive the freedom of his borough, he could think of no more famous son than the Oscar nominee Liam Neeson.

But the Democratic Unionist party believed it had a more fitting candidate - Ian Paisley.

The DUP happily conceded that its leader's finest performances were of a limited range, but it was convinced no one said "No" better, or more often.

Who could forget his role in the 1964 production Tear Down the Flag, an epic leading to the removal of an Irish tricolour illegally displayed in a Belfast shop front? Riots ensued.

All remember his part in 1966's Not in My Back Yard, hurling snowballs at the Irish premier Sean Lamass when he came to Northern Ireland.

DUP councillors in the Co Antrim borough which Mr Paisley represents in Westminster, believe Neeson's appearances in Star Wars and Schindler's List pale in comparison. They particularly disliked his role as the eponymous IRA leader in the film Michael Collins.

The DUP is unhappy that Neeson has been honoured because of comments he made in a US interview last year.

Neeson, 48, a Roman Catholic, said he felt like a second-class citizen in the predominantly Protestant town and that he was forced to stay indoors for the annual July 12 celebrations, when loyalists mark the victory of King William of Orange over King James II at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690.

The festival, he said, commemorated "some bloody obscure war where some bloody Catholic king was defeated by some bloody Dutch king who was Protestant".

The Ulster Unionist, Willie Wright, was also angered, saying he had been poor like Neeson. "I don't go about with a big chip on my shoulder, denigrating the community I was brought up in," he added.

fields.standfirst: Appeal court judges order landowner to hand over £200,000 farm and £100,000 to manager cut out of will after friendship soured
fields.trailText: A landowner who sacked and disinherited a farm manager after 42 years of service was yesterday ordered by the appeal court to give his former employee a farm worth £200,000, and £100,000 compensation.
fields.body:
A landowner who sacked and disinherited a farm manager after 42 years of service was yesterday ordered by the appeal court to give his former employee a farm worth £200,000, and £100,000 compensation.

Three appeal court judges made the ruling after hearing that tenant farmer Geoffrey Gillett, 59, had been cut out of the will of his employer, Kenneth Holt, after he became "obsessed" by a 20-year-old man and changed his will to leave him everything.

Mr Gillett claimed there had been "irrevocable promises" made to him that he would inherit the farm where he had worked since he was 16.

On seven occasions between 1964 and 1989 Mr Holt said that Mr Gillett, who is married with two children, would inherit the entire estate at Baumber, Lincolnshire. In 1986 he was named as the sole beneficiary of Mr Holt's will.

In 1992, however, Mr Holt, 85, met trainee solicitor David Wood, then aged 20, on a salmon fishing trip in Scotland and became obsessed by him. When Mr Wood moved in with Mr Holt at the Limes, the main house on the estate, the relationship between landowner and manager began to sour.

Three years later Mr Gillett received a letter from solicitors acting for his employer informing him that he had been dismissed and written out of Mr Holt's will in favour of the younger man.

Mr Wood, now working for the solicitors, also served Mr Gillett with a notice to quit a farmhouse called the Beeches where he had lived for 20 years. Mr Holt also instigated a police investigation into alleged dishonesty by Mr Gillett but no charges were ever brought.

In 1998 Mr Justice Carnwath ruled that although Mr Holt had made promises, Mr Gillett and his wife, Sally, should have known that he might one day change his mind.

But in an unprecedented ruling the appeal court judges reversed that judgment yesterday after a three-day appeal. Delivering the ruling, Lord Justice Robert Walker said Mr Holt's assurances were "repeated over a long period" and his promises were "completely unambiguous". He added that Mr Gillett had "an exceptionally strong claim on Mr Holt's conscience".

Mr Gillett was awarded the freehold to the Beeches, which includes the farmhouse and 103 acres, and £100,000 "to compensate for the exclusion ... from the rest of the farming business."

The ruling is the first time the doctrine of proprietary estoppel, whereby a sum is awarded to remedy an inequity caused by application of strict law, has been made with both parties still alive. It is also the first time a beneficiary has received some payment before the death of a benefactor.

After the ruling Mr Gillett said he was delighted with the result: "Finally there is recognition of the fact that I devoted the best years of my life to Mr Holt and his farm and did everything which I could do to provide him with the support of a close and loving family which he so plainly lacked."

"We had a great relationship with Mr Holt, he came for Christmas lunch with us every year for 30 years, but we've not spoken since 1995. That is one of the great pities of the whole thing."

The court heard that Mr Wood is now the owner of the Limes, which has been valued at £1.25m, along with cottages, another farm and hundreds of acres of land.

Mr Holt's fortune derived from his grandfather's shipping business, and he began farming in Lincolnshire in 1936 using proceeds from an £8m trust fund.

He first met Mr Gillett in 1952 when the latter was a 12-year-old part-time caddy at a local golf club, and a friendship developed between the two.

When Mr Gillett was 15 Mr Holt suggested that he leave school and work on the farm, saying he would pay for him to attend agriculture college. Mr Gillett left school the following year and moved in at the Limes.

He never went to college as Mr Holt believed he would learn more on the farm, but gradually assumed more responsibility for the day-to-day workings of the farm. At one stage Mr Holt, who was single, even suggested adopting Mr Gillett in order to give him a right of succession to the farm.

The pair regularly went shooting, played golf and went speedboat racing, but Mr Gillett was largely excluded from Mr Holt's fishing trips to Scotland. On one such trip Mr Holt met Mr Wood.

webTitle: Model claims cosmetic surgery cost chance to be millionaire

fields.headline: Model claims cosmetic surgery cost chance to be millionaire
fields.trailText: A former model believed he was set to become a millionaire until liposuction ruined his looks, a court heard yesterday. Mark Russell, 35, had liposuction performed on his face in January 1989, six months after leaving his job as a labourer in a Manchester abattoir to become a full-time model.
fields.body:
A former model believed he was set to become a millionaire until liposuction ruined his looks, a court heard yesterday. Mark Russell, 35, had liposuction performed on his face in January 1989, six months after leaving his job as a labourer in a Manchester abattoir to become a full-time model.

He went to the Harley Medical Centre in Harley Street, London, after seeing an advertisement in Vogue. Instead of achieving a more angular facial appearance, Mr Russell claims he developed hollows on either side of his nose, mouth and chin and that his jaw bone was placed out of alignment.

Mr Russell, originally from Manchester but now living in Leeds, is suing Harley Medical Centre Ltd and the doctor who performed the operation, Alan Kingdon, for £2m. They both deny liability.

"As a male model, I thought I was going to be a millionaire," he told Mr Justice Wright at the high court in London.

Mr Russell, a father of one, is now setting up a cleaning business with cash help from a close friend, the former Manchester United and England soccer star Lee Sharpe.

Under cross-examination yesterday, Mr Russell denied pursuing the action in a bid to get rich. Defence counsel Christina Lambert asked Mr Russell why he had only produced eight rejection letters when he claimed to have applied for between 70 and 80 jobs in the early 1990s when his modelling career dried up. "I would have thought I could come up with more of them," Mr Russell replied.

Mr Russell has told the court he was working five days a week doing camera shoots around London and the North of England until the cosmetic surgery.

"It was to enable him to retain the look that he believed to be marketable at the time in the late 80s," his barrister, Ernest Armitage QC, told the court on Tuesday.

"The fact was that he recognised that he had a tendency, as we all do, to gain weight.

"He was a man who had moved from barrow boy to a rather higher life... someone who was out and about on the town and going to London."

The case continues.

webTitle: Well preserved Honour for medical museum

fields.headline: Well preserved Honour for medical museum
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most remarkable medical museums has been designated a collection of outstanding national importance by the museums and galleries commission.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,    Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
One of Britain's most remarkable medical museums has been designated a collection of outstanding national importance by the museums and galleries commission.

The Hunterian museum, belonging to the Royal College of Surgeons, in London houses over 3,000 exhibits, including the skeleton of Charles Byrne, a 7ft 8in Irishman who claimed to be the tallest man in the world, a coachman's leg and animals in alcohol.

Other items in the collection certainly came from grave robbers, who provided surgeons with bodies for dissection when the only legitimate source was unclaimed bodies of paupers or executed criminals.

The collection was founded by John Hunter, a brilliant 18th century surgeon and scientist. He spent a staggering £75,000 collecting 13,000 specimens, many of which he personally prepared.

The museum's curator, Simon Chaplin, said Hunter was as interested in pigeons, sparrows and moles as the human skeleton. A sparrow in the collection, preserved in alcohol, still has a crop full of the fatal grain with which the surgeon presumably lured it.

After Hunter's death in 1793 the government bought the collection and gave it to the Royal College of Surgeons. The museum was hit by a bomb in 1941, but 3,000 of Hunter's specimens remained undamaged.

fields.headline: £2.5m for brain damage victim
fields.trailText: A woman who was brain damaged because a routine blood test was not carried out within days of her birth at St Mary's hospital, Oldham, was awarded £2.5m compensation at Manchester high court yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who was brain damaged because a routine blood test was not carried out within days of her birth at St Mary's hospital, Oldham, was awarded £2.5m compensation at Manchester high court yesterday.

Sonja Taylor, now 28, was born with phenylketonuria - an inherited enzyme deficiency which could have been diagnosed by a blood test.

If it the test had been carried out, the condition could have been treated by a change of diet.

But because the disorder was not diagnosed, she developed severe learning difficulties, behavioural problems and epilepsy.

Ms Taylor, of Oldham, Greater Manchester, was finally diagnosed when she was two years old.

Oldham health authority admitted negligence and agreed the £2.5m out of court payment.

Her father, Alan Taylor, said: "This money will enable Sonja to have the care she needs for the rest of her life.

"For many years, we were too busy coping with Sonja to think about anything else. Then we started to think about how she would be able to cope in the future.

"The money may seem like a lot, but it is basic calculations of the kind of care she will need."

He said the family was angry that the test had not been carried out and the problem found by the hospital at the time of the birth.

webTitle: Minister admits school funds system indefensible

fields.headline: Minister admits school funds system indefensible
fields.trailText: The government admitted yesterday that its system for funding state schools was "indefensible", leading to huge disparities in class sizes and standard of service for children in England.
fields.body:
The government admitted yesterday that its system for funding state schools was "indefensible", leading to huge disparities in class sizes and standard of service for children in England.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said the way money was parcelled out to local education authorities was "old-fashioned and needs to be brought up to date".

There was no reason for a difference of hundreds of pounds a year in the cost of education for children in neighbouring counties with a similar social complexion. "It is indefensible ... David Blunkett and I want change and that is what we will be working for in government," she said.

Mr Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, rejected the arguments made in the Schools in Crisis series by Nick Davies in the Guardian this week, casting doubt on the government's claims to be increasing education spending by £19bn over three years. Mr Blunkett's reply to the articles will be published in the Guardian shortly.

But Ms Morris, his deputy, accepted the persistent criticism of headteachers' leaders that the distribution of money to schools was unfair.

In January the Secondary Heads Association complained that a state primary pupil in the London borough of Kensington and Chelsea was being provided with education worth £2,582 a year, while only £1,464 was being spent on a child of the same age in a state school in Derby.

At secondary school, spending varied between £3,380 in Kensington and Chelsea and £2,014 in Bradford.

Ms Morris said: "No MP has come to me and said his local education authority gets too much. When we tried to make a change last year, we found for the first time that lobbies were grouped regionally."

Her remarks lifted the veil on a battle that is understood to be raging between Mr Blunkett's education department and John Prescott's department of the environment, transport and the regions, which is preparing a green paper on reform of local government finance.

Mr Blunkett, backed by headteachers, wants a basic cash entitlement for every pupil in England - a minimum sum that each education authority would be expected to provide, adjusted for a child's age and an area's needs.

Mr Prescott, backed by the local authorities, is understood to be defending the more traditional approach of giving councils freedom to switch spending between services.

DfEE sources said the current system advantaged London and the south-east and did not reflect differences in local needs and costs.

Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, said in his annual report: "We have a national curriculum and national expectations of how standards should rise. We do not, as yet, have a transparent and educationally defensible mechanism for the equitable devolution of resources from central government to LEAs and from LEAs to schools. We should."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "The present system is grossly unfair to pupils in many parts of the country who are in larger classes, using fewer text books and less equipment than comparable pupils elsewhere."

 Mr Woodhead has played down the government's warning that secondary schools failing to get 15% of pupils through five good GCSE passes by 2003 would be ripe for closure.

"The target is the target, but it doesn't mean that any school not meeting it is willy-nilly going to be classed as a failing school," he said.

Michael Barber, head of the education department's standards unit, wrote to schools with a low GCSE pass rate reassuring them that they were not on a hit list for closure. This followed reports that a newly-appointed headteacher at Westgate school in Newcastle upon Tyne decided not to take up the post after the school was named in some newspapers as a likely victim of the policy.

webTitle: Bond star Charles Gray dies at

fields.headline: Bond star Charles Gray dies at
fields.trailText: The actor Charles Gray, whose fine line in cads, upper crust crooks and grotesques took him from playing James Bond's arch enemy Blofeld to cult immortality in the Rocky Horror Show, has died aged 71.
fields.body:
The actor Charles Gray, whose fine line in cads, upper crust crooks and grotesques took him from playing James Bond's arch enemy Blofeld to cult immortality in the Rocky Horror Show, has died aged 71.

Gray was one of the busiest British character actors in the business. His last roles, in the TV series Longitude and the film The Tichborne Claimant, were typical of his long line of lip-curling baddies.

His take on Blofeld, the evil genius bent on world domination in the Bond film Diamonds Are Forever, became an icon of popular culture.

His equally unpleasant criminologist in the film version of the Rocky Horror Show only strengthened his cult status.

But it was as a serious actor and Royal Shakespeare Company stalwart that he would have preferred to be remembered. Gray, who died on Tuesday, worked on over 80 films, but regarded many as merely jobs to pay the mortgage.

fields.headline: New talks on Ulster impasse
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and the Irish foreign affairs minister, Brian Cowen, yesterday attempted to revive the stalled peace process in Northern Ireland, bringing all the pro-Good Friday agreement parties together for their first round-table meeting since direct rule from Westminster was restored four weeks ago.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and the Irish foreign affairs minister, Brian Cowen, yesterday attempted to revive the stalled peace process in Northern Ireland, bringing all the pro-Good Friday agreement parties together for their first round-table meeting since direct rule from Westminster was restored four weeks ago.

The meeting followed bi-lateral meetings between the governments and individual parties. It served only to underline the gulf between Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein over arms decommissioning.

James Steinberg, US deputy national security adviser, returned to Washington after a two-day visit to Belfast. He will advise President Clinton ahead of next week's St Patrick's Day celebrations at the White House, to be at tended by all Northern Ireland's leading politicians.

Mr Steinberg said he was confident the parties remained committed to the agreement.

President Clinton is expected to make a speech on Northern Ireland next week reminding the main players of their responsibilities, and he will host a series of meetings to foster rapprochement.

The British and Irish governments, who were divided over Mr Mandleson's decision to suspend the fledgling institutions of government after only 72 days, still appear to have no clear strategy. But there is speculation that they will soon attempt to redefine the decommissioning issue, seeking to encourage the IRA to engage in concrete confidence building measures. The Irish junior foreign affairs minister, Liz O'Donnell, has indicated she would accept an extension to the May 22 deadline for resolution of the issue.

One important development is the virtual ending of IRA punishment attacks since Sinn Fein condemned them during ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the agreement in November. President Clinton is keen to secure the return of devolution before his departure from the White House next January. His vice president, Al Gore, has underlined the peace process would be a major objective of his presidency, and it is thought Mr Mitchell may be his running mate if he secures the Democratic nomination.

The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble is demanding a second formal review of the agreement. Sinn Fein is opposed, and it is expected the definition of the forthcoming negotiations will be fudged.

webTitle: Woman in coma shows signs of life after fight to allow her to die

fields.headline: Woman in coma shows signs of life after fight to allow her to die
fields.trailText: A woman in a coma whose husband was prepared to go to the House of Lords to win the right to allow her to die has started to show signs of life.
fields.body:
A woman in a coma whose husband was prepared to go to the House of Lords to win the right to allow her to die has started to show signs of life.

Lorraine Lane, 43, had been in a persistent vegetative state since she suffered a stroke last February. Her husband Neil had been campaigning to have her food, water and medication withdrawn and had applied for a high court order.

But after tests ordered as part of the legal action, Mrs Lane showed signs of life - by squeezing her husband's hand and occasionally moving her feet. She also showed awareness of her surroundings and tests at the North Staffordshire hospital in Stoke-on-Trent found evidence of electrical impulses in her brain.

Doctors said that Mrs Lane is now minimally aware, which is less severe than a persistent vegetative state.

Her husband, of Loggerheads, near Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, is abandoning his campaign.

"I still think Lorraine would want to die, but it is harder now," he said. "I could not live with the thought of Lorraine being aware of what is going on and being effectively starved to death."

He said the improvement in his wife's condition did not give him hope that she would get better. "She is condemned to exist in a severely disabled condition with physical paralysis down her right-hand side," he said.

Keith Andrews, medical director of the Royal hospital for neurodisability, in London, said that in the minimally conscious state patients showed consistent responses but had not reached the level where there was evidence of thought.

There are a handful of cases of patients coming out of a persistent vegetative state after between one and five years - but the chance of a later recovery is thought to be less than 0.0001%.

Doctors said that Mrs Lane is now minimally aware, which is less severe than a persistent vegetative state. Her husband, of Loggerheads, near Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, is abandoning his campaign. "I still think Lorraine would want to die, but it is harder now," he said. "I could not live with the thought of Lorraine being aware of what is going on and being effectively starved to death." He said the improvement in his wife's condition did not give him hope that she would get better. "She is condemned to exist in a severely disabled condition with physical paralysis down her right-hand side," he said. Keith Andrews, medical director of the Royal hospital for neurodisability, in London, said that in the minimally conscious state patients showed consistent responses but had not reached the level where there was evidence of thought. There are a handful of cases of patients coming out of a persistent vegetative state after between one and five years - but the chance of a later recovery is thought to be less than 0.0001%.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Scouts dismiss group leaders
The Scout Association has dismissed the two leaders of an expedition to Snowdon last October during which 10-year-old Jonathan Attwell died.
fields.body:
Scouts dismiss group leaders
The Scout Association has dismissed the two leaders of an expedition to Snowdon last October during which 10-year-old Jonathan Attwell died.

Peter Findlay and Matthew Wilson, the leaders of Bristol's 19th Kingswood scout group, were told by the Scout Association that their warrants had been withdrawn.

The Scout Association is being sued for negligence by Jonathan's parents.

Dead dolphins washed up
Ten dead dolphins have been found on Guernsey beaches this week, coinciding with the European offshore fisheries season when large trawlers go after mackerel and pilchard. Some dolphins were tangled in fishing gear.

A post mortem is being carried out on one of the dolphins. - Paul Brown

Schoolboy's arsenal
A 12-year-old boy has been cautioned by police after taking a mini-arsenal of weapons to school, it was confirmed yesterday.

The pupil was carrying two air pistols, a knife and a slingshot at Todmorden high school in West Yorkshire, head teacher Ed Collins said. The boy has been excluded from school.

Campaigner gets £10,000
An animal rights campaigner has received £10,000 in compensation plus legal costs from Gloucestershire constabulary in an out-of-court settlement after she was hit with CS spray during a demonstration against live animal exports in May 1997.

Sylvia O'Brien of Birmingham had brought a civil claim for unlawful arrest, false imprisonment, assault and malicious prosecution, her solicitors said.

The constabulary has not admitted liability.

Pets' death due to tortoises
Two tortoises were being blamed for a fire which killed five gerbils at the home of the Rev Peter Worrall, in Hartlebury, Worcestershire, the fire service said yesterday. The tortoises, which were rescued by firefighters using breathing apparatus, knocked over a lamp used to warm them.

Sex play lands police in trouble
Fourteen police officers have been disciplined following allegations of sexual horseplay at their station, Norfolk police said yesterday.

webTitle: Sinn Fein fury as Irish police arrest IRA man who killed SAS officer

fields.headline: Sinn Fein fury as Irish police arrest IRA man who killed SAS officer
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Police in the Irish Republic yesterday arrested a leading IRA terrorist jailed in his absence 20 years ago for the murder in Belfast of SAS Captain Richard Westmacott.
fields.body:
Police in the Irish Republic yesterday arrested a leading IRA terrorist jailed in his absence 20 years ago for the murder in Belfast of SAS Captain Richard Westmacott.

Paul "Dingus" Magee, 52, is expected to face extradition proceedings when he appears at the supreme court in Dublin today. He belonged to the notorious M-60 gang, believed responsible for the murders of eight members of the security forces.

Magee, who later shot dead a British policeman in Yorkshire, was held in Tralee, Co Kerry, close to where another member of the M-60 gang, Angelo Fusco, was arrested in January. Fusco, 43, is currently in custody fighting extradition to Northern Ireland.

Magee's arrest threatened to spark a renewed political crisis. Sinn Fein, which was furious at Fusco's detention, was outraged. The leading Sinn Fein figure Martin Ferris, who is from Kerry and a friend of the men, accused the Irish government of colluding with the British. He called the move "absolutely disgraceful".

He said: "The government should end this incredible farce and release Paul Magee immediately. This has left many wondering if there are those in this state who are determined to destroy the Good Friday agreement."

Magee and Fusco were among seven IRA men who shot their way out of Crumlin Road jail as their murder trial drew to a close in June 1981. They were each sentenced two days later to life, with a recommendation that they serve a minimum 30 years. Magee, first jailed for five years in 1971 on firearms offences, was subsequently arrested with Fusco in the Irish Republic in 1982. Each was sentenced to 10 years for the jailbreak under special cross-border legislation.

They were served with warrants for their extradition just before completing their sentences, and each began a long legal battle to avoid being sent back to Northern Ireland. Both went on the run before the supreme court ruled against them.

Magee was subsequently jailed for the June 1992 murder of Glenn Goodman, 37, a special constable, and the attempted killing of his colleague, Sandy Kelly. He had been stopped during a routine car check in Yorkshire.

But he was repatriated two years ago to serve out his sen tence in the Irish Republic. He was freed just before Christmas under the early release scheme, a key plank of the Good Friday agreement. He has since been living openly in Tralee with his wife, Maria. They have four children.

Sinn Fein claimed last night he had travelled regularly to Northern Ireland to visit his family in west Belfast. It said it was incredible to attempt to extradite him, as the British authorities had already allowed him to move jurisdictions while a prisoner.

Sinn Fein also argued that he could have been served with extradition papers and rearrested when he was freed from Portlaoise prison three months ago. He would be freed in July under the agreement even if he were returned now.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | Analysis
fields.body:
New Zealanders smoke more marijuana per head than any other nation, but it's still illegal. In Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4), Julian Pettifer meets a newly elected Maori MP who wants the law changed. Nandor Tanczos acknowledges that most of the crop is grown in Maori areas, where it helps provide badly needed jobs and incomes. But profit margins depend on selling into the huge black market, which Maori leaders fear will be ruined by legalisation. Tanczos is trying hard to convince them otherwise.

Frances Cairncross launches the 30th anniversary season of Analysis (8.30pm, Radio 4) with a highly sceptical look at the state of the National Health Service. She is less concerned about day-to-day issues like waiting lists and post-code rationing than about the whole tottering structure. Taxpayers currently fork out £50 billion a year for the service but investigation shows an appalling managerial ignorance of what the cash is actually spent on.

fields.headline: Show some respect
fields.standfirst: Sex, drug and alcohol abuse and violent death. That's what you'd imagine soul music gave the world if you believed a new Channel 4 programme on the subject. What, asks  Paolo Hewitt, is the point of such shoddy treatment?
fields.trailText: Sex, drug and alcohol abuse and violent death. That's what you'd imagine soul music gave the world if you believed a new Channel 4 programme on the subject. What is the point of such shoddy treatment?
fields.body:
I can't help it, I love Otis Redding. That man's music has invaded my head and soul a million times and will undoubtedly do so again in the future. His oeuvre may be limited, but Otis was that rare singer, someone whose voice told you immediately of the man within. When I hear Otis I hear a warm, compassionate man. I hear a man not yet scarred by cynicism. It is one of the cruellest acts I know that he should have died at the age of 27 in a plane crash, an absolute tragedy that he was taken from us just as he was reaching his peak.

That year, 1967, Otis had heard The Beatles' Sgt Pepper and, like the rest of the world, he found himself transfixed and then ultimately inspired. His aim was to produce soul's answer to Lennon and McCartney's achievement. And he would do so through Stax Records, the only label that would have understood and then successfully realised such a brave and intriguing project. Otis's first move in this direction was to record his latest song, Dock Of The Bay. An example of the experimental impulse that was slowly growing inside him is the whistle that Otis breaks into as the song nears its conclusion. Amazed, nervous looks shoot around the recording studio. A soul record with whistling on it?

A week later, on December 10th, Otis Redding's private plane plunged into Lake Minona, Wisconsin. You will not learn any of this Redding history on this Saturday's Top Ten 60s Soul show. But, incredibly, you can watch Otis's body being pulled out of the river. The footage is stomach churning and I am mystified as to why it was included in a programme of such a light nature.

Surely those involved would never want to see a loved one of theirs exposed in such a manner on national television. So why display a man who took such great pride in his appearance in this manner. For the ratings? Surely not. Such footage makes for uneasy viewing, and anyway their programme is filled with enough drug stories to hook the casual viewer.

One can only conclude that whoever inserted such footage simply has no love or care for the subject. Of course, this is Saturday night TV and despite Channel Four's original remit to provide innovative intelligent television they too find themselves embroiled in a ratings war that is stripping television of its potential. You want music on television? Fine. Just as long as you insert as many salacious stories about the artists as you can. Oh, and don't forget to keep it simple. (I know for a fact that Four insisted that the All Back To Mine show insert subtitles under their footage: "This is Marvin Gaye. He is a singer. He was shot by his father").

This approach probably works when you're dealing with drug-addled megastars who are now in rehab and don't take themselves or their music too seriously (as in the same series' show on Stadium Rock a while ago). But no such remit exists here. A lot of the artists featured are dead. Few can complain. So we find out that Smokey Robinson was a crack addict in the 80s, and we hear of the drug and alcohol abuse that tore apart the fabulous Temptations and left just one original singer standing - yet we hear very little of the tribulations that touring in a segregated America cost these performers. Likewise, we hear nothing of the psychological scars caused by performers having to travel hundreds of miles, performing in front of huge crowds and then having to spend the whole night searching for an all-black café to eat in, and very little of the financial rip- offs and mistreatment they all suffered.

Now maybe I am taking the show too seriously but soul music is one of the greatest gifts America has given to us and I think it deserves a little bit more than its underbelly being used as a vehicle to gain advertising revenue. Soul is an amazing music, full of drama and emotion. As the show's presenter Smokey Robinson tells us, "On the surface it is glitter, glamour, sharp suits - underneath blood, guts and raw emotion."

Unfortunately, in Britain, despite it causing far more political change than, say, punk, soul music has always run second to rock's dominant culture. From the day 50s singer Ray Charles took some old Gospel tunes and added the Devil's words to them, Soul has brought people together, provided the soundtrack to black protest movements and given us records that are unparalleled in their musical genius.

Time and time again it has seen enthusiastic white boys adopt the form and use it as a springboard to much bigger success. But soul has never been resentful. It has just forged ahead. But when it sees one of its own being treated with such disrespect, soul gets enormously angry. Like the man said, all he ever wanted was a little respect. So give it to him.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which soap will see the biggest percentage increase in ratings during the teenage drama plots (over a period of six months from 13 March)?
fields.trailText: Which soap will see the biggest percentage increase in ratings during the teenage drama plots (over a period of six months from 13 March)?
fields.body:
Teenage crime in Brookside: 11/8

Male rape in Hollyoaks: 7/4

Teacher-pupil relations in EastEnders: 4/1

Teenager pregnancy in Coronation Street: 4/1

Soap fans love a scorching plot and with male rape, teenage pregnancy, teacher-pupil relationships and teenage crime in the offing, fans can look forward to more white-hot stories. We asked Ed Nicholson, of Ladbrokes, to analyse the benefits of these plots to each soap.

"Is it me or have the soaps become younger than ever? To seduce the young audience the plots are as racy as Michael Schumacher's Ferrari and ratings are set to shoot skywards", says Ed, adding that the stars themselves are barely out of kindergarten.

"Based on the fact that Brookside has been losing viewers, they must be favourites to see an increase in ratings over this period. Emily Shadwick grips us as the good girl turned bad", he says. An inside source has told Ed that there are more twists to come.

"Coronation Street is still at number one and has a regular riveted audience. Because of this the percentage increase is unlikely to be huge - but Sarah-Lou (Gail's daughter) being pregnant should still bring in the viewers."

Its handling of 13-year-old Sarah's one-night stand leading to pregnancy has been praised by Public Health Minister Yvette Cooper. "And with months to go it will certainly run and run and run", adds Ed.

"In an attempt to boost ratings, Hollyoaks has a late-night special dealing with a very unsafe subject matter - male rape."

"If you believe tabloid reports, most of the Di Marco family in EastEnders are set to disappear. But future plots centre around Nicky Di Marco developing a relationship with a schoolteacher. Now, call me psychic but I reckon this is why the Di Marco family leave. And peculiar as it sounds, people leaving the Square nearly always prompts viewers to tune in."

fields.headline: On the critical list
fields.trailText: ER | Trust Me: I'm A Doctor | Sex And The City | Children of Drugs
fields.body:
In all the years paramedics have burst through the doors of ER (C4) screaming "78-year-old-woman-with-perpendicular-lacerations-to-forehead-BP- 135-over-88-pulse-normal-CD-player-hyperallergenic", no one has once turned round and said "pardon?" Until now.

Alan Alda has begun to forget things. At first, it was just leaving his reading glasses in the fridge. But soon, it was leaving his reading glasses in a patient. Alda shrugged off such details, practicing a Bourbon-drenched healthcare learnt in the Korean War. At M*A*S*H, no one quibbled about an implement or two left in a patient.

The absurdities of ER are coming more and more to resemble the everyday realities of the NHS. Carter and Benton, once the lantern-jawed dream team who marched purposefully across wards in search of heart attacks to "paddle", now look tired and washed-out.

Alda's departure is the final nail in ER's coffin, a further step down the dreary road to Casualty-cloning. Alda is so good, it was embarrassing to see him cast in this increasingly poor medical drama. Last night, he made his excuses and left. ("I get confused, I've got Alzeiheimer's, you see"). With any luck, in six months, he won't remember a thing about it.

Trust Me: I'm A Doctor (BBC2) is one of those programmes that can't resist a punning subtitle. In this case, "Dr Phil Hammond's Search For The Holy Male". Hammond attempted to ingratiate himself with the audience through an incessant barrage of self-deprecation and irony. "If I'm to remain the world's sexiest TV doctor," he said, "I'll have to get my body in shape", pulling a measuring tape meekly round his unpleasant stomach.

"How do models achieve a body beautiful?", Hammond asked. "Er, by working hard in the gym" answered an incredulous body builder. Hammond reminded me of Jayne Middlemiss on the O-Zone, who last week asked vegan pop star Moby, "So, what do you eat?" "Dirt", he said. "Really!"

Asking Mr Universe if he was "biggerexic" (obsessed with muscle-building), Shaun Dinosaur Bulldog Davis sucked in his pecks and looked down at the small white blancmange of Hammond. "Well, sir. Rome wasn't built in a day."

Sex And The City (C4) was similarly fixated on muscle. Charlotte's boyfriend wanted her to talk dirty during sex, so over a lunch of air and salad, Carrie suggested "ah yeah, do it to me, c'mon, there, oh yes". In bed, however, Charlotte gilded the lily - or the male equivalent. "It's hard as a rock", she said. "And?" "And it's throbbing." "And?" "And it's big. It's a big, throbbing, hard, rock sausage."

Sex And The City is a lot harder and more rock sausage than its interchangable companion piece, Ally McBeal. Like Ally, male eligibility is based directly on money, and "money can make up for anything... even a small dick".

The woman who created Sex And The City complained recently that no one thinks she's as sexy as the actress who plays her in the series. This is like Stephen Hawking whingeing about Leonardo DiCaprio being cast to play him in the biopic of his life.

The show is marketed by C4 as the good-time-girls'-night-in, but the tenor is one of pathos. An endless succession of one-night stands and shoring-up male egos in bed is sad, and it's no surprise that every programme ends with Carrie standing alone in the street, the camera floating off over the buildings.

Children of Drugs (BBC1) resisted the punning subtitle in favour of the tasteless content. "In 1995, a single teenager collapses after taking ecstasy", the voice-over began, portentously. "Leah Betts' death was a turning point. It showed a new generation had arrived. The Children Of Drugs."

A couple of nights before this rubbish, ITV showed John Pilger's documentary about the effects of UN sanctions on Iraq. Here were also children of drugs, except these ones were dying due to Robin Cook refusing to send them (the Iraqis might use antibiotics to build chemical weapons).

One would imagine that Pilger's genuinely investigative film could once have been shown in the post-watershed slot now reserved for such voyeuristic piffle as Children Of Drugs, and the BBC would have been proud to show it. But I suppose that wouldn't be "sexy".

Charlotte's boyfriend wanted her to talk dirty during sex, so over a lunch of air and salad, Carrie suggested "ah yeah, do it to me, c'mon, there, oh yes". In bed, however, Charlotte gilded the lily - or the male equivalent. "It's hard as a rock", she said. "And?" "And it's throbbing." "And?" "And it's big. It's a big, throbbing, hard, rock sausage." Sex And The City is a lot harder and more rock sausage than its interchangable companion piece, Ally McBeal. Like Ally, male eligibility is based directly on money, and "money can make up for anything... even a small dick". The woman who created Sex And The City complained recently that no one thinks she's as sexy as the actress who plays her in the series. This is like Stephen Hawking whingeing about Leonardo DiCaprio being cast to play him in the biopic of his life. The show is marketed by C4 as the good-time-girls'-night-in, but the tenor is one of pathos. An endless succession of one-night stands and shoring-up male egos in bed is sad, and it's no surprise that every programme ends with Carrie standing alone in the street, the camera floating off over the buildings. Children of Drugs (BBC1) resisted the punning subtitle in favour of the tasteless content. "In 1995, a single teenager collapses after taking ecstasy", the voice-over began, portentously. "Leah Betts' death was a turning point. It showed a new generation had arrived. The Children Of Drugs." A couple of nights before this rubbish, ITV showed John Pilger's documentary about the effects of UN sanctions on Iraq. Here were also children of drugs, except these ones were dying due to Robin Cook refusing to send them (the Iraqis might use antibiotics to build chemical weapons). One would imagine that Pilger's genuinely investigative film could once have been shown in the post-watershed slot now reserved for such voyeuristic piffle as Children Of Drugs, and the BBC would have been proud to show it. But I suppose that wouldn't be "sexy".

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey, architecture correspondent
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey, architecture correspondent
fields.body:
Therefore in conclusion, to sum up, to wit and viz, ie, eg, etc... the last sentence of my Story Of Architecture for Dorling Kindersley sings across the screen as movingly as an aria through the lips of Callas. Hem hem. Finis. Finito.

Sorry; this is a long-winded phew! after a 0-100,000 word sprint in not so many months, and you must remember that there are times we authors (loves, darlings) need to let off steam. And worry about the sense (or nonsense) of what we've just handed in for approval by fierce, no-nonsense, books-printed-on-time publishers. Are we even sure that we've been the right person for the job? I do (honestly) know at least as much about the history of architecture as my old Observer's Book, but a man who wrote on oddly stained and lined schoolpaper from south east London has just told me that an article I wrote recently on the new Peckham Library and 150 years of the free public library in Britain was "vapid". Why (and don't say the quality of your prose, my dear, would make Cicero weep)? Because, intones my stain-making correspondent, I am a "New Labour lackey" and they, he says, are "vermin". The Nazi-inspired language aside (when are humans "vermin" except in speeches by Hitler, Himmler and crew?), I have never been either in the thrall or pay of New Labour or any party, government or organisation. My politics are, as I'm sure many of yours are, a mix of many instincts and ideas.

Perhaps, though, in the thrall and rush of writing so many words on pyramids and ziggurats, Post-this and Post-howsyourfather, lintels and Libeskind, Japan and Jakarta, I have lost my identity. Perhaps Strangely Stained Notepaper from Peckham is right: I am a secret Blairite. Do you smell a rat? My correspondent did.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Taming Of The Shrew | The Loneliness Of The Long Distance Runner | Farewell My Concubine | Wilde
fields.body:
The Taming Of The Shrew

(Franco Zeffirelli, 1967)

4pm, Sky Cinema

When it was released, the main lure of this opulent adaptation was for audiences to glimpse some of the fire between Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor. Any furore long since forgotten, it now appears a confident swagger through the tale that seems to know far more than it lets on. Bullish drunkard Petruchio (Burton) and spoiled, petulant Katharina (Taylor) chew up the screen in roles that are more well-sustained arguments than characters. Whether Burton managed to "tame" Taylor is still a matter of opinion.

The Loneliness Of The Long Distance Runner

(Tony Richardson, 1962)

10pm, FilmFour

Another sullen adaptation of an Alan Sillitoe novel; like Saturday Night And Sunday Morning the message is "Don't let the bastards grind you down". Whey-faced and scrawny Tom Courtenay (pictured) is just right as the Borstal boy persuaded by snooty governor Michael Redgrave to run in a cross-country race against the local public school, recalling his dismal past along the way. Black-and-white and dreary with it, but there is young James Bolam as Courtenay's fellow delinquent, a pair of most unlikely lads.

Farewell My Concubine

(Chen Kaige, 1993)

1.45am, FilmFour

Kaige's epic sweep of 50 years of traumatic Chinese history, viewed through the friendship of two Peking Opera stars. The ambivalent relationship between Leslie Cheung and Zhang Fengyi is battered by political events, by betrayal and suspicion; and mainly by the arrival of Gong Li, who, like the film, looks ravishing. It won the Palme D'Or at Cannes in 1993.

Wilde

(Brian Gilbert, 1997)

2.05am, Sky Premier

Absorbing, Julian Mitchell-scripted account of Oscar Wilde's relationship with Lord Alfred "Bosie" Douglas - played by the much feted, Oscar nominated Jude Law - and his subsequent imprisonment. Stephen Fry in the title role physically resembles Wilde and portrays the generous warmth behind the acute wit with touching pathos
