fields.headline: Why you need GM food
fields.standfirst: Sanjida O'Connell  on how to change a plant and change the health of millions
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell on how to change a plant and change the health of millions
fields.body:
Tony Blair's u-turn regarding genetically modified food may have less to do with deeply held convictions and scientific research, and more to do with political expediency. While there are many questions, and few answers about the safety of GM foods, some scientists are urging politicians not to throw the baby out with the bathwater.

Dean DellaPenna, from the university of Nevada, in Reno, has made a breakthrough in what he considers to be a positively healthy form of genetic engineering: he has created a plant that produces vitamin E in massive quantities.

Vitamin E, beloved of the Body Shop and slick women's magazines, is currently a fashionable vitamin with a fashionable role - it makes skin soft and "glowy" and quenches free radicals produced by polyunsaturated fatty acids.

The reality is rather more grim. The recommended daily amount of vitamin E is a bare minimum; 40% of women in the US receive less than two thirds of it. In the long term this mild deficiency can be chronic as the oxidative effect of free radicals builds up in the body, accelerating ageing and causing organs and tissues to deteriorate. A complete absence of vitamin E results in sterility.

New research indicates massive amounts of vitamin E (which we are unable to synthesise ourselves) can have highly beneficial effects. Men's RDA is 15 international units of vitamin E; women's is 12 (2 mg is the equivalent of 3 international units). One hundred IUs can reduce artherosclerosis and promote optimal health; four times this amount may prevent cancer, particularly prostrate cancer, and decreases the risk of heart disease by 40%.

Many of us expect to ingest our entire vitamin and mineral content in tablet form, and taking vitamin E naturally could be rather socially limiting. To eat the minimum amount required for optimal health - a hundred IUs - we would need to eat two and half kilos of spinach or almost a kilo of soya bean oil.

Vitamin E is the end product of a complex enzyme pathway occurring naturally in plants; it is also the sum of four different kinds of molecules called tocopherols that exist in alpha, beta, gamma, and delta forms.

Alpha is 10 times more effective than the others, but is found in limited quantities.

In green vegetables containing vitamin E there tend to be low total levels of tocopherols in the leaves, but a high overall level of alpha tocopherol. The opposite is found in seeds which have a high tocopherol content, but are low in the necessary alpha form. Gaining the right amount of vitamin E from plants may be tricky, but synthetic vitamin E is also problematic: it's derived from petrol and contains eight different molecular forms of these tocopherols, only one of which is the same as natural alpha tocopherol.

Dr DellaPenna was able to identify the genes for a key enzyme in the vitamin pathway, and insert these genes into bacteria to prove that it was possible to manufacture vitamin E by genetic manipulation. He cloned the genes and inserted them into arabidopsis - the first plant to have it's entire genome sequenced. Like plants that naturally produce high levels of vitamin E, arabidopsis produced alpha tocopherol in its leaves, and high levels of gamma in its seeds.

DellaPenna was able to induce the plant to convert gamma tocopherols to the more effective alpha form which has 10 times the amount of vitamin E activity.

Fifty grams of oil from arabidopsis seeds that were not genetically engineered would yield 7.5 IU - half a man's daily requirement. The genetically modified plant produced 75 IUs in the same amount of fat. Fifty grams of fat is the recommended daily maximum of fat one should eat, though few of us stick to those limits. Even eating a dangerously low amount of fat - a mere 10 grams, practically a tea spoon - would give us our current daily RDA.

DellaPenna is trying to engineer more sensible plants than arabidopsis to produce these massive amounts of vitamin E; arabidopsis, the laboratory rat of the botany world, is only a few centimetres across - cultivating vast amounts of it could be even more frustrating than eating a couple of kilos of spinach.

What worries DellaPenna though, is whether his work will reach completion. "In two to three years all the vitamin pathways will have been mapped by the biochemical communities, but I am concerned we won't be able to use these tools," says DellaPenna.

A third of the world's population is vitamin deficient and this is implicated in half of all child deaths world wide. As well as needing vitamins and minerals, we also require micronutrients such as phytoestrogens, phenols, and flavanoids which are found in soya beans, red wine and broccoli and can decrease our risk of getting cancer.

His lab currently examines about a thousand plant produced compounds yet it is estimated that plants produce in excess of 80,000 compounds, many of which could have the same beneficial effects as flavonoids.

"I hope this debate will concentrate on facts and not fears," he adds. "When we debate GM foods we should keep an empty chair at the table for the people who will benefit - or stand to lose out if this work is not done. That empty chair represents 2.5 billion people who are vitamin deficient, and who live on less than $2 a day. They can't afford to buy supplements."

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Lofty view of the waterworks | Rabies called in against HIV
fields.body:
Lofty view of the waterworks
From 200 miles up, you can see clear waters rising. The space shuttle used a technique called interferometric synthetic aperture radar in flights over the flooded Amazon basin to measure subtle changes in water levels, Californian scientists report in Nature today. Researchers could detect a fall in water levels of 7-11 cms a day within 20km of a main drainage channel and changes of 2- 5cms a day 80kms away. It's a technique for direct observations important for understanding flood dynamics, perhaps in the Congo basin, they say. It would no doubt have helped provide some early warning of the inundation of Mozambique, had anyone been watching.

Rabies called in against HIV
Jefferson medical college in Philadelphia has been experimenting with a new HIV vaccine carrier: the rabies virus. It is, of course, weakened and made safe, and the idea is to introduce something that will set off all possible alarm bells in the immune system. So far, a vaccine against the Aids virus has been little more than a dream. It worked in mice, they report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. "This is only in mice so far," said Roger Pomerantz, director of the centre for human virology. "We still have to prove it is safe, and it will work against other worldwide HIV strains and in other animals."

Snow falling on sea stirs
The noisiest thing in the briny deep could be snowflakes, according to the Journal of the Acoustical Society of America. Falling snowflakes deliver more than just crystals to the water surface. "Nine tenths of the volume of a snowfllake is air," says Andrea Prosperetti, of Johns Hopkins university. "When a snowflake strikes the water, it melts and the air inside is freed up as a bubble. When that bubble oscillates, it makes noise."

fields.headline: Death, and lots of it
fields.standfirst: Killing off the world's species can do far more than ruin your day. It could take evolution 10 million years to climb back up, writes  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: Killing off the world's species can do far more than ruin your day. It could take evolution 10 million years to climb back up, writes Henry Gee
fields.body:
The comedian Billy Connolly - no mean country picker himself - has said that the essential ingredient in any country and western tune is "Death - And Lots Of It". The Nashville set never sang about death on a truly epic scale - mass extinction. This is death that carries away not just you, but your friends and neighbours too - and quite a lot of other things besides.

Maybe it's hard to come up with catchy titles. Stand By Your Triceratops and Your Cheatin' Brachiosaurus are unlikely to get toes tapping at the Grand Ole Opry.

If extinction weren't enough to ruin your whole day, a pair of American scientists have learned something about extinction's flipside: how to restore the Earth's ecology afterwards. Conventional wisdom has it that the harder they fall, the longer it takes to get back up. For example, the extinction at the end of the Permian Period, 251 million years ago - the biggest in at least the past 530 million, that exterminated 96% of all marine species - would have had longer-term effects than the relatively piddly end-Cretaceous event, 65 million years ago, that did in the dinosaurs.

But Anne Weil of Duke university in North Carolina, and James Kirchner of the university of California, Berkeley have found something rather odd which they write about it in Nature today: no matter whether a pulse of extinction is mild or severe, it always takes the same time, on average, for biodiversity to climb back to pre-extinction richness. That average time is 10 million years.

Ten million years is too huge an interval of time to contemplate: so busy are we slashing up today's biodiversity to think much beyond next Tuesday. Yet Kirchner and Weil's discovery carries with it an eldritch tale of unspeakable horror. When we wipe out the tigers and the penguins and the polar bears, we won't see their like again.

And given that a mammalian species like Homo sapiens generally lasts only a few million years before popping its clogs anyway, the next eyes to witness comparable species richness will not even be human - even if humanity leaves descendants. We will have destroyed diversity for 100,000 centuries, for our childrens' children so far down the line that they will belong to a different species.

Kirchner and Weil found this using a unique compendium of the time-ranges of fossils from the past 530 million years, collated by the palaeontologist Jack Sepkoski of the university of Chicago, who died last year. With his colleague David Raup, Sepkoski used the data to suggest that mass extinctions happened regularly, every 26 million years or so - an amazing idea that prompted a search for extraterrestrial causes. The most startling was the idea of Nemesis, the dark star - a companion star to the Sun with a long, loping orbit that would carry it close to the Solar System every 26 million years or so, triggering a rain of comets down on to the earth.

Nemesis remains elusive, and the 26-million-year thing has fallen by the wayside, but Sepkoski's data set keeps rolling along. Kirchner and Weil used the data to test whether peaks of extinction correlated with peaks of origination - times when lots of new species appeared at once. They didn't.

However, peaks of extinction did match up with peaks of origination that were delayed by an average of 10 million years. This time lag held true no matter how severe the extinction, and even allowing for the notorious patchiness of the fossil record.

This study says something important about ecology now, as well as in the deep past: it demonstrates the interdependence of species in an ecosystem. The model in which a bigger extinction means a longer recovery works only if species are isolated entities, and recovery is simply a matter of evolving enough species to fill the vacancies. But in real life, no species is an island. Each new species represents an opportunity for a predator, a threat for prey, a home for parasites and diseases, a partner for symbionts.

Each tropical tree is home to a plethora of species - for example, each one of the 900 species of fig is pollinated by its very own species of fig wasp. The extinction of a species therefore removes opportunities for many others - the removal of lots of species all at once removes ecological niches as well as the species that fill them.

This is why the plants that immediately follow mass extinctions tend to be rather boring (ferns, ferns and more ferns - all right if you like that sort of thing, but for millions of years?)

It takes a long time for new species to evolve, and only when a few new ones appear can others evolve to capitalise on the bridgehead formed by these hardy pioneers. One way and another, it adds up to 10 million years.

By rights, extinction and recovery should be cathartic enough for any C&W number. It could be that it's just not kitchen-sink enough, amid all the desertions, wife-beatings and general human heartbreak. Maybe there's a place, though, for a suitably apocalyptic subgenre of country music that makes way for such lofty themes.

Altogether now, Oh Velociraptor, I'm Beggin' Of You Please, Don't Eviscerate My Man.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book Deep Time: Cladistics, The Revolution In Evolution (ISBN 1-885702-986-0) is published on 6 April by Fourth Estate, price £20

But in real life, no species is an island. Each new species represents an opportunity for a predator, a threat for prey, a home for parasites and diseases, a partner for symbionts. Each tropical tree is home to a plethora of species - for example, each one of the 900 species of fig is pollinated by its very own species of fig wasp. The extinction of a species therefore removes opportunities for many others - the removal of lots of species all at once removes ecological niches as well as the species that fill them. This is why the plants that immediately follow mass extinctions tend to be rather boring (ferns, ferns and more ferns - all right if you like that sort of thing, but for millions of years?) It takes a long time for new species to evolve, and only when a few new ones appear can others evolve to capitalise on the bridgehead formed by these hardy pioneers. One way and another, it adds up to 10 million years. By rights, extinction and recovery should be cathartic enough for any C&W number. It could be that it's just not kitchen-sink enough, amid all the desertions, wife-beatings and general human heartbreak. Maybe there's a place, though, for a suitably apocalyptic subgenre of country music that makes way for such lofty themes. Altogether now, Oh Velociraptor, I'm Beggin' Of You Please, Don't Eviscerate My Man.  Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. fields.headline: 'Childish' security advice angers MPs
fields.standfirst: Protest at lack of cash to ensure safety of staff
fields.trailText: A row has broken out over what MPs are calling a "Janet and John" guide to security issued by parliament in the wake of the sword attack which killed a Liberal Democrat councillor trying to shield Nigel Jones, the MP for Cheltenham, at his constituency office.
fields.body:
A row has broken out over what MPs are calling a "Janet and John" guide to security issued by parliament in the wake of the sword attack which killed a Liberal Democrat councillor trying to shield Nigel Jones, the MP for Cheltenham, at his constituency office.

It has been intensified by parliament's finance officers telling MPs that they cannot have any extra cash to protect themselves or their staff - after advising them that they must take extra security measures.

This position is in direct contrast to ministers' treatment, many of whom have extra security at their homes and offices paid for by the taxpayer.

The guide sent out by parliament's sergeant at arms office from the home office - with pictures of Jaguar cars parked outside executive-style homes and anxious children clutching teddy bears - has infuriated some MPs by the childishness of some of the advice.

For example, MPs are advised to "try to be as inconspicuous as possible when in public", and to "walk in company and near the kerb, if possible facing oncoming traffic".

Other advice on the road is to "avoid shubbery, dark doorways or other places where people might hide".

In public life MPs are warned: "Try not to be predictable by using the same restuarant, bar and place of entertainment".

On protecting their families it contains such gems as: "keep young children within sight or earshot or in the care of a trustworthy adult who is aware of the special risks your children may be under."

MPs are warned when driving: "It is inadvisable to pick up strangers or open doors or windows to unknown persons", adding: "It is inadvisable to accept a policeman or other official in uniform as bona fide - ask to see his warrent card."

While being driven MPs are warned: "It is inadvisable to daydream. If you are a passenger be alert to anything suspicious." They are also told to change their route home every day and keep a look out to see if they are being followed.

Peter Bradley, Labour MP for the Wrekin, said: "This guide seems to be treating MPs like children. It is like that basic nursery reading book, Janet and John."

But he and a number of backbench colleagues are particularly angry at a decision by the office to issue the guide - and then tell MPs that they have to find the money themselves to provide protection for their own staff.

"I don't think MPs anyway can live a life behind padlocked doors and nor would I want to," Mr Bradley commented.

"But I do feel we have a responsibility to protect our own researchers, particularly when we are not there ourselves."

The MP, elected in Labour's landslide in 1997, has already had one nasty incident. He had a recent visitor to his surgery, a man known to have mental health problems.

"He came in to tell me about people staring at him and then started brandishing this carving knife which he said he carried around with him to protect himself. Luckily he didn't use it, but it was frightening."

In a letter to the MP, Gillian Crowther, assistant head of parliament's fees office, said: "You should be aware there is no source of funding anywhere ... to cover such costs for members or their staff."

She said that MPs would have to find the money from their office costs allowance which is used to buy computers and pay for two or three staff already.

webTitle: Dobson gambles on mayor scare tactic

fields.headline: Dobson gambles on mayor scare tactic
fields.standfirst:
Londoners reminded of rival's City remarks

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson took a gamble yesterday in his catch-up campaign for mayor of London when he claimed that Ken Livingstone's attitude towards last summer's City riots will scare off foreign investment and destroy the jobs of ordinary Londonders.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson took a gamble yesterday in his catch-up campaign for mayor of London when he claimed that Ken Livingstone's attitude towards last summer's City riots will scare off foreign investment and destroy the jobs of ordinary Londonders.

Some pro-Dobson Labour MPs warned against character assassinations and other dirty tactics at yesterday's weekly meeting of the parliamentary Labour party (PLP). But the ex-health secretary now believes he must dent his rival's cheeky chappie image among voters to have any chance of beating him on May 4.

Launching his plans for a London Development Agency (LDA) - staffed by "serious entrepeneurs" and designed to help create 100,000 jobs in four years - Mr Dobson said London had to remain a hub of the global economy. That meant "sensible taxation policies and a pro-police, pro-business stance".

In a calculated bid to remind Londoners of Mr Livingstone's recent interview with The Face magazine he later added: "I don't want the IMF, the World Trade Organisation (WTO), the World Bank and other global institutions afraid that if they come to London the police will stand aside as London businesses are vandalised."

In his January interview with The Face, not long after police-protester battles at the WTO in Seattle, Mr Livingstone said: "I have always been in favour of direct action." He added that he would not invite the WTO to London "unless we can get vast stocks in so we can throw stuff at them in an organised way".

At the time the MP for Brent East laughed off the remarks as media misrepresentation. But according to Mr Dobson's aides business and City organisations had been "very angry" at the remarks and are now poised to come off the fence and oppose Mr Livingstone's bid for mayor.

Mr Dobson's plans for boosting London's jobs prospects laid stress on cooperation with business in search of practical solutions. "I want a London at work, not a London on benefits," he said.

Unable to confirm rumours that a lottery winner is poised to give him £100,000, Mr Livingstone spent yesterday putting together a full-scale campaign organisation after breaking with Labour. He also addressed a City audience last night. Like Mr Dobson he stressed such issues as the cost of congestion and skills shortages.

The Dobson team hopes it can erode Mr Livingstone's huge lead - 55% ahead according to the Guardian's poll this week - by shifting the debate back onto issues, notably jobs, crime and the police.

"The polling results are so absurd they are not real figures," one aide said yesterday as Mr Dobson was cheered at the PLP. MPs heard Liverpool's Peter Kilfoyle, who quit the government over Blairite failings, warn that a Livingstone mayoralty would create what happened in Liverpool - "attract the flotsam and jetsam, then start to tear itself and the city apart".

fields.headline: Frankly, namesake adds to confusion
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: A retired publisher from the south London suburbs yesterday added an extra mile to Frank Dobson's uphill struggle to become London mayor. He announced he may stand too. And his name is Frank S. Dobson.
fields.body:
A retired publisher from the south London suburbs yesterday added an extra mile to Frank Dobson's uphill struggle to become London mayor. He announced he may stand too. And his name is Frank S. Dobson.

Last night the former health secretary was said to be taking seriously the threat that New Malden's Mr Dobson may syphon off votes from Labour's official candidate, amid hints of legal action. Frank S. Dobson was roused to action by sheer dislike of the mayor's race, the 65-year-old revealed on Radio 4's Today programme. "I feel strongly that one should vote. It suddenly came to me that yes, people could do something positive. If I stood as an anti-assembly candidate, people could express their displeasure by voting for me," he said.

His lack of enthusiasm for the concept of an elected mayor is no worse than John Prescott - whose admission that he was "not a fan" prompted Tory jibes at Commons question time yesterday.

Past precedent suggests voters are easily misled by similar names. In 1994 a west country businessman calling himself a Literal Democrat took enough votes to deprive the Liberal Democrats of a Euro-seat they hoped to win.

Mr F.S. Dobson has nothing against his namesake. "It is just pure coincidence that we have the same name. I had it first, I'm older than him ... this is a genuine attempt to become mayor and bring this to Londoners' notice."

webTitle: Short faces outcry over low wages abroad

fields.headline: Short faces outcry over low wages abroad
fields.trailText: Clare Short faced fresh embarrassment yesterday when it emerged that her department was paying the vast majority of its overseas staff paltry wages, with some workers earning as little as 88p an hour.
fields.body:
Clare Short faced fresh embarrassment yesterday when it emerged that her department was paying the vast majority of its overseas staff paltry wages, with some workers earning as little as 88p an hour.

Figures released by the department for international development show that staff have to reach the highest grades before they can hope to earn only slightly more than the minimum wage for unskilled workers in Britain of £3.60 an hour.

The Tories, who uncovered the low wages in a series of parliamentary questions, last night condemned Ms Short for hypocrisy. Cheryl Gillan, the Tories' foreign affairs spokeswoman, said: "This is clear proof that Labour say one thing and do another. They have introduced a minimum wage in Britain yet they are paying British government employees abroad as little as 88p an hour."

Her remarks came after Ms Short released details of the low wages paid to staff hired by her department overseas. In the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, three workers employed by her department earn 88p an hour. The staff, drivers and receptionists, are paid the equivalent of £1,748 a year, which can rise to £2,934 with fluctuating exchange rates. With a 38 hour week, this works out at 88p an hour.

Four clerical assistants on the next grade up fare little better, earning £1.11 an hour. Staff have to wait until the final grade, as senior professional advisers, before they earn more than the minimum, when they are paid £4.96 an hour.

Staff in the Bangladeshi capital earn marginally more at the lower grades, but less at the higher grades.

Ms Short said: "The UK minimum wage was set in relation to UK conditions and has no particular relevance in the overseas context, especially in those economies where inflation may be substantially greater than the low rates prevailing in Britain."

webTitle: The order has gone out: stop calling him a l**r

fields.headline: The order has gone out: stop calling him a l**r
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has banned the "L" word and ordered Labour loyalists to stop calling the mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone a liar. Party officials, MPs and ministers have been told instead to brand the suspended leftwinger as "untrustworthy" in a subtle yet significant change of tactics.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has banned the "L" word and ordered Labour loyalists to stop calling the mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone a liar. Party officials, MPs and ministers have been told instead to brand the suspended leftwinger as "untrustworthy" in a subtle yet significant change of tactics.

Mr Blair feared the constant use of the "liar" tag might backfire by winning public sympathy for Mr Livingstone.

The switch foreshadows an onslaught not just on his broken promise not to quit the party but on his fitness to run the capital.

The decision to ban using the word "liar" was underlined yesterday by John Prescott during a Westminster meeting with backbenchers to rally support for Labour's candidate, Frank Dobson. One of those present said the deputy prime minister told the group: "We need to be careful. The liar thing does not play well with voters."

Later, the Labour MP Austin Mitchell urged the party to "stop the viciousness" and said: "Labour is fighting its fight by abusing Ken Livingstone, trying to hang every lie and imputation and fear around his neck, and alienating the people of London as a consequence."

A senior Downing Street aide made Mr Blair's concerns clear to staff at the party's Millbank HQ on Tuesday.

Mr Dobson had denounced Mr Livingstone as a liar in interviews the day before when the Brent East MP announced he would stand as an independent despite previous assurances that he would never leave the party. Twenty-four hours later, during a face-to-face debate at the London School of Economics, Mr Dobson was dismissing Mr Livingstone as someone who was untrustworthy - but notably not calling him a liar.

"Calling him a liar was vital in the first few hours because that is what he is, but Tony doesn't like it," said a Labour aide. "Now we have to be more subtle to ram home the message that he can't be trusted on jobs, crime, transport and all the issues that matter while Frank would be a mayor Londoners could rely on."

Labour's Millbank HQ is also planning to reduce the number of head-to-head debates involving Mr Dobson in an attempt to deny Mr Livingstone media coverage. Senior strategists hope his "one man campaign" will struggle when trying to organise its own events.

Labour insiders are already claiming that Mr Livingstone "looks knackered" and will struggle to last the eight-week course.

The sniping is partly revenge for a smear earlier in the campaign that Mr Dobson was "clinically depressed" which Millbank is convinced was started by the Brent East MP.

Labour plans to exploit the appointment of any left-wingers to Mr Livingstone's campaign team to paint him as a dangerous extremist.

webTitle: Chile boosts hopes for Pinochet trial

fields.headline: Chile boosts hopes for Pinochet trial
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.newsunlimited.co.uk/Pinochet_on_trial/0,2759,17493,00.html"> Pinochet on trial: special report</A
fields.trailText: The Chilean government yesterday announced that the public prosecutor's office will take part in criminal proceedings under way against General Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
The Chilean government yesterday announced that the public prosecutor's office will take part in criminal proceedings under way against General Augusto Pinochet.

The public prosecutor had previously rejected efforts to involve the government directly in the judicial process against the former dictator, who returned to Chile from Britain last week after escaping attempts by a Spanish judge to bring him to trial.

The decision means that government lawyers will be able to take part in investigations against Gen Pinochet. They would also be allowed to intervene in any trial.

"The participation of the state defence council is based on the goal of helping to establish the truth and to sanction those responsible," said Clara Szczaranski, president of the council.

The council's involvement is both a practical and a symbolic boost to the effort to judge Gen Pinochet. Many analysts in Chile suggested that the sudden move by the government was a response to the humiliating images of Gen Pinochet's Lazarus-like walk and the military greeting that he received on arriving home.

Victims of the military regime continued to bombard Chilean courts with new criminal complaints against Gen Pinochet. In less than 24 hours, 11 new complaints were filed, bringing the total to 72.

"We have waited 27 years for this," said Camilo Escalona, a leader of the Socialist party. This [government role] is a sign of the political willingness by Chilean society to move forward on the road to justice."

Supporters of the general are now concerned that the tide of public opinion has so turned on Gen Pinochet that the courts will ignore facts and seek a political persecution.

"Judges should not make decisions with the weight of international public opinion on their back," said Senator Ignacio Perez Walker.

A petition to strip Gen Pinochet of immunity from prosecution has been approved by the investigating judge and will now be examined by Santiago's appeal court. A decision is expected in about six weeks.

The court is also considering televising any criminal trial.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Arresting polar bears | Top of the pops
fields.body:
News stream
Few things are as fascinating as historical newsreels, whether they're as old as Tsar Nicholas II's coronation in 1896 or as recent as Nelson Mandela's inauguration. Now, Newsplayer, has assembled more than 10,000 newsreels and television news reports from sources such as Paramount, Empire News, French Pathe, Reuters and ITN and put them online in Windows Media Format. There's a catch - full access costs £25 a year - but the free samples are well worth the trip to www.newsplayer.com.

School death
The shooting of a six year old schoolgirl by a classmate shocked America last week, and the Michigan Education Association's website offers a focus for information. Technically the school was in Beecher, just outside Flint, but television pundit and anti-General Motors campaigner Michael Moore considers it a home-town affair. It remains to be seen what effect the shooting will have on the US presidential elections, where Doonesbury's cartoon candidate, Duke, is campaigning with the slogan: "I believe every American - man, woman or child - should be in a position to return fire." See www.Duke2000.com.

Arresting polar pictures
Greenpeace has set up camp in the arctic just a mile from "BP Amoco's dangerous oil project, Northstar" and is reporting its campaign at www.greenpeaceusa.org/arctic. It does have some great pictures - including the shots of polar bears being arrested at a US protest www.greenpeaceusa.org. Meanwhile in Iceland, Keiko, the killer whale made famous by the Free Willy movies, is being returned to the wild. The Ocean Futures Society is following his progress in KeikoWatch at www.oceanfutures.org.

Skipping over the world
Anyone curious about the world - or just desperate to finish that geography homework - will find much of interest in the World Skip. Pick a region, then a country, for a growing set of links in a wide range of categories. It may not be the first place you'd turn for information about the economic giants, but the coverage of dozens of small countries is invaluable.

Top of the pops
UK-based Worldpop.com hopes to become the leading music portal for teenagers and young adults who follow the pop charts. As well as interviews and Radio 1/ Top Of The Pops-style chat, its offerings include a world singles charts based on sales in 52 countries. The rival Clickmusic.co.uk site is offering a No.1 Game which provides a "warts 'n' all insight into the workings of the music industry".

Remember me this way
A new website wants your memories, and is offering to archive them. More accurately, it's offering to put them online so that other people can browse them by date, by name or by subject. Random Access Memory is described as an "experiment in collective recollection", and once you've registered to gain access, it is an entertaining place to browse. Whether any meaningful themes will eventually emerge is another matter.

In passing
Cloning may one day become affordable, so rather than just having Fido or Tiddles stuffed, you can store its DNA and have it cloned later. That, at least, is the idea presented by the punningly-named Genetic Savings & Clone, which also covers livestock, and plans to store samples of endangered species.

The Oscars are fast approaching, and the official site at www.oscar.com (or www.oscars.com ) has all the nominations, while Yahoo is providing links to further coverage at http://movies. yahoo.com/oscars/ . Fingers are crossed here for Pedro Almodóvar's witty weepy, All About My Mother.

fields.headline: Sim-etry in motion
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams is head of advanced wireless technology at Virgin Mobile which is introducing the first SIM-based web-browser allowing access to WML (WAP) web sites.
fields.trailText: Richard Williams is head of advanced wireless technology at Virgin Mobile which is introducing the first SIM-based web-browser allowing access to WML (WAP) web sites.
fields.body:
How long have you been involved with the net? About three years. I never really had a great deal of interest in it before my involvement with mobile phones. My main interest now is trying to deliver a service to a small-screen device and to access that content quickly and smoothly.

Any favourite sites? I'm a Leeds United supporter so I visit www.lufc.co.uk all the time. I'm also a regular visitor to the BBC site, and when the Superbike racing is on, I visit the Yamaha site at www.yamaha-motor.com.

How important will mobile technology become? Penetration of PCs is so small, but the penetration of mobile phones is reaching 40 to 50% even in quite under-developed countries. So there's now this massive potential to deliver a service through an internet backbone to the real populous. I started getting interested when I found that you could put an internet-type browser on the SIM itself. Every single mobile phone has got a little smart-card and it's only really used for security. There's loads of spare capacity.

How secure are mobiles for e-commerce? Mobile phones are capable of delivering a digital signature that is acceptable for legal documents. If you can accept that as a signature then you can start using it to sign leases, buy cars and all sorts of other things. The public infrastructure for smart-cards isn't going to be secure enough to be acceptable until about probably this September. In the meantime there's Symmetric Security which basically means you do a little sum on the SIM and a little sum on the network then compare the results. If you both have the same result then it's taken as being correct. However, that's only really as good as anybody who trusts you as an operator.

Do you see it as an extension or an alternative to the internet? I don't think anyone can really envisage themselves browsing the internet on their mobile phone - tiny little screen, tiny little keyboard. If, however, someone enabled you to view the top10 albums or the Premier League football results then that's the kind of information you want to know when you're on the move. It's more a kind of internet buddy which gives you information and e-mail while you're mobile, but doesn't try and swamp you with stuff.

How do you see the net developing? I really think that the net is going to take on the fact that mobile is big - providing that it can be delivered over the mobile range. I have a little browser that we developed which is set up to send me only the information I'm after.

Anything you dislike about the net? Intrusive advertising. You get a page up and you have to go through another six pages before you get to what you want! If that's the only way people are able to pay for their sites then the fewer people visiting the site, the more advertising they'll need for revenue. Hence less of the information you want to look at is there for you.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Alive and well
Any internet "visionary" that thinks the book is dead (Online, March 2) should get out more. Indeed, anyone old enough can remember the prophets of doom saying much the same thing about video recorders. If memory serves me well, the argument was that video would kill the cinema industry and also time shift TV viewing habits.

In the end, the cinema industry was reborn and I've still never met anyone that can figure out how to record anything in advance. Books have have a number of advantages over e-publishing. They don't crash, you can snuggle up with them in bed, tear bits out and recycle them. They also feel and smell good.

Just because you can technically make something doesn't necessarily mean people will want it. Don't confuse movement with progress.
Richard Watson
innovation@easynet.co.uk

Phone torture
As I am one of the thousands mentioned in Sarah Wilson's story (Online, March 2) who suffer the torture of broken connections and unusably slow data exchange, her article shed some light on my situation.

Having contacted BT many times and had clueless BT engineers to the house, the truth is revealed: the problem for those of us who cannot afford Home Highway is insoluble. The creaking network we have to use is simply not up to the task.

BT's attempts to meet the requirements of the market place are clearly woefully inadequate. Why, for example, do they push ISDN when ADSL is clearly the sensible option for the future? Maybe they think the Americans have got it wrong.

Given the growing importance of online communications, the revelation that our ability to keep up with other first world countries is doubtful, is nothing short of a national scandal to rival that of the state of our railways. It's a situation the government ought to be addressing.

Failing government intervention, we can but hope that BT's position will weaken and that it will bought out by some enterprising company willing to drag this dinosaur into the 21st century.
Peter Robinson
prob46@madasafish.com

After reading Sarah Wilson's article, I thought I would write in to explode the myth about how great internet access is in America.

True, some parts of the US have blinding internet access using ADSL or a normal phone line, but this is generally restricted to the major cities and some highly populated areas. ADSL is becoming more widely used, with AT&T's @Home service racing ahead. But this is still not available in many parts of the US, and to those that have it, it comes at a high price.

For phone line users, free local calls come at a price averaging $20 a month (around £12-£15), and you will find that most local call providers will also guarantee the line for voice calls only, much the same as BT. I have friends and family there who are annoyingly disconnected from the internet at random - just as here in the UK.

I have stayed in many areas of the US and was constantly disappointed with internet access. Free ISPs still have not become the norm, and the average person will pay around $15 per month (around £10) to access the web (on top of their monthly phone line charge). The free ISPs that are available nearly all provide huge banners with advertisements you can't get rid of, and you are forced to use their software to dial up.

The average connection speed achieved through a phone line in many parts of the US is around 28-33 Kbps, and I was glad to get back to my BT phone line and achieve an average of 40-44Kbps.

As much as I dislike BT in the way they concern themselves with the internet in this country, the average service around Britain is not that bad.

I use Claranet for my internet access in the UK and I pay £15 per month for 35 hours of free call time at evenings and weekends and use a non BT phone company for my international calls. Together that does not work out much different from what my counterparts are paying in the US.
Marcus Purvis
p0key@clara.co.uk

Flash follies
It's surprising that the government is using Flash to deliver its content (Online, March 2); what is not surprising is that the new media company the DCMS commissioned for the site has used it as an opportunity to show off .

Flash is rapidly becoming an industry standard, as it can deliver rich media content at low bandwidth and interface with other systems. However, its versatility seems to encourage practitioners to be as incomprehensible as possible.

But you do not have to go down this route; just because something can be done does not mean that it should be done. Developers should concentrate on how to use Flash's power to deliver content, not obscure it.

This does not mean, therefore, that the tool should be condemned. There is nothing wrong with Flash intros, as long as they are accessible and intuitive. This is the real skill of a web artist/designer, not how clever your code is.
Nik Kraakenes
pink_wizedd@hotmail.com

Boys v girls
Fiona Campbell-Howes's letter (Online, March 2) accuses me of talking "rubbish about girls and low scores" on computer games, and says that girls are more co-operative than competitive.

This assertion does not detract from the point that (on average) males score higher than females in points-based computer games. The difference in spatial ability skills between males and females may itself be a reason why females prefer co-operative as opposed to competitive games.

Gender differences in "competition vs co-operation" has been well researched in relation to the effect of computers (rather than computer games) on educational learning.

It has been clearly demonstrated that girls working together on computers will complete tasks faster than boys working together because boys will compete rather than co-operate with each other.

However, when boys are explicitly told to co-operate, they complete problem solving tasks on the computer just as fast as girls.
Dr Mark Griffiths
Head of Psychology, Nottingham Trent University pink_wizedd@hotmail.com

webTitle: Your chance to prove that small is beautiful

fields.headline: Your chance to prove that small is beautiful
fields.trailText: It's time to still the animations, crunch the applets and halt the movies. For now the great web design challenge is to make something very, very small indeed, writes Neil McIntosh
fields.body:
It's time to still the animations, crunch the applets and halt the movies. For now the great web design challenge is to make something very, very small indeed.

Canadian webmaster Stewart Butterfield is challenging the whole web to design a great web page that weighs in at less than 5 kilobytes by April 2.

To give an idea of how small that is, many pages on the web - weighed down with ever more complex multimedia elements - tip the scales at between 80K and 150K.

Is a decent looking page for 5K not impossible, then? No, says Butterworth, whose homepage www.sylloge.com could serve as inspiration to potential entrants.

"There's a lot of bloat on the web," he says.

"Last summer I found I'd lost sight of what I liked about the internet. It's not about commercial web design for big companies."

Reflecting that old-style internet antipathy towards big money, the prize for cooking up something good with limited resources is modest.

The winner will walk off with 5,120 US cents - the same number as the bytes allowed on your page.

But as well as "fifty bucks", the winner will also earn the admiration - and envious looks - of web designers world wide. See: www.sylloge.com/5k

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Colour Palm | WAP's new
fields.body:
Colour Palm
Palm Pilot has become a must-have fashion accessory as well as a pocket-sized organiser for millions of people. For anyone used to lugging an ever expanding filofax around with them, it is easy to see why. It is a combined electronic notepad, address book, diary and To Do list with facilities to download email and other goodies, including the Guardian's news service, from the internet http://AvantGo.com. This can be done either directly through a mobile phone (as long as the software is installed) or via your desktop computer. The Palm fraternity even bond with each other by exchanging digitised business cards through the infra-red link.

The latest version - which I tested over the weekend - is the Palm 3c which hits the streets today. It adds a colour screen to the Palm's familiar assets and has the new 3.5 operating system, with 8MB of memory. It was surprisingly easy to use the pad that coverts your handwriting letter by letter into digital text - a vast improvement on Apple's failed experiment with the Newton (Moral - never be a pioneer).

When you hook the Palm up to a PC, which backs everything up, there is a useful automatic facility for synchronising contacts book and diaries to make sure they have the same data. You can add an entry to the backed up version, press one button and it makes the same change to the Palm version - and vice versa.

The backlit screen is bright and stunningly easy to read (much better than previous Palms) and one of the most user-friendly I have come across. You simply flip open the top, press the on button and today's diary, split into hours, fills the screen. It's easy to see why it has swept America, culminating in last week's flotation which valued the company at a dizzy $45bn on Friday.

Mind you, it's not designed for anything longer than a short note. To write this review I had to fall back on my trusty Psion Revo which has a small but usable keyboard. The Revo hit our kitchen scales at exactly the same weight as the Palm (22 grams) and has more than 50% more screen area. The colour Palm 3c costs £349.99 against £299 for the (monochrome) Revo.

It's a question of horses for courses. In terms of world-wide sales the Palm has shown a clean pair of heels to Psion proving, maybe, that sassiness and marketing are even more important than technology.

 Guardian Unlimited and 3Com are giving you the opportunity to win a PalmV. Just visit www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/events to enter, or see the advertisement on this page for more details. (VK)

WAP's new
The few people in Britain who have managed to lay their hands on a WAP mobile phone have a funky new service to play with from Virgin Radio. In what the station is claiming is a world first, listeners will be able to interact with the station while on the move.

The most interesting feature is one which allows listeners to find out which song is playing at the moment, and even buy the music online, thus ending any reliance on some tiresome DJ telling you what he, or she, has just played. There's also scheduling information, Virgin's playlist and interactive games and competitions.

The move, like many in the WAP world, is less interesting for what is going on now, but how it will develop in the future. It's no coincidence that the most popular interactive feature on Virgin Mobile is one that allows you to listen to chart music over an ordinary mobile. Next generation mobile devices, much more powerful than today's, are due to arrive in a few years' time, with bidding for licences happening now. Might we begin to see radio and data come over the same device? Virgin Radio seems to be betting on it.

Internet TV
Television maker Alba is to team up with Pace to launch internet-capable television products. The range will include televisions with built-in internet access, starting from under £200, and set-top boxes for under £100, and should go on sale in May. The internet appliance market could hot up in the months to come: watch out for announcements from Amstrad, Sony, Microsoft and even Apple later in the year. (NM)

The Revo hit our kitchen scales at exactly the same weight as the Palm (22 grams) and has more than 50% more screen area. The colour Palm 3c costs £349.99 against £299 for the (monochrome) Revo. It's a question of horses for courses. In terms of world-wide sales the Palm has shown a clean pair of heels to Psion proving, maybe, that sassiness and marketing are even more important than technology.  Guardian Unlimited and 3Com are giving you the opportunity to win a PalmV. Just visit www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/events to enter, or see the advertisement on this page for more details. (VK) WAP's new The few people in Britain who have managed to lay their hands on a WAP mobile phone have a funky new service to play with from Virgin Radio. In what the station is claiming is a world first, listeners will be able to interact with the station while on the move. The most interesting feature is one which allows listeners to find out which song is playing at the moment, and even buy the music online, thus ending any reliance on some tiresome DJ telling you what he, or she, has just played. There's also scheduling information, Virgin's playlist and interactive games and competitions. The move, like many in the WAP world, is less interesting for what is going on now, but how it will develop in the future. It's no coincidence that the most popular interactive feature on Virgin Mobile is one that allows you to listen to chart music over an ordinary mobile. Next generation mobile devices, much more powerful than today's, are due to arrive in a few years' time, with bidding for licences happening now. Might we begin to see radio and data come over the same device? Virgin Radio seems to be betting on it. Internet TV Television maker Alba is to team up with Pace to launch internet-capable television products. The range will include televisions with built-in internet access, starting from under £200, and set-top boxes for under £100, and should go on sale in May. The internet appliance market could hot up in the months to come: watch out for announcements from Amstrad, Sony, Microsoft and even Apple later in the year. (NM)

webTitle: Bill opens a box of tricks

fields.headline: Bill opens a box of tricks
fields.standfirst: Jack Schofield  on Microsoft's latest attempt to conquer the world of computer games
fields.trailText: Jack Schofield on Microsoft's latest attempt to conquer the world of computer games
fields.body:
Microsoft will announce its plans for the games console market tomorrow, perhaps unveiling prototypes of its long-rumoured X-Box. And because of the time difference, when the company's co-founder Bill Gates makes his keynote speech at a game developers conference in San Jose, California, British enthusiasts will already have heard the news.

According to rumours, the X-Box will be a $299 games console based on PC technology, and it will plug into a TV set instead of using a monitor. It's expected to sport a Pentium-compatible Athlon processor from AMD, an Nvidia GeForce graphics chip, and a modem. The rest of the specification is malleable, but the new machine is unlikely to promise anything that hasn't been developed for the PC games market. It's using PC parts, and Windows software, that makes the enterprise viable.

The key questions are, first, is Microsoft going into the hardware business, or can the X-Box be made by anyone who fancies the idea? And second, when will it be available? With Sony's PlayStation 2 already on sale in Japan, isn't the rumoured Autumn 2001 date leaving it too late?

It would send shockwaves through the industry if Microsoft decided to market the X-Box under its own name. That would mean going head-to-head with Sony, Nintendo, and Sega - and Sega is a Microsoft customer, using Windows CE in its Dreamcast console. But it's not impossible, because Microsoft has already built a healthy market for hardware add-ons including mice, keyboards, joysticks, and steering wheels.

Microsoft's usual approach is to provide operating software to all comers and let them duke it out in the marketplace. That way, consumers get a variety of hardware to choose from, and competition drives down prices. Some of the hardware suppliers may lose their shirts, but Microsoft usually wins.

Usually, but not always. Microsoft has been in the games business for two decades, and has already had at least two goes at the consumer market.

The first effort came in the 1980s, with a system called MSX. At the time, the home computer market was struggling with a lot of incompatible formats from companies such as Acorn, Amstrad, Atari, Commodore and Sinclair Research. Software houses couldn't keep up with them all. Microsoft tried to rationalise the business with a single system, MSX, supported by numerous manufacturers.

Canon, Panasonic, Philips, Sony, Toshiba, Yamaha and another dozen companies all made MSX machines, but the system was not very successful outside Japan. Partly this was because it wasn't good enough: MSX was designed to be a versatile home computer but most buyers wanted a hot games machine. It was also too late. The home computers that MSX targeted were already being replaced by a new generation of more powerful models such as the Atari ST and Commodore Amiga.

Microsoft had another skirmish with the consumer market a decade later when CD-rom seemed the format of the future. The idea was a versatile "edutainment" player that would sit under the TV in the living room and run audio CDs, encyclopedias and games. Philips and others tried it with the CDi (CD Interactive) system, Commodore with the Amiga-based CDTV, and Apple and Japan's Bandai with the Mac-based Pippin. They all flopped. Hardly anyone noticed the Microsoft offering - a $699 VIS (Video Information System) running "Modular Windows" - which was sold in the US by Tandy.

Although it was meant to capitalise on the success of Microsoft Windows 3, only about two dozen companies offered VIS titles. The bare handful of games included Chuck Yeager's Air Combat (Electronic Arts), Lemmings (Psygnosis), and The Manhole (Activision).

However, Microsoft soon got serious about games, for very good reasons. It wanted consumers to move to Windows 95 but the games market was still dominated by DOS. Indeed, the Software Publishers Association said that at the start of 1996, DOS games were outselling Windows 95 games by 10 to one. But installing DOS games was a messy business; some people could never get them to work. It was also bad for strategic reasons: how could Microsoft get rid of DOS if the games market depended on it? The growth of games companies such as Electronic Arts also suggested that - altruism be damned - there was money to be made.

To succeed, Microsoft had to put better, faster games technology into Windows, which it did with its DirectX system. Not all versions of DirectX were fully debugged, and it sometimes seemed that every new game installed a new version of DirectX, but eventually the idea worked.

Microsoft also had to forget about writing everything itself and work with third-party developers. In January 1996, it announced link-ups with four US-based developers: Atomic Games, Crystal Dynamics, Rainbow America and Terminal Reality.

To bump up its in-house expertise, Microsoft also bought the Bruce Artwick Organization and hired Alexey Pajitnov. Artwick had developed Microsoft's best-selling DOS game, Microsoft Flight Simulator, while Pajitnov, a Russian, had created the compulsive puzzle, Tetris.

Another astute move was to put a keen gamer, Ed Fries (rhymes with fleece), in charge of the entertainment division. He'd already spent a decade at Microsoft and had worked on Word and Excel. At the time, he said: "I would like to be the number one games publisher. That won't mean I'll have 80% of the market - if you had 15% you'd be number one today. I think the games market will always be very fragmented, but being number one is always the right target. And the way to be number one is to make the best products."

The results have been mixed. Microsoft's games division has grown rapidly. But it has only had one huge hit, the Age of Empires strategy game produced by Ensemble Studios. The good products have been outnumbered by average ones, and some have been dross.

Last year, when Microsoft bought Mechwarrior developer FASA Interactive, Fries said it showed a commitment to "growing our business with a smaller portfolio of top-quality games". That's a good way to make money, but not to become number one.

Microsoft's strategy has been a success in that almost all PC games are now developed for Windows/DirectX rather than DOS - but that's the way the market was going anyway.

Certainly it hasn't done as well with PC games as it has on the internet, where Dataquest analyst Chris Le Tocq says Microsoft is the market leader. Not only has its Game Zone website become hugely popular, it has just launched a highly regarded multiplayer game, Asheron's Call, produced by Turbine Entertainment.

None of this proves the X-Box will fail. But it suggests Microsoft doesn't have the track record or games market share to guarantee its success.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Grandia | Superbike 2000
fields.byline: Andy Bodle,  Jack Schofield  and  Greg Howson
fields.body:
Delusions of Grandia
Grandia Sony PlayStation £34.99 Game Arts/UbiSoft ***
"If you're a fan of the Final Fantasy games, get ready to be enthralled by Grandia!"

With the proviso that "enthralled" may not be the quite the right word, this PR boast is for once not far off the mark. In fact, Ubi Soft's new role-playing game plays for all the world like Final Fantasy VII's slightly anaemic younger brother: not quite so big, not quite so clever, and not quite so annoyingly self-important.

All the familiar elements are here: world screens, town screens and dungeon screens; repetitive random encounters; a sophisticated combat system involving spells, items and special attacks; 150 different kinds of baddie; endless pages of dialogue; and cartoonish backgrounds that give you no idea where the exits are. All of which promises around 80 hours of monster-mashing, level- building, pixel-hunting fun.

And, despite the decision to make the protagonists 14 years old - surely they're too busy fighting their own hormones to take on green slimes and squid kings? - the end product is indeed quite entertaining.

The plot, needless to say, is ludicrous, but in a radical break with tradition, the dialogue is not. Ubi Soft has actually put some effort into the translation, resulting in some refreshingly comprehensible humour. The other new departure is the rotatable isometric view, although what this adds in dimension is generally lost in ease of navigation.

Anyone committed enough to complete Final Fantasies VII and VIII probably wouldn't find enough of a challenge here. But for those that were put off by the archness and complexity of Square's epic RPG, Grandia could be just what the doctor ordered. (AB)

This bike game is no triumph
Superbike 2000 Sony PlayStation £29.99 EA Sports **
The good news is that Superbike 2000 is not just a scrappy bike game: it's a simulation of the 1999 SBK Superbike World Championship with "real" riders, "real" bikes and 13 "real" tracks.

The bad news is that it's not very good. The graphics are pixellated and you get very little impression of speed: doing 150 doesn't feel any faster than doing 50.

In fact, it often feels as though the bike is stationary, and only the road is moving.

The roar of 150 horsepower and a pounding soundtrack ought to increase the level of excitement, but the engine noises lack depth and the musical accompaniment is more likely to send you to sleep.

It's not even hard. Just staying on the track is almost enough to ensure a win.

On paper, Superbike 2000 has got everything right. You can set up the bikes, practise before races, sustain damage, and suffer from random weather effects. There's even a race commentary by Sky Sports' Keith Huewen.

If you really want a bike racing simulation, the PC version of the game, released in January, probably fills the bill.

But if you want a thrilling arcade-style dice with death (from the comfort of your armchair), the PlayStation version doesn't deliver. (JS)

Cartoony but fearfully effective
Fear Effect Sony PlayStation £39.99 Eidos ****
Featuring a twisting Manga-style plot and a curvaceous anti-hero, Fear Effect is a new PlayStation action/adventure from Eidos.

Initial impressions are mixed. While you admire the lovingly-created character animations and soak up the Blade Runner atmosphere, the camera angles and annoying controls are just far too reminiscent of the Resident Evil series.

But look a little closer and you'll notice moving backgrounds rather than pre-rendered stasis.

Play some more and, after solving some derivative puzzles, you'll soon be switching between three characters and getting wrapped up in the Oriental futurisms of the plot.

Playing as Hana and her two co-mercenaries, your aim is to rescue a Triad leader's daughter. Cue graphic violence, betrayal and some infuriating puzzles.

Actually, it's quite disconcerting that a game that places so much value on celluloid characteristics - widescreen, heavy script - allows illogical, code-breaking conundrums to interrupt the flow.

With age doing PlayStation visuals few favours, it's nice to see a developer try something different.

The aforementioned moving backdrops may be constantly looping but the illusion of life is maintained.

Similarly the cartoony visual elements allow seamless transition between cut-scene and game, thus keeping the movie vibe intact.

But it's a shame that loading times couldn't be speeded up as the high difficulty level leads to too much time spent staring at the loading screen.

Thankfully the controls eventually become second nature and soon you'll be blasting zombies - sorry, "cursed villagers" - with the best of them.

Despite borrowing the cinematics of Resident Evil and the tiptoe aesthetics of Metal Gear Solid, Fear Effect manages to transcend these influences and create something plot-driven and enjoyably different. (GH)

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Tomb Raider the movie | Star Trek: Conquest Online
fields.body:
The season to be Jolie
Most of the week's idle gossip has been dedicated to the forthcoming Tomb Raider movie. What's reasonably certain is that the Paramount Pictures film will be directed by Simon "Con Air" West and written by Michael Werb and Michael Colleary, of Face/Off fame. Other snippets, in decreasing order of reliability, are as follows: £20m-£30m budget; Rene Russo and Brian Blessed to play Lara's parents; opening sequence somehow incorporating the Millennium Wheel; and Angelina Jolie, well-turned star of Hackers (above), The Bone Collector and Girl Interrupted, in negotiations for the leading role. If the film gets as many sequels as Eidos's game, Ms Jolie would be a fool to say no.

The game of the film
Last year's Film Most Likely To Be Made Into A Game seems to have realised its potential at last. Rumour is that Interplay is about to sign a deal to publish a title based on The Matrix, the techno phobic special-effects blockbuster starring Keanu Reeves and Laurence Fishburne. No word yet on whether any of the movie's stars will be involved; if so, they might even have to do some acting.

Best of inmates
Ever wondered what would have happened if Kingpin had been caught? Find out later this year in Gothic, a real-time 3D role playing game from German developer Piranha Bytes which begins, of all places, in the slammer. In the first part of the game, you must bribe, intimidate and fight your way up the prison pecking order. Then, of course, you break out and start cutting up goblins. After three years in development, the game will be presented at the E3 exhibition in May. See www.piranha-bytes.com

The final frontier
The massively multiplayer boom continues with the announcement that Activision is to release Star Trek: Conquest Online. Some time later this year, Trekkers worldwide will be able to join forces in order to obliterate alien hordes (or, more likely, find a mutually beneficial solution). Expect lengthy squabbles about who gets to wear the red Starfleet uniform.

Shot down
Codemasters has revealed plans to rewrite Sensible Software's Cannon Fodder for the Game Boy Color. The miniaturised version of this highly addictive real-time strategy game - granddaddy of such giants as Total Annihilation and Command & Conquer -will reportedly feature full-motion video and cut scenes.

Potter plot
What is this Japanese obsession with teenagers and magic? Latest reports suggest that Nintendo is plotting to publish a game adapted from JK Rowling's Harry Potter books. If all goes to plan, the orphaned apprentice wizard will star in his own title on Nintendo's next-generation console, codenamed Dolphin, possibly in time to coincide with the release of the proposed Harry Potter film.

Study time
Good news for all you youngsters whose studies interfere with your videogaming: now, at last, you can combine the two! As of this autumn, the university of California at Irvine will be offering an "interdisciplinary gaming studies programme", with modules on games psychology, sociology, graphic design and human kinetics. Needless to say, anyone found using cheat codes will be expelled.

fields.trailText: Ronald Bergan writes: While not wishing to take anything away from Jim Bailey's achievement (Obituary March 3) in founding Drum, I would like to point out that it was not South Africa's "first black African magazine". My stepfather, Ike Brooks, set up Zonk in 1948, three years before Drum. Zonk came out of the all-black townships variety show Brooks organised. The two magazines competed for readership, but Ike considered Jim "a very dear friend".
fields.body:
Ronald Bergan writes: While not wishing to take anything away from Jim Bailey's achievement (Obituary March 3) in founding Drum, I would like to point out that it was not South Africa's "first black African magazine". My stepfather, Ike Brooks, set up Zonk in 1948, three years before Drum. Zonk came out of the all-black townships variety show Brooks organised. The two magazines competed for readership, but Ike considered Jim "a very dear friend".

David McBrien writes: Lionel Salter (Obituary March 6) deserves credit for his attempts to resurrect one of Elgar's least known scores. Elgar wrote a substantial amount of original music for the 1915 children's fantasy play The Starlight Express, based on Algernon Blackwood's story. The score, orchestral parts and the play were all subsequently destroyed in a fire at the Kingsway theatre. When Elgar's manuscript was discovered in 1965, Salter prepared a performing edition and conducted a Christmas 1965 radio version of the play. Although repeated in 1968 this failed to excite the same interest as more recent "new" Elgar scores. Perhaps the time is ripe to re-examine this delightful work, for a television adaptation.
