David McBrien writes: Lionel Salter (Obituary March 6) deserves credit for his attempts to resurrect one of Elgar's least known scores. Elgar wrote a substantial amount of original music for the 1915 children's fantasy play The Starlight Express, based on Algernon Blackwood's story. The score, orchestral parts and the play were all subsequently destroyed in a fire at the Kingsway theatre. When Elgar's manuscript was discovered in 1965, Salter prepared a performing edition and conducted a Christmas 1965 radio version of the play. Although repeated in 1968 this failed to excite the same interest as more recent "new" Elgar scores. Perhaps the time is ripe to re-examine this delightful work, for a television adaptation.

fields.headline: Students on silicon campus
fields.standfirst: Why bother to go to university when the web can bring it to your desktop? Martin Clark studies the remarkable rise of distance learning
fields.trailText: Why bother to go to university when the web can bring it to your desktop? Martin Clark studies the remarkable rise of distance learning
fields.body:
Universities are dead. Campuses are defunct and everyone gets their degree online. Welcome to the future. Or is it? It's a spectre that haunts the education system, and it is already sending ripples of change through the world's learning communities.

In almost all areas of modern life, the internet revolution has smashed down barriers and blurred boundaries. And education is no exception. Education and employment secretary David Blunkett recently announced plans for a global education alliance - provisionally called the Worldwide Universities Network (WUN) - which will involve eight British and American institutions. He also outlined plans to invite bids for Britain's first e-university, which will be able to award degrees.

If the future of learning is online, who are the key players? And what aspects of education, as we know it, will remain? Revolutions have to start somewhere. At the lowest level, we know the internet allows discussion via email, chat rooms and newsgroups. Next there's the idea of online groups, learning as the "community mind", where you both gain from, and contribute to, collective understanding. Beyond this point, ideas become more hypothetical, like those offered by Xerox chief scientist and distance learning theorist Dr John Seely Brown.

He sees the internet generating a shift from linear learning in books to the idea of "multiple intelligences". Multiple formats such as hyperlinks (highlighted phrases you click on within a body of text, which lead to another web page), video, sound, graphics, all embedded within an online page, mean students learn in more flexible ways. "Learning is a fundamentally social process," Dr Brown says.

"The power of the internet is not just that it provides the content... it provides communities of specialised interest in which to facilitate learning." The institution at the forefront of distance learning over the past 30 years has been the Open University which has shown that such education can be of high quality. So is the OU rushing to put all its degree courses online?

Professor David Sewart, director of student services, is responsible for the delivery of education to the 156,000 students. He says they are "looking to attract the widest possible market". With half of its students online, the OU looks to provide learning through a wide variety of media. Sewart not only has the OU Business School MBA degree, he teaches it. It uses the First Class conferencing system, where students learn as part of an online community. Each has access to chat and gains from other students and teachers online.

The technology to obtain a degree purely through online study does not exist yet. Sewart even says he "remains to be convinced that online learning is going to take over completely within any time frame yet definable".

"Students simply don't want anything to get in the way of their learning experience," he says, adding: "Few technologies teach more effectively than the book." "It's portable, you can access multiple pages at once and annotate them too. Screens just aren't as easy to read from. We find with web courses people are printing more and more." But with companies like Xerox and Microsoft developing technologies to improve text clarity on screens, a challenge is being mounted to the printed page. Would you trust a doctor with just a virtual degree? There is a strong argument for saying certain experiences simply can't be digitised.

Pilots can be trained in simulators, but there comes a point when a surgeon needs to see someone's insides. This is one reason the OU has never offered distance medicine courses. But it does have one completely online course: T171, You, your computer and the net. One of the T171 students is called John. He's no ordinary student. Most people call him Sir. Sir John Daniel is the Vice Chancellor of the OU. " It was a practical way of finding out what I thought of T171 as a teaching tool," he says. "I was glad I took T171 because it attracted over 18,000 applications this year. That makes us the biggest university in cyberspace.

"Because of our history we have a level of sophistication that allows us to be more cautious than those who rush in from scratch. It sets us apart from those who just put their notes on the web and think they have a wonderful distance learning course." There has, nonetheless, been a rush by academic institutions into the distance learning market. It remains to be seen whether those first online will clean up. Unlike books, where Amazon has done so well, what sets education apart from many "products" is the requirement for service after the initial "sale". In the US, large ventures have begun to make an impact online. Phoenix university has also set up more than 60 campuses worldwide employing university lecturers on a consultancy basis.

Jones International, a for-profit university, recently caused controversy by gaining full degree accreditation. The traditional universities have had it good for some time and might find the going getting tougher as overseas institutions start selling distance learning courses . A forthcoming report, Borderless Education, and a recently issued Foresight report both issue warnings. "British universities are ill prepared to cope with the rising forces of globalisation," senior academics have been told.

"Universities need to wake up and see what their role is," argues Dr Robin Mason, a global education expert, based at the OU. What is increasingly possible, she suggests, is collaboration. Cambridge and MIT recently announced an £85m link-up. So are universities dead and campuses defunct? Many people will always want the campus experience. Harvard business school, with its invaluable old boy network, simply wouldn't translate on to the net. Professor David McConnell, of the department of education studies at Sheffield university, points out: "Students need a sense of belonging to learn."

He is one of the British academics looking at how to create that magic social interaction online. For most students, the campus learning experience has always extended beyond the lecture hall. It also educates students in what Sir John Daniel describes as "love, liquor and life". ³"The death of the campus is grossly exaggerated," he adds. But the shift in online possibilities, coupled with the introduction of fees, has meant students increasingly perceive higher education as an investment. And students expect high returns.

One organisation with its roots in online life-long learning is the University for Industry (Ufi). Dr Brian Sutton, director of information and computer technology, says: "We're trying to attract new learners, people who dropped out of the education system early." The university offers "byte-size" courses that can be as short as two hours. It's learning without a big commitment, in a way that fits into people's lives. Ufi is conducting free trials now, and plans to be fully operational by the autumn.

The big movement in educating industry has come from within. Over recent years many corporate big guns have been wielding serious money in the name of education. There are now more than 1,200 "corporate universities", most of which are based in the US. Take for example software giant Microsoft and computer hardware company Cisco Systems, the first and third most valuable corporations in the world respectively. Their computing qualifications, now available to the public, are more highly valued than a degree.

Targeting a completely different market is a new Channel 4 online service, Homework High. Launched in mid January, the site is a well-designed balance of functionality and good looks. Aimed at nine-16 year olds, it is a free service designed to help with homework and revision. Twice daily, Monday to Friday, teachers go online and help tackle pupils' emailed problems. So do kids like it? "The response has been fantastic. Our server melted recently," says Sophie Walpole, Homework High's managing editor of interactive services. But she does stress: "We do not give out all the answers."

Parents can rest easy. What is distance learning going to be like in 50 years time? "The only generalisation you can make about the future is that all generalisations are false, including this one," concludes the OU's Sir John Daniel. But for now the view looks good. Education is online and it is in campuses. It is in commerce and in pieces of every size. There are more players in the field, appealing to more sections of the global public, than ever before. Indeed, it is as fractured and diverse as modern life is itself. "Living and learning are two sides of the same coin," concludes John Seely Brown. Here's to a life of both.

I may live in Munich, but I go to my classes in Milton Keynes
Three weeks into her Open University MA in Open and Distance Education, Frieda Pattenden's experiences have not run to cybersex in freshers' week, although she doesn't rule it out as a possibility some students might wish to explore in the virtual campus's cybercafe.

Pattenden, who teaches English at Munich's Ludwig Maximilian university, has paid £2,500 for the privilege of studying from home, and that's just for one module (you must complete three to gain the MA). But she and the other students, many of whom are already designing courses, are convinced that online learning is a growth area, and some of their employers have contributed towards their fees.

A lot of thought has gone into creating a smooth-running campus, says Pattenden, and there is a real sense of community within her 10-strong tutorial group. The other tutees are based all over the world - Canada, Greece, Portugal - and back in Milton Keynes, the tutor, John Pettit, encourages students to introduce themselves, and be as relaxed with each other as possible.

"The first time you log on, you are invited on a guided tour of the virtual campus, the student union, the library, the tutorial area, where your tutor group conference discussions take place. Each member of staff has a smiling photo alongside their name."

A debate is under way about whether students should post their own photos on site. "Such debates are integral to the course. Through collaborative learning via computer conferencing, we are trying to assess how online education can be productive and worthwhile," says Pattenden.

The course is not trying to emulate face-to-face courses. "I don't feel I'm typing into a void. People's personalities come through clearly in the comments they post up on the conferencing system," she says.

Motivation, it seems, is high. The tutor gives the students a task, and as a group, via the conferencing system, they must present their findings. "Collaborative learning reflects what employers want in the workplace - team players - whereas traditional university courses encourage competition between students," says Pattenden.

Next month those who have graduated will be presented with their certificates. And the ceremony will, of course, be online .
Lucy Blincoe

fields.headline: Remember the Sabbath?
fields.standfirst: Douglas Rushkoff pleads for a respite from e-commerce
fields.trailText: Douglas Rushkoff pleads for a respite from e-commerce
fields.body:
I saw a television advertisement the other day, in which a young executive conducts a business meeting over a cellular phone - while standing at a urinal. When it is time to zip up, he cradles his cell-phone on his shoulder and goes on talking. But then the phone slips out from under his chin, and tumbles - splash - you guess where. The answer to this dilemma, according to the ad, is a new "hands-free" cellular phone service.

The real answer, of course, is not to bring one's business into the bathroom. But today, no place, and -more importantly - no time is sacred. In an internet-accelerated transaction society, we are to be available to our business associates through our mediating technologies at any hour, day or night. We are "on call" 24/7 (web-slave slang for working 24 hours, seven days a week). We feel we are beating the game if we've programmed our cell phone to ring with a unique melody, so that we don't reach into our coat pockets when someone else's phone rings in the same restaurant.

Thanks to the way that technology accelerates and exacerbates nearly every cultural and economic trend, an increasing number of people, including me, are coming to the conclusion that our time, and by inference our lives, are no longer our own. We work six-days or more, usually answering work-related email well into the night, then use our nominal "day off" to go to the mall and shop - or, if we're feeling particularly guilty, take our kids to a historic shopping centre like Covent Garden instead. There, we buy products at a store with a name like Ye Olde Kite Shop instead of Toys "R" Us, and rationalise that it's an educational, family activity.

We live in an age when online marketers measure human attention in quantities called "eyeball hours." Any moment spent thinking instead of spending, or laughing instead of working is an opportunity missed. And the more time we sacrifice to production and consumption, the less any alternative seems available. My radical proposal to combat the contraction of personal time has been borrowed from the book of Exodus, and it's called the Sabbath. What if we all decided that for one day each week, we would refrain from buying or selling anything? Maybe the ancients didn't pick the number seven out of a hat. Perhaps they understood that human beings can only immerse themselves in commerce for six days at a stretch before losing touch with anything approaching a civic, social, or spiritual reality.

Sabbath is a way to reclaim one's time and, as American kiddie-television hero Mr Rogers might tell us, celebrate that we are special, even sacred, "just the way we are." We don't need to do anything to justify our existence. Not answer the phone, not go online, and not pull out the Visa card. It doesn't require that we retreat to the backwoods, purchase generators, and live off the land, only that we find something to do with our friends or family that's not about money. No, the ball game and movies don't count. Try playing ball in the park, or telling your own stories, instead. You might notice just how few public parks and community activities we have left. If the Sabbath's religious overtones offend your secular humanist sensibilities, then call it the "one-seventh rule."

Take back just one-seventh of your time. I imagine it would throw America into a recession - as well as any other nation that has decided to adopt corporate capitalism as its sole cultural imperative. It's not as if we'll get all that buying and selling done during the other six days. We already spend every waking minute doing that as it is. No, it would mean we would buy and sell one-seventh less stuff. And worse, once we get a taste of what that's like, shopping and spending might even lose some of its appeal. I can't imagine what that would do to the Nasdaq index. They'd call it a bloody revolution! Is a whole day too much to ask? Okay, okay, then. Do it one step at a time. Just promise not to take the telephone into the bathroom.

webTitle: Could you pass the tiger test?

fields.headline: Could you pass the tiger test?
fields.standfirst: Their mission is all too possible: to rip your security system to shreds.  Neil McIntosh  meets the ethical hackers who find your faults before the real cyber-villains do
fields.trailText: Their mission is all too possible: to rip your security system to shreds. Neil McIntosh meets the ethical hackers who find your faults before the real cyber-villains do
fields.body:
George Kurtz's hacking team is any system administrator's worst nightmare. A typically harassed systems boss doesn't know when Kurtz and co have gone to work - at least, not until it is too late. But he will find out, eventually, because they tend not to fail. When this squad gets working on a computer system, it is only a matter of time before it gives up its deepest secrets.

The Rampart crew came together only recently, but individually they've been hacking systems for years, tunnelling their way past defences guarding the most sensitive information you could imagine. Each member of the team is a specialist in their field, be it Unix, Java, Windows NT or one of the other languages and systems found on the world's biggest computers. Each knows the weak links to probe for and is ready to exploit them.

Even more terrifying for our oblivious systems chief: the crew has been hired by his bosses to test his skills.

This is no collection of spotty youths working from a bedroom but an elite "tiger team" of ethical hackers, employed to uncover - any way they can - the systems' weaknesses, before someone else does. With recent events proving even the biggest dot com names vulnerable, tiger team attacks are even becoming part of the "due diligence" process start-ups must go through before they win their vital venture capital.

"We're having a hard time keeping up," says Kurtz, who is chief executive of Rampart, the company he founded after years working on tiger teams at the accountancy giants PricewaterhouseCoopers and Ernst and Young.

"We're working with both dot com companies and established ones. If a dot com doesn't get its security right, they can be out of business before their funding dries up. On a larger scale, more established businesses like financial institutions have just as much to lose because the majority of their business is now is being shifted over to the internet."

Computer security has quickly taken over the mantle of the Y2K bug as America's biggest hi-tech concern. Fuelled by recent "denial of service" attacks on major websites including Amazon and Yahoo!, businesses and the government are desperately looking for ways to beef up their defences. The climate of fear even led to the unlikely scene of Kevin Mitnick, America's most notorious computer hacker and high-tech fraudster, appearing before the senate committee on governmental affairs last week - less than two months after completing a near five year jail term for his crimes.

A smart pin stripe suit and a tie replaced his trademark jeans and sneakers, and the committee room was packed for his testimony. The senators were, according to one observer, "star struck". He was there to help them understand the murky world of hacking. Mitnick's message was simple: the problem is not as straightforward as you would think. While recent attention has focused on attacks launched from the internet using freely available software, Mitnick made it clear that these should not be the biggest concern: the big problem is human fallibility.

Mitnick knows just how to exploit those human weaknesses. David Buchwald, Vice President of New York-based Crossbar Security, would agree. He has had plenty of first hand experience of naivete regarding computer security, sometimes from the most unlikely culprits.

"I know someone who worked for a small bank, as a technology manager," he says. "We were trading email addresses, and she said 'oh - just send email to my bank address. I just use PC Anywhere from home to access that'."

Buchwald goes on to explain that PC Anywhere is a program which allows users to dial in directly to their PC over a phone line from a remote location. The problem is, security built into networks is bypassed: a hacker finding that PC would have a direct route on to a company's network. "And here she is using this simply to trade email for her and her daughter, and putting the security of a bank at great risk."

Buchwald confirms this. "The majority of computer crimes which actually cost money - not downtime like denial of service, but actual theft and fraud - aren't being done by the 17 year old hacker in their home. They're being done by an insider, or somebody working with an insider who already has access to a company's resources."

Hacking from inside systems can be painfully easy. Kurtz, who has also co-written a book on hacking, says that is a weakness that has been known for a long time.

"We can come in on an intranet PC and not know anything more than where the network jack is in the conference room," he says. "In two weeks - actually, it's two or three days - we'll be able to compromise most of the systems on the network.

"We were doing a job a couple of months ago at a financial institution. In one hour I had complete control of all their Unix servers. 'We start with zero knowledge," says Crossbar's Buchwald. "The company will hire us, but not tell us anything about how their systems are structured. "Then, using a combination of internet probing and scanning, and looking to see if there are dial-up lines, we try to gain access to the network. Once that is done, we try to show them their prized resource is actually not secure."

The teams will even test physical security, seeing how many locked doors and secure areas prevent them walking in and moving around buildings, from department to department.

"It shouldn't be easy for somebody from, say, the sales group to saunter up three floors, walk into human resources, and peruse their large bins and find things," says Buchwald.

This combination of attacks - which the likes of Mitnick have proved so effective in their "real" attacks - rarely fail, either at established companies or fresh-faced dot coms. The Crossbar team - which boasts a 100% success rate - has worked its way into a phone company's switches, bank customer databases and even a credit card issuer's authorisation systems.

How do their customers react when they find their security has been brushed aside so easily? "Clients usually are not surprised," says Buchwald. "They pick us on reputation, after all, and know we deliver this kind of service.

"It's usually more embarrassment, and then at that point we work with them to fix the network problems, and set up policies to prevent things like this happening again."

fields.headline: WD Hamilton
fields.standfirst: Biologist who died after Congo expedition was leading Darwinian theorist who explained how natural selection acts on social behaviour
fields.trailText: Bill Hamilton, who has died aged 63 after weeks in intensive care following a biological expedition to the Congo, was the primary theoretical innovator in modern Darwinian biology, responsible for the shape of the subject today.
fields.body:
Bill Hamilton, who has died aged 63 after weeks in intensive care following a biological expedition to the Congo, was the primary theoretical innovator in modern Darwinian biology, responsible for the shape of the subject today.

Educated at Tonbridge school, he came across RA Fisher's Genetical Theory Of Natural Selection while a Cambridge university undergraduate. When he prompted one of his tutors about the book, he was told it was mistaken and that the author, still then lecturing in Cambridge, had "no standing to write about biology".

Bill was captured by the intellectual excitement of this remarkable book, and spent his working life pursuing its line. In so doing, he provided the conceptual foundation for our understanding of how natural selection acts on social behaviour, opened up the area of "extraordinary" (that is, unequal) sex ratios, transformed thinking on sexual selection and produced a corpus of work that demonstrates the capacity of parasite-host interactions to support the maintenance of sexual reproduction. These are the primary Darwinian themes of the second half of the 20th century, and can be understood only in the context of Bill's contributions. He, like Fisher before him, took many steps at once away from conventional paths, and found that eventually biologists would change their conventions.

The career of a typical Hamilton paper can be caricatured as follows. In review, it is panned by referees who demand shortenings and revisions. Immediately after publication, it attracts criticism for obscurity. Its significance slowly emerges through secondary works, further work is inspired, and one or more literatures develop around its themes. Later more mathematical work may even be rather patronising about the paper, and emphasise discrepancies, while the primary finding is that the original idea is abundantly confirmed. The original paper is frequently, indeed often obligatorily, cited in papers in the new literatures, but is not read nearly as often as it deserves to be, since it retains a reputation for obscurity. The joy of reading the original paper is becoming aware of remaining steps.

We can look forward to decades of catching up with Bill's biological thoughts. He fused mathematics and natural history. He had a vast personal knowledge of insects and was pretty good on plants too. He kept a vast card index system. He once led an expedition through Wytham Woods, near the village where he lived, and showed an entranced audience the range of organisms that lived in rotting wood in which, he believed, most important events in insect evolution had occurred.

He loved living in Wytham, latterly with his partner Luisa, an Italian journalist. He gave dinner parties during the periods Luisa was in Oxford to spare guests his own cooking, and they were charming hosts.

Much of his thinking was mathematical in nature. He covered pages in algebra, and often drew scribbled diagrams to help his line of thought. His grasp of biological theory was extremely firm, and all his major works draw on mathematical structures. There are many biologists who are better mathematicians, but Bill more than made up in vision and purpose for any lack of formal skills. To take one example that will appeal to recreational mathematicians, his paper Geometry For The Selfish Herd is based on the idea that herds of animals are arranged on the principle that each individual tries to maximise the chance that, if a predator appears at random and strikes at the nearest prey, somebody else gets eaten. He saw genes everywhere. On a train in New England in 1980, he pointed out clumps of sumac trees. Some had smooth crowns over the whole clump, while others had furrows between individual trees. He was sure that furrows existed between genetically different trees, while trees from the same clone had a smooth crown. Everything he saw in nature was viewed through a genetic lens.

He was a lecturer in genetics at London university's Imperial college from 1964-77, a professor at Michigan university from 1978 to 1984, and then became a fellow and later a research professor of the Royal Society and fellow of New College Oxford. He received many international scientific prizes, but the time-scale of recognition led to difficulties.

In his early life, when none of his work was properly recognised, he even doubted his sanity, as he reports in the first volume of his collected papers (Narrow Roads Of Gene Land). Later, he had difficulty obtaining grants and publishing papers. The time-lag could have entertaining consequences, which occasionally gratified Bill.

The authors of one paper who made rather patronising comments waited 15 years to find the criticised theory accepted as commonplace by their own graduate students. Bill's world had different theoretical presuppositions to the worlds of those around him, and a far-seeing prophet can be a poor teacher. He would often speak so quietly that only the front couple of rows could hear properly. If supplied with a microphone, he would often speak more quietly to maintain the same level of general inaudibility. More than once, I have seen him stop in front of a slide with a graph on it, and become so engaged in contemplation of a particular data point that he grew oblivious of the audience. On the other hand, even these talks were inspiring to the few. And sometimes Bill would prepare a lecture that inspired everyone.

At the end of one such talk at the Royal Society, he showed a slide with a male and female parrot, one bright red and one bright green. Conventional theories could explain why one sex was bright, but not why both were. He ended: "When I understand why one sex is red and the other green, I will be ready to die," and seemed to mean every word.

He often referred to his own death. He said to me that he would not grow old, both in discussions of his paper on senescence ("I feel bucked when anyone refers to that paper") and discussions touching on personal safety. He refused to wear a cycle-helmet, even once they became fashionable and he had been thrown from his bike through a car windscreen. He fantasised in print about being buried by one of his favourite organisms, burying beetles, in his favourite place, the Amazonian rain forest.

In late 1999, Fisher's Genetical Theory was republished, and Bill supplied three paragraphs for the back dust-jacket. After blaming the book for his second class degree, he moves on to ask whether "by the time of my ultimate graduation, will I have understood all that is true in this book, and will I get a first?".

The circumstances of his last fatal expedition are characteristic. He became interested in the theory that HIV arose through poorly conducted vaccination trials in Africa in the 1950s, and felt this theory received less attention than it deserved because of entrenched interests in the medical establishment. The implications of this theory for xenotransplantation are very serious. He went to the jungle to collect chimpanzee faeces with the aim of finding a related virus, and testing whether it was very close to the human virus. While there he contracted malaria, and then collapsed after returning to London. He lived for ideas, was especially partial to unpopular ideas, and thought little of his own safety. His focus of interest was always genes, and it was genes he went to collect.

He was separated from his wife Christine, who he married in 1967. She and their three daughters survive him, together with his partner Luisa.

 William Donald Hamilton, biologist, born August 1 1936; died March 7 2000

fields.headline: John Haynes
fields.standfirst: Pioneer of mediation for divorcing couples
fields.trailText: Until 1978, there was no publicly available way in the United Kingdom of resolving divorce issues other than by separate legal representation. For a third person to help the divorcing partners work out, co-operatively, the consequences of their parting was revolutionary. The Finer Committee in 1973 recommended such a scheme, and the voluntary sector began to provide it in the late 1970s. John Haynes, who has died aged 67, was the inspirational mediator who taught the new profession how to do it.
fields.body:
Until 1978, there was no publicly available way in the United Kingdom of resolving divorce issues other than by separate legal representation. For a third person to help the divorcing partners work out, co-operatively, the consequences of their parting was revolutionary. The Finer Committee in 1973 recommended such a scheme, and the voluntary sector began to provide it in the late 1970s. John Haynes, who has died aged 67, was the inspirational mediator who taught the new profession how to do it.

A skilful teacher, he was passionate that mediation should be a professional activity in its own right, not subsumed into legal practice, social work or counselling.

The formation of the UK College of Family Mediators in 1995 reflects that determination. Haynes played a major, though indirect, part in achieving the inclusion of mediation into the family law act 1996, which led to its availability through legal aid.

Born in Isleworth, Middlesex, he was educated at Ealing's Drayton Manor grammar school. After Royal Air Force national service he moved to the United States in 1957 and from 1964-72 was assistant to the president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers. Because of his skills in conflict management he was invited to teach at the State University of New York, Stony Brook, from 1972-85, gaining his doctorate at the Union Institute, Ohio.

He then moved into family mediation, and became the founding president of the Academy of Family Mediators. In 1984, he gave the inaugural lecture in London of the National Family Conciliation Council (later to become National Family Mediation), and began global travels which led to the training of 20,000 mediators - usually lawyers and social science professionals. He worked in North and South America, Europe, Australasia, South Africa, and the Soviet Union. He also continued to practise.

His books formed the core of this new discipline and included Divorce Mediation: A Practical Guide For Therapists And Counsellors (1981) and, with his wife Gretchen, Mediating Divorce: A Casebook Of Strategies For Successful Family Negotiations. He was a founding member of the World Mediation Forum, whose conference in September he had been due to chair.

Haynes's readiness to express his Quaker faith in finding goodness in people could be surprising. "If you can't see good in your client," he observed, " then dig for it". He possessed humility, clarity, a zest for life, a mischievous sense of humour and generosity in sharing his ideas.

He leaves Gretchen and his two daughters. A scholarship in his name has been established at the Union Institute.

 John Haynes, mediator, born October 28 1932; died December 22 1999

fields.headline: Charles Gray
fields.standfirst: Actor who played a series of elegant cads - and a memorable opponent for James Bond
fields.trailText: The actor Charles Gray, who has died aged 71, never wanted to be loved, but he won plenty of applause for his portraits of silken arrogance, self-importance, oily malice and egotism. Among his film parts were the wily Blofeld, James Bond's antagonist in Diamonds Are Forever (1971), and the chief apostle of evil in Terence Fisher's The Devil Rides Out (1967).
fields.body:
The actor Charles Gray, who has died aged 71, never wanted to be loved, but he won plenty of applause for his portraits of silken arrogance, self-importance, oily malice and egotism. Among his film parts were the wily Blofeld, James Bond's antagonist in Diamonds Are Forever (1971), and the chief apostle of evil in Terence Fisher's The Devil Rides Out (1967).

Gray endowed toffs, cads, crooks, and braggarts with hauteur and elegance. What gave them authenticity was his belief in them. The voice was commanding, though it rarely needed raising, and its tone belonged to high society.

Gray learned his powers of spoken speech as a young Shakespearian in Regent's Park, at Stratford-on-Avon and the Old Vic in the post-war heyday of Richard Burton, John Neville and Paul Rogers. The actor cut an imposing figure; and the voice and its inflections were under such control that together they served undetectably as Jack Hawkins's when that even better actor lost his voice from throat cancer.

Gray's shamelessly affected persona, which could be arrestingly camp or plain overbearing, sometimes spilled over into his private life in Kensington. Not as private as some neighbours, Gray used to entertain friends into the small hours on his apartment balcony. When asked why he cut such a self-important dash, he would protest: "I'm not in the least aristocratic in real life, old boy. I much prefer a pint at the local."

Born in Bournemouth, he spent his early adult years in an estate agent's office. By his mid-20s he felt the call of the stage; and under his real name, Donald Gray, made his first professional appearance in As You Like It (1952) for Robert Atkins in Regent's Park, playing Charles the Wrestler.

Changing his name to Charles for the next production, Cymbeline, Gray then moved to Stratford-on-Avon in walk-on parts and in 1954 joined the Old Vic. Almost immediately he created a stir as the messenger Mercadé, coming on at the end of Frith Banbury's revival of Love's Labour's Lost, with decor and costumes by Cecil Beaton.

By 1956 Gray was taking leads. One of his best was Achilles in Tyrone Guthrie's Edwardian revival of Troilus And Cressida. fields.headline: Re-making Ireland
fields.standfirst:
It is time the Northern Ireland secretary remembered that peace involves a new kind of politics

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Before setting off for Australia and then Washington for St Patrick's day, the Irish premier Bertie Ahern proclaimed: "We have seen the future and it works."
fields.body:
Before setting off for Australia and then Washington for St Patrick's day, the Irish premier Bertie Ahern proclaimed: "We have seen the future and it works."

Ahern's priority is to protect Northern Ireland's newly-inclusive democracy. This is also in the mind of President Clinton, whose senior security adviser was at yesterday's Stormont talks.

It is to be hoped that Tony Blair listens to spirits, for the ghost of Gladstone may be telling him: "Do something lest you lose your longed-for place as a leader blessed by the hand of history."

Blair and his first secretary of state in Northern Ireland did something unique: they addressed all its people as if - as it says in the Good Friday agreement - they had "equally legitimate political aspirations". They brought a new tone and temper to the place.

Blair escaped the trap that has snared every British premier since Gladstone. Devolution may never have been to Blair's taste, but it will be his greatest gift to democracy. Mo Mowlam may not have been to his taste either, and he let his sexism show when he allowed Belfast politicians to treat the bearer of Her Majesty's mandate with coarse disrespect. But together they changed the parameters of politics there.

Mowlam saw that the Northern Ireland office is not neutral. It is hard for us, this side of the water, to appreciate this. The NIO and the secret security state were always part of the problem because they were running the place.

In the peace process Blair found a partner, taoiseach Bertie Ahern, who, as was he, was unencumbered by his past. Ahern and Blair became the bearers of something entirely new: the template for an international treaty rooted in the sovereign will of the people on the island of Ireland.

The Republic changed its constitution and its people voted by almost 95% for the agreement. Britain didn't change its constitution because it hasn't got one. More's the pity.

Blair probably didn't need to give unionist leader David Trimble a pledge on arms de-commissioning - though it was offered with good intentions - because the agreement timetabled processes for decommissioning and those forgotten imperatives: demilitarisation, reform of the police, the criminal justice system and much else.

The taoiseach now warns that to protect Northern Ireland's new democracy there must be a timetable not only for decommissioning but "all armies must be stood down".

Blair's pledge allowed two vetos to sneak back - the unionist habit of domination, and Britain's privileged position over an international treaty, co-signed by the Republic. Britain may not yet appreciate that it is another country and that its taoiseach is the head of another state. But we sure are finding out.

Certainly, Trimble was entitled to expect that in these new times republicanism might extend a helping hand - after all he is no longer merely an enemy, he is a political partner in a power-sharing executive.

But Gerry Adams's people also needed help. They needed time. Trimble wasn't giving it. His arbitrary timetable was always about defeating republicanism.

To these dilemmas Mandelson brought the tradition of former Conservative Northern Ireland secretary, Patrick Mayhew, rather than that of Mowlam. An inappropriate intimacy between the new secretary of state and the NIO and the security state has been noted. He appears arrogant and autocratic, and to have alienated everyone except the unionists is not only daft, it is dangerous.

He now claims the assembly could be revived at a stroke. "How?" wondered SDLP leader Seamus Mallon, since it had taken more than 20 years the last time.

The people of Northern Ireland's first experience of a democratic culture that they themselves designed (with a little help from their friends) is all but dead. Our man in Hillsborough did the deed.

The NIO and the security state - not the assembly - will be setting up and staffing the new institutions, their values and their priorities. But the great thing about the agreement, and the assembly created in its name, is that it is the antithesis of the NIO and the one-party state.

Mandelson has returned the management of Northern Ireland's affairs to the very people who produced the past.

How is policing to be reformed if unionism adds that to its veto? The criminal justice system review, even more profound in its implications than the Patten commission, is ready, but doomed to be deferred. Law and order is restored to those who did not champion change.

The pro-agreement parties have been pressuring Mandelson to bring them together. He finally met them at Stormont yesterday where he had a chastening encounter: they bluntly gave their assessment of the suspension and its aftermath.

Assemblywoman Monica McWilliams, of the Women's Coalition, insists "the whole point is to keep the pro-agreement parties on board.

"It seems that every time we meet Mr Mandelson, we have had to remind him of that."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Rebels free jailed comrades
Leftwing guerrillas freed 100 inmates from a jail during an attack in which they fired homemade missiles on the police station, the courthouse and a bank, officials said yesterday.

No deaths were reported in the assault in El Bordo, 250 miles southwest of Bogota, which was carried out by 200 rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.

Reuters, Bogota

Parents' veto on student dates
Students at Bob Jones University who have an inter-racial relationship must tell their parents before the school will allow it. The university, in Grenville, North Carolina, announced an end to its ban on such relationships last week, but says parents must write to the college to approve the relationship.

AP, North Carolina

Women protest in Mitrovice
Thousands of ethnic Albanian women clutching photographs of missing men yesterday marched through the Kosovan city, Mitrovice, urging international officials to free those held in Serb jails. They demanded that the West unite the city, divided by the Ibar river into Serb and ethnic Albanian sections.

AP, Mitrovice

Doctor used phone in theatre
A Hong Kong doctor who used his mobile phone during an operation has been disciplined for "serious misconduct". The patient was not under anaesthesia and heard him chatting.

Reuters, Hong Kong

fields.headline: Tokyo rail crash
fields.standfirst: Four dead and 33 injured in rush hour collision
fields.trailText: A Tokyo commuter train ripped away the side of a carriage in an oncoming train that had derailed in its path during rush hour yesterday, killing four people and injuring 33.
fields.body:
A Tokyo commuter train ripped away the side of a carriage in an oncoming train that had derailed in its path during rush hour yesterday, killing four people and injuring 33.

"With a 'boom' and an impact, my body was lifted up from the seat and I wondered what happened," one of the passengers, Motoshi Yamabe, 30, was quoted as saying in the Japan Times.

An unidentified woman living nearby told the paper: "I heard a very loud noise and windows shook like it was an earthquake."

Of the 33 people injured, several were in critical condition, police said.

The trouble began when a car in the rear of a train emerging from a tunnel derailed on a curve just short of the elevated Nakameguro station in western Tokyo and struck two carriages of the oncoming commuter train carrying 1,300 passengers.

The cause of the accident was not immediately known. Various early media reports blamed the derailment on an explosion - denied by officials - and a lack of air in the hydraulic shock absorber under the derailed car. Transport ministry officials said a possible cause of the derailment was the track's sharp curve along a slope, Kyodo News agency said.

Police were questioning the trains' operators and officials on suspicion of professional negligence, the newspaper added, but police refused to comment.

Three of those killed in the crash were named by fire department officials and police as Shinsuke Tomihisa, 17, Yasuyo Maki, 37, and Tomomi Yamazaki, 29. No immediate details were available on the identity of the fourth.

In parliament, the Japanese prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, defended his decision to go ahead with a haircut despite having just been told about the crash.

Mr Obuchi, like many of Japan's past prime ministers, has been criticised before for his government's slow response to crises.

The crash is believed to be the worst Tokyo rail accident since 1988, when one train rammed into the back of another which had stopped at a station during the rush hour.

webTitle: Door shut on gays getting married

fields.headline: Door shut on gays getting married
fields.trailText: Californians yesterday voted heavily against recognising gay marriages, in what was widely seen as a test of the state's sexual climate. Voters supported proposition 22 by 61% to 39%, bestowing official recognition only on marriages between men and women.
fields.body:
Californians yesterday voted heavily against recognising gay marriages, in what was widely seen as a test of the state's sexual climate. Voters supported proposition 22 by 61% to 39%, bestowing official recognition only on marriages between men and women.

The move to block recognition of same-sex marriages was backed by the Republican state senator, Peter Knight, whose gay son campaigned against the proposition. Many in the entertainment industry also opposed the bill, and $6m was raised in the unsuccessful attempt to defeat it.

The Catholic church and other religious groups had mobilised supporters in favour of the proposition, which had the backing of 79% of the influential Latino vote. Only in the San Francisco area was the proposition defeated.

Voters also backed another controversial bill - proposition 21 - which allows juveniles to be treated as adults if they commit serious crimes. The punishments for gang-related crimes will be increased under the measure, approved 63% to 37%, and it will now be up to local prosecutors rather than judges to decide whether defendants should be tried as adults.

Civil rights groups had campaigned against the the proposition, under which a new crime of gang recruitment will be created.

California's native American community celebrated proposition 1a's approval, which opened the way for additional casinos on reservations. Its passing, by 65% to 35%, was bankrolled by the existing reservation casinos. It is thought that Nevada casinos will now seek partnerships with those on the reservations.

However, voters turned out in large numbers - 52% of the electorate compared with 42% four years ago - to defeat attempts by the tobacco industry to repeal a tobacco tax. In a state where smoking is banned in public places, the move was defeated by 72% to 28%.

webTitle: Report confirms oil slick cancer risk

fields.headline: Report confirms oil slick cancer risk
fields.trailText: Thousands of volunteers and military conscripts who have helped clean up Brittany's beaches after an oil leak have been exposed to a cancer risk, an official report revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of volunteers and military conscripts who have helped clean up Brittany's beaches after an oil leak have been exposed to a cancer risk, an official report revealed yesterday.

Pregnant women are particularly at risk, along with workers involved in treating seabirds soaked in fuel that leaked from the Maltese-registered tanker, Erika, after she sank before Christmas. The report says protective clothing lessens, but does not remove, the danger.

French company TotalFina, which chartered the vessel, insists the cargo was industrial fuel, but environmental organisations have alleged it was toxic waste from a refinery.

The government analysis, carried out by the national industrial environment institute, Ineris, follows a study by a private laboratory whose findings last weekend caused a rapid drop in the number of people helping to clean a 250-mile stretch of the Atlantic coastline. Their departure coincided with reports of new leaks from the sunken wreck, which still has 12,000 tonnes of oil aboard.

Ineris's disclosure was received angrily by an organisation called the Anti-Black Tide Committee, which has helped recruit volunteers, including children, from all over Europe.

The group's chairman, Franck Laval, said volunteers had been tricked by the government's reluctance to acknowledge the danger of clearing the first slicks by scraping rocks, shovelling oil into skips or treating seabirds, of which 58,000 have died.

"I won't go as far as saying it was criminal neglect but there was certainly a serious error of judgment," he added. "If the cancer risk had been admitted more than two months ago no one would have come to help. The authorities had to be forced to carry out these health tests."

Henri Pezerat, an official of Alert, which studies risks at work, said one of the poisonous substances in the fuel was also present in cigarettes.

"But you would have to smoke two or three million before inhaling as much as from a kilo of the Erika's toxic cargo," he added. "Just think how much there is in 11,000 tonnes."

Reports of a growing boycott by volunteers, following Ineris's warning that there was a "real danger of cancer", makes it unlikely that many tourist beaches will be clean before Easter. There were reports of fumes causing vomiting and headaches.

The report said that the fuel contained nearly 20 times more cancer-causing materials than the level needed for the cargo to be declared as potentially dangerous.

Although TotalFina has been accused of disguising the real nature of the fuel, it has been confirmed that the cancer risk was registered before shipping the cargo with instructions that it should "not be dumped into the environment".

Meanwhile, a navy vessel has been rushed to the Erika, now lying 120m (394ft) deep, to start a pumping operation after a new three-mile slick was reported by Greenpeace.

Pope John Paul II's imminent apology for the Catholic church's errors was snagged yesterday on his decision to beatify a predecessor who kidnapped a Jewish child.

Italy's Jews denounced the elevation of Pius IX as in effect condoning the 1858 snatching of Edgardo Mortara, who was raised as the pope's son after a maid said she had baptised him.

They said putting a "criminal" like Pius on the road to sainthood had soured the build-up to Sunday's long-awaited, sweeping mea culpa for 2,000 years of mistakes and persecution.

They did not want to spurn the offer of reconciliation, but said it was necessary to speak out against the beatification of a pontiff who herded Rome's Jews into a ghetto and forcibly converted their children.

Liberal Catholics fear that the ailing John Paul's increasingly frantic pace of canonisations and beatifications is elevating unsuitable subjects and provoking backlashes.

Protests have flared in Spain over a proposal to sanctify as martyrs 10,000 priests, monks and nuns who backed Franco in the civil war.

Italy's Jews hesitated to speak out just before the mea culpa, but said that Pius's beatification, planned for September, could not go unchallenged.

"He was a criminal, a theological kidnapper," said Enrico Modigliani at a press conference of Jewish organisations.

Pius IX, who reigned for 32 years until 1878, was initially a reformer, but the revolutions of 1848 shook him. He executed enemies, promulgated the doc trine of papal infallibility and ordered Jews back to the ghetto which had been torn down.

Jewish children were kidnapped, but the most sensational case occurred in Bologna when papal police seized the six-year-old Edgardo Mortara.

Even though his wealthy parents petitioned papal and Italian courts, and Britain, France, the US, the Netherlands and Spain lobbied for his return, Pius adopted the boy as his son.

The Vatican considered beatifying Pius in 1954, but it emerged that he had humiliated and psychologically scarred his charge. The idea was dropped until 1986, when an alleged miracle was submitted for scrutiny.

In his eagerness to supply Catholic role models, John Paul has outstripped his combined 20th-century predecessors in beatifying and canonising more than 1,200 candidates.

Israel, aware that a bigger fight looms next year when the Vatican may beatify Pius XII despite claims that he failed to help Jews during the Holocaust, has not protested over Pius IX.

Yesterday's protest ratcheted up tension over how specific and how contrite Sunday's apology should be. Some conservative Catholics are appalled at the initiative.

The Catholic writer Margaret Hebblethwaite said Pius IX had been chosen to balance the simultaneous beatification of John XXIII, who is revered by liberals for calling the modernising second Vatican council.

fields.headline: What's eating George Walden?
fields.standfirst: One is 'an ageing prat'. The other is 'a monumental prat'.  Peregrine Worsthorne   on his very public falling out with an old friend
fields.trailText: One is 'an ageing prat'. The other is 'a monumental prat'.  Peregrine Worsthorne   on his very public falling out with an old friend.
fields.body:
According to George Walden, writing in the letter's columns of this week's New Statesman, I am "an ageing poseur of no interest or consequence". What have I done to deserve such contempt? Truth to tell, quite a lot; and the least of it was in the article of mine, commemorating the Labour Party's 100th anniversary, which provoked this retaliation. That article, which contained only a passing reference to George, was just the last straw, so to speak, which broke - in the absence of a funny bone - George Walden's back.

We used to be friends. As an aspiring official in the foreign office, he was a bit too prone to suck up, and continued to do so in his early days as a Conservative MP. Indeed, I recall with pleasure at least one lunch as his guest at the House of Commons, the purpose of which was to tell me that he agreed with every word I wrote. Relations grew even friendlier when he became brother-in-law to my friend, Paul Johnson, having married Marigold Johnson's beautiful and talented sister, Sarah, the art expert.

So what went wrong? I rather suspect that the rot set in one day when we were, by chance, lunching at the communal table in the Garrick Club and I overheard George pontificating to a number of glazed-eyed members about English literature and the modern novel. What had set him off was the fact that the Booker Prize judges of that year had just chosen Kazuo Ishiguro's, The Remains of the Day - "nostalgic snobbery", as he put it, "about a pre-war English butler" - instead of Martin Amis's much more "relevant" London Fields, about contemporary dropouts and drug addicts.

Annoyed by such Philistine trendiness I tried to point out that Ishiguro's novel was a subtle study of loyalty, showing it to be as much a vice as a virtue, and as such a subject of perennial interest and importance. Then, hitting a bit below the belt, I went on to inquire whether he thought an English butler too lowly a figure to be expected to do justice to such a grand theme?

Looking back, I cannot quite remember why I had become so angry. I think it must have been because, for the first time, I began to see in George the outlines of that monumental prat which he has gone on to become.

That, however, would have been that, had not, a few years later, George Walden been made chairman of the Booker Prize judges.

Do you remember when the narrator of Anthony Powell's Dance to the Music of Time rubs his eyes with horror on hearing that the insufferable Widmerpool, of all people, has been chosen to chair the Arts Council, or some such body? Well, my reactions were exactly of that order. It was too bad to be true and I wrote a column in the Daily Telegraph saying so. Then, most recently of all, I piled on the heat by writing a vicious review in the Spectator of his self-aggrandising autobiography, Lucky George.

So, as I say, his retaliation in this week's New Statesman is more than justified and long overdue. I had certainly asked to be given the old heave-ho, and deserved everything I got. The trouble though, is that, in his letter, he goes to great lengths to insist that he has not read a line that I have written "for a decade or more"; has not read, that is, the very words which might be thought to justify him in hitting back.

What can the trouble really be? I fear that it all comes down to the servant problem, which seems to have got under George's skin. Arguing with me, he writes, is quite beneath him; "it would be like arguing with the servants". Then, searching around for a way to deliver the coup de grace, he can think of no worse insult than to say that I have "the intellect and manner" and even the appearance of, wait for it, "an under butler", a de haut en bas putdown worthy of that most superior person, George Nathaniel, Marquis Curzon of Kedleston.

Oddly enough, in the book section of the same issue of the New Statesman in which George's abusive assault on me appears, there is a review of a recently published diary of a Prussian aristocrat who, on meeting Hitler in 1936, writes him off as the very "stereotype of the head waiter". Sad to say, the Prussian aristocrat's disdain cost him dear, since the head waiter in question, less than 10 years later, did the brave aristocrat to death in Dachau. Autres temps, autres moeurs. Lucky George indeed.

fields.headline: Saturday morning fever
fields.standfirst: Ant and Dec's madcap Saturday morning kids' show took on the might of the BBC and won. Now they've got their eyes on prime time. Bibi van der Zee met two boys fast becoming a national institution.
fields.trailText: Ant and Dec's madcap Saturday morning kids' show took on the might of the BBC and won. Now they've got their eyes on prime time. Bibi van der Zee met two boys fast becoming a national institution.
fields.body:
There are crowds of teenagers outside the London Weekend Television studios all Saturday morning while Ant and Dec record SM:TV and CD:UK. Once the shows are over, out come Mel C (who signs every single autograph book offered to her), Savage Garden, the Bluetones and various boy and girl bands who are largely indistinguishable.

The girls go mad, jump up and down, and scream a lot. And when they spot Ant and Dec up in the bar being photographed against the huge glass windows, they form a drop-jawed semi-circle like triffids, staring and waving up at us until I, uncomfortably, suggest moving. "Nah, they're all right," says Dec, smiling easily down at them and waving back. "This isn't actually as bad as when we were doing the music side of stuff." Ant smiles and waves, too. "That was full-on, that was, girls standing outside your house and stuff. Now it's calmed down, apart from Saturdays, when they come for the bands, really. You get used to it. Really."

They're both small and slim, with their three-letter names and floppy, boy-band haircuts. Ant (Anthony McPartlin) is the dark-haired one, while Dec (Declan Donnelly) is frequently referred to as the Paul McCartney lookalike: cheery, open-faced and always likely to make a joke if he feels all is not going smoothly.

A year ago, few people over the age of 17 would have been interested in telling the difference between them; but SM:TV and CD:UK have changed all that. As friend and journalist Jordan Paramor says: "When they went into pubs a couple of years ago, big blokes used to want to beat them up. Now they come over and tell them the answer to that week's Wonky Donkey." Their children's Saturday morning TV show has become a cult favourite, with at least half its 2.2m audience made up of 16 to 34-year-olds. Sections like Chums, their take-off of Friends, has celebs ringing up and asking to appear (the week that I meet them, Caprice has turned up to play Ant's girlfriend).

Although no one will ever know for sure, rumours flew in early 1999 that the reason Zoe Ball was quitting Live and Kicking was because, for the first time in television history, ITV was beating the BBC on a Saturday morning.

Their new show for the BBC - Friends Like These, designed to capture even "people who hate game shows" - is showing signs of doing even better. The ad at the end of the one-off pilot last year, asking for teams of friends to take part, received 2,000 answers, and the programme has been getting ratings around the 6m mark: not much below Blind Date. The BBC have already commissioned a second series.

Ant and Dec have enjoyed quite extraordinary success at almost everything they've tried from the age of 13. Originally, they were both cast in the BBC series Byker Grove, a kids programme set around a Newcastle youth club, in which they played PJ and Duncan, a couple of boys forming a pop band. Then it seemed like a good idea for the boy band in the series to really release a single. Although Tonight I'm Free, their first single, went absolutely nowhere, the next single went to number 15, and suddenly they were a real pop group, touring and being screamed at and followed around by teenage girls wanting to have their babies. Of the 14 singles they released, most reached the top 15.

They won Smash Hits awards, and Brit awards (plus a Bafta in 1996), and their albums - the first two under the name of PJ and Duncan, the last as Ant and Dec - went platinum. But music was not really what they wanted to be doing. They're both self-confessed television addicts: when Dec moved house last year, he sorted out cable before he'd even bought a bed. "They just decided not to renew their contract with Telstar," says Paramor. "They got to the studio, and were due to be working on the next album, and just looked at each other and realised they didn't really want to be there, and phoned up the record company and said, 'Sorry, that's it'."

Ant and Dec had had a couple of good mornings on the Big Breakfast, then they sold their breakfast TV show to London Weekend Television in late 1997, but the launch was a disaster. "For the first six months, the BBC were thrashing us - every week," remembers Dec. "Each Saturday, we'd just think, 'They're going to can us'."

Executive producer Conor McAnally describes the way they tried to redesign the show while they were on air, "which is never a good idea. But there were things we had to get rid of, like outside broadcasts that were supposed to be live interviews at places like record stores. We'd get there and there wouldn't be anyone around because, of course, no one buys records on a Saturday morning, for God's sake." At the time, he points out, the BBC had dominated Saturday morning scheduling for as long as anyone could remember. "They had about 45% of the viewing audience, while we trailed along with about 28%. But we made the decision to keep running over the summer, when Live & Kicking shut down for the holidays. Slowly, things changed. Now those figures are completely reversed." Exit Zoe. Enter Ant and Dec.

The boys at the heart of all this are stunningly normal. No one has a bad word to say about them: down-to-earth and nice are the words that crop up. "We learnt early on to get on with it: as kids on Byker Grove, it wasn't possible for us to muck around." Everyone who works with them talks about what a pleasure it is. "Utterly professional," is how David Young, head of light entertainment at the BBC and the inventor of Friends Like These, describes them. "They're really nice guys, very intelligent. We didn't want old-school light entertainment, we didn't want spangly jackets. We wanted something that would pull back that 16- to 34-year-old audience that probably didn't really like Saturday night TV, that had been disillusioned with it. And it seems as though Ant and Dec will be able to do it."

Their friendship appears rock-solid: they no longer share a flat, but have bought houses just down the road from each other in Chiswick. They go to their regular pubs together every week to do pub quizzes, and both have long-term girlfriends. "It's funny," says Dec. "I don't really think of us as TV presenters. I think of TV presenters as responsible people who show children what to do with empty fairy liquid bottles. Not a couple of blokes who don't mind telling kids to shut up."

webTitle: Welcome to Britain's capital of happiness

fields.headline: Welcome to Britain's capital of happiness
fields.standfirst: When the telephone came into service in 1902, Hull's civic fathers embraced the new technology. This week, the phone service they created became one of Britain's 100 biggest firms, having already turned the city's council into Britain's wealthiest local authority and made small fortunes for the one in three residents who bought shares.  Martin Wainwright reports on a modern fairy tale
fields.trailText: When the telephone came into service in 1902, Hull's civic fathers embraced the new technology. This week, the phone service they created became one of Britain's 100 biggest firms, having already turned the city's council into Britain's wealthiest local authority and made small fortunes for the one in three residents who bought shares.  Martin Wainwright reports on a modern fairy tale.
fields.body:
There was once a beautiful little city which had to dress in rags and lived with hideous statistics of deprivation until, one day, a handsome prince came along and said: "Cinders, there is a magic object in your grubby cellar which can turn everything else into gold."

Cinders, whose real name was Kingston upon Hull (she was a genuinely aristocratic lady fallen on hard times) looked all round, at her broken council estates and grotty, bottom-of- the-league table schools, and she couldn't see anything. But then, suddenly, she heard a magic ringing and there, in a beautiful white box with glass windows, was the magic moneymaking telephone.

And this is a true story, a modern version of Whisky Galore with the whisky bottles changed into mobiles and digital TV internet links, even if they tell it rather more crudely in Hull. "There's a certain justice, in't there," says Marie Coleman, scampering to get back to work at her sandwich stall near the river Hull swingbridge. "The phone service was the only thing Hull council ever knew how to run."

The phone service, floated only last July as a public limited company, gatecrashed the FTSE 100 index of the biggest companies in Britain this week, valued at an extraordinary £5.6bn. This makes Hull city council, thanks to its 45% share, the richest local authority in the country. More, in Britain's current capital of happiness, 44,000 local people have stakes in the firm which have multiplied seven-fold from their original values of between £100 and £5,000.

"The first thing people used to talk about when they came into work was football," says the security man on reception at Kingston Communications, the Stock Exchange name of the former Hull Corporation Telephone Service, where the number of radiant beaming faces compare with a training school for Mormon missionaries. "Now it's nothing but the price of the shares - and not just our shares. People are getting the knack of it."

Behind him on the wall is a plaque which gives another spin to this story and takes it beyond a simple Lady Luck bonanza for a place which needs good fortune more than most. It recalls the fact that Telephone House, one of the most hideous of many hideous Old Labour monuments in the Yorkshire port, was opened by Lord Morrison of Lambeth - Peter Mandelson's grandfather - who for some reason connected with the then Labour mafiosi, was in 1964 the High Steward of Kingston upon Hull.

The pride engraved in the bronze lettering reflects an experience of municipal socialism and public sector management which was on target right from the start, and never got mired in complacency or deadbeat ways. When the novel, and to some rather suspicious new telephone invention was licensed for service in 1902, Hull Corporation was one of a score that took up the option offered to town halls with zest.

They were influenced by the spirit which animated nearby Bradford at around the same time, but in the different world of sewage, where enterprise and ruthless competition worthy of a Murdoch or Gates saw lanolin, women's cosmetics and soap produced at a profit from the cleaned and hydraulically-pressed products of the city's sewers.

Hull's councillors had similar Victorian drive and imagination. Along with the white telephone boxes that became one of the city's trademarks they introduced unlimited phone use for a fixed annual fee 96 years before Alta Vista's announcement this week. There was no internet in 1904, but for six guineas any subscriber could phone anywhere as often and for as long as they liked. Fifty years later, the package was on offer unchanged, except that it cost £36.

The idea was twinned with a fixed charge for local calls, like the old one penny to see Kew Gardens, which also survives for Kingston Communications' 165,000 East Yorkshire subscribers, albeit now set at 5.5p. "People can, and do, talk all day for less than sixpence round here," says Sue Frost, who works at Hull Council for Voluntary Service, "though my mother's not from Hull and she's never got used to it. She only rings us from Hedon (about six miles from Hull) but she talks very fast just because it's the phone."

Sue reckons that her family is one of very few in largely affluent Beverley not to have taken up the share offer, which was marketed hard locally by Kingston and made as easy as possible in paperwork terms by branches of banks and buildings societies. The company knew the strength of local loyalty and its importance in stabilising share values in the uncertain world of the Stock Exchange.

Colin Ashcroft of Kingston points out that only 7,000 of the original investors - every third adult in Hull - sold their shares, and even the FTSE announcement - an obvious tempter for profit-takers, saw the £15.79p price dip by less than 40p. "Hull shareholders have got 8% of the stock and if you add that to the size of the council's stake, with institutions holding the rest, you've got a pretty good guarantee of stability," he says. The council can be a liability, though. A suggestion that Hull might sell up, thought to have emanated from the guildhall, sent Kingston's value crashing by £200m last autumn, although it soon pulled back up.

Her living room in Crayford Close almost disappeared under Guildhall bigwigs as the council's team of fitters - reinforced by a new 12-strong evening shift and 14 extra window specialists - celebrated the first of thousands of contracts paid for by the Kingston flotation cash.

The rest of the spending list reads like a municipal version of the average lottery winner's promise of a bungalow for mum and dad, a new car and a really nice holiday: £35m is going to repair all the city's schools, £10m as an extra for social services, £30m for street lighting and sweeping (but not, contrary to rumour, repaving with gold) and £38m to a SuperStadium for rugby league and Hull City's Tigers. The latter may be just in time; the Tigers' players threatened to walk out on Tuesday night, shortly before going down 3-0 to Rotherham, unless their wages were paid within 14 days.

Doyle's top priority, however, is longer term, recognising that what goes up can come down, and in keeping with the prudence shown by his 44,000 neighbours who are spurning easy money - such as Sarah Poole, receptionist at Hull Chamber of Commerce, who is sticking with the £7,192 which has mushroomed from her £1,000 investment in July. Doyle is using the huge success of both the old phone company, its privatisation and now its flotation, to lobby the treasury for greater flexibility in local authority finance.

The city is leading a campaign to end the ring-fencing of councils' housing revenue accounts, which means even Hull is having to propose a maximum £1.60 council house rent increase (while freezing council tax, where there is more flexibility, for at least two years). Councillors are also talking to Gordon Brown's officials about easing the very tight restrictions on town hall investment policies, perhaps by allowing the sort of trustee status which gives more freedom but no less responsibility to trustees of superannuation funds. Interest on their treasure chest could double if they succeed.

Meanwhile, Hullonians show little dramatic inclination to leave their city, which is indeed a princess emerging from rags, with graceful Georgian buildings, the romantic keening of gulls and the excitement of brightly coloured funnels and foreign flags as you sweep in along the inevitably aldermanic Clive Sullivan Way from the M62. The "grim and head-scarfed wives from fishy-smelling streets" conjured up in a bite-back at Philip Larkin by a lesser-known Hull poet, Maurice Rutherford, are being PR branded out of existence by the council's London consultants Wolff Olins, marketeers for the likes of Orange and First Direct, and one of the two universities is pumping students into new lofts and attics at the confluence of the Hull and the Humber.

If people are spending a bit more, it's going on enjoying the place, rather than blowing their gains on a ski trip or a cruise, according to Julie Walton, who manages the hi-tech, metal island shopping centre on Prince's Quay. Last week the ferries and flights from Humberside airport were average; but the tramp through her mall was 15% up on the same period last year.
