fields.headline: The Dali murder mystery
fields.trailText: Salvador Dali certainly found Perpignan station a turn-on. On August 27 1965, he declared it the centre of the universe, a fact which would probably be reduced to a mere footnote in the art history books by now were it not that, in the past five years, three young women have gone missing in Perpignan, and in a very macabre fashion.
fields.body:
Nothing remarkable about it, really. Classic, single-storey, 19th century stuff: four platforms, smart red bricks, pale stone arches. Pleasing in its way, but hardly arousing, hardly sexy. Unless you happen to be a more than usually surreal surrealist. Or, perhaps, a serial killer.

Salvador Dali certainly found Perpignan station a turn-on. At 4.21pm on August 27 1965, he declared it the centre of the universe, alerted to its aura by a bright, shining light and a revelation in which "everything become overpoweringly evident". As if to confirm the vision, he later wrote: "My penis sprang to attention with joy and ecstasy."

In recognition of this brave, if indisputably barmy, attempt to propel a small, dozing Catalan town to cosmic fame - Dali, driving up to Paris from his native Spain, would often stop there to send his luggage ahead by train - the local authorities in Perpignan promptly named the square outside the station Place Salvador Dali. The surrealist master himself was to feature the building in future canvases, several of them filled with the bizarre, grotesque and sexually violent imagery that is a hallmark of his work. One painting titled The Railway Station at Perpignan includes a depiction of a man preparing to sodomise a young woman.

All of which would probably be reduced to a mere footnote in the art history books by now were it not for the fact that, in the past five years, three young women have gone missing in Perpignan, and in a very macabre fashion. One, Tatiana Andujar, aged 17, took a train into town and was never seen again. The horribly mutilated bodies of the other two - Mokhtaria Chaib, 19, and Marie-Hélène Gonzalez, 22 - were found near the station.

Short of other clues, police are wondering if they are not dealing with a serial killer inspired by the tortured visions of Salvador Felipe Jacinto Dali i Domenech, born May 11 1904, died January 23 1989. "It's a theory they've tested and are continuing to test," says Mohamed Iaouadan, a lawyer for the Chaib family. "I've seen the files, believe me. They've commissioned analytical reports from art experts on the significance of Dali paintings. They're looking for anything that could tie in with the killings, anything."

Dali's world, on display in an otherworldly museum in his hometown of Figueras, just over the Spanish border a few miles from Perpignan, is a weird one. The artist had a marked preference for masturbation over intercourse. His obsession with vaginas, says one biographer, stems from a profound "loathing of the female genitalia". He was, writes Ian Gibson in The Shameful Life of Salvador Dali, "an impotent outsider", desperate to join in his friends' sexual escapades but incapable of doing so.

Dislocated body parts, notably female breasts, began to appear in his work when the artist was in his early 20s. Later productions feature sprawling, limbless, decapitated bodies; in some, unattached vaginas and anuses fly across the canvas. In the grotesque 1934 The Spectre of Sex Appeal, a small boy stares up at a naked female body without a head and a hand, and with sacks replacing her breasts and womb.

That's the point. The naked body of Gonzalez, who worked in a butcher's shop at the seaside resort of Argelès-sur-Mer, a few miles south of Perpignan, was found on wasteland near the motorway to Barcelona in June 1998. She had been dead for 10 days. Her head and hands had been cut off. Her vagina had been neatly sliced out, and some of her internal organs had been removed and placed carefully in a cardboard box by her side.

Gonzalez was independent and bubbly, says her family's lawyer, Etienne Nicolau. She had come into Perpignan on June 16, on the 8.33pm train from Argelès. She had left the station, crossed in front of the Htel Paris-Barcelone, turned right into the Rue Courteline, lined with apartment blocks. Four hundred yards further on, she had passed the Café Figuère before plunging into a dodgy district of lock-up garages and disused workshops.

She was, Nicolau is sure, planning to hitch a ride to her parents' home in Toulouges, a small village just outside Perpignan. The route she took is one used by a lot of young people who arrive at the station and want a lift out of town. The favoured spot is the Avenue Julien Panchot, 20 minutes' walk from the station. That afternoon, she had told her parents she would be with them by 10pm.

For the Perpignan police, the killing was a grisly echo of another unsolved murder from December 1997. Five days before Christmas, Mokhtaria Chaib had spent the evening with a boyfriend in the Avenue Générale de Gaulle, 200 yards from the railway station. She left his apartment at 11pm, planning to walk back to her campus lodgings at the Cité Universitaire three miles away.

A sociology student of Algerian origin, Chaib had fought long and hard with her father and stepmother to lead a life free from the constraints of Islam. She had run away from home at 16, spent a year in a teenage hostel, but completed her baccalauréat exam successfully and enrolled at the university in September. She had worked that summer in a beach restaurant at Collioure, just down the coast, to fund her studies. She was a laugh, her friends say: the plaque they paid for on her tomb reads: "A funny lady."

Like Gonzalez, Chaib's route took her past the station, down the Rue Courteline, across the Avenue Julien Panchot, and on past a cemetery to the campus. Someone out walking their dog found her nude body the next morning. She had died from three stab wounds to the heart. Her breasts had been cut off and her uterus removed. Her anus, too, had been expertly sliced out. According to the police doctors, the whole operation could only have been done with a scalpel, and must have taken close to an hour.

After Chaib's murder, investigators made the link to Tatiana Andujar, a secondary school student who disappeared on the evening of September 24 1995. Another rebellious teen, Andujar had left home for two months that summer, sharing an apartment with friends and working as a waitress in the beach resort of Port Leucate. Back with her Spanish parents in the nearby village of Llupia for her last year at school, she was heading home after a weekend in Toulouse. She called her father to ask him to pick her up at Perpignan station when she arrived, at about 7.30pm. He couldn't leave home.

"So she says no problem, I'll hitch," says Nicolau, who also represents the Andujars. "And she leaves the station - she was seen there by two schoolfriends - and walks down Avenue Générale de Gaulle and turns into the Rue Courteline. And disappears, completely."

For a while, the police had a suspect who was almost too good to be true. Picked up in the wake of the Chaib murder, Andres Palomino-Barrios was an unemployed Peruvian-born doctor. A homosexual drifter and down-and-out eccentric, he had been kicked out of - or let go from - half a dozen hospitals in south-east France, and was banned from practising further. He had a police record, for illegal residence, trafficking in stolen passports and stealing hospital equipment: stethoscopes and surgical instruments. He lived 300 yards from where Chaib's body was found, little more than half a mile from the station. And, almost unbelievably, he was in training to become a butcher.

Palomino-Barrios was arrested, and placed under formal investigation for "murder and acts of barbarity". But there was not a shred of forensic evidence against him. Minute searches of his sordid apartment and minivan - which one witness saw him washing vigorously the morning after Chaib was killed - revealed nothing. No blood, no fingerprints, no semen, no hair, no DNA.

Police did turn up traces of blood on his clothes, but they proved to be from an animal - which was put down to his butcher's apprenticeship. And while the chief suspect was nearing the end of the six months he spent in Perpignan prison, Gonzalez was murdered, dismembered and partially disembowelled. The doctor was released.

Plenty of policemen in Perpignan, however, believe he is guilty of at least one murder. Plenty - there are 15 on the case, full-time, and they have so far interviewed 2,000 people - also believe that, if he is guilty, this pretty, pastel-coloured town with its terrace cafes, Catalan restaurants and winding medieval streets has not one but two sickos on the loose.

"Barrios is definitely the man for me," says one senior policeman, who asked not to be named. "But there could well be two or even three killers here. There's absolutely nothing to say that the last murder, the Gonzalez girl, wasn't done to throw us off the scent - by some guy who owed Barrios something."

The same investigator is, perhaps understandably, less forthcoming about the Dali angle. "Yes," he sighs, "we've looked at it. It's improbable, but this whole thing is so murky you have to look everywhere. At present we have nothing, sweet nothing. And some of those paintings show women with their heads off, their bowels removed, no genitals to be seen. They do . . . well, they do remind you."

Stare long enough at a particular strain of Dali painting and you can see almost anything you're looking for: so many twisted, butchered bodies; so many grotesque imaginings. The artist himself once said, famously, that the only difference between himself and a madman was that he was not mad.

"I'm not sure what I think," says Iaouadan, the Chaibs' lawyer. "Maybe it's madness, this Dali stuff. But killers are inspired by films, aren't they? Why not by decapitations, eviscerations and dismemberments in the painting of the man who made this town famous?"

Stare long enough at a particular strain of Dali painting and you can see almost anything you're looking for: so many twisted, butchered bodies; so many grotesque imaginings. The artist himself once said, famously, that the only difference between himself and a madman was that he was not mad. "I'm not sure what I think," says Iaouadan, the Chaibs' lawyer. "Maybe it's madness, this Dali stuff. But killers are inspired by films, aren't they? Why not by decapitations, eviscerations and dismemberments in the painting of the man who made this town famous?"

fields.headline: No: 1590
fields.standfirst: Victor Kiam
fields.trailText: Victor Kiam
fields.body:
Age: 73.

Appearance: Clean shaven and persuasive salesman.

I remember, he's the man who liked his razor so much . . . he bought the company, correct. In 1979 Victor Kermit Kiam II was given a Remington Microscreen electric razor by his wife. He used it, liked it (it shaved as close as a blade you'll recall), acquired Remington Industries via a leveraged buy-out, and the rest is advertising industry.

So what's he doing now? Kiam's latest appearance in the UK came this week in the witness stand at the high court in London.

Don't tell me, the razors didn't shave as close as a blade? Far from it - he's suing the Mirror newspaper over an article in the paper's City Slickers column which said that his company Ronson was in serious trouble. The Mirror denies the libel.

Odd they should be accused of getting that wrong. If anyone should know about "serious trouble" it's the Slickers. Your knowledge of the press is as impressive as your recall of seminal 70s TV moments. You are referring, are you not, to the recent dismissal of the authors of the City Slickers column, Mr James Hipwell and Mr Anil Bhoyrul, from the Mirror for breaching the PCC code relating to financial journalists?

If that means they were fired for trading in shares they had tipped, yes, I am. What did they say about the Vicster? In January last year Hipwell wrote a piece reporting that receivership was round the corner for Ronson, a firm in which he owns shares.

VKK II must have been furious: He's never been the kind to take this sort of thing on the chin. The truth, he says, is that he's turned Ronson round from the brink of disaster.

Where does this leave the Mirror? In court. They did offer Kiam a £50,000 settlement last week but it was rejected as "too little, too late".

A clear case of your money back. Touche.

Do say: "It could be a close shave, Piers."

Don't say: "Give my regards to Lady Remington."

webTitle: Volvo hardens its stance on bid for rival Scania

fields.headline: Volvo hardens its stance on bid for rival Scania
fields.standfirst: Truck maker at impasse with EU competition body
fields.trailText: Volvo raised the stakes in its battle with the European commission over its bid for fellow Swedish truck maker Scania yesterday when it ruled out making further concessions to have the deal approved.
fields.body:
Volvo raised the stakes in its battle with the European commission over its bid for fellow Swedish truck maker Scania yesterday when it ruled out making further concessions to have the deal approved.

Chief executive Leif Johansson also warned that his board would look at any bids made for the bus and truck maker if the Scania deal were blocked.

"The conditions do not exist for Volvo to reach agreement with the EU competition authority," he said.

"If a bid is proposed [subsequently] the board will look at it and consider what is best for shareholders."

Although the decision to rule out further concessions is academic in the short run because the deadline for modifying the merger terms has already passed, Volvo's move will increase the political pressure on both competition commissioner Mario Monti and the Swedish government.

This weekend prime minister Goran Persson's social democratic party meets to discuss the timing of Sweden's accession into the single currency. But campaigning on the issue will be hindered if, as looks increasingly likely, the EC blocks the merger of the two Swedish truck makers, particularly if one or even both is then taken over by a foreign automotive maker.

"It is bound to have an impact if the Swedish public sees what it does not consider a fair deal. Euroscepticism has always been quite high and [a decision to block the bid] would definitely make that a little bit worse," according to Gustav Wessberg, deputy director general of the confederation of Swedish industry.

"The play here is pressure on the commission; they want to send a message to the politicians," said Hans Westberg, an analyst at den Danske Bank.

The EC is concerned that the merger would give the Volvo-Scania combination 90% of the Swedish truck market and around two-thirds of the markets in the Nordic area.

But the Swedish truck makers argue that the commission should look across the whole single market, rather than looking at one region in isolation. Volvo-Scania's share of the western European market would be around 30%.

"We are not doing this [merger] to strengthen our position in the Nordic countries - this is a global issue," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: Endowment top-up trap
fields.standfirst: FSA bars insurers from quoting extra premiums for at-risk policies
fields.trailText: Letters to millions of mortgage endowment victims next month will not be allowed to encourage people with shortfalls to top-up with another endowment policy after a battle between the financial services authority and life insurance companies.
fields.body:
Letters to millions of mortgage endowment victims next month will not be allowed to encourage people with shortfalls to top-up with another endowment policy after a battle between the financial services authority and life insurance companies.

Around 5m people will receive letters from April onwards spelling out any shortfall, with up to 3m policies believed to have fallen behind the target required to repay the mortgage. The letters, which follow a "holding" circular sent out in January, were expected to tell homebuyers how much extra they will have to put up every month to put their policy back on track.

But the financial services authority is so concerned that policyholders will pour more money into the failing policies rather than consider other options - such as taking out an Isa instead - that it has banned endowment sellers from quoting extra premium levels in the letters.

It is believed to have been particularly concerned about life insurance companies and advisers cashing in by selling commission-based "top-up" endowments, carrying the risk that homeowners could lose out a second time.

Instead, policyholders will receive a letter that identifies the total shortfall in a cash amount and then lists five options for action. These include extending the term of the mortgage, paying in a lump sum and changing part of the mortgage to a repayment loan. Homeowners will only be able to obtain a figure for increasing their monthly payments into the endowment by filling in a tear-off strip and sending it to the insurer.

The standardised-format letter follows weeks of wrangling between the FSA and insurers. In a private memo circulated by the Association of British Insurers this week, the ABI warns that members should think "very carefully" about deleting or replacing the wording of the letter, and that members will have to judge the risks of "media criticism and regulatory intervention". .

The memo says that the FSA is finalising a "traffic light" range of letters on a red, amber and green basis.

Although they will not be printed in different colours, the "red" letter will go to those where the insurer considers "there is now a high risk that your plan may not pay out enough".

The "amber" letter is for those where it is considered "possible that your plan may not pay out enough" while the "green" letter is intended to reassure those whose policies are still on target.

However, the regulators have been forced to back down on certain key points. The FSA wanted insurers to include the original projected growth rate used when the endowment was sold, so policyholders could compare it with the 4%-8% levels that will be used in the projection letters. The life companies refused.

webTitle: Co-ops get more muscle with merger

fields.headline: Co-ops get more muscle with merger
fields.standfirst: Deal will create £4.7bn sales group
fields.trailText: The UK's two biggest co-ops agreed to merge yesterday in a move which will give the enlarged operation far more muscle to compete in the grocery business.
fields.body:
The UK's two biggest co-ops agreed to merge yesterday in a move which will give the enlarged operation far more muscle to compete in the grocery business.

The Co-operative Wholesale Society and Co-operative Retail Services will formally merge on April 2, creating a group with annual sales of £4.7bn. The new society - which will be renamed - will operate 1,110 supermarkets and have 52,000 employees. It will also be the UK's biggest funeral service, with 18% of the market.

The Co-op Bank, including its highly-rated Smile internet bank, and the Co-operative Insurance Society - both subsidiaries of CWS - will also become part of the enlarged group. Its other business divisions will span 516 travel agencies, 361 Shoefayre outlets and 70 opticians, together with dairy and farming businesses.

The two societies - which started to explore the possibility of a merger last October - each also have motor trade businesses, which together will create a single business with a turnover of £200m.

The merger was given the go-ahead last weekend when 98% of CRS members voted in favour at a special general meeting. Their decision came just two weeks after a commission was set up, backed by Tony Blair, to explore the modernisation of the co-op movement. Yesterday the CWS chief executive, Graham Melmoth, described the merger as "a good start" to the work of the commission. He will lead the new combined operation while the CRS chief executive, Andy Meehan, is leaving the organisation.

"I'm moving on", said Mr Meehan, who joined the CRS from Storehouse in 1998. "Two chief executives don't go into one job".

He had complete confidence in the newly merged business, but insisted: "They don't need me". He will receive one year's salary as compensation for loss of office.

Altogether the merger will cost 320 jobs, mostly at the CRS and CWS head offices. The new group will use the CWS HQ in Manchester, while the Rochdale base of the CRS is likely to be sold.

Mr Melmoth said the prospects for the new co-op were good. "Our tails are up. This gives us the prospect of bringing two lively organisations together and creating a situation where two-plus-two equals five."

He had e-commerce plans, which would put all the co-op services on one website - from banking to travel bookings and grocery orders. He also intended to speed the roll-out of the CWS Welcome convenience store brand, and is piloting a new format for larger food outlets.

webTitle: Millennium effect adds sparkle to De Beers results

fields.headline: Millennium effect adds sparkle to De Beers results
fields.trailText: The "millennium effect" boosted diamond jewellery sales around the world by $500m (£313m), gemstone group De Beers said yesterday. This turn-of-the-century bonanza topped off a record year for diamonds, and boosted De Beers's headline earnings to $838m last year, from $639m in 1998.
fields.body:
The "millennium effect" boosted diamond jewellery sales around the world by $500m (£313m), gemstone group De Beers said yesterday. This turn-of-the-century bonanza topped off a record year for diamonds, and boosted De Beers's headline earnings to $838m last year, from $639m in 1998.

Roaring demand generally, especially in the United States, helped De Beers - the world's biggest diamond producer - to put behind it the troubles of the mid 1990s, during which recession in Japan, followed by meltdown in the Asia-Pacific region, cast huge clouds over the group's prospects. Only an American slump can prevent 2000 from setting a new record, it seems.

The clearest signal in yesterday's results that the crisis years have passed was the shrinkage of the strategic diamond stockpile, with which De Beers tries to smooth diamond prices on world markets.

Topping $5bn at one point in 1997-98, it has been reduced by nearly $1bn in 1999, from $4.8bn to $3.9bn, as the group has taken advantage of strong demand to offload some of the stones it mopped up during the bad years in order to support prices.

In line with this, De Beers's borrowings were also down, with long- and medium-term liabilities dropping by $751m to $615m, and net current assets increasing from $193m to $265m.

All major markets other than Japan bounced back last year from the troubles of 1997 and 1998. Globally, the value of diamonds in retail jewellery - excluding the other precious elements in jewels, such as gold - surged 11% from $11.7bn in 1998 to $13bn in 1999.

An estimated $500m of this increase is thought to have been caused by a boom in jewellery sales around new year, with north America taking the lion's share.

De Beers spent heavily on a promotional campaign, one of the slogans of which was: "Show her you love her for the next 1,000 years". The campaign seems to have paid off handsomely.

The group is currently in the middle of a review aimed at sharpening its focus on gemstones, a process that has raised questions about the future of its cross-shareholdings with mining giant group Anglo-American. Yesterday chairman Nicky Oppenheimer said there were no immediate plans to sell any of the 35% stake. Anglo, in turn, holds 32% of De Beers.

The dividend is to rise 31% in dollar terms.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Harland & Wolff in jeopardy

The future of Harland & Wolff's Belfast shipyard was in doubt last night after the company served 90-day redundancy notices to all 1,745 staff. Its survival will now depend on the firm winning a multi-million order to build a superliner for the Cunard fleet, Queen Mary II.

The yard has an empty order book and faces closure unless it can pull off the deal and save one of Northern Ireland's biggest single employers.

A spokesman said the firm was in deep trouble with its only current order close to completion. The notices were issued to all staff working for Harland & Wolff Shipbuilders and its two subsidiaries. "The extent to which this will be implemented will depend on the ability of the company to secure work in the immediate future," said the company spokesman.

Power switch made simpler

Energy consumers will be able to switch suppliers of both gas and electricity faster and more simply under proposals put forward yesterday by the industry regulator, Ofgem.

The watchdog body said that 500,000 customers were last year prevented from switching to a new company or had their transfer severely delayed because of objections from their original supplier.

Callum McCarthy, Ofgem director-general, accused companies of using technicalities to block the transfer process and "lock-in customers who would rather be with another supplier." The new rules, which require 90% backing from companies, would prevent this.

DoubleClick ombudsmen

DoubleClick, the online ad placement firm, has hired two prominent New Yorkers as "privacy" officials as it battles against public and government criticism of its intention to offer the names and details of web surfers to market research companies.

Jules Polonetsky, head of consumer affairs in the New York City administration, and Robert Adams, formerly New York state attorney general, will act as ombudsmen for internet users, the company said. Its shares rose 6% to $102.

Stern moves to World Bank

Nick Stern, the former chief economist at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is to become the chief economist at the World Bank. The 53-year-old British economist will replace Joseph Stiglitz, who left the Bank last year after a behind the scenes row over his outspoken criticism of the International Monetary Fund's role during the Asian crisis.

Qwest talks 'still on'

Qwest, the American telecoms group, insisted it is still in merger talks yesterday as reports circulated that Deutsche Telekom, its mooted suitor, had backed out of negotiations.The German group had reportedly been scared off by the position of US West, which is being taken over by Qwest. US West has threatened legal action if its own takeover by Qwest is scuppered by any other merger.

Qwest talks 'still on' Qwest, the American telecoms group, insisted it is still in merger talks yesterday as reports circulated that Deutsche Telekom, its mooted suitor, had backed out of negotiations.The German group had reportedly been scared off by the position of US West, which is being taken over by Qwest. US West has threatened legal action if its own takeover by Qwest is scuppered by any other merger.

webTitle: Horlick beats target and rakes in £5bn for SocGen

fields.headline: Horlick beats target and rakes in £5bn for SocGen
fields.trailText: Nicola Horlick has proved her credentials as the superwoman of the financial services sector by attracting £5bn to her new investment venture three years ahead of target.
fields.body:
Nicola Horlick has proved her credentials as the superwoman of the financial services sector by attracting £5bn to her new investment venture three years ahead of target.

Ms Horlick, whose early days as joint managing director of SG Asset Management were overshadowed by the death of her oldest child, and interrupted by the birth of her sixth child, said she was "thrilled" that investors were flocking to SocGen. The company had initially predicted it would need five successful years before attracting that level of funds.

It said its active approach to investments meant that intelligent fund managers could outperform increasingly popular funds which simply tracked the stock market, but Ms Horlick also maintains there is a benefit in being smaller and faster in switching from one share to another to maximise returns.

Ms Horlick underlined her claims to a top slot in the fund management world after providing the best investment returns in her first official appearance in the industry's league tables last summer. She runs SG Asset Management in harness with Keith Percy and John Richards. They all accepted a pay cut in return for an equity investment in the organisation.

She admitted that her UK income fund had suffered from the "complete turnabout" in stock market conditions last year. But SG had purchased a slug of high-growth telecommunications and technology stocks which had put the fund on target to outperform the FTSE100 index by 1% on a rolling three-year basis.

fields.headline: EU doubts Schröder's IMF nominee
fields.trailText: German chancellor Gerhard Schröder was last night facing double humiliation after his new nominee for the top job at the International Monetary Fund won only partial backing from EU members.
fields.body:
German chancellor Gerhard Schröder was last night facing double humiliation after his new nominee for the top job at the International Monetary Fund won only partial backing from EU members.

Although France and Portugal offered support for Horst Köhler, Italy said the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development lacked authority. Other governments, including Britain, failed to declare themselves, either for or against him.

The United States, which is the IMF's biggest shareholder, was also non-committal, saying only that it continued to look forward to the IMF being led by "a strong European candidate of maximum stature".

While EU governments may yet rally behind Mr Köhler, he appeared to be in danger of suffering the same fate as his predecessor, Caio Koch-Weser - Germany's deputy finance minister - who withdrew from the race to become the IMF's managing director on Monday after being vetoed by the US as being too lightweight.

The rejection of a second German candidate would leave Mr Schröder's already damaged international standing in tatters. The row could further undermine the euro, which has been seen as a victim of a lack of European cohesion.

Yesterday Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, a member of the European Central Bank's board, said the currency would benefit from closer political ties.

"Since the strength of a currency - and the public's confidence in it - is closely related to the political structure that supports it, the current imbalance and the euro system's institutional loneliness will need to be addressed," he said.

Seeking to build momentum behind Mr Köhler, German government spokesman Uwe-Karsten Heye confirmed that Germany had officially put forward Mr Köhler as the European candidate, and said nobody else was in the running.

He said that President Bill Clinton had been informed of the candidacy and "expressed positive interest".

Claiming that quickly settling on a new nominee was a test of Europe's credibility, Portuguese prime minister Antonio Guterres - whose country at present holds the rotating EU presidency - said he supported Mr Köhler, as did the French finance minister Christian Sautter.

However, the lack of a European consensus was underlined by Italian foreign minister Lamberto Dini, who said Mr Köhler was a better candidate than Mr Koch-Weser but still not perfect.

"This candidacy is a bit stronger. Of course, it still does not fulfil the levels of authority that had been hoped. It's not the candidacy of a former treasury minister or a former prime minister," Mr Dini said.

His comments suggested that Italy, and possibly others, favoured nominating Giuliana Amato, the former Italian prime minister, for the IMF.

White House spokesman Joe Lockhart dodged questions about Mr Köhler, saying: "I'm not going to discuss any individual candidate."

fields.headline: Manufacturing takes a seasonal hit
fields.standfirst: Worst output data for two years points to rates being kept on hold
fields.trailText: Only the strength of the booming hi-tech industries kept the manufacturing sector out of recession last year, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Only the strength of the booming hi-tech industries kept the manufacturing sector out of recession last year, official figures showed yesterday.

Despite claims by some analysts that industry is learning to live with sterling's strength, the office for national statistics revealed that most of manufacturing has been in recession for the last year, with all the growth occurring in a few hi-tech areas.

Eleven of manufacturing's 14 sub-sectors have cut output over the last 12 months.

The hardest-hit sectors over the last year have been coke and petrol refining, which is down more than 10%, leather products, down 4%, and machinery and equipment, which has fallen by 3.6%.

Growth is being driven by electrical and optical manufacturers, pharmaceuticals and transport equipment makers - high value-added products which seem able to withstand sterling's march up the foreign exchanges.

The ONS said that stripping out the contribution of these three areas, which account for just under a third of the manufacturing output overall, would have fallen by 0.6% instead of rising by nearly 2% over the last 12 months.

The fragility of the manufacturing recovery was illustrated by a surprise drop in output in January, according to the ONS. Output fell 0.4% over the month, the sharpest decline for more than two years.

The ONS blamed factory shutdowns for the millennium for some of January's downturn, which came after a drop of 0.3% in December.

City analysts warned that yesterday's figures illustrated the delicate health of the sector squeezed by the pound's rise against other currencies.

"The industrial recovery under way since last spring, which has been instrumental in returning the economy to an above-trend rate of GDP growth much more quickly than expected, is clearly less well entrenched than thought," said Richard Iley, UK economist at ABN-Amro.

"These data point to rates on hold at tomorrow's MPC meeting," he said.

Business surveys suggested growth in manufacturing would continue to be slow over coming months while the pound appeared to be stuck at the equivalent of 3.20 marks, well above most estimates of its long term competitive level.

The growth rate rose to a projected 0.8% in the three months to February, up from a revised 0.7% in the three months to January, according to the latest estimate from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

webTitle: Merger rumour mill goes into top gear

fields.headline: Merger rumour mill goes into top gear
fields.trailText: Talk about jumping the gun. True enough, the merger of Deutsche and Dresdner bank - due to be unveiled formally this morning - will turn the German banking industry upside down.
fields.body:
Talk about jumping the gun. True enough, the merger of Deutsche and Dresdner bank - due to be unveiled formally this morning - will turn the German banking industry upside down.

But even before Deutsche's Rolf Breuer and his Dresdner opposite number, Bernhard Walther, have had a chance to take the wraps off their revolutionary plans, the pundits are already planning the next great coup to hit the sector.

Indeed they look to be planning several.

Last night the buzz was that HSBC was planning an assault on Commerzbank. Just market rumour and speculation was the response from London.

That should probably be taken as a no. In the wake of Vodafone AirTouch versus Mannesmann it would be a brave institution which sought to take out one of Germany's biggest banks.

But that will not stop the rumour machine grinding out a whole raft of putative deals. Yesterday, shares in both Commerzbank and HypoVereinsbank were on the rise.

Despite the fact that Commerzbank remains wedded to an independent strategy and that HypoVereinsbank is rather bigger in Bavaria than anywhere else, they are seen as ideal marriage partners by those infected with merger mania.

And because the insurer, Allianz, is set to play a key role in the Deutsche/Dresdner tie-up - it is expected to take a large minority stake in the two banks' merged retail business and then outright control somewhat further down the line - another big German insurer, Munich-Re, finds itself caught up in the speculative fray.

There will be more to come. The Deutsche/Dresdner deal will be a big challenge to the German tradition of universal banks.

German bankers will now have to draw up strategies to deal with the growth of internet banking, domestic consolidation and pan-European alliance building.

Bags of scope for the speculators there. Even more German investors might start to believe the equity game - played to Anglo-Saxon rules - is much more fun than boring old bonds.

fields.headline: Mobile auction hots up
fields.trailText: Vodafone and Orange continued to push up bidding prices in the government's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences yesterday as total offers rose to £755.8m.
fields.body:
Vodafone and Orange continued to push up bidding prices in the government's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences yesterday as total offers rose to £755.8m.

Licence B, the largest of the four available to Britain's existing mobile phone carriers, drew top bids from both Vodafone and Orange of £230.4m each. Third-generation phones will transmit data at 200 times the speed of today's mobiles.

The auction is expected to extend at least over the next three weeks with some analysts speculating that a total of £5bn could be raised for treasury coffers.

However, Chris Doyle, director of telecoms at the London Economics consultancy, expects the total to be about £3bn. London Economics is advising One.Tel, which is backed by Rupert Murdoch.

A fifth licence - known as licence A - has been reserved for a new entrant. The Canadian group, TIW, led the bidding for that yesterday with an offer of £199.5m.

Dr Doyle said the auction was working well for the government. "Perhaps for the first time in Europe we are seeing the sale of spectrum in a sensible way."

Bids for the other three licences ranged from £105.2m to £110.7m. The licences are expected to come into effect in 2002.

webTitle: Stakeholder rights slip off the agenda

fields.headline: Stakeholder rights slip off the agenda
fields.standfirst: Victorian company law looks set to stay after review fails to deliver on Labour's promise
fields.trailText: Officials are putting the finishing touches to plans for reforming the basis of company law - which prime minister Tony Blair promised would create the "stakeholder company". They will, however, be preparing for an outcry when their report is published next week because the supposedly fundamental review has backed off from radical proposals to revolutionise Victorian statutes.
fields.body:
Officials are putting the finishing touches to plans for reforming the basis of company law - which prime minister Tony Blair promised would create the "stakeholder company". They will, however, be preparing for an outcry when their report is published next week because the supposedly fundamental review has backed off from radical proposals to revolutionise Victorian statutes.

The review team will propose that shareholder value remains paramount, although suggesting that directors should be aware of wider social responsibilities.

But the bulk of the consultation document will be preoccupied with details of company formation and administration, disappointing those who hoped it would address the broad purpose and responsibilities of business.

Among specific changes to current practice, the law review will propose making the "preliminary results" statement the main reporting point of the year, with the annual report available to shareholders only on request.

Plans to make the annual meeting optional have been put on hold, however. The document will propose making mandatory the broad "operating and financial review"- or OFR- of the year which is at present required by accounting standards. But plans to turn the OFR into a wide ranging, forward looking statement of values and prospects have been ditched at the eleventh hour after fierce opposition from the City and worries about adding to the reporting burden for smaller companies.

Organisations including the TUC, think tanks and pressure groups are likely to complain that an opportunity to create a structure appropriate to business in the 21st century has been wasted. The review will propose only limited changes to the company structure, directors' duties and accountability introduced 150 years ago.

The fundamental review of the corporate legal framework was launched by Margaret Beckett two years ago when she was secretary of state at the department of trade and industry.

She made it clear that it was time to look again at the whole concept of the joint stock company, which emerged as commerce expanded in the 19th century. New technology and other aspects of the e-conomy needed to be addressed, in line with Labour's concern to deregulate and modernise. But the review was also asked to consider the stakeholder ideas which had been part of the government's election platform.

Tony Blair talked of a "stakeholder company" that would take account of interest groups other than shareholders - customers, employees and communities - and the review team was asked how this could be incorporated in law.

At the time it may have seemed academic, but since then a series of high profile controversies has emphasised the unsatisfactory nature of shareholder value as the sole official objective of the company. Monsanto's troubles with genetically modified organisms have been the most dramatic example. Railtrack, too, has been accused of focusing on financial returns at the expense of safety.

A first consultation document published a year ago acknowledged the argument for some kind of stakeholder model: "The principal arguments are that the present scheme of law fails adequately to recognise that businesses best generate wealth where participants operate harmoniously as teams and that managers should recognise the wider interests of the community."

The review team dubbed this approach "pluralism". The alternative was decribed as "enlightened shareholder value", which amounts to business as usual but with companies encouraged to be more long-term and mindful of wider society.

In October the steering group overseeing the review secretly ditched pluralism in a move which prompted the resignation of a key proponent of social and environmental responsibility - David Wheeler, the former Body Shop executive now turned academic. In his resignation letter he wrote: "Enlightened shareholder value will always fail what we might one day call the 'Railtrack test'."

There is a question, however, over whether company law can force directors to act responsibly on social and environmental issues, with ill-defined interest groups who might seek some kind of redress. For example, the 1985 companies act lays down that directors owe a duty to employees, but that has had no influence on the widespread closures and "downsizing" of the last 15 years.

The review's approach is to concentrate on disclosure. Until recently it had been intended to require companies to report on a wide range of issues, including purpose, values and strategy, key relationships, investment programmes, social, ethical and environmental issues.

But at the last minute, these reporting requirements have been made voluntary - unless directors consider them to be "material" to the business. As one person involved in the battle put it: "There is a whole load of rhetoric which doesn't do justice to social reporting."

Legislation to put into effect the review's conclusions will not be introduced until the next parliament, which suggests a lengthy battle ahead. The TUC, in its manifesto for the next five years to be published shortly, will demand the revival of the "stakeholder company". It will be joined by many other pressure groups seeking to wrest the soul of business from the City and introduce non-shareholder interests into board decisions.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Dealers arrived at their desks yesterday morning expecting the worst. The Dow Jones was off almost 400 points overnight, and the old rule of thumb used to be that the FTSE 100 would drop by half the Dow's measure in terms of raw points.
fields.body:
Dealers arrived at their desks yesterday morning expecting the worst. The Dow Jones was off almost 400 points overnight, and the old rule of thumb used to be that the FTSE 100 would drop by half the Dow's measure in terms of raw points.

In the event selling was relatively light, and the final Footsie figure of 6,411.2 was viewed as something of a "result."

In truth, the oil sector saved the day. Having moved through $30 for the first time since the Gulf war, the price of crude remained firm yesterday after the agreement between the Saudi and Iranian oil ministers on the need for "adequate and timely oil supplies to balance the market".

At one point, crude surged to almost $32 a barrel, prompting analysts at Deutsche Bank to raise their earnings forecasts for the entire European integrated oil sector by 10%.

Together BP Amoco, which jumped 49p to 554p, Shell, up 29p at 492p and BG Group, 17p higher at 312p, added about 60 points to the blue chip index.

Among the mid-250 stocks Enterprise Oil leapt 47p to 431p, while Lasmo added 8p to 125p.

But elsewhere there were signs of stress as all the broader indices moved lower. The FTSE 250 fell 45.8 points to 6,743.5, the FTSE Small Cap indicator lost 29 points to 3,491 while the TechMark ended 187.5 points lower at 5,413.82 - possibly the worst one-day performance by the new growth stock indicator since it was launched in early November.

Media stocks were in the firing line. BSkyB, which on Monday reached a record high, was hit hard by profit takers, slicing 182p from the share price to £19.59. It was closely followed by Reuters , off 173p at £14.44, and also Daily Mail & General Trust , down 75p to £12.23.

Among the purer hi-tech stocks, ARM Holdings lost 329p to £43.08, Logica surrendered 165p to £25.74, Sage eased 59p to 802p and Misys fell 64p to £10.18.

In a mixed telecom sector - whose blue chip weighting is expected to be boosted to around 40% after the FTSE International review - profit-taking saw heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch slip 6p to 378p, while Cable & Wireless gave up 91p to £14.70 and this week's instant Footsie newcomer Kingston Communications give back 157p, coming to rest at £14.44.

British Telecom, up 1p at £11.71, ended well off its highs as its new package of internet services designed to hit back at supposedly free offers from NTL and AltaVista met with a lukewarm market response.

fields.headline: Playing to the gods
fields.standfirst: The Handmaid's Tale opera is a work of genius, says  Stephen Johnson
fields.trailText: Astonishingly, 32 years have passed since the Danish Royal Theatre last premiered an opera that it had commissioned. But it made stunning reparation with Poul Ruders's The Handmaid's Tale.
fields.body:
Astonishingly, 32 years have passed since the Danish Royal Theatre last premiered an opera that it had commissioned. But it made stunning reparation with Poul Ruders's The Handmaid's Tale. The Margaret Atwood novel on which it is based paints a bleak picture of a future totalitarian state, Gilean - the former USA - ruled by Christian fundamentalists, in which women are valued solely as breeders.

The problem for an opera composer is that much of Atwood's story is told as a dream-like inner monologue, full of flashbacks and flash-forwards, with the final outcome left tantalisingly open. But Paul Bentley's libretto is a triumph. Though faithful to the spirit of the novel, it reshapes the order of events so that the opera tells a simpler story. The life of the central character (we know her only by the name given to her after the revolution, Offred) is told in two parallel stories, before and after the Christian regime seizes power. Both Offreds, past and present, are frequently on the stage simultaneously, the latter contemplating earlier horrors - the loss of friends, rights, partner and child - from the vantage point of her present powerlessness.

There is nothing tricksy about this in Phyllida Lloyd's superb production; in fact, it leads naturally to the opera's most telling moment, in which the two Offreds sing together, sometimes in unison, sometimes taking alternate words, sometimes in free-flowing counterpoint.

Ruders's music at this point is unbearably moving. He has never been the kind of composer to distance himself from his emotions. But there is nothing in his large output which is as tenderly, simply heart-breaking as this marvellous duet.

Ruders's music is remarkable at every stage. The scoring - for full, colour-enriched orchestra, with exotic percussion and keyboards with samplers - is fabulously inventive; Ruders is the Richard Strauss of the computer-age orchestra. At first, tonal music, larded with all the cliches of fashionable Holy Minimalism, represents all that is false and stifling about the new regime, while real, forbidden emotions are expressed in pained atonality. There are some gruesome variations on the old hymn Amazing Grace. But later, these distinctions are blurred.

The orchestra is pushed to the limit. The writing for the singers, however, is sensitive. There is superb singing and acting here from the versatile Anne Margrethe Dahl. Equally outstanding were Marianne Rorholm as the "present" Offred, and Susanne Resmark as the TV gospel singer Serena Joy. In the orchestra pit, conductor Michael Schønwandt worked wonders. Hair-raisingly challenging as this score is, there was nothing tentative about playing or singing in this first hearing.

There is talk of bringing The Handmaid's Tale to London; after this performance, I'd say a British staging was just about essential.

La La La Human Steps ** Sadler's Wells, London/touring

For years Edouard Lock has been having a passionate argument with gravity. The performers in his company La La La Human Steps have made a special skill of vaulting through space. They've moved as if they feared the stage would scorch their feet, or a pause for breath would put their mission in peril. So even though Lock is one of the most muscularly postmodern of choreo- graphers, it's not entirely surprising that his latest work, Salt, turns to the classical pointe shoe in its pursuit of flight.

The pointe shoe may have evolved as the footwear of sylphs and princesses, but it also facilitates a vocabulary of predatory, high-speed dancing. When Lock's five women dancers bourrée across the stage, their toes stab the floor like needlepoint drills; when they balance high on their pointes, they tip and tilt like suicidal tightrope walkers; when their feet are fully arched, they slice the air like scimitars.

Yet Salt is not just about speed and danger. When the women dance with their male partners, the duets are intense, garrulous conversation, hands gesturing and legs flickering with an energy that is both sensuous and mocking.

These formal contrasts are enhanced by the design, essentially a play of white spotlights on a darkened stage. The circles of light abruptly expand and contract, so that the dancers move now in bright, open spaces, now in close confinement. David Lang's music for live cello, piano and electric guitar also ranges between introspective riffs and angry howls, and with all nine dancers performing at an extreme pitch the piece has the potential to be one of Lock's finest.

At 100 minutes, though, it is way too long. Lock invents a mass of interesting steps, but his unwillingness to venture beyond solos and duets into group composition severely limits his range. It also deprives the work of a compelling structure. The occasional film clips that project human faces from infancy to adulthood are too intermittent to create a coherent logic, and by the end our sensation of Salt is less of pungent intensity than of ideas being scattered to the winds.

webTitle: I'm a famous Hollywood actor. So why would a woman think I was going to steal her purse?

fields.headline: I'm a famous Hollywood actor. So why would a woman think I was going to steal her purse?
fields.standfirst:
Denzel Washington on racism in Hollywood - and beyond
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Denzel Washington on racism in Hollywood - and beyond.
fields.body:
I already knew the story of Rubin "Hurricane" Carter when I flew to see him in Toronto. Wrongly jailed for a triple murder in 1966, the boxer became a cause célèbre in the early 70s, even inspiring a Bob Dylan song, but it wasn't until 1985 that his conviction was finally overturned. So I was expecting to meet this very angry and bitter man, but I didn't. I met this sweet guy who will tell you to this day that he wouldn't change a thing, that everything that has happened to him has made him a better person, the person that he is today.

I was talking to Rubin as preparation for The Hurricane, the movie based on his life story (and that recently won me an Oscar nomination for best actor). After we had talked for a while - after I'd figured out how much he weighed and the fact that I could run faster than him - I said, "Maybe you got exactly what you deserved," and he said, "I did."

There's a line in the film: "Hate put me in prison and love got me out." I took that to mean more than the hatred that was sent his way from different forces - police, the judicial system. I told him that I thought it was the hatred in his own heart that put him in the position that he was in, and once I'd opened my eyes and stopped worrying about getting hit, he said, "You're right."

Rubin was a mean, angry person in the 60s. He was also living at a time in America when if you spoke about what you believed as a black man, it could cost you your life, as it did Malcolm X and many others. He was very much under the eye of the FBI and other powerful organisations, and he knew that, but for me the journey was a personal journey. It's the story of his spiritual evolution and that's the way I attacked the role.

We all have anger in us. We've all had some level of injustice - 20 years in prison, or 20 minutes sitting in your car waiting for a police officer to determine your future. Or even a few moments in an elevator with some woman clutching her purse thinking you're going to rob her - regardless of celebrity. That has happened to me. Nothing like what has happened to Rubin has happened to me, but I can relate. In fact, the reason I'm in America is the result of it, so I understand that racism. I understand that's how America was founded, I understand that that history and hatred are passed down from generation to generation. I understand especially now because I'm a father, so I use those kinds of things to fuel my own fire.

I spent a lot of time just talking with Rubin, and he walked me through his past and how those agencies and individuals affected him in his life. So I related to the experiences I had and drew from the experiences he told me about, to try and shape my character in The Hurricane. When we were sitting around and talking before shooting, he said to me, "If you don't get this right, Denzel, I'm a-gonna come and see yah." I said to him, "If I didn't think this was bigger than you and I, then I'd be worried about that."

Racism is a factor in the US, if not in the world. It's also obviously a factor in Hollywood. Where I think the most work needs to be done is behind the camera. One of the things we've seen in the 80s with the Spike Lees and the Robert Townsends and other film-makers is that if you really go for it - make the effort to write your own material and insist on making your film - it is difficult whatever colour you are. But I think that's where the future lies. I think that if there is racism, it's to do with the lack of opportunities for writers and producers and the people behind the camera.

That said, it's very difficult for women of any colour in Hollywood. The men get older and the women get younger, and I think the bottom of the totem pole is African-American women, or women of colour. They get the fewest opportunities. I've been very blessed. I've made 26 films in 20 years. But I'm an exception to the rule and we've got a long way to go. The NAACP have been putting a lot of pressure on the studios to hire more people of colour, and I think that's good, 'cause I know the minute they stop doing that there'll be fewer and fewer in those positions.

One good thing about acting is that it's good therapy. I express a lot of my emotions and anger in the work itself. As Malcolm X used to say, it's one thing to be angry, and another thing to know. Just to be angry and out of control won't do you any good. If you have an enemy, then learn and know your enemy - don't just be mad at him or her. My career for a long time has been about doing something about the anger that I felt through the roles that I play - like Malcolm X and The Hurricane. I'm not afraid to upset people.

What would upset me is if I didn't use the abilities I'd been given. Yes, I'm just making movies, but I receive thousands of letters a year and I see the impact they have on people.

fields.headline: Tube tales
fields.standfirst:
A lot of fuss has been made about different approaches to funding London Underground but in fact there is little to chose between them

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians too often sound off about issues about which they know little. So it made a refreshing change when Frank Dobson said that as mayor he would appoint an independent panel of experts to advise him on the best way to finance investment in London Underground. The trouble is that the decision is out of the mayor's hands and shrouded in commercial secrecy. Until the public private partnership (PPP) proposed by the Blair government is signed and sealed, the tube   will remain the responsibility of Whitehall.
fields.body:
Politicians too often sound off about issues about which they know little. So it made a refreshing change when Frank Dobson said that as mayor he would appoint an independent panel of experts to advise him on the best way to finance investment in London Underground. The trouble is that the decision is out of the mayor's hands and shrouded in commercial secrecy. Until the public private partnership (PPP) proposed by the Blair government is signed and sealed, the tube will remain the responsibility of Whitehall.

Ken Livingstone has successfully branded this PPP as partial privatisation. His option is to finance investment using public sector bonds. But on closer inspection, the similarities between the two options are at least as great as the differences. Both would keep the ownership of the system and the operation of services in the public sector. And where the two options do differ, it is not clear who has the advantage.

There are trade-offs between, on the one hand, less risk for the public sector under the PPP and lower costs of finance with public bonds and, on the other, flexibility with public bonds and the security of long-term contracts with the PPP.

Under PPP, the modernisation and maintenance of trains, track, tunnels, signalling and stations would be contracted to private companies. Three contracts would be let. One would cover sub-surface lines such as the Circle and the other two the Northern and deep tube lines. Service charges would be paid to the infrastructure companies, with a system of rewards and penalties depending on performance.

Over the first 15 years of such contracts (lasting 25 to 30 years), the infrastructure companies should deliver a programme of investment and maintenance, costing about £12.5bn on figures produced by accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC). They would bear much of the risk for cost overruns and would need to raise some finance in the private sector, about £2.5bn, according to PWC. The rest of the money would come from fares.

With PPP, competition for contracts should reduce costs. There would be no more stop-go funding for the tube, because the service charges would have to be paid under contract. And the same companies which renovate the system would be responsible for its long-term maintenance, an incentive for high quality work.

The Livingstone bond would give the mayor flexibility to decide which parts of the work to contract to the private sector and greater flexibility to respond to changing circumstances. The PPP ties the mayor to long and detailed contracts. This could pose difficulties in responding to changes in technology or passenger demand. But what you gain in flexibility with bonds you may lose in efficiency savings.

Although the cost of borrowing is lower with public bonds than private finance, this is balanced by the public sector taking on a greater share of the risk. And this difference in costs could be reduced if the state guaranteed bonds issued by the private sector, as it did for the Channel tunnel rail link. So far the government has refused this option for the tube.

In defence of PPP, the government cites the Jubilee line extension. The public sector took the risk and paid the price. It came in two years late and £1.4bn over budget. By contrast as a public private partnership the Docklands Light Railway extension was completed ahead of schedule and on budget. Bond proponents might say this has less to do with the method of finance than the quality of management.

Under both scenarios there will have to be continuing public subsidy. Even the favourable assessment by PWC suggests a funding gap of nearly £100m a year. And this assumes 20% additional efficiency savings compared with the Livingstone option and steady passenger growth. Without these savings, the subsidy requirement would be more than £250m a year.

Stephen Glaister, of University College, London, says that if the same savings could be achieved with the bond option, the tube would almost break even. But without the extra efficiency savings, the bond option could be more expensive than PPP.

In short, there is not much to choose between the two. The devil is in the detail. John Prescott has promised that the PPP will not go ahead unless it is better value than the public sector option but this call will be made by ministers in private. The suspicion is that the PPP will not be compared with the best public sector alternative on a fair basis.

What normally happens with major projects of this kind is that the National Audit Office (NAO) reports after the event on whether public money has been wisely spent. For example, it concluded that of the first four road schemes built under the private finance initiative (PFI), two were better value than conventional public sector procurement and two were worse.

Since the PPP for London's tube is a one-off, why not get the NAO to make an assessment before contracts are signed. If the bond option is the best public sector method it should be the option against which PPP should be compared. Involving the NAO carries a risk for ministers since it might conclude the PPP is not the best option. But an independent survey would also smoke out Ken Livingstone's opposition to the PPP - is it ideological or pragmatic?

 Tony Grayling is at the Institute for Public Policy Research. It will shortly publish "Public private partnerships and investment in transport" by Stephen Glaister and colleagues

fields.headline: The best bombshell scene
fields.standfirst: Topsy-turvy
fields.trailText: Topsy-turvy
fields.body:
Having recovered from an attack of the flu, Arthur Sullivan (Allan Corduner) holds a business meeting with his patron, Richard D'Oyly Carte (Ron Cook), manager of the Savoy Theatre, and the latter's right-hand woman Helen Lenoir (Wendy Nottingham).

"The show is doing splendidly, Arthur", D'Oyly announces. "Full houses and a healthy advance. Three tours on the road."

"And New York can't wait for Ida", continues Lenoir.

Sullivan smiles warmly.

"Ah, New York."

"Helen has us booked up to the end of the year."

"Tireless as ever."

Helen catches Sullivan's eye.

"I hope you're confinement hasn't made you restless, Arthur. How have you been passing the time?"

"I've made some resolutions, Helen. A little late for the New Year, perhaps..."

"...but better late than never."

A moment of silence descends; Lenoir finally speaks.

"And may we know what they are, Arthur?"

"Why not?" replies the composer. "One - travel to the continent, as soon as my health permits."

D'Oyly nods enthusiastically.

"Very wise."

"Thank you. Two - to look for a country house where I may repair each summer. Three - to take more exercise."

"Excellent, Arthur. And about time too."

"A leaf out of your book, D'Oyly."

"The show is doing splendidly, Arthur", D'Oyly announces. "Full houses and a healthy advance. Three tours on the road." "And New York can't wait for Ida", continues Lenoir. Sullivan smiles warmly. "Ah, New York." "Helen has us booked up to the end of the year." "Tireless as ever." Helen catches Sullivan's eye. "I hope you're confinement hasn't made you restless, Arthur. fields.headline: Prescott's smoke and mirrors
fields.standfirst: Interactive guide to concreting over the South East
fields.trailText: Regional Affairs Correspondent Peter Hetherington explains how initial enthusiasm for John Prescott's building plans for the South East has been replaced by scepticism
fields.body:
Initial enthusiasm for John Prescott's decision to "scale-down" housing plans in south east England began to wane yesterday as councils accused the Deputy Prime Minister of disguising the true impact of revised building targets.

Mr Prescott, Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions, portrayed himself as a countryside saviour by allowing no more than 43,000 houses a year for the next five years - when plans would be reviewed.

But Chris Williams, chairman of a strategy group in a local council planning consortium - known as Serplan - accused Mr Prescott of a "smoke and mirrors" exercise to downplay the long-term impact of building in the fast-growing region, Britain's wealthiest.

Because so little flesh had been put on the skeleton of a bald announcement, he said the south east could easily face a 15 per cent increase in house building over the next few years, with 860,000 houses between 1996 and 2016. Currently, 39,000 homes a year are being built. While Serplan had proposed a maximum of 718,000 homes in the 20 years up to 2016, a panel of government-appointed inspectors, chaired by Professor Stephen Crow, called for 1.1m. Mr Prescott says he has struck a compromise between these two extremes.

Chris Williams, who is also environment director of Buckinghamshire County Council, says authoritiess are eagely awaiting the finer details of housing projections for each county in two week's time. A period of lengthy haggling is now likely.

Predictably, the issue has now been earmarked as a major campaigning theme by the Conservatives in the run up to council elections in two months' time. Many authorities in the region are Tory-controlled. They argue that house building is being imposed on councils, against the democratic wishes of local people.

At the other extreme, housing organisations yesterday criticised Mr Prescott for paying lip-service to creating mixed communities of home owners and tenants. They say a building level closer to Professor Crow's figure is needed because an acute shortage of housing is forcing up prices.. They also want the Government to give councils stronger powers to insist that builders provide sufficient low-cost homes for key workers on average incomes, such as teachers, young doctors and policemen.

webTitle: Pakistan crumble to wiles of Murali

fields.headline: Pakistan crumble to wiles of Murali
fields.trailText: Muttiah Muralitharan showed his customary flair for the dramatic yesterday, snatching two wickets in the final two balls of the day to take Sri Lanka to the cusp of a series victory over Pakistan.
fields.body:
Muttiah Muralitharan showed his customary flair for the dramatic yesterday, snatching two wickets in the final two balls of the day to take Sri Lanka to the cusp of a series victory over Pakistan.

The off-spinner will start the final day of an enthralling second Test in Peshawar on a hat-trick, with Pakistan requiring an unlikely 72 runs for victory and Sri Lanka only two wickets.

Muralitharan swung the match when, in fading light, he got a ball to spin viciously and trap Yousuf Youhana leg-before. His next delivery claimed Waqar Younis, who offered a catch to the bat-pad Mahela Jayawardene, and the umpires immediately halted play because of bad light.

The key wicket was that of Youhana, whose 88 - featuring eight fours, three sixes and two lives - had put the home side within reach of their target of 294. Saeed Anwar and Shahid Afridi started well for Pakistan, 1-0 down in the series, before the captain collided with an umpire in attempting a quick single and was taken to hospital for neck x-rays.

The rest of the batsmen, apart from the new keeper Atiq-uz-Zaman, fell under the spell of Muralitharan, who has taken five for 71. Anwar will resume his interrupted innings this morning with only Arshad Khan and Shoaib Akhtar to come.

Earlier a 79-run stand between Aravinda de Silva and Russel Arnold - who fell one short of a century - ensured Pakistan faced an uphill battle.

webTitle: Dyke's offer catches the new mood at Lord's

fields.headline: Dyke's offer catches the new mood at Lord's
fields.standfirst: How the BBC rolled out its big guns to secure a future for Test Match Special
fields.trailText: How the BBC rolled out its big guns to secure a future for Test Match Special.
fields.body:
By the time officials from the England and Wales Cricket Board arrived at Broadcasting House last Wednesday the choice facing them was obvious.

The officials, led by the ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin, the marketing director Terry Blake and the marketing committee chairman Martin Gray, had already visited Talksport's office where Kelvin MacKenzie tabled a lucrative offer: if his emerging radio station were given broadcasting rights for the next five years, the cash-strapped ECB would receive £7.5m.

The position was clear-cut: either opt for the money and relegate cricket to a fledgling radio station with few listeners, or leave it in the safe hands of the BBC where at least exposure was guaranteed.

But what more could the BBC offer cricket, given that it could not match the sum offered by Talksport at a time when the game is in danger of being overlooked by the nation?

The ECB officials were led into the council chamber of Broadcasting House, where they were met by a BBC team comprising the director general Greg Dyke, the executive director of sport Gordon Turnbull, the controller of sports radio rights Mike Lewis, the director of BBC Radio Jenny Abramsky, and Jonathan Agnew, the BBC's cricket correspondent. Peter Baxter, pro ducer of Test Match Special, was also present along with representatives of Radio 5 Live.

It was an impressive line-up, a wheeling out of big guns designed to convince the ECB of a real wish to hold on to the rights. The BBC might not have the money but it could cash in on years of cricket expertise.

Using a combination of vintage commentary, slide shows highlighting letters from Test Match Special listeners, and video footage from last year's Cricket World Cup, the BBC went out of its way to demonstrate the role cricket has played in the corporation.

Perhaps in the past it has been blase about the institution that is Test Match Special and its importance, but under the guidance of the sports-loving Dyke things were about to change: that was the BBC message. It was also pointed out that Test Match Special had been nominated for a Sony radio award for its coverage of last year's World Cup.

The director general's enthusiasm won over the ECB, which was impressed with the commitment to spread cricket across national and local radio stations. What won the day, however, was not the BBC's money offer, a fraction of Talksport's, but the innovative idea of spreading the popularity of cricket to younger listeners. One of the ECB's stated aims is to increase cricket's appeal to a younger, wider audience; the BBC's presentation involved outlining how Radio 1, with a large number of listeners under 25, could be used to cover cricket.

There would be regular reports of Test matches on Newsbeat, the station's main news programme; and other programmes aimed at the young would highlight cricket and its personalities. The BBC would also market cricket and sponsor a young cricketer of the year award.

The only problem that remained was money. The BBC refuses to reveal how much it paid for the five-year rights, claiming it is commercially sensitive information. However, it is known that four years ago, when the current radio deal began, the corporation paid about £200,000 for the rights. This time it is reckoned to be 10 times as much.

The ECB came away delighted with what it had seen. Originally it was not supposed to announce its decision for another two weeks but, given that cricket in general is at a crossroads, it saw virtue in taking a positive route swiftly.

webTitle: BBC lands cricket on the air

fields.headline: BBC lands cricket on the air
fields.trailText: The BBC scored a major victory in its battle to hold on to sports rights with the announcement last night that it had been awarded an exclusive five-year deal by the England and Wales Cricket Board for the radio broadcasting of domestic Test cricket.
fields.body:
The BBC scored a major victory in its battle to hold on to sports rights with the announcement last night that it had been awarded an exclusive five-year deal by the England and Wales Cricket Board for the radio broadcasting of domestic Test cricket.

The agreement ensures the future of the long-running Test Match Special programme, which celebrated its 40th birthday last year and has become one of the game's great institutions.

The BBC was competing against the independent radio station Talksport for the rights to broadcast international cricket, and both organisations had made presentations to ECB officals last week outlining their plans for coverage of the sport.

Last night Kelvin MacKenzie, head of Talksport, attacked the decision, claiming that the "establishment decided our money wasn't good enough".

He added: "We were prepared to spent our own money to buy the rights; the taxpayer has ended up with the bill. How can we flourish when a government-aided business is able to wield such power in such an anti-competitive manner?"

The deal will start this coming season and covers one-day internationals too. It is a victory for the BBC's director general Greg Dyke, who has vowed to hold on to existing rights and add new ones as part of his drive to ensure sport remains an important part of future programming.

It is believed Talksport offered more than the BBC but ECB officials were impressed by the latter's commitment to ensure all its network would be utilised for cricket coverage.

MacKenzie said Talksport had bid £7.5m for the rights. The BBC's undisclosed fee for the rights is thought to be much less than half that. Four years ago it paid £200,000 and this time it is believed to have offered 10 times as much.

The BBC won by stressing its commitment to using its radio network to increase the popularity of cricket among a younger audience, which is one of the ECB's stated aims.

Under the deal cricket will be featured on Radio 1's Newsbeat programme and there will be extensive coverage on BBC local radio and the creation of a new Test Match Special young cricketer of the year award. The BBC has also agreed to support its coverage with a marketing campaign.

Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the ECB, said last night: "We have had to think long and hard before making this decision as both the BBC and Talksport made very impressive bids for the radio rights.

"What eventually swung the decision in the BBC's favour was their willingness to promote the game right across the network from Radio 4 through to 5 Live and Radio 1. We believe the breadth of their coverage coupled with enhanced promotional and marketing support will help us achieve our goal of maximising cricket's appeal still further."

MacKenzie, referring to the amount of money rejected by the ECB, said: "Is it because we don't talk like a peer of the realm? Lord MacLaurin, who earned his peerage by selling brussel sprouts, refused in the end to sell us the rights. It is a disgrace and we will be using this case as a further illustration of why we need to go to the competition commission to see the BBC broken up."

Dyke said: "This is terrific news for cricket lovers. We're delighted with this vote of confidence from the ECB and it marks the start of a great new era for BBC and sport."
