webTitle: Threat to cut off benefits to cheats

fields.headline: Threat to cut off benefits to cheats
fields.standfirst: Lord Grabiner's report on the black economy
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will launch a government-wide crackdown on the hidden economy in his budget this month, taking aim at a hard core of 120,000 who work while claiming benefits.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will launch a government-wide crackdown on the hidden economy in his budget this month, taking aim at a hard core of 120,000 who work while claiming benefits.

New powers for investigators and the courts are to be introduced to deal with those who fail to respond to a campaign to persuade moonlighters to join the mainstream workforce.

For people working on the side and paying no tax, magistrates will be able to try a new crime of fraudulently evading income tax. And data protection laws will be changed so fraudbusters can use the phone system to catch cheats.

The chancellor - who described benefit cheating as "defrauding the poor" - intends to implement all 17 recommendations of a report published today by Lord Grabiner, the senior QC commissioned to look at Britain's "informal economy", valued at £100bn annually.

Other tough measures could include a US-style "two strikes and you're out" policy, where benefits would be cut off for a period for those convicted of two tax or benefit offences, and more frequent and less predictable "signing on" times for those suspected of working while claiming benefits.

Lord Grabiner called also for measures to end "Day of the Jackal fraud". It takes its name from the Frederick Forsyth thriller in which a character builds a false identity using the birth certificate of someone who died in childhood.

"Cases of quite sophisticated and well organised fraud using this procedure are regularly discovered," he said.

The chancellor said: "[For] years, billions of pounds have been lost to the informal economy every year, leaving honest, hardworking taxpayers who play by the rules footing the bill for those who either don't pay the taxes they owe or claim benefit while they are working."

The Grabiner report estimates that the exchequer is losing about £500m each year in fraudulent benefit claims alone, without taking into account lost tax revenues.

Over the next six months there is to be a drive to help back into the legitimate workforce those who may feel trapped in the hidden economy.

Later today, the chancellor will announce an extension of the new deal for the over-25s to make self-employment one of the options for the jobless.

webTitle: No change: for this month, at least

fields.headline: No change: for this month, at least
fields.standfirst:
Economics correspondent Mark Atkinson on why interest rates were left unchanged today

Bank leaves interest rates unchanged
Interest rates explained
fields.trailText: Economics correspondent Mark Atkinson on why interest rates were left unchanged today
fields.body:
The Bank of England left interest rates on hold today but the sense of relief felt by businesses and homeowners is likely to be temporary.

The "no change" decision was widely expected after the bank's forecast last month that inflation was on target over the next two years.

However, with consumer spending continuing to grow strongly and the labour market tightening, borrowing costs are unlikely to have peaked at 6%.

After raising rates four times in the past six months, the Bank's monetary policy committee has paused for breath for fear of further increasing the value of sterling.

The strong pound is making it hard for manufacturing to compete in international markets and exposing them to extra competition from cheaper imports, resulting in widespread job losses and a widening trade deficit.

But unless the booming service sector shows decisive signs of slowing down, the Bank is likely to raise rates again soon to prevent the economy overheating irrespective of the state of manufacturing.

How much further rates will rise is the key question.

Some City analysts predict that they will go above 7%; others forecast just one more quarter point increase.

The eventually peak of borrowing costs will be determined by the economic data over the coming months.

In particular, the Bank has indicated that it is keeping a particularly watchful eye on the labour market.

Figures released last month showed average earnings growth accelerating to 5.5% a year in January, a worrying sign if the figures are reliable.

It suggests falling unemployment is allowing workers to bargain for higher wages not justified by productivity gains, forcing firms to raise prices to protect their profit margins.

Some members of the bank's monetary policy committee think the figures have been artifically boosted by one-off millennium bonuses.

They are therefore prepared to wait for a few months to see if earnings growth slows.

If earnings are still accelerating in a few months time, however, they may well change their minds.

fields.bodyText: The Bank of England left interest rates on hold today but the sense of relief felt by businesses and homeowners is likely to be temporary. The "no change" decision was widely expected after the bank's forecast last month that inflation was on target over the next two years. However, with consumer spending continuing to grow strongly and the labour market tightening, borrowing costs are unlikely to have peaked at 6%. After raising rates four times in the past six months, the Bank's monetary policy committee has paused for breath for fear of further increasing the value of sterling. The strong pound is making it hard for manufacturing to compete in international markets and exposing them to extra competition from cheaper imports, resulting in widespread job losses and a widening trade deficit. But unless the booming service sector shows decisive signs of slowing down, the Bank is likely to raise rates again soon to prevent the economy overheating irrespective of the state of manufacturing. How much further rates will rise is the key question. Some City analysts predict that they will go above 7%; others forecast just one more quarter point increase. The eventually peak of borrowing costs will be determined by the economic data over the coming months. In particular, the Bank has indicated that it is keeping a particularly watchful eye on the labour market. Figures released last month showed average earnings growth accelerating to 5.5% a year in January, a worrying sign if the figures are reliable. It suggests falling unemployment is allowing workers to bargain for higher wages not justified by productivity gains, forcing firms to raise prices to protect their profit margins. Some members of the bank's monetary policy committee think the figures have been artifically boosted by one-off millennium bonuses. They are therefore prepared to wait for a few months to see if earnings growth slows. If earnings are still accelerating in a few months time, however, they may well change their minds. fields.headline: The new FTSE 100
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100's dramatic change of character came to pass yesterday as nine of Britain's better known businesses slipped from the company of blue chips. You may be forgiven for regarding food, drink, energy, building materials and tobacco as staples but they are no longer so for investors.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100's dramatic change of character came to pass yesterday as nine of Britain's better known businesses slipped from the company of blue chips. You may be forgiven for regarding food, drink, energy, building materials and tobacco as staples but they are no longer so for investors.

The FTSE constituents committee confirmed the widely predicted changes on Tuesday evening after the close of the market.

Whitbread, Hanson, Imperial Tobacco, PowerGen, Thames Water, Associated British Foods, Scottish & Newcastle, Allied Domecq and Wolsley all made way and without exception were punished for it. Wolsley, the construction group, gave up about 7.5% of its value with its shares dropping to 278.5p, Whitbread was off 6.1% at 478p, S&N lost 4.3% to close on 382p and Hanson was down 4.8% at 369p.

Shares which fall from the ranks of the blue chips suffer because they drop from funds that track the FTSE. Those in ascendence are uniformally from the new economy - telecoms, internet, IT, media and biotech.

As forecast, the nine are Cable & Wireless Communcations, Freeserve, Thus, Baltimore Technologies, Psion, Nyc comed Amersham, Celltech Chiroscience, Capita Group and Emap.

Some were subject to profit-taking after heavy climbs on the previous session.

Changes in the FTSE rules also meant that for the first time companies which are in effect subsidiaries of another blue-chip stock can gain entry. That paved the way for CWC which is in large part owned by Cable & Wirless, Freeserve, still 80% owned by Dixons, and Thus, the telecoms business spun out of Scottish Power.

CWC though will only make a brief appearance. The company is in the process of being broken up with the residential cable and telephony business bought by Nasdaq-listed NTL and the corporate telecoms arm being brought back into the parent group.

The changes take effect from March 20.

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst:
Baby Doll
Royal National Theatre, London
Rating **
fields.trailText: 1956. The Deep South. Archie Lee, owner of a failing cotton plantation, has married but not bedded his teenage bride, Baby Doll. They have an agreement that he will wait until her 20th birthday. But with the date just two days away, Baby Doll insists that the seizing of almost every stick of furniture from the house for non-payment of bills invalidates their deal. So the desperate Archie sets the rival cotton plantation on fire.
fields.body:
1956. The Deep South. Archie Lee, owner of a failing cotton plantation, has married but not bedded his teenage bride, Baby Doll. They have an agreement that he will wait until her 20th birthday. But with the date just two days away, Baby Doll insists that the seizing of almost every stick of furniture from the house for non-payment of bills invalidates their deal. So the desperate Archie sets the rival cotton plantation on fire. He gets his rival's business but is cuckolded and becomes a laughing stock.

When Elia Kazan's film of Baby Doll based on Tennessee Williams's script was released in 1956 it caused outrage because of its sexual explicitness. Time magazine called it "just possibly the dirtiest American-made motion picture that has ever been legally exhibited". Cardinal Spellman denounced it from the pulpit of St Patrick's cathedral in New York with the kind of vigour that would now do wonders for the box office.

Even today the film's poster has an iconic status: the scantily clad Carroll Baker lying in a baby's cot with a thumb in her mouth like some Lolita of the cotton fields. Lucy Bailey's production begins with that image too and the evening, based on her own adaptation of the screenplay, uses light and sliding doors to capture the peeping Tom intensity of the film itself. It makes you feel soiled just to watch it.

But there is no getting away from the fact that Williams's melodrama is a creaky old thing and with the exception of Jonathan Cake's Silva Vacarro, the manager of the rival cotton plantation, who is despised for his Italian ancestry and dark skin, the performances are not strong enough to stop it tipping over into unintentional humour.

There is one fantastic scene. Left alone with Vacarro on a hot afternoon, Baby Doll retreats into the house. Vacarro breaks and enters, leading to a game of hide and seek through the empty rooms that is so sexually charged it feels as if you've held your breath for the entire scene. But for the most part Williams's writing is too crudely explicit and suggestive to be interesting.

There are niggles in the production too: accents that slip not just into different states but different continents, a set which, for all its cleverness, often obscures the view, and in the case of Charlotte Emmerson's too old Baby Doll, a mistaking of vacuity for sexiness.

webTitle: Banks rule out double charges at cashpoints

fields.headline: Banks rule out double charges at cashpoints
fields.standfirst:
Minister forces retreat on disloyalty penalties

The issue explained: cash machine charges
fields.trailText: Cash machine users won a partial victory after the government yesterday forced banks and building societies to rule out the possibility of customers being double charged for withdrawing money.
fields.body:
Cash machine users won a partial victory after the government yesterday forced banks and building societies to rule out the possibility of customers being double charged for withdrawing money.

Following a meeting with trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, the Link machine network said its members were set to ban double charging, where people using other banks' machines face a disloyalty charge from their own bank and a surcharge from the bank owning the machine.

The decision, if ratified by the Link members, would stop customers being charged up to £2.50 for taking out as little as £10.

But there was still no agreement on what to charge customers for withdrawing cash. Don Cruickshank, appointed by the government to scrutinise the banks, has said customers should have to pay no more than 30p.

Link members prompted an outcry when they last week backed moves to introduce surcharges for customers of rival banks who use their machines.

Barclays has proposed that the surcharge should be £1. In the past few days Lloyds TSB and Abbey National have also confirmed they will introduce surcharges from January 1 next year, though neither has said how much these will be.

The five banks and building societies that attended yesterday's meeting - Barclays, Bank of Scotland, Co-operative Bank, Royal Bank of Scotland and Nationwide Building Society - said they would recommend the no double charging option to the next meeting of the Link network on March 28.

They also confirmed that any charges would be indicated on all cash machines by January 1.

John Hardy, chief executive of Link, said: "The members have given an assurance that they will seek to ensure there will be no possibility of double charging." He added that specific charges by each bank had not been discussed and would remain a matter for each institution.

Several institutions, including the Co-operative Bank, Bank of Scotland and Nationwide, have indicated they do not intend to charge a fee.

Mr Byers said the banks and building societies "should not underestimate the feeling of anger among their customers" as a result of the decision they took last week to introduce surcharges.

The banks were forced to climb down after Tony Blair threatened them with multimillion pound fines when he raised the prospect of enforcing the new competition act, which contains powers to impose penalties on businesses behaving in an anti-competitive manner.

John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading, has said double charging would be "impossible to justify to consumers".

Many cash machine users will now be able to obtain money from their local pub. Scottish & Newcastle Retail, which has more than 2,650 pubs throughout the UK, said it was extending a cashback facility - similar to that operating in supermarkets - to 80% of its pubs and restaurants by the end of the year.

"The outlets selected to offer the facility will include country pubs and those that are not close to cashpoints," said a spokesman.

Barclays, which said last year that it was closing up to 200 branches, yesterday announced that 172 of them would close on April 7.

fields.headline: Hip and refreshing
fields.standfirst:
Jackie Ryan/ Barbara Thompson
Ronnie Scott's
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Ryan is as hip as anyone in the business in her timing and sense of space, but has a refreshing indifference to presentational hipness. She described the story of a Jon Hendricks bop song about childhood with a warmth that paid no mind to those late-night inhabitants of jazz clubs who believe that the mention of children is sacrilegious.
fields.body:
Although jazz instrumentalists sometimes pull rank on jazz singers for having it easy, the reverse often seems to hold - and not only for musical reasons. Lyrics are manipulations of the materials of everyday social exchange; they tempt the performer to come nearer the audience, sometimes to the point of clouding the message, whereas the tumbling patterns bursting from a saxophone infuse personality within the sound, and allow the perpetrator to be a more distant figure.

Jackie Ryan, the formidable jazz vocalist, is in danger of having her gifts overlooked because she maintains exactly the same practical, undemonstrative presence as an instrumentalist. But if she and her trio don't bother with a hard sell and give the impression they'd be playing whether the audience was there or not, her musicality is nonetheless subtle and strong, and her range (within a pretty orthodox blues-and-standards idiom) is often startling.

As Ryan demonstrated on a previous visit here with the same band (Brian Cuomo on piano and Joe Gallivan on drums), she can turn up all the raw power of a big-band blues-shouter when she chooses, as she did with an evocative account of Lonely Woman. At the same time, where some singers can sound self-consciously clever with tricksy, pirouetting jazz, Ryan is light and agile. She exhibits a sonority and pliability of pitch at low registers that recalls the late Betty Carter.

Ryan is as hip as anyone in the business in her timing and sense of space, but has a refreshing indifference to presentational hipness. She described the story of a Jon Hendricks bop song about childhood with a warmth that paid no mind to those late-night inhabitants of jazz clubs who believe that the mention of children is sacrilegious. The sensitive Gallivan on drums and the resourceful Cuomo on keyboards (he often keeps up a left-hand synth bassline whilst rattling through uptempo melodies on the regular piano with the right) give Ryan fine support, but to hear her with a bigger and punchier group would be interesting.

Headlining at the club this week is the saxophonist Barbara Thompson, with an elegant, faintly New Agey and very tautly organised brand of jazz-fusion that sometimes recalls earlier McLaughlin and Jean-Luc Ponty bands. It's melodically a little soupy and tonally a shade classical for some, but drummer Jon Hiseman still sounds like a towering inspiration to anyone who has dreamed of lifting a drumstick.

Until March 18. 0171-439 0747.

fields.headline: BT rivals scorn £30 internet package
fields.standfirst:
Free net access explained
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday launched an unmetered internet package costing almost £30 a month, which industry groups attacked as too expensive.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday launched an unmetered internet package costing almost £30 a month, which industry groups attacked as too expensive.

The offer is part of a wider BT internet package called SurfTime for business and residential customers wanting limitless internet usage for a fixed fee - £29.25 for residential customers and £29.74 for businesses. However, residential customers who wanted unmetered access only at night and weekends could get a monthly package for £5.99, with an additional £9.26 for line rental.

One of the company's biggest rivals, AOL UK, said the BT cost of unmetered internet access was still on its research "twice what the consumer wanted to pay".

"Pity the consumer in this," Mark Peacock, communications director for AOL UK, said. "It's not the way to grow the medium nor build users in this country or to build the new economy that Tony Blair wants."

Sustained pressure from the government to lower the cost of using the net has seen announcements from new entrants such as American cable company NTL this week to offer free "unmetered" access to the internet for a third of the BT package.

The government has said it wanted internet costs halved by 2002 to match US prices and that every British customer should have access to the web within five years.

Industry experts said the former state-owned company was more concerned about protecting its cashflow than its customers.

The Telecommunications Managers' Association said: "We get these price improvements only after gentle prodding from Oftel and more vigorous prodding from the government." The TMA director general, David Harrington, said. "I think they are scared about what it's going to do to their traditional revenues."

BT defended its package, which will not be available until June 1 after a review by the government phone watchdog Oftel. Peter Macleod, managing director BT UK markets, said: "We are doing our best. I think what we are doing is opening up the internet. It's a good deal for the customer."

In particular he emphasised that the offering of unmetered access to business for a flat fee of almost £30 monthly meant BT was delivering the government its new economy.

Mr Macleod said his challenge to the government was now "let's see every civil servant on the net". Asked about BT's product yesterday, the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, said: "It is certainly them engaging in what they recognise as a very competitive market place".

BT's SurfTime package also should offer users a choice of internet service providers such as Freeserve, VirginNet, Tesco or AOL UK. It has not confirmed if any of those internet service providers would con tract to use BT SurfTime. VirginNet confirmed it was talking to BT yesterday and Freeserve welcomed any product which would entice more users on to the net.

However, AOL UK's Mr Peacock said contracting to BT SurfTime could actually increase the cost of customers access to the web. "You need to look at it very closely," he said. "We would want some answers from BT."

 Mobile phone masts, which have triggered planning battles across the country, may be replaced by "flying teatrays" patented by British university scientists, writes Martin Wainwright.

An electronics team at York university has won European funding for a system of high altitude telecom platforms, attached to balloons, light aircraft or even airships. Known as Haps, for high altitude platforms, prototype "teatrays" should be airborne within two years.

webTitle: Old Mutual ducks out of UK bid

fields.headline: Old Mutual ducks out of UK bid
fields.trailText: Old Mutual href>, the South African life insurer, has ruled itself out of the bidding for big British fund manager Gartmore href>, the NatWest offshoot which has been put up for sale in the fallout from the Royal Bank of Scotland takeover.
fields.body:
Old Mutual href>, the South African life insurer, has ruled itself out of the bidding for big British fund manager Gartmore href>, the NatWest offshoot which has been put up for sale in the fallout from the Royal Bank of Scotland takeover.

Despite a 23% rise in operating profits to £656m last year, Old Mutual said its bid for Gartmore had been pitched "way below" the £900m potential bidders such as CGNU, Zurich Financial Services, State Street and ABN Amro were said to be ready to pay.

The company had failed to make it into the second bidding round even though its £5.5bn capitalisation and debt-free balance sheet had given it significant firepower, said finance director Eric Anstee.

Old Mutual made clear, however, that it was still in the market for takeovers. The company, which expects to extract cost savings of £55m a year, has already acquired broker and fund manager Gerrard Group, which owns Greig Middleton. Those operations have been merged with Capel Cure Sharp, and together have £27bn under management.

The group's main business has benefited from cost reductions as well as an uplift in its original home market.

This has helped Old Mutual's shares outperform the UK life assurance sector by 19% in the past quarter, although the fall in the sterling-rand exchange rate depressed earnings.

webTitle: Soho sex strike over eviction row

fields.headline: Soho sex strike over eviction row
fields.trailText: The withdrawal of labour by Soho's working girls was a throwback to a bygone era. Without a sniff of a secret ballot, prostitutes yesterday left potential clients searching for alternative sources of furtive pleasure in protest at council attempts to evict them from the flats where they work.
fields.body:
The withdrawal of labour by Soho's working girls was a throwback to a bygone era. Without a sniff of a secret ballot, prostitutes yesterday left potential clients searching for alternative sources of furtive pleasure in protest at council attempts to evict them from the flats where they work.

Dressed in masks to protect their identity, the occupants of the district's dingy stairwells took to the streets which they may be forced to ply if Westminster council gets its way.

"The girls here have done nothing wrong," one prostitute said. "Nothing that ordinary people don't do every day." (Except perhaps a bit more often - most welcome around 20 clients daily.)

The women see themselves as casualties of what they claim is Westminster's determination to gentrify the area. The council claims it wants to bring their properties back into "proper residential use".

Niki Adams, a spokeswoman for the English Collective of Prostitutes, insisted that the women's decision to withdraw their labour would have serious economic consequence. The Soho sex industry is a tourist attraction, and the sex workers spend their own hard-earned cash locally. "By going on strike, these women are showing the contribution they make to society in the same way as other workers would."

The Soho professionals' premises are dotted around the famous red light district, usually identified with a card bearing the word "model". Most work with a "maid" who welcomes the clients, takes the cash and cleans the sheets.

fields.headline: Existential sing-along
fields.standfirst:
The Handsome Family
Manchester University Students Union/touring
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: After wandering the stage setting up their instruments, Chicago's Handsome Family were still not ready when the lights went up. "I'm having a bad tuning experience," laughed singer-guitarist-composer Brett, his glasses and goatee adding a comedy aspect to his avuncular features. His wife, Rennie, lyricist, bass-player and percussionist, chose to pass time by chatting to the audience. "Any questions about insects?" she asked, looking like a youthful Morticia Addams in a knee-length black dress. "Especially ants. I'm good on ants."
fields.body:
After wandering the stage setting up their instruments, Chicago's Handsome Family were still not ready when the lights went up. "I'm having a bad tuning experience," laughed singer-guitarist-composer Brett, his glasses and goatee adding a comedy aspect to his avuncular features. His wife, Rennie, lyricist, bass-player and percussionist, chose to pass time by chatting to the audience. "Any questions about insects?" she asked, looking like a youthful Morticia Addams in a knee-length black dress. "Especially ants. I'm good on ants."

Finally, Brett finished twiddling with his Macintosh G3, the machine which provided an oom-pah-pah back-beat of demented cymbals, tambourines, dustbin-lids and an occasional drum. Giggling as they waited for their intro, the eccentric twosome began with The Giant of Illinois, Brett's country drawl growing steadily more sonorous for the poignant tale of a giant who "died from a blister on his toe". This was followed by the equally freakish and forlorn The Sad Milkman, during which Rennie hugged and stroked her autoharp as if it was a kitten she'd just rescued from the river.

Foregrounded by the Family's bare bone sound, Rennie's lyrics conflate a twisted pastoralism, an off-beat humour and a nice line in American gothic, all of which were afforded the necessary respect by Brett's doleful voice, and his uncomplicated guitar twangs. With Rennie puffing on her melodica, The Woman Downstairs told the story of a neglected neighbour who starved herself to death, while Arlene, a spurned lover's lament, returned to traditional country roots.

Although the bizarre lyrics invoke a chronically romantic vision of love and blood and snow and leaves, and a repeated desire for flight, this is usually countered by a rueful self-parody. The Family's best songs, such as Weightless Again and In the Air, the title track of their new album, combine the two and offer a jovial fatalism, a morbid glee. It's difficult to dismiss existential angst when it comes with a sing-along chorus.

Growling like a female Tom Waits or a madcap hillbilly, Rennie sang Down in the Ground, her only lead vocal of the night. When the drum machine carried on after they'd finished When That Helicopter Comes, she wondered whether "we should remove the human element completely". Really, though, it's the computer they should get rid of. With an additional member or two, the Family would be unmissable.

Handsome Family play Aunt Annie's, Belfast, March 15, Attic, Edinburgh, March 18, then touring.

fields.headline: Limited amnesty for tax dodgers
fields.trailText: The government is to combine a limited amnesty to tax dodgers and benefit fraudsters with a drive against hard-core cheats in an attempt to bring down the curtain on the "Only Fools and Horses" culture of the last three decades.
fields.body:
The government is to combine a limited amnesty to tax dodgers and benefit fraudsters with a drive against hard-core cheats in an attempt to bring down the curtain on the "Only Fools and Horses" culture of the last three decades.

The chancellor hopes a package of carrots and sticks will root out moonlighting and save the government at least £465m a year.

Advertising will be used to try to change public attitudes "insofar as they regard the hidden economy as socially acceptable". In place of the cuddly Del Boy image, the government will portray fiscal offences as attacks on the poor.

Treasury sources emphasised yesterday that the incentives were as important as the draconian penalties for the hard-core evasion of tax and the milking of the benefit system.

The key "carrot" is a £1.5m confidential telephone advice service to help those in the black economy to join the legitimate workforce.

It will be up and running by the summer and will point repentant moonlighters in the direction of a more understanding and even forgiving Inland Revenue and other official bodies.

A report by Lord Grabiner, accepted today by Mr Brown, said that "in some circumstances" offenders may be told there will be no further efforts made to pursue them for past misdeeds providing they give a full and frank admission.

But the senior QC ruled out a blanket pardon. "Amnesties were perceived as unfair: as a free lunch for those who had not met their responsibilities, at the expense of honest taxpayers."

Mr Brown believes that, with the economy booming and unemployment tumbling, there will never be a better opportunity to bring in from the cold those working illegally.

"In the 1980s there were no jobs and the Tory obligations on the unemployed were to penalise them. Now there are jobs and we are removing the barriers to opportunities.

"It is right to say the help must go to those who need it - not those defrauding the system."

Other incentives will be the extension of the jobseeker's allowance and income support to bridge the gap for those moving from benefits to work.

But the "stick" will change radically the enforcement of Britain's tax laws.

At present, only one branch of the Inland Revenue, the special compliance office, has the power to prosecute, and does so only in a handful of "heinous" cases.

fields.headline: Money talks
fields.standfirst: 'How can I persuade my employer to give me a well-deserved pay rise?'
fields.trailText: The problems
fields.body:
The problems

 I am currently doing my third-year apprenticeship at a garage where I am doing car body repair, and I feel that I should be getting paid more as I basically work alone.

The thing is, I'm getting paid £2.50 and hour and I just cannot afford to work there any more as I have so many money problems.

Can I ask for a minimum wage as I am 18?

 I work for my family's company (a landfill site) as an administration clerk.

When I started 18 months ago my duties solely consisted of working with the purchase ledger, inserting weighbridge tickets onto a spreadsheet and answering the phone.

18 months later I'm designing spreads and overheads for company growth as well as designing spreadsheets and completing them to send to the environment agency.

I literally run the office myself every afternoon, as well as doing all the little jobs that nobody likes doing.

Since I've been here, more labourers have been taken on, trained in absolutely nothing, and are being paid more than me. Please give me some sound advice.

The solution

Both these questions are related so I'll answer them together:

First of all, everyone has the right to be paid the minimum wage, which, from the age of 18, is £3 an hour (£3.60 when you are over 21. Also, the first twelve months of an accredited training apprenticeship should net you £3.20 when you are over 21).

You can and should ask for it, and cannot be sacked for doing so since you are asserting a statutory employment right. Put your request in writing, politely pointing out that they must pay you the legal minimum wage.

The second issue here is asking for a pay rise. There are sound and unsound reasons for wanting a rise, and I'm afraid that comparisons with your colleagues do not generally cut much ice with employers.

However, it does seem that you have sound reasons too - going beyond your job description, taking on more responsibility or saving/making your company money are all good reasons to negotiate a pay rise (doing the 'little jobs that nobody likes doing' is not).

Follow this three-point plan in order to maximise your chances of getting that well-deserved rise:

1. Arrange a meeting with your boss or line manager.

2. Prepare your case. Get a copy of your job description and craft a new one, pointing out new responsibilities or changes from the original. Or, provide data showing money you have saved or made the company. List any special achievements or examples of where you have represented the company well. Calculate a reasonable salary that you feel you ought to be on, based on your current market value (have a scout around and see what other companies pay for someone doing your work).

3. Go through your report with your boss at the meeting. Avoid being aggressive or demanding and never threaten to leave (unless you intend to). State your case reasonably, emphasise how much you enjoy your job but be firm about the fact that you deserve to be paid more.

If the answer is still 'no', find out why and what would be needed to get that rise. If it is, for example, more training or experience that is needed, send your boss a letter confirming any agreement that you are likely to get your rise on completion of x, y or z. If, on the other hand, your boss indicates that a rise is never likely to be forthcoming, that is the time to start thinking about finding a firm prepared to pay you what you are worth.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)
